fields.headline: Player of the week
fields.trailText: No one had appreciated quite how intimidating Lord's was, until last Wednesday. All power then to the little-known Chris Taylor who became the first batsman ever to make a hundred there on his championship debut.
fields.body:
Chris Taylor Gloucestershire

No one had appreciated quite how intimidating Lord's was, until last Wednesday. All power then to the little-known Chris Taylor who became the first batsman ever to make a hundred there on his championship debut.

Coming to the crease with his side 29 for four, the midget-like debutant - 5ft 8in and 10 stone - got Middlesex in a bit of a lather by making batting look so easy.

The fielders wouldn't have known that the little fellow had a triple century for the county's 2nd XI, and before that an undefeated 278 at Colston College, Bristol (where he eclipsed all Chris Broad's records).

Even his present coach, John Bracewell, had not seen Taylor bat before a pre-season tour of South Africa. 'It immediately struck me that he played either side of the wicket, letting the ball come to him and playing it underneath him. That's the Australian way. I'm not putting him on the level of the Langers and Pontings, but he has that technique.'

fields.headline: Rise of the green factor
fields.standfirst: In a special report Jobs & Money looks at how to make sure your money is put to work according to your values
fields.trailText: In a special report Jobs & Money looks at how to make sure your money is put to work according to your values.
fields.body:
After a decade and a half of being out in the cold, ethical funds are about to celebrate their coming of age.

They are no longer just for the sandal-wearing, brown rice-eating set who want something better than the building society without the guilt trip of full capitalism.

They are starting to make a real impact on share prices - and that in turn has an effect on other investment thinking. Mainstream funds are increasingly having to take note of ethical investment decisions even when they do not subscribe to them. Ethical principles are acting on companies everywhere, from the Bank of Scotland to Monsanto via Marks & Spencer.

From July 3, pension funds must disclose in their Statement of Investment Principles "the extent (if at all) to which social, environmental or ethical considerations are taken into account in the selection, retention and realisation of investments".

Mark Manley of the socially responsible investment consultants Claros, who is author of the recently published Socially Responsible Investment: A Guide for Pension Funds and Institutional Investors, says: "It is clear the government is looking for a serious response from the pensions industry, and although the regulation does not directly require any action on SRI [socially responsible investment], its real power is that it does require trustees to consider these issues properly and thoroughly."

But there's more to it than this regulation. Pension scheme members prefer a more ethical approach.

A survey from the Ethical Investment Research Service (Eiris) shows that 77% of members would like to see their pension fund invested ethically if it makes no difference to returns.

Mr Manley adds that this "may overstate the interest but there is undoubtedly a growing awareness of, and interest in, socially responsible investment".

The risks of being unaware of ethical issues surrounding one's investments are growing. Campaigning organisations are increasing in financial understanding and are more than prepared to challenge institutions which invest in companies they consider undesirable.

Earlier this year, Friends of the Earth named and shamed insurance firms that invested in stocks of companies whose activities, according to FoE, were likely to damage the planet. All this could help push up prices of ethically approved stocks.

Most believe SRI involves a trade off in performance; there has been long-term evidence to show this. But Mr Manley believes appropriate approaches to SRI can actually enhance performance.

Matthew Harragin, the ethical investment director at stockbrokers Rathbones, says: "The ethical dimension now has to be discussed, and once it is officially on the agenda, it is far harder to ignore. Pension trustees who go hell for leather for companies causing pollution or selling arms to all and sundry may have some explaining to do."

He cites the way in which share prices reacted to the GM food issue as one example of this. Iceland, which has taken a very anti-GM line, was rewarded with a share price which has outperformed competitors despite the recent lack of enthusiasm for its takeover of Booker.

Monsanto, at the heart of the GM food debate, is now being swallowed up by rivals - helped on its way by the likes of Calvert, the US ethical managers who have linked up with Murray Johnstone to direct the Murray Ethical World funds.

US ethical managers take a very hard line with companies they disapprove of - often threatening to mobilise the stock they hold in non-ethical funds as well.

Mr Harragin also took an ethical stance this time last year, when the Bank of Scot land planned a link-up with the rightwing US evangelist Pat Robertson. There were substantial protests from gays, Catholics, ethnic minorities and women, who felt under attack. Ethical investors protested and, in many cases, sold their shares.

"This was real money speaking so even those who dismissed the protesters as cranks had to sit up and take notice," Mr Harragin says.

Bank of Scotland shares have since lost a third of their value - more than many banks. Worse, the one-time ethical favourite will now have to work very hard to get back into favour.

Marks & Spencer was also a top ethical choice. No longer. Leaving aside the problem of frumpy fashions, green investors were outraged by its stance on GM food. It first ignored the issue and then treated it more lightly than rival groups. Ethical investors were also unhappy at the way it ended long-standing contracts with British textile firms such as William Baird. "From ethical paragons, they risk becoming ethical pariahs," says Mr Harragin.

But BP Amoco - once beyond the pale - could be back on the agenda for "light green" funds which are prepared to buy shares in companies which are making progress. It is now ready to negotiate with groups such as Greenpeace, a move that also forced its rival Shell into serious talks with environmental groups.

Whatever the end result, huge multinationals now have to take notice of green factors - or risk their share price dropping.

webTitle: The high-tech takeovers give market a big boost

fields.headline: The high-tech takeovers give market a big boost
fields.standfirst: Vodafone's sale of its Orange phone subsidiary to France Telecom led the revival of UK technology stocks. Robin Stoddart reports
fields.trailText: Vodafone's sale of its Orange phone subsidiary to France Telecom led the revival of UK technology stocks. Robin Stoddart reports.
fields.body:
A global view of investment is reasonable and necessary only when trade and commerce are headed that way. Unlike life assurers and some other large fund managers who match assets and liabilities in the same currency, private investors should seek wider opportunities, particularly when the pound weakens.

This applies particularly when advanced technology shares are in vogue. The rebound that emanated from Wall Street and its dominant Nasdaq market in newer computer and telecommunications issues was concentrated on software and other Techmark issues in London this week.

Unfortunately, the UK is less well-endowed with computer and new technology firms than the US and other advanced industrial countries. It is short of both world-class businesses and top managers. With luck, it may produce entrepreneurs as well as inventors on a scale that provides hope of continuing prosperity. There is some expectation that after American acquisitions and its move out of defence, Marconi, formerly GEC, will attain the top rank of high technology international operators.

Invensys, the largest engineer outside the foreign-owned automotive sector, was one of the market's heaviest losers. The former agglomeration of Siebe and BTR is using proceeds from disposals in miscellaneous manufacturing to take over the heavily loss-making and managerially troubled Baan software group based in Holland.

This was greeted with a big thumbs-down by fund managers who sold millions of shares. Automation and domestic equipment controls are the present core business, though with less than spectacular growth prospects. Mixing in software was not immediately regarded as a logical or progressive move.

To a far greater degree than in other countries, where home control remains the norm, the revival in UK technology issues was spurred by takeover moves. Vodafone's sale of its Orange subsidiary to France Telecom realised a big profit on what its new Mannesmann component paid, though the main billionaire winner remains Hans Snook, the Hong Kong founder of the UK's number three mobile phone business.

Continental operators remain in the van of international link-ups and a German internet services provider is now expected to buy Dixon's Freeserve business. BT no longer looks able to afford the likely £5bn-plus price as it needs to buy more mobile operation licences in Europe.

Investment funds, particularly those with large US and American holdings, joined in the recovery. Leading suppliers in their field, rather than smaller companies, were preferred. For example Finland's Nokia, Europe's most valuable company and leading mobile phone manufacturer, made fair progress closer to its peak and Siemens, Germany's and Europe's foremost electronics manufacturer, rebounded sharply. Many Europe-oriented unit and investment trusts benefit from the spectacular growth of the former, though Siemens' high-tech potential has only been recognised in the last year.

Two of the internationally-orientated investment trusts reporting this week were able to claim outperformance compared with their chosen benchmark, but the proliferation of indices and benchmarks makes such claims confusing, even spurious.

In the six months to April 30 both Edinburgh Worldwide and Scottish Investment Trusts beat their benchmark by around half, but Edinburgh reported net asset value growth of 20% and Scottish barely 12%.

The latter cobbled together a combination index comprising the FTSE Actuaries All Share and a currency adjusted world index as its benchmark, whereas the former uses the Morgan Stanley Capital International World Index. It rose much more than the sluggish UK All-Share. Both have large US stakes, but Scottish is heavily UK oriented, so retaining Personal Equity Plan status. The Isa replacement allows broad international investment.

Edinburgh, the smaller and younger fund, ventured more into technology issues, but took profits opportunely and avoided internet retailing. Scottish added somewhat dull issues in the US, though the small stake in venture capital and unquoted issues did well. Perhaps its best decision was to raise gearing through a 30-year bond at interest of barely 6%.

Given better selection on both sides of the Atlantic, this could help to keep the growth rate near the 16.4% average of recent years. Share buy-backs have limited the discount to near the average. Edinburgh, at a discount fluctuating around 20%, looks the better bet while the dollar remains strong.

Although it was left behind by the technology specialists, it has performed better than all except Baillie Gifford's Scottish Mortgage among international generalists during the last year, though Far Eastern selection has now turned difficult for them all.

webTitle: Savers seek banks with a conscience

fields.headline: Savers seek banks with a conscience
fields.standfirst: Competitors are benefiting from the unsavoury side of high street institutions, says Nick Pandya
fields.trailText: For philanthropic savers, ethical use of their money on the stock market can be arranged by leaving it with one of the green investment funds. However, applying a personal moral code to banking and savings can be more tricky.
fields.body:
For philanthropic savers, ethical use of their money on the stock market can be arranged by leaving it with one of the green investment funds. However, applying a personal moral code to banking and savings can be more tricky.

Banks, by their nature as lenders, have their fingers in several pies, many of them unsavoury. But banking became more of a green issue in the aftermath of Barclays' decision to close more than 100 rural branches. At the same time it was rumoured that that its chief executive, Matthew Barrett, would be getting a £3m bonus. This led many to wonder what the stance of their bank was.

Banks argue that their prime motive is to boost shareholder value not moral values, but for high street bank customers who have strong principles but wish to use a major institution, the outlook is not all gloomy.

Former building societies turned banks such as Abbey National, Halifax and Woolwich are generally the best choice on ethical grounds. They rank ahead of rivals on three counts: third world debt exposure; corporate lending record; and their own environmental policies.

Elsewhere on the high street the Co-op Bank (0845 725 2000) publishes its ethical screening criteria, refusing to invest customers' money in regimes which violate human rights, organisations involved in arms sales, those who test on animals, tobacco producers or those whose core activities are harmful to the environment.

The bank has a current account with full facilities paying between 3.12% and 5.75% gross, on a sliding scale. Its cash Isa pays 5.75% on every pound invested. Its internet bank, Smile, has the same ethical profile.

Smaller institutions are also in the savings business. The Bristol-based Triodos Bank (0500 008720), an independent Dutch public company, only lends money to projects with social and environmental objectives. Its accounts provide customers with the chance to target their savings at specific projects or sectors.

Gross interest rates on its Social Investor range of accounts start at 3.25% rising on a sliding scale to 5.45% on minimum deposits of £500.

The Ecology building society (01535 635933) operating from Cross Hills, near Skipton in Yorkshire, is Britain's youngest building society and is committed to the protection of the environment.

The society offers an Eco-Instant savings account, returning 1.5 % gross on deposits under £500 rising to 3.75% on balances of up to £2,500. It pays a top rate of 4.25% on investment of at least £10,000. The rates on its 60-day notice account start at 4% gross on a minimum deposit of £500 rising to 5% gross on balances of £10,000 and over. It also offers a cash mini-Isa, paying 5.05%.

Savers willing to accept a rate of interest lower than inflation in the knowledge that funds will be used to improve trading conditions for producers in the developing world, can go to the Newcastle-based co-operative society Shared Interest (0191 233 9100).

Investors, who are also voting members, can save £100-£20,000 in a postal account paying a gross rate of 2% on all balances. The balance of the interest goes towards the charitable aims of the organisation.

More information on ethical investment can be found at the new UK Social Investment Forum website: www.uksif.org.

webTitle: Cheap loans for a life in the green house

fields.headline: Cheap loans for a life in the green house
fields.standfirst: Some lenders will help you renovate derelict homes and fit energy saving devices like solar panels, says Ian Wylie
fields.trailText: Some lenders will help you renovate derelict homes and fit energy saving devices like solar panels, says Ian Wylie.
fields.body:
People hoping for a green house should shop around for a mortgage. Some lenders are offering cheaper loans to borrowers interested in buying an environmentally-friendly home, building their own house or restoring a dilapidated property.

A green mortgage is no different from other types of home loan but the lender is likely to focus on features of the property that are of environmental interest. And as in stock market investment, borrowers can choose the shade of green to suits them.

At the light end, the Norwich & Peterborough building society offers loans that aim to "increase awareness about energy efficiency among home buyers". On newly built homes, the N&P is offering a 1% discount off its variable rate for four years (increasing to 1.25% with compulsory insurance), provided houses meet energy-efficient standards.

For existing properties, N&P's green mortgage discounts are reduced respectively to 0.75% and 1%, but the society compensates with a free energy survey offer and £500 cash back to be spent on energy-saving home improvements. It also offers a better than average first-year discount on advances to existing borrowers, where the extra money goes on energy-saving measures.

The Ecology building society takes a darker green, stance, and lends only on properties that give an "ecological payback" such as derelict buildings that would otherwise be abandoned or those in need of major renovation; new, energy-efficient homes; back-to-back terraced houses that are energy-saving by nature; organic smallholdings and farms; and properties that promote community life.

While most lenders will normally lend little or nothing on a derelict property, the Ecology says it believes every property has a value and will lend up to 80%.

As renovations progress and the value of the property increases, the Ecology may provide funds for further improvements. It has helped several buyers to restore properties in areas such as the East End of London.

In rural areas, it looks favourably on loans for properties such as village shops, which do not produce the profits a mainstream lender would require. It also supports borrowers who are building environmentally-sound properties.

The N&P is also happy to finance self-build properties but the Ecology goes a step further by encouraging applications from people with "earth-sheltered" dwellings, or new-builds that have turf roofs and compost toilets.

Like the N&P, the Ecology offers energy surveys. Its Earthsaver Remortgage, for example, surveys properties to see how environmentally sound they could be. Borrower must agree to comply with 80% of the energy-saving measures in the survey to qualify for a mortgage.

Currently the Ecology charges a competitive variable rate of 7.39%, with a 0.5% discount in the first year. The society also offers a 0.25% cut in the rate after four years, where borrowers have maintained their mortgage satisfactorily and undertaken promised energy-saving measures.

The Ecology's mortgage conditions usually include a requirement for insulation and, where appropriate, for windows to be hardwood double-glazed rather than using conventional uPVC.

Another form of ethical mortgage comes from the Catholic building society which offers "socially responsible" loans to people of any religious denomination who have been shunned by mainstream lenders.

Founded in 1960 to provide mortgages for single women who could only get loans from mainstream lenders if they had male guarantors, the society also helps people with disabilities and those who have had serious financial difficulties.

The Catholic will lend to women in financial difficulties due to separation and divorce and around a third of its current borrowers are single women.

It has helped several buyers to restore properties in areas such as the East End of London. In rural areas, it looks favourably on loans for properties such as village shops, which do not produce the profits a mainstream lender would require. It also supports borrowers who are building environmentally-sound properties. The N&P is also happy to finance self-build properties but the Ecology goes a step further by encouraging applications from people with "earth-sheltered" dwellings, or new-builds that have turf roofs and compost toilets. Like the N&P, the Ecology offers energy surveys. Its Earthsaver Remortgage, for example, surveys properties to see how environmentally sound they could be. Borrower must agree to comply with 80% of the energy-saving measures in the survey to qualify for a mortgage. Currently the Ecology charges a competitive variable rate of 7.39%, with a 0.5% discount in the first year. The society also offers a 0.25% cut in the rate after four years, where borrowers have maintained their mortgage satisfactorily and undertaken promised energy-saving measures. The Ecology's mortgage conditions usually include a requirement for insulation and, where appropriate, for windows to be hardwood double-glazed rather than using conventional uPVC. Another form of ethical mortgage comes from the Catholic building society which offers "socially responsible" loans to people of any religious denomination who have been shunned by mainstream lenders. Founded in 1960 to provide mortgages for single women who could only get loans from mainstream lenders if they had male guarantors, the society also helps people with disabilities and those who have had serious financial difficulties. The Catholic will lend to women in financial difficulties due to separation and divorce and around a third of its current borrowers are single women.

webTitle: Pension funds catch charities on the hop

fields.headline: Pension funds catch charities on the hop
fields.standfirst:
British charities invest pension funds in companies they oppose
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Some of the UK's leading charities are effectively financing the causes they oppose by investing pension funds worth tens of millions of pounds in companies involved in the arms trade, genetically modified crops and petrochemicals.
fields.body:
Some of the UK's leading charities are effectively financing the causes they oppose by investing pension funds worth tens of millions of pounds in companies involved in the arms trade, genetically modified crops and petrochemicals.

Oxfam, the British Red Cross, Friends of the Earth Scotland (FoES) and Christian Aid are among 3,500 charities whose occupational pension schemes are run by the Pensions Trust, which specialises in investing on behalf of voluntary organisations and charities.

A detailed list of Pensions Trust investments dated February and seen by the Guardian reveals that its portfolio, worth £1.6bn, included shares in arms manufacturers GKN and BAe Systems; the petrochemical companies BP Amoco and Shell; Novartis and AstraZeneca, developers of genetically modified crops, and Nestle, whose marketing of powdered milk in the third world has been censured.

It also holds assets in Rio Tinto, the world's largest mining company, which is subject to campaigns by environmental groups across the globe.

FoES, which campaigns against GM crops, Rio Tinto and the oil industry, has become so concerned that it is in the process of switching to an ethical pension fund.

A spokesman said that FoES had assumed that because the Pensions Trust operated in the voluntary sector it would provide a more ethical dimension. A decision to withdraw from its scheme must be ratified at the next FoES board meeting.

Christian Aid, which has around £9m invested with the Pensions Trust, yesterday condemned some of the investments. "Investing in companies which sell arms, for example, is in our opinion immoral," it said. "It really is no good charities campaigning against pollution, supplying arms to children or on alcohol related issues when they ... are propping up the very instruments of harm."

Christian Aid and Oxfam, who have some £25m invested, are working with the Pensions Trust to develop a 100% ethical fund.

British pension funds control an estimated £850bn of assets and account for 35% of the London stock market. According to the Ethical Investment Research Service, 60% of stocks do not meet ethical criteria. The Pensions Trust offer their 80,000 scheme members an ethical option, managed by Friends Provident, that blacklists ethically unsound stocks.

Some charities however are prevented from investing all their funds in the ethical scheme. Independent actuaries acting for Oxfam only permit the charity to invest 30% of its pension fund in an ethical scheme because of concerns about the volatility of the ethical investment market.

An Oxfam spokesman said they had been aware that the Pensions Trust invested in multinationals, but "saw it as the best deal that was on offer given the world that we live in".

"We're close to clinching a deal with the Pensions Trust to have a 100% ethical scheme," he said.

The Red Cross said it "promoted" the Pensions Trust's ethical option but was keen to see staff get "the return they deserved".

Richard Stroud, chief executive of the Pensions Trust, said that while the company did of fer an ethical option to its clients and was working to develop a fully ethical scheme, its main portfolio was run on a market basis. He said he had encountered apathy on the issue in the charitable sector.

"We wrote to 3,500 employers regarding the question of ethical investment and only 17 responded," he said.

Currently, pension funds are only obliged to maximise their client's investments. From July 3 however each fund's statement of investment principles must say whether it takes ethical considerations into account when investing.

The Pensions Trust issued a statement in January saying that ethical considerations are at the discretion of fund managers. Schroders, Fidelity, Capital, Hendersons, Legal & General, Richard Ellis and the ethical specialists Friends Ivory and Sime, manage 80% of the Pensions Trust's assets.

fields.headline: Wall Street bluegrass
fields.standfirst:
Laura Cantrell, Radio Sweethearts, Ramshorn Theatre
Big Big Country Festival, Glasgow ****
fields.trailText: Laura Cantrell, Radio Sweethearts, Ramshorn Theatre Big Big Country Festival, Glasgow ****
fields.body:
The double life of New Yorker Laura Cantrell might be straight out of Gotham City in Tim Burton's movie Batman. By day she works for the Bank of America's equities research department. By night she rides into the lonesome skyscraper canyons and hits the saloons of New York to sing bittersweet country music. In between, she broadcasts her own show on the influential Radio WFMU station.

If this is Cantrell's secret triple identity, then it won't stay secret for long, judging by the sell-out at the Ramshorn, as the most successful yet Big Big Country Festival swung towards its finale. And if Shania Twain is the Bardot of post-new country then Cantrell is its saloon-savvy Lauren Bacall - whom she resembles, with a smoky look, and with stinging lyrics that tell you not to get too close.

For instance, the title track of her debut album, Not the Tremblin' Kind, is all about female strength, employing S&M imagery to describe power and submission. Equally perversely, she has released her album on the embryonic Glaswegian label Spit and Polish, run by the country fanatic and Radio Sweethearts drummer Francis MacDonald. The connection was established when Cantrell played the band's music on her radio show, and they backed her with their distinctive shuffling swing, her brittle voice sometimes clattering up the high registers as if surprised by her Glaswegian cohorts.

The music is about familiar busted hearts and road stops in Reno, but is sung with direct honesty and the tiniest twinkle in Cantrell's eyes. She was born in Nashville and was weaned on the bluegrass of Earl Scruggs and Lester Flatt, and she doesn't attempt to hide it.

Cantrell delivered a captivating show, with a hint of the nervy edge of the great Mary Margaret O'Hara. Hell, she proves that even Wall Street analysts can get the honky tonk blues.

Big Big Country Festival ends tomorrow.

fields.headline: Modernist romances
fields.standfirst:
Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra/Mariss Jansons
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra/Mariss Jansons
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
In the three years since Mariss Jansons was appointed music director, he has turned a good orchestra into a great one. Their appearance at last year's Proms lingers in the memory as a great musical event. Now they are briefly back at the Barbican as part of the final stretch of a European tour. The programme, Stravinsky's Petrushka and Brahms's Second Symphony, showcases the orchestra's colouristic range.

Using Stravinsky's 1947 revision, Jansons turns Petrushka, romanticised by some, into a hard-edged modernism, in which excruciating emotions surfaced from beneath a gleaming veneer. The Shrovetide fair, its blocks of sound gradually locking together, was a constructivist saturnalia, orgiastic and chilly. The ballet's characters were sharply etched. The Charlatan was sinister and grotesquely funny. Petrushka's pathetic eagerness to please made you squirm in your seat and his final trumpet shrieks, emerging from an unusual, but telling, lull, shocked even if you know the score backwards. The ditsy Ballerina's music - Jansons does much with its absurdly exaggerated bassoon arpeggios - travestied Tchaikovsky.

The Brahms was also phenomenal. In an age when conductors are favouring a lean approach and Brahms is taken up by period bands, Jansons still sees him as an arch-Romantic. The orchestral sound was transformed, Stravinskyan stridency giving way to opulence. The emotions at the centre of the first two movements were intense, the finale - breathtakingly done - had the audience on its feet.

fields.headline: Battle between dark and light
fields.standfirst: Funds can be purist or pragmatic, writes Patrick McLoughlin
fields.trailText: Funds can be purist or pragmatic, writes Patrick McLoughlin.
fields.body:
There's a new sense of purpose and excitement in Britain's ethical investment industry, but also an element of a fight. In the red corner stand the dark green funds - ready to defend their strict investment stance.

And in the blue corner - younger and with less punching power as yet - are the light green funds. They believe that the best way to push the ethical cause is by encouraging the less pure to improve.

The Ethical Investment Research Service, or Eiris, says when ethical trusts were introduced to the UK in 1984, they had a quasi-religious ethos, aggressively screening out investments in companies that produced or were connected with industries such as tobacco, gambling, armaments or alcohol. They also choose on environmental grounds now.

These funds are now dubbed "dark green" and are the most hardline. Friends Provident Stewardship is the most prominent - if not the most successful in the performance tables. Jupiter Ecology and Equitable Ethical also take a darker than average stance.

Latterly, many funds have become more flexible. They have been dubbed light green funds and they invest in a wider range of industries, so long as companies have a positive approach to environmental and social policy. One recent launch in this field is Jupiter Environmental Opportunities.

The telling difference remains the shade of green. There are no hard and fast definitions of what is acceptable. Karen Eldridge, head of client services at Eiris, says: "Some dark green funds might exclude British Petroleum because it's involved in fossil fuel generation which to some is morally questionable.

"But some funds might include BP because it is 'best of sector'. It has a good environmental policy and has a solar power division."

According to industry insiders, the strong challenge to the hard liners comes from the trend towards light green funds. These have a wider investment remit and hence an easier choice for investment managers.

Alison McEwen, with Scottish Equitable Asset Management, says her group has two dark green funds which apply a "negative screening policy", barring outright investments in arms manufacturers, animal products and companies which make certain political donations.

"Generally people see ethical investments as desirable but they want to maximise returns," she says. "The way things are going at the moment, the light greens are more appealing than the dark greens."

Some perceive the light greens as having the potential to compromise the entire ethical industry.

But Karen Eldridge of Eiris says the evidence is that dark green funds aren't under threat. Nor, she reckons, have more light green funds been introduced as an easy way for the unit trust industry to tap into a genuine demand.

The purists may take issue with that.

Dark Green investments

 Cadbury: It is a food maker with little or no exposure to meat processing, an area banned by dark green investors.

 Waste Recycling Group: Involved in recycling paper for local authorities.

 First Group: Dark greens want to encourage public transport - they will not invest in the car industry - and bus companies like First Group are developing environmentally sound engines.

 Norwich Union: Chosen because it is in insurance and not banking. Dark greens don't like banks because they can't monitor where funds are lent.

Light green investments

 Tesco: Picked for its positive business practice and staff polices. Unacceptable to dark green funds because it sells animal produce and leather goods.

 Marks & Spencer: Chosen for similar reasons to Tesco.

 Diageo: Chosen because of its general policies towards the environment and community. Banned by dark greens because it is in the brewing industry.

 Barclays: Yes from light greens because of business practices. No from dark greens, who are strict on banks.

 Tate & Lyle: Acceptable to light greens because of good social policies. Blocked by darks because it operates in some countries with questionable human rights regimes.

 Glaxo Wellcome: Under review by lights because of positive business practices but barred by dark greens because of the animal testing it carries out to acquire US drug approval.

webTitle: EasyJet takes on the big bank

fields.headline: EasyJet takes on the big bank
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The big bank for the big world is under attack again, this time by Stelios Haji-Ioannou, chairman of budget airline EasyJet.
fields.body:
The big bank for the big world is under attack again, this time by Stelios Haji-Ioannou, chairman of budget airline EasyJet.

Mr Haji-Ioannou, the Greek entrepreneur who never misses a publicity opportunity, is blaming Barclays for threatened rises in the "low cost" tickets on the airline he started five years ago.

"There's going to be a £5 Barclays tax on your ticket," Mr Haji-Ioannou said yesterday, rejecting any suggestion that his airline rather than his customers could carry the cost of any increase in operating out of Luton Airport.

Barclays puts its stake in Luton Airport at 43% but airport officials say it is 65%.

The spat could not have come at a worse time for the bank. It is only just recovering from a PR disaster of its own making - after it closed down 171 rural branches, while running an advertising campaign telling customers "the world needs the big bank". If that was not enough to annoy punters, it was revealed that the bank's chief executive stood to make 36 times his £850,000 annual salary. All this makes the bank easy meat for a self-styled consumer champion such as Mr Haji-Ioannou.

Fresh from cutting up his Barclaycard in disgust at the pressure he believes the two Barclays funds that invested in Luton two years ago are putting on the airport's management, Mr Haji-Ioannou is calling on others to follow his example.

He also plans to lead a demonstration outside the Barclays branch in Luton in an attempt to either persuade the government that it should regulate Luton Airport, or embarrass the bank into reducing the new rates being introduced at the airport.

While Barclays is a major shareholder in Luton Airport, the hub of EasyJet, which is based in the Bedfordshire town and accounts for 60% of its traffic, it insists Mr Haji-Ioannou is channelling his efforts in the wrong direction. The rebirth of Luton and the birth of EasyJet are considered to be intertwined.

"We're investors, not an airport operator," a Barclays official said yesterday, backed up by her counterpart at Luton who said "Barclays is not involved in any way in fee issues".

But such comments fail to deter Mr Haji-Ioannou, who may soon have shareholders of his own if his plan to float EasyJet on the stock market reaches fruition. Like all venture capitalists, Mr Haji-Ioannou says, Barclays private equity operation is eager to turn its investment into profit as quickly as possible and as a shareholder is doing all it can to make sure its aims are achieved.

He is incensed by the idea that he should help pay for the cost of a the new terminal at the airport - which he dubs the "tin shed" and insists leaves Luton with too much capacity - through higher fees for his aircraft.

EasyJet pays a fee of around £1.60 for every passenger who departs on one of its planes leaving Luton. The airport says it has to pay the local council £3 for each EasyJet traveller and wants to increase the fee to around £7. While Luton, which refuses to discuss the level of the fees, says that it is only fair that it should renegotiate the favourable rates it offered EasyJet to help it get off the ground for the first time.

Mr Haji-Ioannou, though, while not claiming any breach of contract with Luton, insists that the new fees breach the spirit of the arrangement which he says worked on a basis of "the more [passengers] you bring, the less you pay".

fields.headline: Return of the dot.coms
fields.standfirst:
Buyers jump back on the bandwagon for technology, media and telecom shares
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Buyers jump back on the bandwagon for technology, media and telecom shares
fields.body:
Technology stocks returned to favour with a vengeance yesterday as heavy buying by investors out to recoup losses suffered in recent weeks prompted a 8% jump in the Techmark 100 index.

By the close of trading, the technology-driven index had completed its sixth rise in consecutive days to end up 272.9 points at 3634.95, well off recent a lows of 2925 points.

The benchmark FTSE 100 closed up 155.9 points at 6626.4, helped by strong performances from mobile phone company Vodafone AirTouch, handheld computer expert Psion and software group Baltimore Technologies.

The London market was also helped by a strong early per formance from the US Nasdaq index which was up 5% at 3694.8 at lunchtime.

Traders there were buoyed by receding fears of interest rate rises and figures showing a slight rise in unemployment, indicating the Federal Reserve's attempts to keep a lid on the booming economy were succeeding.

On the European mainland Italian internet service provider Tiscali added 6%, while Spain's Terra Networks put on 4%.

Dealers said they hoped the rally was evidence that the sell-off had bottomed out although they warned that even some of the day's strongest performers remain valued at less than a third of the highs they reached in early March.

Among the strongest per formers were NetBenefit which jumped 50% to 562.5p, Geo Interactive which climbed 34% to 870p and Redstone Telecom up 33% at 327.5p. However, all three shares are still trading at less than a third of their levels of two months ago. "The quality stocks had been tarred with the same brush as those of lower quality and the selling had gone too far," one dealer said. "The quality plays are now returning to sensible levels."

Spencer Crooks, a director at stockbroker Winterflood Securities, said: "We've gone from one extreme to another. Everything was too high in March and now it's looking too low. webTitle: Ask experts to sound out the best deals

fields.headline: Ask experts to sound out the best deals
fields.trailText: You may think you can rest easy when you opt for an ethical investment but how do you know if the advice you are getting is ethical to match? The answer is you don't. There is no accreditation for ethical advisers or watchdog regulation. You have to take their word for it.
fields.body:
You may think you can rest easy when you opt for an ethical investment but how do you know if the advice you are getting is ethical to match? The answer is you don't. There is no accreditation for ethical advisers or watchdog regulation. You have to take their word for it.

The Ethical Investment Research Service which provides data on the sector has compiled a list of 70 ethical advisers. But getting on the list is simple - either 40% of a firm's business must be ethical, they advise on more than £100,000 a year in the sector, or they have simply requested the leaflet "choosing an ethical fund".

Eiris defines an ethical adviser as "somebody with an understanding of the issues. It is nice to see an adviser who has an interest in ethics and can demonstrate it".

It adds: "From a customer's point of view it's better to have a good financial adviser than someone who gets business in by promising to donate money to charity."

Lee Coates, director of the Cheltenham-based Ethical Investors Group, says: "I chose this area because it gave me the opportunity to do what I was interested in and get paid for it at the same time." He and his colleagues have interests ranging from gay rights to the Quaker movement.

Geoff Griffiths, principal of the Salisbury firm Barchester Green Investment, chose his nine advisers for their integrity and track records; a strategy that fellow advisers Holden Meehan also adopts. But London-based Holden Meehan says it has trouble finding people who are professional enough.

Its sales director, Richard Hunter, says: "Our ethos is to be both socially responsible and ethical. We are for city bods with consciences. The trouble is that the ethical movement has not always been 100% professional, but we are committed to it."

Mr Griffiths agrees it is hard to find the right calibre of employee. He says: "It's like trying to find a shy retir ing used car salesman or Bambi in Babylon because you are looking for people who are the exception to the rule and have survived."

He started out advising Anglican clergy from his garden shed in 1985. At that time he was mainly selling Friends Provident Stewardship fund, as it was the only one available. He still recommends it but his biggest sellers these days are the NPI global care funds.

He likes NPI for their "policy of engagement" which means they looks for compa nies that have a green investment strategy as well as good employee relations. The NPI fund comes in income and growth incarnations. The former had growth of 7.2% last year just below the sector average of 7.66%

The NPI funds buy into "companies of the future" which it says are technology and smaller companies. Companies it invests in include Vodaphone and the Body Shop as well as lesser-known names such RM plc which produces computer software for schools.

Mr Griffiths also tips the Jupiter Ecology fund which invests heavily in waste recycling and waste management and the Murray Johnstone ethical world fund for its stringent screening. There are seven criteria including the environment, work place issues, human rights and weapons manufacturing. Its growth to date has been consistently in the top quartile.

Holden Meehan's favourite is Friends Provident, which invests in any company that has the making of a green policy and uses its status as a shareholder to develop it.

The Friends Provident Stewardship fund, its trailblazing ethical fund, has recorded growth of 219.38% over 10 years compared to a sector average of 245.33%. Its biggest holdings are in services.

Holden Meehan also flags the Henderson ethical fund to investors because of its faith in the fund managers.

Mr Coates, who puts his money where his mouth is by giving thousands to charity each year, speaks highly of the Norwich Union UK ethical fund on cost grounds. He says: "It has a large stake in technology and telecoms but is diversified enough not to fall." He also recommends the Murray Johnstone fund.

And like the funds themselves, ethical advisers come in shades of green. Investors wanting a more socially responsible home for their cash should try more than one adviser before deciding.

Alternatively, they can make up their own minds and buy through a discount broker.

fields.headline: What's the drill for B&B?
fields.standfirst: As another building society heads towards conversion, Rupert Jones looks at the benefits and pitfalls for the members soon to vote on its future
fields.trailText: As another building society heads towards conversion, Rupert Jones looks at the benefits and pitfalls for the members soon to vote on its future.
fields.body:
Between £647 and £815 each - that's what more than 2.5m members of Bradford & Bingley building society look set to pocket if, as seems highly likely, approval is given for its conversion to a bank.

It's been a long wait but Britain's second-largest building society this week finally unveiled full details of exactly who will be getting what and when.

The headline news is that members look like getting quite a bit less than the unofficial estimate of £1,000 that was being bandied around last year.

However, looking on the bright side, the figures above are quite a lot higher than some pundits had been speculating. One or two analysts recently suggested payouts could be as low as £350-£400 as a result of the banking sector having plunged in value on the stock market during the last few months.

B&B said this week that every eligible member will receive 250 shares worth an estimated £2.59 to £3.26 each, which works out at a total of £647-£815. If one takes the mid-point of this price range, that would mean payouts worth £731.

It was in April last year that B&B members voted by 62% to 38% in favour of carpetbagging plumber Stephen Major's proposal that it float on the stock market and pay windfalls that he claimed would average £2,000 (how wrong he was... )

The result was a terrible blow to the society's board, which had urged members to vote for it to stay a mutual (member-owned), warning them: "If we turned into a bank, our first priority would change from serving members to maximising profits."

That was then, this is now - B&B's bosses this week painted a glowing picture of its future as a "pro-consumer plc" and insisted that little about the way it deals with its customers would change as a result of conversion.

For the change of status to go ahead, members will have to approve the plans. Voting packs, which include the 140-page "transfer document" giving full details of the proposal and the voting form, start going out to members from this Monday.

Here we answer some of the questions policyholders are likely to have.

So what happens now?

B&B is urging members to use their vote. As well as allowing people to vote by post, it is holding a special general meeting at Sheffield Arena on July 17 where they can have their say in person. The result of the ballot will be announced at the end of the meeting. Those voting by post must get their forms back to the scrutineers by midnight on July 12.

For conversion to go ahead, 51% or more of B&B's borrowers and at least 75% of savers must vote in favour (and at least half of its savers must take part in the vote).

Provided this happens - and, based on past experience, it almost certainly will - B&B will float on the stock market on December 4. A facility will be put in place to allow people to sell shares if they wish.

Hang on, the vote took place last year. Why does there have to be another one?

Last year's vote wasn't a proper conversion ballot - it was more of an opinion poll. By law, there now has to be a formal vote on the proposal that B&B becomes a bank. "Each and every vote is important. A large turnout and a positive vote is required if we are to proceed with conversion," says chairman Lindsay Mackinlay.

How do I know if I'm eligible for a windfall?

In order to qualify for a payout, a saver must have had at least £100 in their account(s) on two dates - April 25, 1999 and May 21, 2000 - and must also have held their account(s) continuously between the first of those dates and December 3, 2000. Borrowers need to have had a B&B mortgage on April 25, 1999 and must also hold one with the society on December 3, 2000.

I'm a B&B saver and I also have my mortgage with them. Do I get two lots of shares?

Yes.

My son has a KidZone children's account. Will he get a windfall?

Yes, provided he meets the eligibility criteria applying to adults. While many past flotations excluded kids from windfalls, B&B is awarding full payouts to 129,000 children, including for the first time 96,000 youngsters whose accounts are in the names of trustees (usually their parents).

My husband opened a B&B account in 1995 and died in December last year. I've inherited the account. What's my position ?

Again, provided the minimum balance requirements are met, you'll be entitled to receive the same size windfall your late husband would have got had he been alive at the time of conversion. You'll need to formally notify the society of your husband's death, if you haven't already done so.

My mother is in a nursing home and has a B&B account, though it is operated by a nurse there. What happens with her?

Around 10,000 trustee account holders for elderly, ill and disabled people will get payouts under B&B's conversion plans. Legislation was introduced in 1997 to protect the rights of those who rely on others such as carers to operate their accounts. Now, a nurse in a care home operating accounts on behalf of seven mentally disabled residents would get seven payouts, plus one for herself as well if she has her own qualifying account. Under the old system, she would have only got one payout because she was the first-named on the accounts.

I've read in the past that mortgage-holders have a lot more to lose from conversion than savers. Is that true?

Yes. B&B has already warned that if it becomes a bank, "we would have to raise mortgage rates". Building societies typically charge variable rate borrowers up to 0.5% less than banks. For example, Nationwide's standard variable mortgage rate is 7.29% while the Halifax's is 7.74%. On a £60,000 interest-only mortgage that adds up to an annual saving for the Nationwide borrower of £270. These figuresshow that many borrowers windfalls could be cancelled out by higher mortgage costs.

To find out more

Bradford & Bingley's conversion helpline, 0845 601 1456, is open 8am-8pm Mon-Fri, 9am-noon Sat. Information is also available on B&B's website: www.bradford-bingley.co.uk.

Or you can look at www.bradford-bingley.org.uk. This is not an official B&B site. It's run by a group of members who oppose conversion and puts the case for staying mutual.

Those of a pro-mutual persuasion may also want to look at www.sobs.org.uk, the website of the Save Our Building Societies campaign group.

webTitle: Banks boost profits by taking their time

fields.headline: Banks boost profits by taking their time
fields.standfirst: That infuriating delay while you wait for a cheque to clear means you lose out while others gain, reports Jessica McCallin
fields.trailText: That infuriating delay while you wait for a cheque to clear means you lose out while others gain, reports Jessica McCallin.
fields.body:
Banks are taking too long to clear cheques and are making interest off your money in the meantime. The Consumers' Association says more than a quarter of banks are failing to clear cheques when they say they will, while some customers have to wait up to 11 days to withdraw money.

Once banks have received your money, they can invest it and earn substantial amounts of interest before making it available to you.

The Consumers' Association asked 22 volunteers to pay in a total of 440 cheques to the top 11 institutions. All cheques paid into Barclays and NatWest cleared a day later than they should have. Half the cheques paid into the Lloyds current account at Lloyds TSB cleared a day late, as did a quarter of those paid into the Co-operative Bank, HSBC and Nationwide.

When you pay a cheque into your account, it passes through a set cheque clearing process unless you and the cheque writer bank at the same branch. It then takes three working days for the money to travel from the cheque writer's bank to yours - unless you pay extra for fast-track clearance. And some banks end their "working day" earlier than others, anything up to two hours before they shut the branch doors.

However, just because your bank or building society has received the money doesn't mean you can actually get at the funds. Cheques first have to "clear for value". This is the day you start earning interest on the money and usually happens three days after you've paid the cheque in. They then have to "clear for fate". This is the time when you can actually withdraw the money you have paid in.

The problem, according to the Consumers' Association, lies here: "Although every bank and building society uses this same procedure, each can decide when to let you withdraw your money. Some let you do this on day four. Others make you wait up to seven days to be sure the cheque isn't going to bounce. This means that, in most cases, the money is in your bank on day three but you can't touch it. In the meantime, your bank can invest your money and earn interest on it - banks make a substantial amount of money this way."

The major banks control the payments system, known as Apacs (the Association for Payment and Clearing Services) and so, according to the Consumers' Association, have no interest in changing it. Along with the government-commissioned Cruickshank report into banking services, the association is calling for control to be taken away from the banks and for a new independent payments regulator to be set up.

Further, it says the industry should use the phone, fax or computer to speed up the process. At the very least, it thinks customers should be paid interest from day three and be allowed to withdraw money on day four. Better still, it would like all banks to behave like Barclays, currently the only bank which lets customers withdraw against cheques worth up to £1,000 on the day they are paid in.

In response, a spokesperson for Apacs said: "The banks give value when they themselves make value. They usually start paying interest on day three, when they actually receive the funds. But it's a competitive issue between banks and some start paying interest sooner."

The spokesperson added that banks are unlikely to upgrade the system because the number of payments made by cheque is diminishing. Apacs research shows that by 2009 consumers will use cheques for just one in 50 payments.

Instead, the banking industry is investing in a same-day electronic payments system which it aims to have in place by next summer.

webTitle: Average house set to break the £100,000 barrier

fields.headline: Average house set to break the £100,000 barrier
fields.standfirst: Prices have been soaring. But, reports Rupert Jones, the north-south divide is making comparisons  tricky as London leads the way with streets full of £1m properties
fields.trailText: Prices have been soaring. But, reports Rupert Jones, the north-south divide is making comparisons tricky as London leads the way with streets full of £1m properties.
fields.body:
The upward spiral in house prices means the typical home is on the brink of crashing through the £100,000 barrier, according to government figures for England and Wales published this week.

They reveal that the average property has increased in value by a record 16.8% over the last year - from £84,973 to £99,295. But a closer look at the data reveals that the north-south divide in property prices is wider than ever, making such averages increasingly meaningless.

In Greater London, for example, the average price-tag is now £163,317 - 23% up on a year ago, when it was £132,570. This annual rate of house price growth is more than four times that experienced by the north of England, where property values rose only 5% over the same period. There, the average home sells for £59,343.

The figures from the Land Registry, a government department (www.landreg.gov.uk), compare prices in the first three months of this year with the same period last year. They are generally regarded as providing the most accurate picture of the state of the housing market because they are based on the vast majority of all house sales.

One revelation is that, contrary to what many might have imagined, London is no longer leading the way in terms of house price growth. Prices are rising faster than anywhere else in the genteel Georgian spa town of Bath, where a typical property will now set you back £130,470 - a whopping 38% up on a year ago, when the figure was £94,028.

Meanwhile, two southern seaside towns, Brighton and Bournemouth, are basking in the glow of annual price growth of 27% and 25% respectively. Average property prices there are £106,169 and £98,000 respectively. Reading is another star performer, with prices there up 26% over the year, and several other locations are giving London a run for its money including Surrey, the town of Poole and Windsor and Maidenhead.

At the other end of the spectrum, six areas saw property prices fall over the past year: Carmarthenshire, Kingston-upon-Hull, Darlington, north-east Lincolnshire, Rutland and Warrington.

London figures provide further evidence that the housing boom has filtered through to traditionally less lusted-after areas. In the borough of Newham prices have surged 38% in a year (from £63,689 to £87,777) and in Southwark the increase was 32% (from £121,574 to £160,477).

But anyone who thought that London's most desirable locations might be calming down after the huge price increases of the last couple of years is in for a surprise. Buried deep within the Land Registry's 20-page report is a remarkable statistic: the average terraced house in Kensington and Chelsea now costs £1,153,000. That's more than double what you'd have paid a year ago.

So it's no surprise to learn that of the 237 houses sold for more than £1m in Greater London between January and March this year, 101 are in Kensington and Chelsea. Westminster comes in second place on the rich list with 62 £1m-plus properties.

It's no wonder so many people believe the property boom has driven prices up to unrealistic levels. Research out this week reveals that 45% of all homeowners think houses in their area are overvalued. This figure rises to 63% in London and the south.

The survey was conducted by NOP for online estate agent asserta home, which has nearly 150 properties on its website (www.assertahome.com) valued at more than £2m. "City bonuses and dot.com windfalls are undoubtedly fuelling the buoyant nature of the top end of the market," says an asserta home spokesman. The phenomenon has led to some streets in London being made up entirely of £1m-plus homes.

It all begs the question: how long can the boom carry on? Well, figures out this week from Nationwide building society back up suggestions from other commentators that the market is beginning to run out of steam. It says that house prices fell 0.4% in May - the first monthly fall for almost two years - on the back of recent stock market jitters, fears of higher interest rates and the April abolition of Miras (mortgage interest tax relief).

With the economy in good shape, there is little to suggest the housing market is heading for a slump, says the Nationwide. But it adds: "Compared with the start of the year, recent economic growth is moderately slower, the number of houses being sold is lower and consumers are feeling less confident."

fields.headline: How'd they do dat?
fields.standfirst:
Bentley Rhythm Ace
Manchester University Students' Union
**
fields.trailText: Bentley Rhythm Ace Manchester University Students' Union **
fields.body:
Formed in 1995 by Brummies Mike Stokes and ex-Pop Will Eat Itself bassist Richard Marsh, Bentley Rhythm Ace have always acknowledged that the big-beat scene is more of a car-boot sale than a boutique. But now that their fusion of hip-hop, funk and jazz has become something of an anachronism, can the Bentley boys survive?

Having released a second album, For Your Ears Only, on Brighton's Skint label, the band has recruited ex-Black Grape singer Kermit to add some furiously soulful vocals over the bass-lines and frenetic rhythms. Kermit also features on the next single, How'd I Do Dat?, which was one of the better tracks of the night. With its Two Tone jauntiness and its breathless refrain, it's obviously destined for the top 10.

Bentley like to make a big noise, and it is structured by jumping-bean bass-lines. Then they add a few splashes of guitar, some jazzy keyboards, and a procession of samples, or Kermit works the voice-box to add a much-needed vocal. Theme from Gutbuster, their last single, exemplified their sound: annoyingly catchy, and gaudy as hell. Midway through the gig, the Bentley racket lost its powers of discrimination and congealed in an ineffective sonic sludge. Only Kermit's spirited vocals rose above the bass-laden monotony.

For the encore, Bentley's Gonna Sort You Out!, from their first album, all the elements came together to mesmeric effect, though this only emphasised how the band has since lost its way.

fields.headline: Fire in the  family
fields.standfirst:
Fireface
Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, London
****
fields.trailText: Fireface Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, London ****
fields.body:
The Germans have a phrase for new young British dramatists: the Blood and Sperm Generation. Maybe on the evidence of this play by Marius von Mayenburg and its immediate predecessor at the Court, David Gieselmann's Mr Kolpert, we should call young German writers the Fire and Fury Brigade, epitomising their anti-bourgeois anger.

Dominic Cooke's production and Ultz's design are even more striking than the play. We are ushered into a transformed Theatre Upstairs where we sit on swivel chairs around long white tables backed by steep perpendicular walls. In a sense we become part of the nuclear family - father, mother, daughter Olga and her fire-raising brother Kurt - whose disintegration takes place all around us. The production makes exciting use of the space to express the play's governing idea: that adolescent withdrawal and parental heedlessness are part of a familiar pattern, but that they also contain a secret fury which here erupts in spectacular violence.

Since we no longer worship the household gods, Mayenburg's conclusion may not surprise us; and any student of Max Frisch's The Fire Raisers will quickly grasp the narrative structure. What makes the play unusual is the dry humour, well brought out in Maja Zade's translation, with which Mayenburg invests the situation. Confronted by mutinous teenagers who are into incest and arson, the parents placidly reflect that "one or two more years, then they'll leave home".

It is the ignorance, rather than the brutal oppressiveness, of the bourgeoisie that is Mayenburg's real target. But it is the conceptual staging that brings the play home to us. We sit at dinner with the family as the silences roll like thunder. Lyndsey Marshal's provocative Olga teases, seduces and taunts Michael Mallon's alienated Kurt under our noses.

And we seem guiltily to participate in the surreal blandness of Gillian Hanna's mother and Ian Gelder's father, who shows more concern for the abuse of his daughter's biker boyfriend, Mel Raido, than he does for his own son's catatonic de spair. In most plays we are observers: here the staging implicates us in the fiery destruction of a particular family.

At the Theatre Upstairs (020-7565 5000) till June 17.

fields.headline: Baby-faced assassin over-priced for Euro 2000
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with a clog in one hand and a box of luxury chocolates in the other, points out the value bets for Euro 2000, before having a good old bitch about the result of this year's Eurovision Song Contest
fields.trailText: Our man with a clog in one hand and a box of luxury chocolates in the other, points out the value bets for Euro 2000, before having a good old bitch about the result of this year's Eurovision Song Contest.
fields.body:
Apart from paying their respects at the bar where Oliver Reed had his last drink, England's merry men will also be required to turn out against Malta's national football side on Saturday. The white shirts are sure to win but the fear of picking up injuries could let the home side in for a jammy goal. As the only bet worth chancing here is the correct score, try 1-4. Keegan will want to get another run under Robbie Fowler's belt but should he choose to start with Kevin Phillips, take the Sunderland striker to be the first to ripple Maltese netting.

All in all, it's best to go easy this weekend and hold off on your big ante-post Euro 2000 wagers for another few days. The top scorer market hasn't fully settled yet, but the 50-1 (Hills) offered about baby-faced assassin Ole Gunnar Solskjaer really catches the eye. If Spain get up to their usual big competition antics, it's not beyond the bounds of reason to suppose that Norway could take Group C, and if that happens Manchester United's super-saviour should only need a couple more goals to clinch it. Alan Shearer took the honours at Euro 96 with a grand tally of six, so if you take Norway to get at least as far as the semis, stake your money on Ole. A brace from him against Slovenia early doors will do very nicely, thank you.

Naturally, if you're tempted to back Solskjaer it's also worth taking Norway each way at 28s with Coral. They're as low as 16s with some other firms and when you see a gap that big you're assured, at the very least, of value. Coach Nils Johan Semb's squad, which contains eight Premiership players, will attempt to continue Norway's fine current record. They've lost just three of their 25 games since the 1998 World Cup.

As for other possible winners, go easy on heavyweights Holland and Spain, even though one from those two is nailed on to reach the final. Take instead the each-way 20s about the Czech Republic (Coral). They're the reigning runners-up and coach Jozef Chovanec says he is "very satisfied" with the team - great news that, in a straw-clutching sort of way.

Chovanec may, however, miss girl-haired Liverpool star Patrick Berger, who has been suspended for the Czech Republic's two opening games. Like an utter fool, Berger was sent off during the final qualifying game against the Faroe Islands, of all teams. His madness was the only blot on an impressive record of ten straight wins. That kind of form shouldn't be taken lightly.

If Sweden weren't so riddled with injury, they'd also be worth chancing at 20s bearing in mind the problems they gave England during qualification. They won Group Five, but they'll find it tougher now without Stefan Schwarz, Pontus Kaamark and Andreas Andersson. Striker Henrik Larsson has still not fully recovered from his nightmare leg injury, so where will the goals come from?

Nowhere, probably. Sweden's highlight for this year will remain their competent hosting of Eurovision 2000. How those crooning Danes stole it we'll never know. Russia was robbed.

webTitle: Figo sends out a message to United

fields.headline: Figo sends out a message to United
fields.trailText: Portugal's Luis Figo has let it be known that he would welcome a move to Manchester United, who have made a firm approach for the player likely to be Wales's chief tormentor tonight in Chaves and England's in 11 days in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Portugal's Luis Figo has let it be known that he would welcome a move to Manchester United, who have made a firm approach for the player likely to be Wales's chief tormentor tonight in Chaves and England's in 11 days in Euro 2000.

United and Milan have been made aware of Figo's unhappiness at Barcelona and it is understood he prefers the Premiership to Italian football. On £25,000 a week, the winger is one of the lowest-paid senior Barcelona players and knows greater riches await him at Old Trafford.

Figo, who lines up against the Welsh in Portugal's final preparatory game before facing Kevin Keegan's side in Euro 2000, has enjoyed a magnificent season for Barcelona, though it ended disappointingly as they missed out on all three targets. His form has prompted the outgoing club president Josep Nunez to put a £60m valuation on the dazzling winger but no one is treating that seriously.

Wales, hit by so many injuries, leave the responsibility for scoring tonight with the Norwich team-mates Craig Bellamy and Iwan Roberts.

The Manchester United defender John Curtis has left Old Trafford for Blackburn with Graeme Souness paying £1.5m for the England Under-21 player. The deal follows Curtis's successful loan spell with Blackburn's First Division rivals Barnsley.

webTitle: Hasselbaink left out in the cold by Dutch

fields.headline: Hasselbaink left out in the cold by Dutch
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is about to become Chelsea's £14m record signing but yesterday one of Europe's most prolific strikers was shocked to find himself made redundant by his country.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is about to become Chelsea's £14m record signing but yesterday one of Europe's most prolific strikers was shocked to find himself made redundant by his country.

Holland ditched the 28-year-old striker as the Euro 2000 favourites named their 22-man squad and, to Hasselbaink's surprise, he was squeezed out of the five-strong striker contingent by Celta Vigo's Roy Makaay and Feyenoord's Peter van Vossen.

"I didn't expect this," admitted Hasselbaink, "as Ruud van Nistelrooy is not there injured and Pierre van Hooijdonk has to start the first game on the bench."

Hasselbaink, who scored 24 Spanish league goals for Atletico Madrid, appears to have missed out because he is seen as an out-and-out striker whereas some of the Dutch coach Frank Rijkaard's selections can also play in midfield.

Juventus hope to persuade Arsenal to part with Patrick Vieira, named in France's final 22 yesterday, in exchange for £14m. Given the midfielder's huge contribution to Arsenal and his relatively young age - 24 later this month - Arsène Wenger is likely to resist any overtures. Vieira has three years left on his Highbury contract.

Wimbledon have appointed Terry Burton as manager. He was in caretaker charge for last season's final two games after Egil Olsen was sacked.

webTitle: So would you pass the chair test?

fields.headline: So would you pass the chair test?
fields.trailText: Radio 5 Live's Ian Payne gets to the bottom of what makes a hooligan a hooligan.
fields.body:
The other morning an Arsenal fan rang Radio 5 Live's daily phone-in. He said he had been one of the supporters hurling chairs in the square in Copenhagen on the afternoon of the Uefa Cup final. He added: "I'm not a hooligan. I've never been involved in violence before. But if someone picks up a chair and threatens you, what are you going to do? Stand there? Put your hands over your face? Run away? You're going to chuck one back, aren't you?"

Another supporter, who'd also been in the square, rang in a few moments later and agreed: "Who's to say that if Barry [let's call him Barry] hadn't picked up a chair, would we even be talking to him now? Or would Barry be lying in hospital with stab wounds ... or worse?".

So is Barry a football hooligan? Of all the subjects we discuss on 5 Live phone-ins (and we're talking expertise here, because we do a lot) football violence always, always elicits the greatest response. Because still no one has been able to say why it happens. And it will continue to be a big talking point up to and during Euro 2000.

A few years ago I thought I'd worked it out. It was troublemakers who went there deliberately to start the trouble. This, combined with England's reputation, which always brings out the worst in the opposition supporters, and a lot more English fans on the periphery who joined in because they were drunk, was the cause. If you wanted to avoid the trouble, you could.

I went to Rotterdam, for example, for the "do I not like that" international between England and Holland. I went as a fan, travelling with friends by ferry and car to the game. There was trouble at the railway station and in the main square. Where you'd expect it to be. We stayed out of those areas. We were fine. There were no real problems getting to the stadium, apart from the usual snarling police dogs, but if you kept your distance, you were OK.

When Ronald Koeman scored (he shouldn't even have been on the pitch after a professional foul earlier), we, in the England penned area, were assaulted by a couple of flares that were thrown at us. But a few neat sidesteps and we were just dandy, thanks. Most England fans ignored the taunting and afterwards we made our way home. No trouble.

When we got home the TV, radio and papers were full of "England violence" stories. Then there were the more hysterical columnists (as they were still doing after the Copenhagen trouble, incidentally) suggesting that England withdraw from various championships and qualifiers, and give up World Cup bids etc. Whatever. All that mattered was that I'd solved it. If you wanted to avoid trouble, you could. It was the people who wanted trouble who found it.

But now I'm not so sure. The more you hear about it, the more each case seems to be different. At Marseille during the World Cup it happened before and during the match as people watched on the beach. According to colleagues, it definitely wasn't planned. In Turkey the night before the Uefa Cup semi-final, many innocent Leeds fans who had never been involved in anything before were caught up in it.

So what do we do about Euro 2000? Not go? Ban booze for all England games? (Surely they must). Segregate the Turks and the English? What about the German fans or the Dutch?

If you were going to predict trouble, you'd do it for this tournament, wouldn't you? All the elements seem to be there. And will local police really go on strike? Maybe the solution is for everyone to visit an Amsterdam coffee shop in the build-up to the matches.

Like many reporters I used to think the trouble was caused entirely by yobbos who seemed to enjoy violence. But I can't get Barry out of my mind.

fields.headline: England's young guns fire blanks
fields.standfirst: Babnic 67, Nemeth 74
fields.trailText: Never mind getting to the final. This defeat, which flattered the losers, meant England finished third in their group and will not even have the consolation of a third-place play-off on Sunday.
fields.body:
Never mind getting to the final. This defeat, which flattered the losers, meant England finished third in their group and will not even have the consolation of a third-place play-off on Sunday.

Eight days after arriving here, Howard Wilkinson's side are coming home with a record of two defeats and one win, a record that has come as a big surprise, given that they started the tournament among the favourites.

Seven minutes after Peter Babnic's opener, Szilard Nemeth won possession in midfield and slotted the ball under Nicky Weaver to give the hosts hope themselves of reaching the final, although Italy's 3-1 win over Turkey just edged them out.

Maybe it was the shock of playing in front of a nearly full stadium and a partisan crowd but England failed to carry on where they left off on Monday. Then, they walloped Turkey 6-0, scoring three late goals, but here in the Inter Bratislava stadium they failed to create a single chance of note in the first half - a sorry fact, given that England had to score and win to have a hope of reaching Sunday's final.

Indeed their hosts had the run of things before the break and should have opened the scoring after 26 minutes. Nemeth, the top scorer in the domestic league and playing on his home ground, missed a sitter from eight yards having been teed up by his captain, Juraj Czinege.

It was unclear why England should be so lethargic, with Wilkinson making only one enforced change, bringing in Jon Harley for the suspended Seth Johnson on the left of midfield. But it was the Slovakians who made the running, forcing save after save from Weaver.

The England manager decided valour was better than discretion at half-time, replacing the ineffective David Dunn and Harley with Lee Hendrie and Andy Campbell.

Not that it made a great deal of difference, with Slovakia continuing to dominate and forcing the best from Ledley King. The Tottenham defender has been of the few plus points in this tournament and he came to the rescue after 54 minutes as he chased back to cut out a pass from Czinege that was destined for Nemeth. But 13 minutes later King was unluckily involved in Slovakia's first goal as Babnic finished his winding run with a shot that deflected off King and past Weaver.

England (3-5-2): Weaver (Manchester City); Young, King (both Tottenham Hotspur), Carragher (Liverpool); Dunn (Blackburn Rovers), Lampard (West Ham), Harley (Chelsea), Murphy (Liverpool), Mills (Leeds United); Cort (Wimbledon), Jeffers (Everton).

Slovakia (4-4-2): Contofalsky; Hrncar, Lerant, Hlinka, Cisovksy; Gresko, Czinege, Petras, Barcik; Nemeth, Babnic.

Referee: H Fandel (Germany).
