fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The very idea of England without Graham Thorpe is hard enough to swallow, let alone the fact that the Surrey southpaw prepared to face Hampshire at the Oval with 33 runs in five championship innings and a top score of 18.
fields.body:
The very idea of England without Graham Thorpe is hard enough to swallow, let alone the fact that the Surrey southpaw prepared to face Hampshire at the Oval with 33 runs in five championship innings and a top score of 18.

He and Nasser Hussain will not be alone in their relief at his half-century yesterday. While Thorpe and Mark Butcher were in harness a substantial total was on the cards but after they had put on 73 in 37 overs, the champions slid to 166 for six before Martin Bicknell ensured the circuit's shortest tail wagged with customary vigour in stands of 43 with Jonathan Batty and 53 with Alex Tudor.

On his much-delayed championship debut for Hampshire, Alan Mullally owed a debt to David Saker, the Victoria fast bowler currently playing club cricket in the north. Saker was paying a visit to his state colleague Shane Warne when he was drafted in as a substitute fielder and caught Ally Brown to give Mullally his first wicket.

Don Trangmar, the Sussex chairman, promised this week that his captain Chris Adams would "make every effort to behave responsibly without curbing his natural enthusiasm" after his £500 fine for bad behaviour from the England and Wales Cricket Board.

Adams backed up those words at Hove with a combative 90, with three sixes and nine fours, against Glamorgan . Building on the solid base of half-centuries from the openers Richard Montgomerie and Toby Peirce, Adams and Michael Bevan put on 131 for the third wicket, with the Australian left-hander reaching a 193-ball century. Sussex closed on 433 for eight, a lead of 248.

Two of Adams's former Derbyshire team-mates also enjoyed productive days. Dominic Cork, the captain, dragged his team back into their First Division match against Lancashire with three quick wickets just before tea, although his most significant delivery may have been the one that forced Peter Martin to retire hurt with a suspected broken thumb.

That brought the Lancashire first innings to a close with a lead of 43, Joe Scuderi left unbeaten nine runs short of a maiden championship half-century. But Derbyshire have already lost Steve Stubbings and Trevor Smith in their second innings and are still 19 in arrears.

At Ilford, Devon Malcolm, who left Derbyshire with Adams at the end of the 1997 season, was leading a fightback by Northamptonshire against Essex. Northants had comfortably the worse of the opening day and there was little sign of improvement as a half-century by Ronnie Irani took Essex to 204 for four, a lead of 90.

But Irani's run-out, after a mix-up with Stephen Peters, triggered a collapse in which Essex lost their last six wickets for 12 runs, with Malcolm claiming four for one in a dozen balls.

Northants then moved quickly into the lead with a second-wicket partnership of 118 between Matthew Hayden and Mal Loye, although Essex then reduce the visitors to 203 for four, a lead of 101.

An enterprising declaration by the Middlesex captain Justin Langer failed to produce an immediate dividend on another rain-affected day at Lord's. Langer called his batsmen in on 204 for nine, 55 behind, after Mike Smith had done the bulk of the damage with five for 52. But Gloucestershire's openers survived to reach 20 without loss by the close.

A 109-ball century by Sanath Jayasuriya set Sri Lanka on the way to victory over India in the Asia Cup in Bangladesh. Jayasuriya made 105 in a total of 276 for eight and India fell short despite 93 from Sachin Tendulkar.

fields.headline: Durham funk Masters
fields.trailText:
Kent 177 & 45-4
Durham 81
fields.body:
Batsmen came and went all day, 16 in all, in melancholy procession. Their expressions conveyed disbelief, puzzlement or exasperation at the seemingly turgid vagaries of the pitch. They might also have revealed self-rebuke. Too few came to terms with what they argued was an often inanimate festival track that still managed to be capricious.

Occasionally from the railway end, one heard a train on its way to Charing Cross. This suggested a sense of purpose never enacted by a long line of batsmen who appeared at times immobilised by neurosis. Stroke-making looked impractical; Durham, for instance, summoned up just four well-spaced boundaries.

Perhaps much of the huffing was justified. But would not a despairing spirit of adventure have made sense? Grim defending of the stumps proved contagious. John Wood (five for 36), emerged from near the bottom of the order only to insist on playing like a somnolent opener, pledged to save the game on the last day. He took 48 balls to score and almost at once, as if overcome by such wanton exertions, was one of the day's many lbw victims.

There were still aspects to applaud. In only his fourth first-class match David Masters took six for 27 for Kent. Four came off 10 overs during which he gave away nine runs.

His team-mates made the ritual way for him at the end of the Durham innings and Masters's shy, though joyful, reaction offered a moment to cherish on a day mostly devoid of them. The young seamer's father, Kevin, was also a Kent fast bowler; cricketing continuity on yesterday's evidence is in good hands.

Earlier Matthew Fleming, so resolute the previous day, added only two more runs and Kent were all out for 177. Durham's innings extended to 64 overs, a reflection on the disinclination to challenge the conditions. Nicky Peng, the least experienced of the batsmen, looked the likeliest to succeed. Simon Katich went to a slower ball, Martin Speight to a diving catch by Matthew Fleming at extra cover.

Kent's absence of established seam bowlers this season has brought its own bonuses, Martin Saggers finding some aggression against his former county. There were a few attacking shots as Kent batted again after some more scoreboard paralysis.

Matthew Walker was most alert; Ed Smith stayed for 33 balls before being dismissed without a run. Kent are 141 ahead and within the context of the strange batsmen's hypnosis, it may be enough.

webTitle: Cronje names devil who made him do it

fields.headline: Cronje names devil who made him do it
fields.trailText: The beleaguered former captain of South Africa Hansie Cronje, at the centre of cricket's match-fixing scandal, has made another confession, this time to a church leader, in which he lays the blame for his misconduct firmly at Satan's door.
fields.body:
The beleaguered former captain of South Africa Hansie Cronje, at the centre of cricket's match-fixing scandal, has made another confession, this time to a church leader, in which he lays the blame for his misconduct firmly at Satan's door.

The confession, made in Cronje's home country to the Rhema Church leader Ray McCauley, has made its way to the official commission of inquiry that was instituted after Indian police accused Cronje and other South African cricketers of having rigged matches during the recent tour of the sub-continent. The inquiry begins next week.

"In a moment of stupidity and weakness I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me," Cronje says in the confession. "The moment I took my eyes off Jesus my whole world turned dark."

The confession is consistent with Cronje's deeply held Christian beliefs, which began when a little girl was accidentally killed after she darted in front of Cronje's car as he was travelling to Empangeni in Zululand for a provincial game in 1993.

The commission, which will he headed by the retired judge Edwin "Sharkie" King, has confirmed the authenticity of the confession.

Although Cronje publicly confessed that he had not been "entirely honest" in his denials of involvement in match-rigging, he admitted after the scandal broke to having accepted money from a bookmaker for the triangular one-day series involving England and Zimbabwe.

The Indian police have tapes allegedly of Cronje discussing targets, playing conditions and batting orders with bookmakers. The King commission is due to go to India to hear the tapes.

webTitle: Lara looking to new Svengali for inspiration

fields.headline: Lara looking to new Svengali for inspiration
fields.standfirst: Jimmy Adams must unravel the great enigma as tour gets underway
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver On how Jimmy Adams must unravel the West Indies' great enigma as thier tour gets underway.
fields.body:
As a batsman the West Indies captain Jimmy Adams, acquisitive and adhesive but now past his best, does not make England's bowlers miss a single 'z' of sleep; but as a Svengali figure he frightens them sick.

This quietly intelligent son of a Jamaican doctor and his Canadian wife is probably the one person who can restore brilliance to Brian Lara, with all respect to his New York shrink, his Port-of-Spain mentor, his agent and all the hangers-on.

There is a friendship and mutual respect between these two players and it goes back to when they were teenagers in the first Youth World Cup.

Lara, 31, has not played while Adams has led West Indies to fragile recovery, with series victories over Zimbabwe and Pakistan. Instead, he relaxed in his native Trinidad where he joined the band Poison and became a masquerader in the famous local carnival.

But he was again the main topic of conversation yesterday as he and his team-mates loosened up for today's tour opener here.

Adams said: "As captain, and as a personal friend, I'm hoping for more than he's done in the past. I honestly believe he hasn't reached his peak.

"I look at great players like Clive Lloyd, Viv Richards, Gordon Greenidge, Desmond Haynes and Graham Gooch, and see that they peaked between 30 and their late 30s.

"I see no reason why Brian, with his talent, drive and ambition, won't exceed what he's done before."

This is a little frightening. Lara, after all, scored 375 against England in Antigua six years ago, when his series aggregate was 798 and his average 99.75, a little better than his 765 (85) on his last tour of England 18 months later.

Adams continued: "Brian is just returning to cricket after a break. At this point in time he prefers to concentrate on his cricket. He needs to get some privacy and to refocus on his cricket." That was just before Lara disappeared with his tabloid ghostwriter.

"We played very good and positive cricket in Brian's absence but I speak for everyone when I say I'm delighted to have him back in the squad."

What does he give you, someone asked. "Greatness," said Adams. "His ability is beyond question. If he is not close to 100% come the first Test he will be close enough.

"Why he took a rest is a question that must be directed to Brian. We could sit here and come up with a lot of suppositions. We're just pleased to have him back. He knows how well the team performed without him and that should be another incentive for him."

The presence of Lara has delighted not only Adams, but most England players and supporters too. There is a similarity between West Indies, who have lost their last 10 Tests abroad, and England, and not just because both these troubled sides have launched fragile recoveries by bashing Zimbabwe.

Both have also looked towards articulate intelligence to drag them out of their malaise: Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher in the case of England, Adams and the coach Roger Harper in the case of West Indies.

Many respected voices in the Caribbean felt that Viv Richards should have been kept on as coach. But Adams and Harper know each other well. They worked together during the A-team tour to South Africa in 1997-98, and again when Jamaica won this year's Busta Cup.

Adams, 32, who took over after the tour of New Zealand last winter, said: "The first thing we did was get a squad of players together in Jamaica. We have had camps before, but never before a home series.

"For close on two weeks we paid a lot of attention to every aspect of our cricket, technical, physical and mental. It gave us all the chance to bond and, looking back, it was a tremendous success."

webTitle: Timeless Trent Bridge - apart from the rail-cam and dot.coms

fields.headline: Timeless Trent Bridge - apart from the rail-cam and dot.coms
fields.trailText: Podmore The Zimboks could learn a whole lot about commitment from any one of the 200 hospitality rooms in the Radcliffe Road stand.
fields.body:
You could tell by the way the wind lifted the tassels on Beefy Botham's loafers at 11am that it was always going to be an in-and-out sort of day. The portents hadn't been good, what with the flooding on the A453 heading for Trent Bridge.

Pod is nothing if not public spirited so I rang Radio 5 Live Roadwatch to report the tailback. I reckoned this would also keep Dave Podmore's name in the news, which could be useful over the next few weeks here at Notts, when young master Shoaib Akhtar arrives in all his glory, and seasoned professionals who don't break down at every opportunity are unlikely to get a look-in.

Needless to say, the BBC chose not to relay my message, name-checking instead someone stuck in the same jam called Keith; no doubt some sad sales rep with nothing better to do than pester busy people.

Pod's spirits were lifted on arrival, though, by the news that play would be limited to 75 overs and an early lunch was being taken. A three-hour lunch is an excellent idea and went down really well with the guests of Ray Poole Reinforced Doors (Heanor) Limited, who'd been networking hard since eight o'clock.

Anyone who thinks that Test cricket is boring should have looked through the windows of Derek Randall Suites 1 and 2, where Ray and the guys were giving it 140%, and incidentally aiming the scotch eggs with more accuracy than some of friend Nkala's wilder efforts.

In fact, the Zimboks could learn a whole lot about commitment from any one of the 200 hospitality rooms in the Radcliffe Road stand. Fair enough, their minds are obviously on all the trouble at home. But we all have to go through that. There was the time just after my second benefit with Derbyshire when I had to concentrate just as the Halifax interest rate was fluctuating all over the shop. But I still kept it tight on the park.

I know I'm biased but on quiet afternoons like the first day of a Test there's nowhere to touch Trent Bridge. It has a timeless quality: as one of Pod's predecessors on this page put it, the sun's always shining and the doughnuts are always £3.60 for four.

And the knowledgeable crowd is legendary. They can tell you where Parr's Tree stood, when it was cut down and how many Scrumpy Jack and Bacon Bap concessions it has happily made way for.

Trent Bridge has never been afraid to move with the times. One of the most exciting innovations has been the Sky-Track digital rail-cam, with an interactive option that enables the viewer to sit at home and edit the commentary so that Beefy isn't slagging off Ramps all the time. You can even press a button and return Jeff Thomson's hair to its natural colour. No way can you stop progress.

As for Team England, they are unrecognisable from the outfit of a few years ago. A look round the car park told its own story. No more Devon Malcolm taking up three spaces with a wild stab at putting it on the spot. Instead, a neat row of sponsored cars, all the dot.com logos pointing in the same direction with Nass's Merc leading the way. A word of advice to the Zimboks' coach and its driver: Get the parking right, you get the cricket right.

A word of advice to the Zimboks' coach and its driver: Get the parking right, you get the cricket right.

webTitle: A worried nation frets for Ramps

fields.headline: A worried nation frets for Ramps
fields.trailText: david Hopps Callers to a Test Match Special phone-in were obsessed with how Ramprakash might handle a delayed start.
fields.body:
A favourite English ritual was in full swing here yesterday, as vital to the arrival of summer as the roar of motorbikes and the dusting down of the garden furniture. It was the Worrying-On-Behalf-of-Mark-Ramprakash syndrome.

That Ramprakash would have achieved greatness were it not for an uptight temperament has become one of cricket's truisms, but if he was nervous as he sought to reinvent himself as an opening batsman, at the wrong side of 30, he was not half as petrified as most of those who were watching him.

Callers to a Test Match Special phone-in were obsessed with how Ramprakash might handle a delayed start. Men in ECB blazers wondered if he might be disturbed by the commonplace nature of Zimbabwe's attack. Only when he produced the shot of this embryonic summer - lashing Pommie Mbangwa through extra cover - did hearts briefly beat as normal.

A special section of the ground should have been set aside for those worrying on behalf of Ramprakash.

You can imagine their misgivings. Only 56. Oh, no. That's one fewer than the number of varieties developed by Mr Heinz. Substantially below pensionable age. Twenty short of the number of trombones in the big parade. The subliminal damage could be devastating.

It is all horribly out of proportion. To milk this Zimbabwe attack for a Test hundred would have done Ramprakash a power of good. He has only made one in 40 Tests. But watershed this was not, and was never going to be.

It is the West Indies series that will judge Ramprakash's Test credentials, just as West Indies series have reflected his progress throughout his career.

In his debut summer, in 1991, he was the maker of dogged 20s; four years later a pair at Lord's symbolised a career in abeyance; and, most memorably, it was his 154 in Bridgetown three winters ago that brought hopes that he had reached fulfillment.

Zimbabwe should not be rubbished. But there were times when they resembled a decent club attack. They even benefited from the club bowler's favourite weapon - as play was frequently halted for people moving behind the arm.

Zimbabwe's players wore armbands in memory of Tony Oates, the fifth farmer to die since squatters occupied white-run farms. His son, Jason, toured England with Zimbabwe's Under-19 side last summer.

By such standards, worrying about Mark Ramprakash is pointless. He is old enough and good enough to be left to get on with it.

webTitle: Reborn assembly flags up fresh divisions

fields.headline: Reborn assembly flags up fresh divisions
fields.trailText: 02/06/2000: After patching over their differences on the                                                                    huge issues of IRA disarmament and                                                                    police reform, Ulster Unionist and Sinn                                                                    Fein ministers in the Northern Ireland                                                                    executive are now squabbling over which                                                                    flags to fly over their departments.
fields.body:
After patching over their differences on the huge issues of IRA disarmament and police reform, Ulster Unionist and Sinn Fein ministers in the Northern Ireland executive are now squabbling over which flags to fly over their departments.

Today is Coronation day, and naturally the Unionists want to see the Union flag hoisted. Equally naturally, Sinn Fein won't hear of it - unless the Irish tricolour flies alongside. That in turn is rejected by the Unionists.

Many onlookers in Britain will find all this despicably petty. But it would be hasty, and more than a little condescending, to dismiss the vital importance of national symbols in Ireland.

Nationality, after all, is what it is all about: 30 years of conflict and terror, and more than 3,250 lives lost, all boil down to which flag shall fly over the six counties.

It is a tribute to the new, albeit grudging, spirit of cooperation in Belfast, that neither faction is talking about the flag issue as a serious threat to the power-sharing executive, all of three days old in its latest incarnation. There are, alas, much darker clouds on the horizon.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is under fierce and increasing pressure over his police bill, designed to implement the radical reforms spelled out in the Patten report. The Unionists want to retain the name and insignia of the Royal Ulster Constabulary - symbolism again - while Sinn Fein and the more pragmatic Social Democratic and Labour party are determined to have a new force called the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

Republicans and nationalists suspect that Mandelson is prepared to water down the police reforms to keep the Unionists sweet. The Irish government shares that concern.

The first minister of the fragile executive, David Trimble, would dearly like to extract more concessions on the police issue, to suppress a rumbling rebellion in his own Unionist ranks. He must also be looking over his shoulder at Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party, which is spearheading the loyalist anti-power sharing movement.

Under the complex formula for distributing power around the parties in the Northern Ireland assembly, the DUP has been given two departments to run. Its ministers, Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds, have taken up their posts and the fat salaries which go with them, but say they do not accept the doctrine of collective responsibility.

They will not attend government meetings with Sinn Fein ministers. Even more provocatively, they say they will resign after a month or so, handing on their ministries to DUP colleagues who will then themselves resign.

It has now emerged that each time a Northern Ireland minister resigns, he or she is entitled automatically to three months' severance pay. The DUP says that this nice little earner will go into a campaign fund to bring down the whole power-sharing structure.

Trimble and his SDLP deputy, Seamus Mallon, have summoned the two DUP ministers to a meeting on Monday. Robinson says he won't go, because he will be too busy earning his other fat salary as an MP in Westminster.

The problem for the pro-agreement parties is that they cannot gang up on the DUP and kick it out of the devolved government without undermining the central tenet of power-sharing - and setting a dangerous precedent for future exclusions in more dubious causes.

webTitle: Rain prevents any play on second day

fields.headline: Rain prevents any play on second day
fields.trailText: Play was abandoned without a ball bowled on the second day of the Second Test at Trent Bridge. Light drizzle hung in the air for much of the day, and despite the valliant efforts of the Nottingham groundstaff when the rain did subside, match umpires Mervyn Kitchen and Dave Orchard decided no play would be possible shortly before 5.30pm.
fields.body:
Play was abandoned without a ball bowled on the second day of the Second Test at Trent Bridge. Light drizzle hung in the air for much of the day, and despite the valliant efforts of the Nottingham groundstaff when the rain did subside, match umpires Mervyn Kitchen and Dave Orchard decided no play would be possible shortly before 5.30pm.

Michael Atherton must now wait at least another night before he gets the chance to turn his 96* into his 14th Test century. When play is possible, England will resume on 203 for three, with Alec Stewart the other not-out batsman on 8*.

webTitle: Zimbabwe land-owners face compulsory purchase orders

fields.headline: Zimbabwe land-owners face compulsory purchase orders
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, today said his government would compulsorily acquire 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to black people. But he said that the process would begin after the parliamentary elections later this month.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, today said his government would compulsorily acquire 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to black people. But he said that the process would begin after the parliamentary elections later this month.

"The president intends to acquire compulsorily the land described in the schedule for resettlement purposes," the government said in a statement published in the state-owned Government Gazette.

The Gazette, which identified 804 farms around the country, said owners and others with an interest in the land would have until July 2 to object.

The government, facing parliamentary elections on June 24 and 25, last week passed a law giving it the right to acquire the farms without paying its owners compensation. Owners may be able to claim some compensation for improvements they have made to the property.

More than 80 white land-owners have fled their farms after receiving death threats from militants led by veterans of the war that ended white rule in Rhodesia, as Zimbabwe was called, in 1980.

The home affairs minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, said last week that the war veterans should prepare to leave the land once the list of 804 farms was published. But the veterans have said they will only move on Mr Mugabe's orders.

"We are actually very happy for them to be there," Mr Mugabe said in an address to 500 veterans and supporters of his ruling party, Zanu-PF.

An independent foreign group of observers said last week that the conditions did not yet exist for free and fair elections. Nominations close tomorrow, although the final lists will still have to be approved by the special courts sitting in each of the country's eight provinces.

fields.headline: Strikers, Hackers and Golfers
fields.trailText: HASSEL OVER
fields.body:
HASSEL OVER

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink today finally brought an end to the laziest transfer story in recent years when he roused himself out of his armchair, put on his dressing gown and ambled to central London to sign a six-year contract with fashionable-again West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea. Dutch international Jimmy, with a soothing mug of hot chocolate in his hand, met the press and said: "It's a very big move and I feel happy with it. I hope to get as high as possible."

High in terms of league position, you understand. Although no-one would deny the man who scored half of Atletico's goals last season a celebratory 'cocktail' on his return to the league he loves so much. "I had two great years at Leeds and I love that club," said the man who walked out on them last summer. "When I left Leeds I had an offer from Chelsea. I wanted to come here but they didn't want to let me go to another English club. So I had to leave to Atletico."

But now Jimmy has got his all-time dream move of all time. And a small matter of a contract believed to be worth around £60k-a-week. This means that Chris Sutton is likely get 60 reminders a week to sling his hook, and Gianfranco Zola will probably have to pack up his bag of tricks and hitch his way back to Italy. George Weah's loan is also up and Tore Andre Flo could leave for Leeds. But as far as Jimmy is concerned: "It's a strong squad at Chelsea with a lot of players." Stay off the yoghurts Jimmy, that would be our advice.

FUN WITH ENGLAND

Earlier today, everything about England's pre-Euro 2000 warm-up trip to Malta was going perfectly. Dennis Wise had been bundled into a swimming-pool sized locker for the fourth successive away trip, while Robbie Fowler was busy in the toilet, eagerly preparing to open up the Saturday night festivities by dropping hundreds of water-filled condoms all over Derek Fazackerley. A traditional boring nil-nil draw in tomorrow's match and England would be set up perfectly for Euro 2000.

But then Kelvin Koogan strolled in and ripped apart weeks of intricate planning for the biggest booze-fest in Valletta since Napoleon's troops passed through in 1798. "There is no way my players will be taking it easy in this match," Koogan promised the press - prompting astonished looks from his squad, who thought that was the whole idea. "I promise it will not be like a testimonial and if players perform as if it is then they will be replaced. We have to look at this as another game where we can learn a lot about ourselves."

And to prove his point, Koogan then named a side close to his first eleven. Nick Barmby, Kevin Phillips and Richard Wright have been given the opportunity to prove themselves, but Koogan is taking the match as seriously as any other. "Football is a competitive game and we will be going in to win the ball," he said, when asked about his tactics for tomorrow's game. Not bad when you think the Maltese are known for being a tough-tackling side. Actually, let's dispense with the journalese - they're hackers.

England team: Wright, G Neville, P Neville, Campbell, Keown, Wise, Beckham, Scholes, Barmby, Shearer, Phillips.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have put the idea into a safe and I have lost the combination to that safe. Let it stay there in peace" - Sepp Blatter has abandoned the idea of a World Cup every two years. At least until he finds a safe-cracker.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DOUBLE TROUBLE

Now that Celtic have made Martin O'Neill their manager, what is poor old caretaker boss Kenny Dalglish going to do? Well, obviously he's going to play a lot golf. A hell of a lot. But what about in-between rounds, will he just hang around Parkhead and get in the way?

"From my own point of view, that's my spell as interim manager over now," began Kenny as he obstructed an agitated Irish bloke with some important business to attend to in the corridor. "I'll be moving back to my original position," the Director of Football continued, ordering an impatient curly-haired chap to carry his clubs to his car. As he sped off for the sanctuary of the Old Course, he was heard to shout: "I hope Martin's time at the club is very successful."

So it looks like everything's back to normal at Celtic. But what of poor old left-behind Leicester? Fans still reeling from O'Neill's departure were served another body blow today when Steve Walsh revealed he would put himself and Tony Cottee forward as a management dream ticket. "When a manager departs it doesn't always benefit the club to bring in a new face," explained Walsh, reading verbatim from 'Manage This, Relegate That', the best-selling self-help guide by top executive guru David Platt.

"I believe that myself and Tony are as capable as anyone of keeping this team together and on the road Martin has put us on," the stalwart defender said, almost believing it himself. "I will be confirming my intention as soon as possible to the chairman of my and Tony's intention to apply for the roles of manager and assistant manager." Ah well, it was good while it lasted.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds are interested in signing Lee Hendrie from Aston Villa. "I've heard a few things about it", the £5m-rated midfielder said today. "I don't know for sure what's happening because I've been away from home and I'm not too sure how far it has gone. I will have to see what the manager says first."

Southampton, West Ham and Coventry are scrapping it out to bring another Moroccan international to the Premiership. All three clubs want to sign central defender Abdullah Saber from Sporting Lisbon, although the lure of Big Cup football (Sporting are Portuguese champions) could be enough to keep him at the club.

Middlesbrough are reported to have agreed terms with Christian Karembeu over his proposed move to the Riverside. The transfer could be completed over the weekend. Earlier today a club spokesman confirmed: "We have declared an interest in the player."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

A top Uefa official has attacked the British government for not banning hooligans from travelling to Euro 2000. Egidius Braun, who is chairman of the organising committee for Euro 2000 and president of the German FA, said: "The German government are not only taking passports off known hooligans but they will also be obliged to report to the police station every day during the championships. I think it is not the best idea that they are not doing anything in England."

Darlington will have one league point deducted next season if there is any repeat of the incident in which one of their fans attacked a opposition player. The club pleaded guilty today to a charge of failing to control their spectators towards the end of a Third Division match with Shrewsbury on April 5.

Bradford will play either Turkish side Kocaelispor or FK Atlantas of Lithuania in the second round of the Intertoto Cup.

Dutch midfielder Edgar Davids is recovering quickly from an ingrowing toenail and should be fit to play in Holland's opening Euro 2000 match.

Barcelona's Brazilian forward Rivaldo has pledged his future to the club - if they decide they want to keep him. Lazio were reported to be leading the chase for a player valued at around $50 million but Rivaldo insisted: "If Barcelona want me in the team then I'll stay."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

History Channel: The Tsar's Faberge Eggs (7pm)

No football at all on television or radio tonight. We like the sound of this, though.

Dutch midfielder Edgar Davids is recovering quickly from an ingrowing toenail and should be fit to play in Holland's opening Euro 2000 match. Barcelona's Brazilian forward Rivaldo has pledged his future to the club - if they decide they want to keep him. Lazio were reported to be leading the chase for a player valued at around $50 million but Rivaldo insisted: "If Barcelona want me in the team then I'll stay." * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO History Channel: The Tsar's Faberge Eggs (7pm) No football at all on television or radio tonight. We like the sound of this, though.

webTitle: Norman Tebbit in his own words

fields.headline: Norman Tebbit in his own words
fields.standfirst: Tebbit: 'Too many gay ministers and Hague's small, bald with odd voice'
fields.trailText: Tebbit: 'Too many gay ministers and Hague's small, bald with odd voice'
fields.body:
On the unemployed
"I grew up in the 30s with our unemployed father. He did not riot, he got on his bike and he looked for work." Tory party conference, 1981
On the prime minister
"Tony Blair said 'set my people free'... He has: more than 250 terrorists, bombers, extortionists, knee-cappers, kidnappers, arsonists and killers." October 1999
On why gay people should be barred from becoming home secretary
"The Home Office is responsible for laws affecting society - the adoption of children and the strengthening of the family. It is better not in the care of someone who doesn't feel for those issues." June 2000
On Michael Portillo's admission of a gay past
"Michael made a terrible mistake. His initial answer was truthful but it didn't embrace the whole truth  It was damaging for him, because he didn't do that." June 2000
On celibate politicians
"For example, there's Ted Heath. He was celibate. But Ted wasn't a raving queer." June 2000
On the Northern Ireland peace process
"We are being asked to buy a pig in a poke. It is always the same pig and always the same poke and it has never yet been delivered." July 1999
On political affiliation with Germany
"If Mr Blair wants to be in step with Mr Schröder  he will have to learn the goosestep." February 1999
On Muslims
"We must see if we can find a way in which Muslims can be truly British. I think there are ways in which that can be done, in which their law and their tradition can be respected. But it has to be respected that, if one is living in a Christian country, it is Christian law that overrides it." 1997
On Michael Heseltine
"At times his conduct has been tasteless, tacky if not dishonourable, and self-centred beyond even the call of his profession." February 1997
On the Conservative government's European policy
"A parliament composed largely of parliamentary pygmies accepting a slide towards being little more than a provincial assembly with subordinate powers to legislate over a shrinking proportion of our national affairs." November 1996
On the destination of western aid to Africa
"Down in the same sink of iniquity, corruption and violence in which most aid goes in Africa" November 1996
On corporal punishment
"I was caned at school and I suspect that I would have been more unruly had I not been." October 1996
On his Spitting Image puppet
"I found that many people, particularly the young, found that it made me a recognisable and not unsympathetic figure." March 1995

fields.headline: Most wanted:  bespoke spectacles
fields.trailText: As glasses wearers will know, it's a tough job choosing new frames. If you get it wrong, your whole appearance changes and you risk the mockery of friends and family - and sometimes there's nothing in the shop you can bear sporting on the bridge of your nose.
fields.body: As glasses wearers will know, it's a tough job choosing new frames. If you get it wrong, your whole appearance changes and you risk the mockery of friends and family - and sometimes there's nothing in the shop you can bear sporting on the bridge of your nose. So give a big round of applause to Stuart Jones, a designer who has just opened the first bespoke spectacle shop in the country, in Manchester's Royal Exchange (0161 839 3500). Jones analyses your features, colouring and personality, before sketching both your face and possible frame shapes. From there, he can advise on what would suit you and create completely individual, made-to-measure glasses or sunglasses. Word of Jones' talents is spreading and there is already a waiting list, apparently. Prices start at £160, but as glasses are such a vital part of your image, it's worth it. No one will ever call you four-eyes again. OK, they might, but at least you'll be a fashionable four-eyes.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:   men in pastels
fields.trailText: Days were when a man walking into a pub in pink, duck egg or pistachio would be at serious risk of being beaten to the more manly colours of black and blue. But days have changed and pastels are coming out of women's closets and making their way into men's.
fields.body:
Days were when a man walking into a pub in pink, duck egg or pistachio would be at serious risk of being beaten to the more manly colours of black and blue. But days have changed and pastels are coming out of women's closets and making their way into men's. The footballer (yes, Beckham), the actor (rent-a-lad Nick Moran) and even the hip hop bad boy (Sean "Puffy" Coombes) are showing their feminine side with a penchant for pastels.

There is a theory that the tougher you are, the pinker you can go because, hey, you can handle the stick. But much of this new passion for pink, this lust for lemon, has to do with the ironic (or is it?) imitation of classic Brit aristocrats. Dressing like a pansy has always been de rigueur among floppy-haired Oxbridge boys (and their Euro and US imitators) and the message is: "I have money." Even if it's ever so tongue in cheek, wearing pink Burberry shirts, pale blue Prada slacks and yellow Lacoste tank tops is still proclaiming the wearer a man of leisure (dark tones are for those who get dirty).

This fact has been rammed home by Jeremy Scott, whose pink and gold sportswear has swept the fashion world with a shameless filthy-rich cry. In these affluent times, everyone is doing the "I've got a yacht" look, from nouveau-trad English brands such as People's Wardrobe and Paul Smith to the slicker DKNY and Armani. You can even find it on the high street, from Hennes to Gap. So stifle that cry of "Ponce!" when you next see a bloke in baby blue or powder pink because, well, try it and you'll see why.

fields.headline: Contrex
fields.trailText: I am overly interested in water. This probably makes me a prime candidate for Hackwatch and yet a small hunch says I'm not alone. After all, sales of bottled water have increased by 400% over the past decade - a fact that will surprise nobody who lives in London.
fields.body:
I am overly interested in water. This probably makes me a prime candidate for Hackwatch and yet a small hunch says I'm not alone. After all, sales of bottled water have increased by 400% over the past decade - a fact that will surprise nobody who lives in London. Even with the fiercest of hangovers, I'd rather dehydrate like an old prune than stave my thirst with cloudy, bleachy tap water.

Annoying as it is to lug home every evening, bottled water is a fridge necessity. But which brand to swear allegiance to? The fasherati has traditionally favoured Evian: its pink and blue bottle meets with their high standards of aesthetics, while the dinky little spritzer cans are oh-so-handy on flights. Perrier is another favourite for its classic appeal. Clubbers, meanwhile, have been quick to go for Naya: its easy-drink "sport" cap prevents water dribbling down your chin while you're dancing.

But now there's a newcomer on the block that might just challenge the big guns. Contrex is the number two still mineral water in France and has just arrived exclusively at larger Boots stores across Britain. But it is not the water's French heritage that makes it so desirable, nor the fact that it undergoes 350 quality checks each day to guarantee purity and taste. It's the high level of calcium - 729mg per bottle, about the same as three glasses of milk - that gives it the edge. Launched yesterday to coincide with the first day of National Osteoporosis Month, Contrex is the perfect tipple for anyone needing a calcium top-up, such as pregnant women, adolescents and those with dairy intolerances.

While nobody is advocating that water should replace food as a source of minerals, it's still important that we drink plenty of it every day. Fact-lovers, did you know that even a 3% loss in total body-water will cause fatigue, while a 10% loss is life-threatening?

Our only quarrel with Contrex is: must it really retail at £1.09 for 1.5 litres? Bottled water already costs silly money. Can someone have a word?

fields.headline: Naked ambition
fields.standfirst: When Joely Richardson got ready for the royal premiere of her new film, she knew she had a winning combination: no back, front pages.  Laura Craik on what revealing little numbers reveal about their wearers
fields.trailText: When Joely Richardson got ready for the royal premiere of her new film, she knew she had a winning combination: no back, front pages. Laura Craik on what revealing little numbers reveal about their wearers
fields.body:
You can imagine the conversation. "Please, Jo. Go on, be a love." "I'm not sure, Ben. It's ages since I went to the gym."

"I know my new film's fantastic and will be as big a hit as Notting Hill, but even so, it could do with extra publicity. Can't you just ... get 'em out?"

"I don't know, Ben. I'm a serious actress, part of a distinguished showbiz family. I don't need to get 'em out."

"Christ, Joely. Can't you even show a bit of leg? You might make front page of the Mail, like Carol Vorderman."

"Oh, OK, then. Just let me book a quick St Tropez tanning session first."

Whatever possessed the habitually demure, sophisticated actress Joely Richardson - more commonly seen in crisp Calvin Klein white shirt and Joseph trousers - to don a strappy, plunge-neck, backless minidress festooned with golden fringes? True, the event in question - the royal premiere of the film Maybe Baby, written and directed by Ben Elton - was suitably grand and high profile. But a simple black velvet number would have done. Something tasteful from Prada, perhaps? Richardson's dress, which hailed from the fantastical imagination of Welsh designer Julien MacDonald, wouldn't have looked out of place in the Spice Girls' tour wardrobe. Indeed, Posh wore a similar MacDonald creation to the British Fashion Awards in February. She, too, got a lot of publicity for it.

Joely Richardson looked stunning. Tall, blonde, tanned and buffed, she was a golden goddess, her lithe legs made longer by the addition of strappy three-inch heels (in gold, of course). If you've got a body like that, why not flaunt it? With her Model Looks, Richardson would have made the papers whatever she'd worn. But only by upping the ante and exposing Ibizan levels of flesh did she stand a chance of bagging the front pages of the Mail, Mirror and Telegraph - plus gratuitous footage on TV.

Dressing for special occasions is difficult. Women, unlike men, can't just don a smart tie and hope for the best. Women must take into account current fashions, the type of occasion, the level of their self-esteem on said night. If they have a tan, they might just show their legs. If they've lost weight recently, a glimpse of midriff might feel acceptable.

For models and actresses, the stakes are even higher. These women are paid to look good and command attention. Every social event is fraught with sartorial danger. What if they pick the wrong dress? Wrong colour? Wrong style? What if - horror of horrors - they have a Celine Dion Moment?

Little wonder flesh so often prevails over common sense and decency because one thing is for sure: exposing your skin will get cameras clicking, tongues rolling and lips licking. Liz Hurley knows it: she and Versace have made thousands out of her creamy taut flesh. Princess Diana knew it: post-Charles, her first public outing was in a figure-hugging creation with a risqué décolletage. How many newly-single women have resorted to the same trick? It works every time: the misty stares of men act as an instant, meaningless ego-boost.

Of course, these days we are somewhat inured to the shock value/sex appeal of flesh. Even the cleavage has lost its erotic appeal in the face of so many wholly exposed breasts. When, in 1991, Transvision Vamp frontwoman Wendy James graced the cover of The Face wearing nothing but two diamanté nipple studs, it was considered outrageous. Fast forward 10 years and suddenly it's OK to be seen in public with your tits out. Recent examples: rapper Lil Kim exposing one breast at the VH1 awards, Jennifer Lopez flaunting breastbone and bosom in a sheer Versace dress and Meg Mathews' nipple poking through a slashed Galliano evening gown.

Consequently, women have had to look for new erogenous zones with which to gain attention. Though a great favourite with designers this season, the breastbone hasn't caught on with Real Women - not surprising, since you need the tits of a 12-year- old to carry it off. Far more popular is the backless dress, as sported by everyone from Mariah Carey to EastEnders' Tamasin Outhwaite and Barbara Windsor. The bare back is a great bet for older women as backs often age better than other parts of the body. Bare backs look sexy without being try-hard or tarty. Carol Vorderman, 39, stunned onlookers at the recent Bafta awards in a plunge-back turquoise dress, her flesh slick with fashionable body glitter.

Some celebrities have to go further. Remember Liz Hurley's silver panties? Let's be blunt: Ms Hurley had more than one pair of lips on show. When Vivienne Westwood picked up her OBE in 1992, she exposed her entire "front bum" to the world, pulling her skirt up to reveal no pants under sheer tights. Naturally, this made the papers, though as Westwood is slightly less desirable to the average man than Liz Hurley, some of the reports were less than complimentary.

And there's the rub. It is excellent that these women - of all ages - feel confident enough to bare their flesh when the occasion suits. For what's more feel-good than slipping on a dress that empowers you and sailing off into the night? Joely Richardson knew her dress would get her column inches, sure. She also knew that men would admire her in it.

But woe betide the less firm of flesh if they stick their wrinkly paps above the parapet. The sad reality is that saggy bums and flabby tums will not increase your status, even if they are swathed in Versace. Because however beneficently you judge your own reflection in the mirror, men will judge you harshly if you don't come close enough to their idea of Goddess. Don't believe me? Four words: Sporty Spice in Barbados.

webTitle: How to look great in the great outdoors

fields.headline: How to look great in the great outdoors
fields.standfirst: Grey skies getting you down? Slip on a blue one. Got a yen for greenery? Look out the leaf prints. Fashion editor  Laura Craik on how to have a change of scenery without leaving home
fields.trailText: Grey skies getting you down? Slip on a blue one. Got a yen for greenery? Look out the leaf prints. Fashion editor Laura Craik on how to have a change of scenery without leaving home
fields.body:
This one's for all you city-dwellers out there. Bored of the dank grey concrete all around you? Fancy a change of scenery but you've run out of annual leave? Never mind. Summer may not be in the air, or even round the corner, but at least you can wear a rendition of it on your chest. Or, if you prefer, on your legs. This season, designers have gone all Constable on us, offering a plethora of pretty landscapes printed on to all sorts of clothing. Did they know it was going to be a lousy May or something? How else did they guess we'd all be yearning to feast our eyes on something more attractive than a gloomy rain-filled sky?

Forget gazing longingly at travel brochures: for virtual holiday environments, these clothes are hard to beat. Want to conjure up the balmy warmth of a tropical paradise? Versace's palm leaf print trousers are just the ticket - and only half the price of a real one to the Caribbean! Cheaper still is Holland and Holland's grass print dress: all the beauty of the countryside, minus the hayfever. Still too pricey? Try Bandolera's uplifting cloud and beach T-shirt: at £39, even the cheapest bucket flight to Benidorm can't possibly compete.

"They've been marvellous sellers," says Sharon Beatty, spokesperson for Bandolera, a new Dutch company whose Regent Street shop opened in March. So popular have the tees been that a new range, featuring rocky mountains, is planned for autumn.

But how does the romance of the beach transform into the reality of the T-shirt? Through photoprinting: snapping the image of your choice, scanning it, then transferring it, with the help of special fixing chemicals, on to fabric. You can try doing it yourself with Dylon Image Maker, which can permanently fix photocopied images on to any washable garment - and costs less than a fiver.

Where did this trend for printed landscapes come from? Well, second-hand tees emblazoned with pictures of eagles and sunsets have been popular with London kids for years: they like them for their authentic 70s vibe, man. Stella McCartney incorporated her own version into Chloe's autumn/ winter 99 collection - which is possibly why the high street has spawned so many six months down the line. Miss Sixty and New Look both do versions (or they did last time I looked - with the high street's fast turnover, they may be sold out now). Never has it been so easy to broaden your horizons without leaving the country. Or, indeed, the town centre.

Miss Sixty and New Look both do versions (or they did last time I looked - with the high street's fast turnover, they may be sold out now). Never has it been so easy to broaden your horizons without leaving the country. Or, indeed, the town centre.

fields.headline: A bar is born
fields.standfirst: It opens, rammed with A-list celebs. A few months later they've been replaced by soap stars and cheap suits. Then even the puffa-jacket crew won't touch the place.  Richard Benson  on the life cycle of a trendy drinking hole
fields.trailText: When clubland entrepreneur Oliver Peyton opened the Atlantic Bar and Grill in 1994, a generation of fashion-conscious late twenty- and thirtysomethings regarded him as the drinking man's Moses.
fields.body:
When clubland entrepreneur Oliver Peyton opened the Atlantic Bar and Grill in 1994, a generation of fashion-conscious late twenty- and thirtysomethings regarded him as the drinking man's Moses. They thought he had come to lead them out of the slavery of the pub into the promised land of Manhattan-style bars, with their elaborate interior designs, cocktails and properly-served drinks, decent food and grown-up hours. Of course the posing rump moaned about everyone being pretentious, but they still went there, and looked upon Oliver's promised land and saw that it was good and believed - even if they did mutter that they preferred old blokes pubs, actually.

Peyton was not the first to attempt such a thing in London; several smaller fashionable restaurants and hip, late bars had opened in the months before the Atlantic, as three socio-economic factors coalesced. Thatcher's Beer Acts had forced breweries to release licensed properties on to the market at low prices; Martini was launching an aggressive marketing campaign aimed at re-promoting the cocktail against lagers; and the increasingly heavy use of Ecstasy in clubs was, says Peyton, alienating many of his generation. What the Atlantic's huge queues demonstrated was the scale of demand for such venues, and it gave momentum to a trend that brought the phrase "style bar" into today's night life lexicon. The question now is how many bars the market can sustain; smart, upmarket bars rely on smart, upmarket customers, and the competition to attract them is intensifying.

Three new style-conscious bar-restaurants have opened in London in the last month alone; The Purple Bar at Ian Schrager's Sanderson hotel, Smith's of Smithfield on Charterhouse Street, and for(m) (no, that's how they spell it), which is a member's club on Greek Street. Such frenetic activity means that the bar economy now support its own business conferences, with the first, (called, in that arch, modern, monosyllabic way, "bar") taking place at the Business Design Centre in Islington, London next week.

"There is still unsatisfied demand for these bars, so they'll keep opening," says Simon Difford, the visionary publisher of Class, a "Magazine of Bar Culture" that in the last three years has gone from being a trade journal to successful newsstand title. "They've come about partly because of an economic boom, and the trend of people trading up, looking for better food, homes, holidays and everything. The ultimate trade up in a bar is a cocktail."

But Peyton adds that there is a problem in that "London's bar culture is beginning to feel like New York's - famous for 15 minutes. The ones falling by the wayside are the ones with no big idea; the owners start a bar because people say you can make money in them, but they're not interested in running a cool and interesting place. But I think people are learning from the mistakes."

Of course to make your bar "a cool and interesting place" you need the right clientele; no one's going to think they're "trading up" if they're surrounded only by besuited and belligerent after-work office gangs. Maintaining the right crowd has become something of a science. According to Debra Bourne, media consultant and event organiser, it's "a bit like sustaining a relationship, and suffers accordingly - there's the initial chasing, posturing and courting the in-crowd, the early euphoria, a honeymoon period until the inevitable downward spiral of mundanity sets in and then it's a case of pulling out a few new tricks to spice things up. And even then, two out of three marriages break down."

The story is not always the same - the owners with ideas will find different strategies - but the standard pitfall-laden process usually runs like this: three months before opening, the bar PR contacts figureheads - people who will get other people talking about the venue. Primarily celebrities that the owner fondly imagines will be his long term regulars, these individuals are tempted in with free meals, given membership cards, then cited as regulars in briefings to journalists. Others invited to preview the venue will be society hosts like Fran Cutler and Meg Matthews (who may be unofficially paid to host a night so they can invite their famous and fashionable friends down), artist liaison officers from record labels (so they'll bring their pop star charges in) and successful party promoters (who will be asked to run club nights on Sundays, Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, when customers are scarce).

The launch party will be handled by a PR firm chosen on the strength of its contacts with cool celebrities, socialites, the influential and the rich. The "influential" set is made up of editors, PRs, photographers, fashion editors, promoters, artists and models. The rich - some of whom may be influential too - are fashionable ad agency account managers, film industry executives, financiers, property developers, property agents and the investors. Generally these are the rich who like to think themselves fashionable, the kind who hang out with the demi-monde, and who will flex their platinum credit cards for the privilege. Ironically, the demi-monde will be there chiefly for the free booze and food. The hope is that this lot will stick around, which they will - for about six weeks or until the next bar opens. The posing rump will defect first, complaining that their previous favourite is now "full of suits".

After about six or eight weeks a few aspirational gangsters and barrow boys will have drifted in by word of mouth, adding what is euphemistically referred to as "a bit of colour". The atmosphere will now be at its best, and the challenge is to preserve it; the period between two and three months after opening is crucial, because the bar has been open long enough to get in newspapers and magazines, and for the figureheads to have been heard talking about it. The door manager will now pick selectively from the people who have heard about it through the media, and have come to have a look; their choices will make or break the bar. Who will they pick from? This third-wave will typically include: hyper-trendy Japanese students; City boys trying to impress their dates; middle managers who have heard about it from their boss and have come down to try to impress a potential new one; young women who work in the arts and media, have seen it mentioned in Vogue and have come to look for Robbie Williams. The key is to choose a mix of people who won't bother the celebs and the influentials with star-spotting, and who won't make a fuss if they discover their manager doing cocaine in the toilets.

If the door staff get the mix wrong, the remaining original crowd will move on and the bar owner is in difficulty. He or she has invested heavily in the decor and staff and needs to keep the place full. Do they keep their nerve and keep exclusive? Or do you try to keep your bank manager and investors happy, and let the ordinary punters in? If they choose the latter, the next wave will be what one Soho bar manager refers to as the "Cecil Gee Posses" - after-work groups of young male office workers in cheap suits. They have an equivalent in the gangs of after-work office girls who will come down too, but the boys are a bigger problem. As individuals they're OK; but the work suits make them feel like brothers in uniform; the strong lager makes them leery; the knowledge that they are in a trendy bar makes them show off. But the real reason they tend to be unwelcome is that they start hassling women. If the women go and don't come back, the atmosphere dies. Young men do not like drinking with each other, and women feel uncomfortable in an overly-masculine environment; this is why the history of club culture is often shaped by promoters attempting to attract cool young women to their nights. The Cecil Gee Posses will start to scare off Third Wavers, though new out-of-towners will keep coming for a look at weekends for a while until the bar's reputation fades.

The owner can now a) accept the downward trajectory or b) try to make the best of it by going low-cool and bringing in the kind of celebrities they were striving to avoid 12 months ago; the EastEnders cast (notoriously easy to get to parties), teen-pop acts, and maybe a DJ who had a good reputation a few years ago to do a Thursday night. The DJ will welcome the chance to "try something a little different", which generally means playing his old jazz funk records. If that doesn't work, the best bet is to play up the commercial, clubbing element and get more ropey DJs; this will at least bring in the 18 to 25 year olds who inhabit puffa jackets and commercial house clubs and care more about music and drugs than ambience. When they leave - well, that's when it becomes simple. You just close down, re-open under a new name, and start again. Learning from your "mistakes", of course.

fields.headline: Super salaries for super heads?
fields.standfirst: As the National Association of Head Teachers' conference draws to a close, education editor Will Woodward asks if calls for heads of failing schools to be paid £100,000 are realistic
fields.trailText: As the National Association of Head Teachers' conference draws to a close, education editor Will Woodward asks if calls for heads of failing schools to be paid £100,000 are realistic
fields.body:
After spending a week among the tax exiles of Jersey, headteachers at their annual conference, can be forgiven for feeling a little short of the readies.

Outside the conference hall, delegates to the National Association of Head Teachers' conference may have passed an estate agent's window on this VAT-free channel isle, where nothing was going for under £300,000. Enough, as one wit put it, to buy a one-bedroom flat in Camden.

Maybe this was why David Hart, the general secretary of the NAHT, called for heads of failing schools to be awarded £100,000 salaries with all the trimmings: private health care, cars, even time off for expenses-paid MBA courses.

His demand will make some blanch - that's almost what the salary cabinet ministers get - but he insisted it was backed up by business analysts. Why not give even heads in regular, large secondary schools £80,000? Comparable people in business, managing budgets of up to £2.5m and with that number of staff, would be on about that whack, he said.

It was an ambitious claim at the end of a good-natured conference. But then the heads and the government (gripes about Ofsted aside) tend to see eye to eye these days. The education secretary, David Blunkett, came to Jersey yesterday and promised almost everything the heads wanted: more control over budgets; fewer directions from central government; a national funding formula so that similar schools will get similar cash; even help on pupil exclusions.

The NAHT is reluctant to wind the government up too much, and in turn, the union gets a good hearing. Mr Blunkett has already promised salaries of £100,000 for so-called "super heads" - those headteachers to be put in overall charge of more than one (and up to five) failing schools in an area.

There will be billions more for education when the chancellor has finished his spending review. So maybe the first one school, one hundred grand headteacher isn't that far away.

webTitle: Winning on losing streak with Holyrood outburst

fields.headline: Winning on losing streak with Holyrood outburst
fields.standfirst: Cardinal brands Scots parliament a failure
fields.trailText: 2 June, 3.30pm opinion: The leader of Scotland's Catholics has attacked the devolved parliament and its "liberal agenda".But religious affairs correspondent Stephen Bates says his latest attack will prove counter-productive.
fields.body:
Oh dear. The leader of Scotland's Roman Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, is at it again. In a Scottish Catholic newspaper and on television (though not, to the apparent outrage of one of its presenters, on the Today programme) he has been inveighing against the Scottish parliament.

It's too liberal, he says. An "utter failure". Its MSPs have let him down and make him feel ashamed because they haven't backed his line on section 28.

The cardinal's clearly entitled to his views and to express them on the occasion of his 75th birthday. If you can't speak robustly then, when can you? And many people in Scotland share his views, as the multi-millionaire bus conductor Brian Souter's self-financed poll earlier this week indicated.

Winning is entitled also to shout them from the pulpit and to instruct his flock about his position. He should stand up for what he believes in over section 28. He may even be right.

The cardinal stands shoulder-to-shoulder with Scottish Presbyterians for what is probably the first time ever. Even the "Wee-Frees", the most extreme of the Presbyters, who won't attend the funerals of friends if they take place in Catholic churches and who see Papist plots behind everything short of the weather forecast, can probably scarce forbear to cheer. It's a notable triumph for ecumenism.

But what the cardinal is not entitled to do is expect that the Scottish parliament should bow before him. It might even be considered a healthy sign for democracy if it doesn't and, to be fair, the cardinal has not demanded that it should surrender.

Even in Ireland the days of priestly rule are past, drowned in a sea of secular disgust at revelations of the church's temporal shortcomings and hypocrisy.

The church knows that the faithful hear its word in western societies - for instance on birth control - and then make up their own minds. It is a dilemma particularly puzzling to the Catholic church: do you stand like a rock on your teaching or do you subtly modify it to take account of current secular practice? The answer has to be that you stand by your teaching - otherwise you are lost - but with understanding of your flock's difficulties.

There also appears to be a hole in the middle of Cardinal Winning's argument. He does not say what he thinks the parliament should do. Should its MSPs fall on their swords? Or should they just become more illiberal? One thing is certain. His outburst makes it less rather than more likely that he will get his way.

fields.headline: Summer festivals threatened by bug
fields.standfirst: Glastonbury festival
fields.trailText: European scientists are threatening the traditional British summer by pulling the plug on open air rock festivals, fairs and car boot sales on much of the country's farmland.
fields.body:
European scientists are threatening the traditional British summer by pulling the plug on open air rock festivals, fairs and car boot sales on much of the country's farmland.

The scientists say muddy and cowpat laden fields, on which thousands of events take place across Europe every year, pose a particular danger to young children and old people. Organisers should not use land recently used by livestock and should instead use more hygienic spots with plenty of clean running water and soap.

Festival promoters must already meet health and safety conditions laid down by local councils but the scientists are worried about the potential for E coli to spread because people do not wash their hands properly after coming into contact with soil or paths contaminated with animal dung, sometimes weeks before.

Nine people among 100,000 at the 1997 Glastonbury festival, in Somerset, were infected when the dairy farm hosting the event became a quagmire after heavy rain.

Although deaths are still relatively rare, the bug is almost impossible to eradicate from healthy animals. Symptoms in humans range from mild diarrhoea to huge changes in body fluids, leading to brain damage or kidney failure.

About 1,100 cases of E coli 0157, the most virulent strain, were reported in the UK last year. Victims are admitted to hospital in a third of cases and the death rate between 1992 and 1996 was 3.7%. Between 1994 and 1999, eight outbreaks were linked to farm visits.

The scientists recommend protective clothing for millions of schoolchildren and families going to farms on education or tourist visits, an end to picnics near farm animals, and compulsory food hygiene lessons in EU primary schools.

The measures, being considered by the European commission and EU member states, are contained in a report from the commission's scientific committee on veterinary measures relating to public health. They represent the opening of an EU-wide debate over food hygiene that will lead to a directive from Brussels.

Mac Johnston, of the Royal Veterinary College, in London, one of two British members on the committee, insisted: "We are not politicians. We are saying: 'Here are the risks, you decide what to put in the directive. You decide whether it is politically appropriate to ban pop concerts'."

There was evidence that the E coli bug could remain active in cow dung for 30 days, and longer in soil. Land used by other animals such as goats, sheep and pigs could also be risky for children under five, older people and those with weakened immune systems, the scientists say.

"If you are standing in a field, where are you going to wash your hands?" said Prof Johnston. "If you go to Glastonbury and it is as muddy as hell, the stuff gets everywhere. How many sinks do you need for washing 20,000 people? Washing hands with soap and water is a very good control measure."

Organisers of next month's Glastonbury festival, jointly sponsored by the Guardian, said they had met conditions set by Mendip council, including removing cattle from fields two weeks before the event. "We have had 100,000 people every year for year after year and have not had a serious problem," said a spokesman.

The source of the outbreak of 1997 had not been traced, he said, despite an investigation into whether it had been caused by food brought in by festival goers or bought from a particular stall.

A six-year-old boy, Tim Dowling, is likely to be awarded huge damages after being left with brain damage after contracting E coli on a farm visit two years ago. The health and safety executive (HSE) revealed that it has rejected the idea of plastic gloves and aprons for pupils on farm visits as impractical.

A six-year-old boy, Tim Dowling, is likely to be awarded huge damages after being left with brain damage after contracting E coli on a farm visit two years ago. The health and safety executive (HSE) revealed that it has rejected the idea of plastic gloves and aprons for pupils on farm visits as impractical.

webTitle: Would you die for your country?

fields.headline: Would you die for your country?
fields.standfirst: All that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, repeats British Legion member Neil Griffiths. But it is not Neil's readiness to die, but his willingness to kill other people that bothers philosopher Soran Reader. He argues that since they are prepared to kill in ignorance and on command, it its time to "confiscate the soldiers' toys". Have your say here.
fields.trailText: Dear Soran,
fields.body:
Dear Soran,

I'm too young, at 43, to have fought in the second world war. But I did serve several months in Northern Ireland in the 1970s as an ordinary infantryman. And I've never had any doubts about the cause, or the personal risks involved. We backed up the RUC, and we knew the consequences: the reality of becoming a casualty oneself was incontrovertible. The rather grand concept of dying for one's country was not debated, but it was implicit, and I knew - in common with the 66% of British people who said, in the BBC's Soul of Britain survey reported this week, that they would do the same - that I was doing the right thing in fighting for my country. Admittedly, the Northern Ireland campaign didn't include the threat of fascist invasion and the sweeping away of all our liberties. That was exactly what our forebears faced in 1940, and it was not just understandable but imperative that men and women were ready to lay down their lives to defend the country. If ever there was a war fought for moral reasons, it was the second world war.

The argument that all war could be avoided if only politicians behaved themselves, and soldiers refused to fight, ignores reality. Duplicity, misjudgment and ambition are unavoidable in politics, so politicians will always create the need for war; soldiers will always know whether a cause is true. If an armed psychopath attacked all your neighbours, you would know that at some stage you would be called on to defend yourself. Conscientious objection has nothing to do with it. I was, and still would be, ready to die for a country I love and believe in.

Yours sincerely,
Neil Griffiths
Royal British Legion (Scotland)

Dear Neil,

I have no problem with your readiness to die for your country - it's your readiness to kill other people that bothers me. Killing is a very grave act, justifiable only when the victim has done or threatens something very grave. How can you claim to respect the moral importance of human life, yet be willing to serve as a soldier, ready to kill any foreigner on command?

Your position relies on unrealistic assumptions about soldiers. First, you assume it is morally acceptable to kill them. But many soldiers don't understand their state's plans, and take up arms for economic and other reasons. So when you risk killing them, you're doing something wicked. Second, you assume that soldiers are good. But soldiers must be willing to use extreme violence, and must obey orders unquestioningly. Both characteristics are bad and dangerous.

Millions must struggle to clean up the bloody mess soldiers make - they need help. I suggest it's time to confiscate the soldiers' toys, curtail their fantasies of protection through domination, and put them to work which will benefit the country they claim to love. You believe that producing and bearing weapons helps to make the world safer. But violence is ill-suited to producing lasting peace. You talk - most war-ists do - about the second world war. Why not the first? Our country won - isn't this proof that "war works"? You know it isn't. Nazism was nurtured - made possible, even - by anti-German attitudes in the victorious "peace". The conclusion is clear: war makes things worse, not better. Bearing arms is a mug's game.

Yours sincerely,
Soran Reader
Department of Philosophy, University of Durham

Dear Soran,

You're right that killing is a very grave act, and that it is justifiable when the victim has committed, or is about to commit, a very great evil. That is the basis for my position, with which you appear to agree. It is a sad fact that soldiers die serving their country. But being ready to kill any foreigner, on command? Really? How would you motivate troops to do that? Soldiers need motivation. You say many soldiers don't understand their state's plans. In my experience, soldiers know exactly why they are on active service. Northern Ireland is a good example. I do not think killing enemy soldiers or terrorists, is wicked. You say yourself that you believe there are times when the act is justifable, and so do I. It is also true that soldiers must obey orders unthinkingly (including "Stop firing!"). But the assumption that war is a bloody mess made by soldiers overlooks the fact that troops would, by and large, prefer to stay at home. Wars are declared by politicians.

This is how the first world war came about, and the continent then spent the 20s and the 30s rushing towards the inevitable, thanks to the aggression and misjudgments of politicians. Sitting back and letting aggressors march all over you is the real mug's game. Letting others defend you is the prerogative only of the weak.

Yours sincerely,
Neil

Dear Neil,

We agree about how killing can be justified, then. But do you see what follows: that when a soldier kills in ignorance, on command, what he does is unjustified? It can only be morally acceptable to kill someone you know to be guilty. Terrorists come into this category; impoverished soldiers in corrupt enemy countries do not.

Are soldiers even responsible for their actions, in your view? Sometimes you say they are responsible, motivated and knowing; but sometimes you imply that they fight only against their will, forced into it by evil politicians. You can't have it both ways. You think pacifism is "weak" - but it is far from weak. Pacifists forgo the war-ists' option of killing off their opponents. This gives them a compelling motivation to see to it that negotiation is maintained. Luckily, - because pacifists also forgo the dubious war-ists' pleasures of creating ever more ingenious ways to kill - they also have more time, money and goodwill to invest in serving their country in this far more arduous and challenging way. There is no weakness in pacifism; just a clear-eyed recognition of the great limits on what violence can achieve.

Yours sincerely,
Soran

Dear Soran,

Ah - we have further areas of agreement. Soldiers cannot and should not kill in ignorance. This is why they need to understand why they are fighting. I agree that untrained, ill-educated troops can be persuaded to create mayhem anywhere. But everyone, especially soldiers, understands that terrorists who bomb supermarkets or target innocent civilians of a different religion are utterly wrong, especially in a democracy. I didn't mean to say that soldiers are forced into war by "evil" politicians - only that it is rulers who create wars. Soldiers have not, in our recent history, fought against their will but instead to protect and to defend.

In your references to "war-ist pleasures" and "soldiers' toys", you've twice walked into the biggest misconception around: that soldiers take pleasure in battle. They are generally frightened out of their wits. They know there is no pleasure to be had. We all have a duty to protect our own, and it is the charge that pacifism is blind to this that highlights its greatest weakness - although I agree the stance can often require great bravery. Violence does indeed have limits, but so does peaceful negotiating (Saddam, Galtieri). But just as we need a police force because the world is far from perfect, so too we will require an army with men ready to die for their country. There will always be aggressors, and we cannot allow them to trample our freedoms. All that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing.

Yours sincerely,
Neil

Dear Neil,

No single group creates wars. Everyone bears some responsibility, and faces a choice: continue to play your part, or try to change things. Pacifists try to change things. When I said soldiers kill in ignorance I meant that, in battle, individual soldiers never know enough about the individuals they kill, to justify their killing. Yet those enemy individuals are all people, with a moral right to the same justice as citizens.

You liken the army to a police force. As a pacifist, I support the introduction of a system of international law equipped to bring wrongdoers to justice wherever they are found. But armies of soldiers or, worse, citizens eager to "fight for their country", cannot possibly play this role. Police act within the law. You insist that soldiers are reluctant fighters. But you must know that many of our soldiers fight (and train others) for non-British causes. Pacifists don't think we should "do nothing" about tyranny. We must take stronger police-style action far earlier because we cannot act violently against a state. It is the war-ist whose arsenal encourages him to be intolerant and complacent. Why bother to negotiate? You can always use violence to drive them away. But we know people will suffer and die in this process, and more problems result. Play with dangerous toys, and people will get hurt. Bearing arms does not show strength - just incompetence and fear.

Yours sincerely,
Soran
