webTitle: Glos hit poverty - and drunks - for six

fields.headline: Glos hit poverty - and drunks - for six
fields.standfirst: Why Nevil Road is bracing itself for a student invasion, the Test stars who are ready to party during the Lord's Test and how Sky Sports drew the short straw this summer
fields.trailText: Fear of drunkenness takes the Glos off Oxfam's big game
fields.body:
Fear of drunkenness takes the Glos off Oxfam's big game

FEARS of crowd trouble at a high-profile university match at the county ground in Bristol this weekend have forced a last-minute rethink and put Gloucestershire at odds with Oxfam. Gloucestershire, unhappy that the clash between Bristol's two universities was being marketed as "the outdoor summer party to end them all", even hinted that Sunday's fixture might not go ahead unless the organisers, Oxfam, took extra steps to ensure that student spectators behaved themselves. The club feared a repeat of drunken scenes witnessed at a recent student match at Trent Bridge.

The match at Nevil Road, between Bristol University and the University of the West of England (UWE), is the first in a new series of university derbies being staged this month up and down the country to raise money for rehabilitation work following the floods in Mozambique. The six Oxfam Varsity Cricket Matches - slogan: "hitting poverty for six" - have official backing from the unlikely trio of MCC, the Professional Cricketers' Association and the Barmy Army.

As the charity's web pages confirm, the games were promoted, until Gloucestershire's intervention, as offering "outdoor discos, swimming pools, BBQs, fancy dress and a bit of cricket in the middle of it all". Oxfam has agreed to drop the words "party" and "frisbee" from promotional material for an occasion now billed, more soberly, as "the ultimate summer social". It has also reluctantly accepted that music cannot even be played to introduce batsmen during the 40-over contest, which starts at 2pm (admission £3 - inquiries call 0117 970 6703).

Mark Kirton, Gloucestershire's marketing manager, says: "There was a bit too much emphasis on the party and drinking element, and not enough on the cricket - which should be at the centre." He's now confident that the club's standard limit on the quantity of alcohol which each spectator can bring in - a bottle of wine or two pints of beer - will be observed, even by 1000-2000 students in post-exam mode. "If there is any trouble," he adds, "it'll be sorted quickly by our stewards."

Oxfam's co-ordinator Billy Cotton, pointing to the good record of crowds at Oxfam's varsity rugby matches, says: "We're not stupid, and we're not naive. We've emphasised that stewarding should be effective rather than aggressive. If things get hairy, the bars will be closed." He adds: "We'd have liked a little more rock'n'roll cricket. But people will still come in fancy dress, whatever the club says about that. It's a free country. There may be a few streakers at the end of the day, as at our rugby matches. But that's harmless fun."

And after Wasim it will be - who?

Who will replace Wasim Akram in the Channel 4 commentary box if, as expected, he's fired as a result of the Qayyum report's damning verdict on his alleged involvement in match-fixing?

The field is thin. Most of the obvious names are already contracted elsewhere. Geoffrey Boycott, Christopher Cowdrey and Shane Warne are with TalkSport and Viv Richards has agreed to do at least the first two West Indies Tests as a summariser on the BBC's Test Match Special. Sir Viv was considered by C4 for a commentary contract this season, but it was felt he was too expensive.

Furthermore, Viv didn't enjoy commentating for BBC television during the last World Cup. He found the earpiece he was supposed to wear as unwelcome as a batting helmet. In any case, his genial presence and discursive style are better suited to radio.

One former Test player definitely still available is Colin Croft, who's having discussions with TMS but could help fill the C4 vacancy during some of the Windies Tests. But he too is more at home on radio.

The unofficial word from C4 is that while Richards or maybe Graham Gooch - during the three Tests he's not with TMS - may be invited to join the odd studio discussion, Wasim is unlikely to be replaced as a commentator. "He wasn't all that good last season anyway, though he brought cachet," says a source. "We need a star. But we trawled the world last winter and came up with very few good names. We don't want just anyone. If Wasim is replaced, the favourite has to be Barry Richards."

Ramps throws a mid-Test party

These days Test players rarely party until the final ball has been bowled. But England and West Indies are making an exception during the second Test at Lord's. Most members of both sides have agreed to attend a Caribbean Calypso Ball in aid of Mark Ramprakash's benefit fund.

The event takes place at the Landmark Hotel, near Lord's, on the third evening of the match, Saturday July 1 (for tickets call 020 7938 6182; for information on other benefit events, click here).

It's not a do for the less well-off cricket lover: tickets cost £99 each. For that, you get a rum punch reception, a four-course dinner including wine, and entertainment from a steel band, limbo dancers and Sol Raye, a Nat King Cole tribute singer. Ramprakash's county team-mates Justin Langer and Angus Fraser are coming up from Chelmsford, where Middlesex are playing that weekend (Ramprakash will be making the journey, too, if he has lost his Test place). There may also be a rare chance to see Ian Botham and Mike Gatting throwing their weight around the dance floor.

But don't expect a glimpse of Ramps, Curtly, Courtney or Jimmy strutting their stuff. Ramprakash's benefit secretary, Julia Pearce, says: "The Test players won't be dancing the night away until 2am. But - as Mark says - you've got to have dinner somewhere during a Test. So they'll do the reception and dinner and go home at 10 o'clock."

Sky draw the short straw

It may turn out quite differently, but on paper the current Test against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge is the least attractive of this season's seven Tests. It's also the only one being screened live by BSkyB rather than Channel 4. This isn't a coincidence.

Under the ECB's complex £103m four-year contracts with the two broadcasters, C4 automatically has exclusive live rights to all five matches in the summer's main Test series, plus one of the two games in the mini-series preceding it.

An almost unknown clause specifies that C4 is entitled to choose which of these matches it wants. This time they made the obvious choice, plumping for the Zims' Test debut in this country, at Lord's, leaving their rivals with the Nottingham game - as well as the triangular one-day series, which is the non-negotiable centrepiece of Sky's live output.

Last season, C4 - perhaps anxious to finetune their operation - let Sky have the first of the four New Zealand Tests, and missed a trick: Sky made a flying start to the new era of cricket coverage, bringing viewers that extraordinary game at Edgbaston in which England recovered from 45-7 to win by seven wickets inside three days (nightwatchman Alex Tudor 99 not out). It was the last thing England fans had to cheer all season. We'll know soon enough whether C4 made the right call this time.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Elvis Presley
fields.standfirst: The king of rock and roll is alive and well - on the net.
fields.trailText: The king of rock and roll is alive and well - on the net.
fields.body:
1. Everyone knows that Elvis Presley lived at Graceland, Memphis, Tennessee - but only now do we know that his roots were really in the valleys of South Wales.

2. Or so says lecturer Terry Breverton of Cardiff University, in a new book.

3. He thinks that Elvis's family name is really Presili and says that in the Welsh hills of the same name there is a chapel dedicated to St Elvis, the only one in Britain. St Elvis was the monk who baptised St David, the patron saint of Wales.

fields.headline: Another bomb scare in London
fields.trailText: A bomb scare paralysed the City of London this lunchtime, as police closed off London bridge, Bank tube station and streets around the Bishopsgate area.
fields.body:
A bomb scare paralysed the City of London this lunchtime, as police closed off London bridge, Bank tube station and streets around the Bishopsgate area.

One officer confirmed they were not looking for a car bomb, but were checking buildings in the heart of London's financial centre for a smaller device. Some offices were being evacuated as many lunching workers were prevented from returning to their buildings.

The scare follows the explosion of a bomb under Hammersmith bridge in west London early yesterday morning.

More than 24 hours after the explosion, no group has admitted planting the bomb, amid speculation that it was the work of dissident Irish republicans.

Deputy assistant commissioner Alan Fry, the head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, urged people to be vigilant in the wake of the attack. "I am asking people that if they see a suspect package to contact us immediately on 999."

He added there would be more high visibility policing on London's streets in the wake of the bomb and said measures would be taken to reassure the public.

webTitle: The England team: you have your say

fields.headline: The England team: you have your say
fields.trailText: Seaman or Martyn? Ince or Gerrard? Phillip Neville or Gareth Barry? Just who should Kevin Keegan pick for England's first match in Euro 2000? And which formation should he play?
fields.body:
Seaman or Martyn? Ince or Gerrard? Phillip Neville or Gareth Barry? Just who should Kevin Keegan pick for England's first match in Euro 2000? And which formation should he play?

They're the questions being debated in offices and pubs throughout the land. Yesterday the Football Unlimited staff had their say. Now it's your turn. We've received hundreds of emails, most of which have been accompanied by detailed pen-portraits and explanations like: "Scholes - equals goals" (Stuart Daniel); "Nigel Martyn - best English keeper aroundgreat reflex" (Harvey Hui); "Adams - "experience make him captain" (Jack Saunders).

What follows is a brief taking of the pulse of the nation - we'll announce the full results next week.

1) Which formation England should play?

At the moment a majority of Football Unlimited readers still prefer 4-4-2, but England's performance on Wednesday night has convinced many that 3-5-2 is the way forward.

"Definitely a 3-5-2 rather than 4-4-2 as that hides our lack of left-footed players and makes us more solid and creative," claims Matthew Poulton. "Also, it means that there is no place for the Neville brothers."

But Mark Abbot disagrees. "4-4-2 maybe perceived as quaint in some quarters, but to play 3-5-2 effectively you need two intelligent, pacy, real quality, box-to-box merchants that can both defend and attack - otherwise don't do it."

Of course many of you have completely different ideas. Some suggest an attacking 4-3-3 or an exotic 3-4-1-2, others an El Tel-inspired Christmas-tree formation, while James Leith reckons: "Forget 4-4-2 or 3-5-2, let's enjoy ourselves with a fluid 4-3-1-2."

2) Should Keegan pick Seaman or Martyn?

A clear majority favour the Leeds man. "Martyn - far more reliable, fitter, flexible and no silly tache," opines Gareth Jones. And Richard Calland agrees: "Seaman looks increasingly slow, Martyn, looks, in comparison, as sharp as mustard."

However there is still some support for the Arsenal keeper, with many claiming that his previous tournament experience, along with his understanding with Adams and Keown, just puts him in front.

3) Who should play in defence?

Whether they prefer 4-4-2 or 3-5-2, most people have Adams and Campbell as shoe-ins. After that it's the proverbial lottery. Dominic Jones speaks for many when he says: "Don't let the incompetent Nevilles near the team." And Stephen Fuller isn't the only one to argue that, "Barry will be able to move down the left without instinctively cutting back on to his right foot like Neville does all too often." But both Nevilles, Keown and even Southgate all have their share of supporters - and a surprising number pick Campbell as a right or left back.

4) Would you play Gerrard in midfield?

Since the Ukraine game there's been a huge upsurge in support for Stephen Gerrard. The only difficulty for many is where to play him. Richard Calland sees "Gerrard sweeping in the front of the back four like a sort of dynamic new Batty", while Californian resident Jeff Forward insists "Gerrard's speed is the only viable option on the left wing".

Of course many of your wouldn't play him at all, and name Ince or Wise instead. In fact the only consensus is that Beckham should stay on the right. "As far as I'm concerned he is a one-trick pony," says Elshan Aliyev. "The man is the best crosser of the ball, no arguments. But I don't see him going past players."

5) Should it be Shearer and Owen up front?

Another huge area of contention is which forwards Keegan should play up front, with many of you thinking Shearer should be dropped. "Shock, horror, no Shearer!!! Too right, he is slow and boring and much too reliant on crosses and set pieces," says Dan Ballard - while Stuart Daniel believes that "even sacred cows have to go to the abattoir in the end."

There is no clear consensus, however, about who should replace him. Sam Hutchinson reckons Keegan is holding Phillips back as a secret weapon: "He's fast, he reminds Keegan of himself, he can score from anywhere, he is two-footed and he's intelligent - and most of all he has a passion to please."

But perhaps Robin Cannon is the voice of the silent majority. He says: "There really isn't much other choice but Shearer and Owen up front. Heskey shouldn't be near the squad. I don't think the Leicester fans called him 'Bruno' for his physique - more for his habit of collapsing in a heap if a defender so much as goes near him."

Keep sending your England teams in to the.boss@theguardian.com - we'll have the results early next week.

fields.headline: £15m Hasselbaink signs for Chelsea
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink made his return to the Premiership today when he completed a £15m move to Chelsea. The Dutch international striker has signed a five-year deal with the club.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink made his return to the Premiership today when he completed a £15m move to Chelsea. The Dutch international striker has signed a five-year deal with the club.

The transfer fee paid by Chelsea to Hasselbaink's previous club Atletico Madrid equals the British record fee for a transfer set by Newcastle when they signed Alan Shearer in 1996.

An obviously happy Hasselbaink, who scored 24 goals during his one season in Spain, said today: "It's a very big move and I feel happy with it. When I heard Chelsea were interested I was very pleased and hoped the deal would go through.

"I enjoyed my time in English football and I am happy to be back at a great club like Chelsea, who are very ambitious. I hope to get as high as possible, that's my aim next season. I hope I can make Chelsea stronger and I'm going to give 100%."

The arrival of Hasselbaink at Chelsea is likely to hasten the departure of Chris Sutton from the club. The former Blackburn player was a £10m recruit only last summer, but has failed to make an impression at Stamford Bridge.

fields.headline: Rain keeps Atherton waiting
fields.trailText: Rain has delayed the start of the second day's play in the Second Test at Trent Bridge. Light drizzle hung in the air until 12.30pm, but hopes of a resumption at the end of the scheduled lunch interval were dashed when rain again started to fall as the ground staff removed the covers. Play will not now begin until mid-afternoon at the earliest.

fields.headline: Speight stakes his claim
fields.standfirst: Fji special report
fields.trailText: Fijian coup leader George Speight is tightening the screw on his hapless captives by claiming the prime ministership in return for their freedom.
fields.body:
Fijian coup leader George Speight is tightening the screw on his hapless captives by claiming the prime ministership in return for their freedom.

Speight told an Australian radio reporter this morning that he had made detailed proposals for ending the crisis to the country's military authorities, and to the highly influential Great Council of Chiefs.

He stonewalled questions about his nomination for the prime ministership, but when asked directly whether he wanted the job, he giggled and said "yes".

Speight, whose interview technique features charm laden with menace, is now saying that he hopes his 35 hostages - including elected prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry - will be free by Monday. He told the BBC Today programme that the releases would probably come on Sunday "because it's church day; that's appropriate".

He went on, suavely but unmistakably, to lay bare his aim to exclude the country's ethnic Indian community - which comprises 44% of the population - from all power. "It doesn't matter whether we are a majority in our own country. Whether we are 5% or 100%, our rights are uncontestable and cannot be overridden by any other rights," he said.

Speight has steadily cranked up his demands in the 10 days since he seized control of the parliament building compound in the Fijian capital, Suva. First, he forced the president to summon the Great Council of Chiefs to discuss his demands for a new constitution. Then, after the military assumed control of the country, he extracted promises of a new constitution, a new prime minister, and an amnesty for himself and his backers.

Now, with the armed forces apparently unable or unwilling to confront him and his ragtag force of rebels, he is demanding a monopoly of power for the 51% majority community of ethnic Fijians - with himself as their leader.

fields.headline: Dissident republicans
fields.standfirst: The bombing of Hammersmith bridge has raised fears that hardline Irish nationalists opposed to the peace process may embark on a fresh terror campaign. We find out who they are and what they may do next
fields.trailText:
Who are they?
Dissident republicans have become increasingly disillusioned with the IRA's ceasefire and the participation of its political wing, Sinn Fein, in the Good Friday agreement and Northern Ireland's devolved assembly. Many are former IRA members intent on bringing about a united Ireland through a continued campaign of violence.
fields.body:
Who are they?
Dissident republicans have become increasingly disillusioned with the IRA's ceasefire and the participation of its political wing, Sinn Fein, in the Good Friday agreement and Northern Ireland's devolved assembly. Many are former IRA members intent on bringing about a united Ireland through a continued campaign of violence.

Why are they in the news?
There is speculation that the bomb which went off on Hammersmith bridge in west London yesterday was the work of hardline republicans, upset by Sinn Fein's participation in the Northern Ireland assembly and anxious to destabilise the fragile peace process.

Who are the main dissident groups?
There are three main dissident republican groups, although security forces in Ireland believe that there is little to distinguish between their more extreme members, who are active across all the groups.

 The Irish National Liberation Army (INLA) was formed by IRA members disillusioned by the 1975 ceasefire. It first gained notoriety four years later when it planted the bomb that killed Conservative MP and Northern Ireland spokesman Airey Neave in the House of Commons car park. It is believed to have killed more than 140 people before it declared a ceasefire in 1998. Last August it became the first hardline republican group to declare the war was over, but dissident INLA members are still thought to be active in other republican terror groups.

 The Real IRA was founded after the IRA's quartermaster left the group with a dozen others in the autumn of 1997, in protest at Sinn Fein's entry into dialogue with the British and Irish governments. It has developed into one of the most active factions opposed to the Good Friday settlement, with around 120 members, although not all are active terrorists. The Real IRA was responsible for the Omagh bombing on August 15 1998, the worst atrocity of the Troubles, in which 29 people died. The group called a ceasefire less than a month later, but is widely believed not to have kept it. Last week, the former IRA quartermaster was arrested and questioned by Irish police along with 14 other men suspected of Real IRA involvement. All were subsequently released

 The Continuity IRA dates from a split in Sinn Fein in 1986, when Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness dropped the party's policy of boycotting the Irish parliament. It is said to be associated with Republican Sinn Fein (RSF), a dissident group headed by former IRA chief of staff, Ruairi O Bradaigh, although the RSF deny this. The Continuity IRA is opposed to any deal not based on a united Ireland. Its name has been used to claim responsibility for terrorist attacks this year that were actually the work of the Real IRA, which, says the Guardian's John Mullin, infuriated the "grey-haired ideologues" who are seen to make up the group. The republican outfit has never killed anyone in Ireland, but is the only one not to declare a ceasefire.

Are the dissidents stepping up their terrorist activities?
Since February, there has been an attack or incident engineered by dissident republicans every 12 days - a higher frequency of attacks than the IRA organised in the 1990s before its ceasefire. The Real IRA has targeted army barracks. It planted a bomb, which failed to explode, at Shackleton barracks, Londonderry, on February 25; attempted to fire a rocket at Killymean army barracks in Co Tyrone two days later; tried to plant a bomb at another barracks in Belfast in March; and detonated a small bomb at Ebrington barracks in Londonderry on April 6. The Continuity IRA is believed to have carried out a bomb attack which damaged a hotel in Fermanagh in February.

Are they growing in numbers?
Sinn Fein's increasingly positive role in the peace process was always a high-risk strategy for its leader, Gerry Adams, and it is alienating more extreme republicans. A recent BBC Northern Ireland poll underlined the splits within republicanism. It found that 22.5% of Sinn Fein voters believed that allowing the inspection of their arms dumps was tantamount to surrender. Security forces as have detected more extreme IRA members defecting to the dissident groups after the latest peace initiative. The Irish police believe the Real IRA has recently recruited several former IRA members with considerable bomb-making experience.

Could they launch a major terror campaign?
Little is known about the dissident groups' capabilities and resources. The Garda (the Irish police) believe the Real IRA recently acquired a large consignment of rockets and commercial explosives from a source in Croatia. The RUC and the Garda say the group also possesses a small number of rifles, handguns, machine guns, unknown quantities of semtex, detonators, homemade mortars and grenade launchers. The Continuity IRA is believed to have small quantities of rifles, pistols, semtex, detonators and has a huge M79 grenade launcher.

The bomb on Hammersmith bridge has been interpreted by many as a warning shot. Even though dissident groups may not boast enough resources to mount a concerted campaign to match the IRA's bombing of London in 1996, just one bomb could have devastating consequences.

The RUC and the Garda say the group also possesses a small number of rifles, handguns, machine guns, unknown quantities of semtex, detonators, homemade mortars and grenade launchers. The Continuity IRA is believed to have small quantities of rifles, pistols, semtex, detonators and has a huge M79 grenade launcher. The bomb on Hammersmith bridge has been interpreted by many as a warning shot. Even though dissident groups may not boast enough resources to mount a concerted campaign to match the IRA's bombing of London in 1996, just one bomb could have devastating consequences.

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Sylvester Stallone plans to tread the boards, Matrix wins 'multicultural' award, Catherine Zeta Jones set for Elizabeth Taylor role, plus Kristin Scott Thomas, Jon Voight and Mira Sorvino on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Prepare for Hollywood's newest arrival on the London stage: Sylvester Stallone is practising his projection. According to an unnamed theatrical agent, quoted yesterday in the Daily Express, "we've been asked to find out if there are any suitable projects floating around for him. Apparently it's a credibility thing and he wants to do a British stage play. It's not the easiest of briefs, is it? There are a lot of preconceptions about him. But if he decides to do something, it'll certainly cause a big hoopla." King Lear, anyone?

 The Matrix has won an Ethnic Multicultural Media Award - even though star Keanu Reeves is white. Many were bewildered when the movie won Best Production - including Lock, Stock star Vaz Blackwood, who intoned, "Mmm, The Matrix. There were a lot of black people in that." But awards organiser Bobby Syed justified the gong, saying "Keanu Reeves is Hawaiian and Larry Fishburne is African-American. It is not a black awards, it's multicultural. That's being racist towards Keanu because he's not black." Hmm.

 Catherine Zeta Jones is the frontrunner to star as Elizabeth Taylor in the biopic of Montgomery Clift's life. American Beauty star Wes Bentley has already signed up for the role of Clift. If Zeta Jones gets the gig, filming will have to wait until after she has given birth to her first baby.

 Kristin Scott Thomas has optioned the rights to Scottish author AL Kennedy's acclaimed novel, Original Bliss. Scott Thomas is expected to star as Helen Brindle - the downtrodden Glaswegian housewife who enlists an expert in cybernetics who's addicted to violent pornography to help her avoid her abusive husband. If Scott Thomas takes on the unlikely role, filming will have to wait until after she has given birth to her baby.

 Jon Voight is to star as President Franklin Delano Roosevelt in Disney's megabudgeted second world war drama Pearl Harbor for film-makers Jerry Bruckheimer and Michael Bay. The film is already in production.

 Mira Sorvino is in negotiations to direct the upcoming indie pic Wisegirls, in which she's committed to star. The movie tells the story of three waitresses in a Mafia-owned restaurant.

fields.headline: By the book
fields.standfirst:
Shayler 'agent' taunts Home Office

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: A book written by David Shayler was handed to the Home Office yesterday to highlight the plight of the renegade MI5 officer living in Paris.
fields.body:
A book written by David Shayler was handed to the Home Office yesterday to highlight the plight of the renegade MI5 officer living in Paris.

The Organisation, a thinly-veiled attack on MI5, was described by his "agent", Chris Joseph, as a "gritty thriller about spies, sex and football". It has yet to be accepted by a publisher. Two copies of the book were delivered to the Home Office in Queen Anne's Gate, central London, by Mr Joseph. As a dancer performed the cancan on the Home Office steps and six "agents" in sunglasses played football, Mr Joseph handed the manuscripts to a treasury solicitor.

Mr Joseph said: "It is hypocritical and completely ludicrous for the government to even consider allowing Stella Rimington's factual memoirs when they have tried to ban David's fiction.

"There is obviously one law for the boss and another for the troops. For fiction to be subject to vetting at all obviously contravenes freedom of expression and human rights." Dame Stella Rimington, former head of MI5, has submitted a draft of her memoirs for vetting.

Her book has provoked a furious argument in Whitehall with her opponents arguing that it gives succour to Mr Shayler and Richard Tomlinson, the former MI6 officer who has also written a book for which he says he has a Russian publisher.

webTitle: Reborn assembly flags up fresh divisions

fields.headline: Reborn assembly flags up fresh divisions
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: 2 June, 12.30pm: The latest row between the Northern Ireland parties is over symbolism - which flag to fly over departmental buildings. But former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown argues that the dispute goes to the heart of the problems that have beset the province.
fields.body:
After patching over their differences on the huge issues of IRA disarmament and police reform, Ulster Unionist and Sinn Fein ministers in the Northern Ireland executive are now squabbling over which flags to fly over their departments.

Today is Coronation day, and naturally the Unionists want to see the Union flag hoisted. Equally naturally, Sinn Fein won't hear of it - unless the Irish tricolour flies alongside. That in turn is rejected by the Unionists.

Many onlookers in Britain will find all this despicably petty. But it would be hasty, and more than a little condescending, to dismiss the vital importance of national symbols in Ireland.

Nationality, after all, is what it is all about: 30 years of conflict and terror, and more than 3,250 lives lost, all boil down to which flag shall fly over the six counties.

It is a tribute to the new, albeit grudging, spirit of cooperation in Belfast, that neither faction is talking about the flag issue as a serious threat to the power-sharing executive, all of three days old in its latest incarnation. There are, alas, much darker clouds on the horizon.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is under fierce and increasing pressure over his police bill, designed to implement the radical reforms spelled out in the Patten report. The Unionists want to retain the name and insignia of the Royal Ulster Constabulary - symbolism again - while Sinn Fein and the more pragmatic Social Democratic and Labour party are determined to have a new force called the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

Republicans and nationalists suspect that Mandelson is prepared to water down the police reforms to keep the Unionists sweet. The Irish government shares that concern.

The first minister of the fragile executive, David Trimble, would dearly like to extract more concessions on the police issue, to suppress a rumbling rebellion in his own Unionist ranks. He must also be looking over his shoulder at Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party, which is spearheading the loyalist anti-power sharing movement.

Under the complex formula for distributing power around the parties in the Northern Ireland assembly, the DUP has been given two departments to run. Its ministers, Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds, have taken up their posts and the fat salaries which go with them, but say they do not accept the doctrine of collective responsibility.

They will not attend government meetings with Sinn Fein ministers. Even more provocatively, they say they will resign after a month or so, handing on their ministries to DUP colleagues who will then themselves resign.

It has now emerged that each time a Northern Ireland minister resigns, he or she is entitled automatically to three months' severance pay. The DUP says that this nice little earner will go into a campaign fund to bring down the whole power-sharing structure.

Trimble and his SDLP deputy, Seamus Mallon, have summoned the two DUP ministers to a meeting on Monday. Robinson says he won't go, because he will be too busy earning his other fat salary as an MP in Westminster.

The problem for the pro-agreement parties is that they cannot gang up on the DUP and kick it out of the devolved government without undermining the central tenet of power-sharing - and setting a dangerous precedent for future exclusions in more dubious causes.

webTitle: More gays disregard safe sex warnings

fields.headline: More gays disregard safe sex warnings
fields.trailText: The number of gay men having unprotected sex is on the increase for the first time, new research reveals.
fields.body:
The number of gay men having unprotected sex is on the increase for the first time, new research reveals.

If the trend continued, rates of HIV and Aids among the homosexual community might begin to rise after years of "safe sex" campaigns, the researchers warn.

More effective treatments for HIV and Aids may be encouraging gay men, particularly in younger age groups, to adopt "high risk" behaviour, according to an article in the British Medical Journal.

There is concern that gay men are becoming complacent about the threat of HIV 20 years after the epidemic began, and at a time when HIV infection among homosexuals has stabilised.

The report's co-author, Danielle Mercey, of University College London, suggested that "safe sex" campaigns needed to be more closely monitored to see if they were having an effect. "A lot of money is spent on Aids prevention but we don't know that all of the interventions are effective."

Dr Mercey suggested that "giving out condoms in a bar" and measuring the success of the initiative on the number of condoms given out was not rigorous enough.

To be effective strategies to reduce the spread of HIV had to look at the wider environment in which gay men lived.

"If they have grown up in a homophobic environment in which they have to be secretive about their sexuality it is harder for them to get advice about sexual health, and they will have grown up with lower self-esteem and that leads to more risk-taking behaviour."

Dr Mercey and her colleagues' study of 6,600 homosexual men found that in 1998, 38% admitted having unprotected anal intercourse in the past year, compared with 32% in 1996.

In 1998, 21% said they had indulged in sex with a man whose HIV status they did not know, compared with 18% three years earlier.

That admission will cause the greatest concern to those working in the front line of Aids prevention.

Young men under 25 were much more likely to have risked having unprotected sex, the survey found.

Most of the men lived in London and the findings were gathered from questionnaires distributed at bars, clubs, saunas and clinics.

In a BMJ editorial, Andrew Grulich, of the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology in Sydney, said: "Twenty years after the start of the HIV epidemic, a new generation is growing up with HIV. Within gay communities there is some evidence that optimism over HIV treatments is associated with a rise in risk behaviour."

He added: "In a situation where the immediate, overwhelming threat of death from Aids is no longer present, promoting condom use is likely to be much more difficult than in the 1980s."

He warned that if high-risk behaviour continued to rise there might be another increase in HIV infection rates.

Will Nutland, manager of the gay men's HIV prevention team at the Terrence Higgins Trust, drew attention to a survey of almost 10,000 men presented to a conference in March.

It showed 45% had unprotected anal sex in 1999 - an increase of 7% on the previous year.

The survey also showed there was an increase in the number of gay men having unprotected sex with partners whose HIV status they knew.

Mr Nutland said: "As far as we are concerned, the real story is that there has been a significant increase in the number of men having unprotected anal intercourse with a partner they knew had the same HIV status.

"But your HIV status is only as certain as the last person you had unprotected sex with, so that strategy is not foolproof."

fields.headline: Naked ambition
fields.standfirst: Britons in the buff, an ill wind, coal scorers and our feathered friends
fields.trailText: An extraordinary tale of courage and determination from Huddersfield this week, when 200 nudists stripped off their clothes and cavorted in the altogether, braving freezing winds and driving rain.
fields.body:
Nudes of the world

An extraordinary tale of courage and determination from Huddersfield this week, when 200 nudists stripped off their clothes and cavorted in the altogether, braving freezing winds and driving rain.

The nudists, from all over Britain, were attending the annual British Naturism jamboree, held this year at the Ashdene Naturist Club in Brighouse.

Although the elements forced some to keep their clothes on, many refused to be deterred by the appalling weather and spent two days naked as God intended, playing boules and mini-tennis in the garden, and attending various meetings and forums on nude issues. "I love being naked," said Bryan Jago, Ashdene's club secretary. "In France they have nudist banks and supermarkets. When your clothes are off there is no class status and people are much friendlier."

Pat Thompson, vice-president of British Naturism, agrees. "People assume that there are lots of naughty things going on, but that's just not the case."

Despite the Arctic conditions, the event was declared a resounding success. The only dissenters were a small number of non-nudist locals. "It's just not right," said one lady. "If God had meant us to be naked, why did he bring Laura Ashley into the world?"
Huddersfield Examiner

A bit of a blow


More evidence, if it were needed, that living in Wales can damage your health came with confirmation that Swansea has been hit by a tornado.

The freak storm, a phenomenon more normally associated with the American mid-west than the Welsh valleys, swept in from the sea, sucking up fishing nets and polythene sheeting and leaving more than 500 homes in Swansea and Gower witthout electricity.

"We were out for a family drive and saw it over the bay," said witness John Davies. "It was a tremendous sight: a huge loud funnel of rotating cloud."

The tornado was estimated to have been more than 400m tall and 200m wide and left a trail of havoc in its wake, although fortunately there were no injuries.

It eventually swung back out into the bay and was last seen heading up the Bristol Channel and out into the Irish Sea. We were working in the garden and it came straight at us," said another witness. "My wife screamed, 'Oh my God, we're going into the suck zone!' I thought, 'Promises, promises...'"
This is South Wales

Fuels rush in


Britain's sporting triumphs have been a bit thin on the ground in recent years, but now the nation -indeed, the whole world - can salute the athletic prowess of a group of Dewsbury men. For this week eight locals claimed a new world record for that most thrilling and emotionally-charged of sporting events: long-distance coal-carrying.

The men succeeded in lugging a hundredweight sack of coal over a distance of 80 miles between them, raising more than £40,000 for a local hospital.

"It felt like winning a grand prix when we crossed the finishing line," said competitor Andy Shaw. "Someone was waiting with a bottle of champagne and everything. It was the proudest moment of my life."

The men began their Herculean feat at 6.15am, carrying their sack of coal 387 times round a quarter-mile circuit, finally finishing 11 hours, 23 minutes and 33 seconds later. The world record was witnessed and verified by the local mayor, and video evidence and official lap-sheets have now been sent to the Guinness Book of Records for authentification.

"It was really exciting," enthused one spectator. "Although not quite as exciting as turnip carrying. A grown man sprinting with a large sack of root vegetables on his back: now that really gets the pulse racing!"
Dewsbury Reporter

Pigeon fancier


The full force of officialdom came down hard on a Manchester woman this week when she was officially ordered to stop feeding her loved ones in an outdoor shopping precinct.

The woman in question was 76-year old Eileen Rennie, and her "babies" are the pigeons she has fed three times a week for the last year outside Droylsden shopping centre. She has ignored repeated requests from her local council to stop doing so.

"I don't see what harm I'm doing," cooed Ms Rennie. "I feel so sorry for them. They all seem to recognise me whenever I come over with my shopping trolley, especially the little faun one."

But Tameside council has failed to bond with the birds in quite the same way. It insists that not only do the pigeons cause a mess, but they also carry infectious diseases. Council officials are now planning a cull in an effort to reduce their numbers.

"I can't believe that pigeons carry diseases," insisted Ms Rennie. "They're such beautiful creatures."

"Until a few months ago I would have disagreed," said one local man. "But then I went to Egypt and had one stuffed with couscous and spit-roasted, and she's right: it was absolutely gorgeous."
Manchester Evening News

Letter of the week


I would like to draw your attention to the war raging in Middlesbrough between motorcycle owners and motorcycle thieves which has been at epidemic proportions for at least the last 10 years.

I have had eight motorcycles stolen - the latest being last week. I had bought the bike the day before.

Luckily on this occasion I managed to retrieve it, having spotted three miscreants riding it down Victoria Road without crash helmets. I gave chase on a reserve bike I use for emergencies, and a fellow motorcyclist joined me in the pursuit.

Eventually, after flying through the subway at the Riverside stadium, down Dockside Road and over the level crossing at the Navigation pub, I managed to pull level with them. They challenged me, and then decided to cut and run across a field.

During this chase no police were to be seen. It was a shame it wasn't along the Stockton Road where I picked up three penalty points for a minor speed infringement a couple of weeks ago.
Mr SW, Middlesbrough Evening Gazette

fields.headline: Cricket's Crucible of corruption
fields.trailText: When Arthur Miller wrote The Crucible he wanted to use the play as a tool to highlight the hysteria created by McCarthyism in mid-twentieth century America. Yet recently the play has struck an alarming similarity with that most gentlemanly of games - cricket.
fields.body:
When Arthur Miller wrote The Crucible he wanted to use the play as a tool to highlight the hysteria created by McCarthyism in mid-twentieth century America. Yet recently the play has struck an alarming similarity with that most gentlemanly of games - cricket.

In the past few months, we've seen it all. The entire cricketing world has been brought tumbling to its knees as the power of the almighty dollar has infected the once-noble game. Suspicion is rife; no-one is innocent until proven guilty. The witch-hunt has begun. The people want answers, yet they and the authorities alike are scared of what they will find.

We have already witnessed the downfall of the mercurial Hansie Cronje, a man seemingly devoid of compassion. Kapil Dev, the former Indian captain and national icon, found himself implicated in the pernicious trade of match-fixing and resorted to tears when questioned on television. They are not alone. Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje, Salim Malik and Chris Lewis are but a few of a growing number of international cricketers to become embroiled in the scandal.

It seems everyone has an opinion, but no-one has the answers. We were promised the truth from the Pakistani inquiry into match-fixing, yet all that has resulted from that is a life ban for Salim Malik (which he plans to appeal against) and Ata-ur-Rehman and fines for several other Pakistani cricketers. It seems convenient that the only cricketers to be banned as a result of the inquiry are not at present playing for Pakistan.

Many of the players that were merely fined and warned about "future conduct" are actively involved with the national team, including Inzamam-ul-Haq, the present vice-captain. One senses a lack of conviction; the people with the power to make the radical decisions that are so desperately needed seem reluctant to face the challenge staring right at them.

Providing proof to back up claims of impropriety is itself proving difficult. Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian all-rounder, has accused Kapil Dev of trying to tempt him into "throwing a match", yet has struggled to provide any cast iron proof that what he says ever happened. The whole idea of "naming" cricketers believed to be involved in match fixing is creating an air of panic; Arthur Miller called it "fanaticism".

Chris Lewis, the man once labelled "the new Botham" feels he has been treated like a scape-goat for his part in the scandal. Perhaps he has, but his policy of naming players is not good enough. We need hard evidence with which to hang the criminals of cricket. Hearsay will not suffice and there is little to be gained from petty mud slinging. In a moment of desperation the besieged Kapil Dev even dared to mention that the great Sir Donald Bradman, a man synonymous with an era of chivalry and fair play, couldn't avoid suspicion. Where will it end and more importantly how will the future game be moulded by this crisis?

The seeds of the saga were sown long ago and as they have matured the grim reality of the state of international cricket has shocked us all. Or has it? When Dennis Lillee and Rodney Marsh bet against themselves in the infamous "Botham Test" at Headingley in 1981, few eyebrows were raised. It was harmless fun. It was definitely nothing to do with match fixing we are assured. Such promises are now beginning to wear thin. The frenzy that has followed the initial Cronje revelations mirrors the blood lust created by Abigail Williams in Miller's The Crucible to a frightening degree. The match fixing scandal has left the beast wounded and it is looking to strike out in revenge. Everyone has been placed under a veil of suspicion.

The Puritan inquisition led to the witches in The Crucible paying for their paranoia with their lives; one can only pray that the cost of this current crisis isn't the life of cricket. Senator McCarthy, the man whose anti-Communist ideals prompted Miller to write The Crucible talked of America being subverted by "twenty years of treason". Have we, the cricket fans, suffered the same indignity?

Daniel Jeffreys, 23, is a British citizen currently living and working in Sydney, Australia

fields.headline: Fiji faces international isolation
fields.standfirst: Fiji: special report
fields.trailText: Britain today warned Fiji's coup leaders that the country could be thrown out of the Commonwealth unless it returns to democratic rule.
fields.body:
Britain today warned Fiji's coup leaders that the country could be thrown out of the Commonwealth unless it returns to democratic rule.

Foreign Office minister John Battle said the Commonwealth ministerial action group would meet in London on Tuesday to consider "a range of options".

Fiji was thrown out of the organisation for 10 years after a coup in 1987 which was also directed at the island's Indian population. Asked whether expulsion would happen again if the democratic government was overthrown, Mr Battle replied: "I think it really is a serious option if Fijians were to find themselves in this position."

But international pariah status holds no terrors for George Speight, the failed businessman who led the coup. Mr Speight dismissed any international fallout or damage to Fiji's economy from his act and accused some of his foreign critics of running governments that have trampled on the rights of indigenous people.

"They tend to have Caucasians running the country with other ethnic groups  shackled by democracy and suppressed to the extent that they are minorities with hardly a voice," he said. Mr Speight said that he did not want Fijians ending up like Aborigines in Australia, forced to live on handouts. The United States, New Zealand and Australia have all threatened sanctions if Fiji does not return to democratic rule.

Mr Speight took Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and the entire cabinet hostage on May 19. Mr Speight, who has the backing of Fiji's special forces, said he wanted to make the rights of indigenous Fijians "paramount", although the country has a sizeable Indian population that has been established for around 100 years.

The coup leader said today he was prepared to release Mr Chaudhry and about 30 other hostages at the weekend. Speaking from inside the compound where the hostages are being held, Mr Speight insisted rumours that the prime minister was ill were not true, although he refused to allow him be interviewed. He said the council of chiefs, Fiji's indigenous tribal leaders, would decide on the nature of an interim government on Monday.

It was "up to them" whether he was a member of that government or not, he said. Asked whether the only people allowed to shape the new constitution would be ethnic Fijians, he replied: "Correct. We are talking about the right to rule in our own country - that's not such a strange idea, it's practised all over the world." He claimed Fiji's Indian population understood "our need to secure self-determination in our country of birth and heritage".

When it was put to him that Indians had roughly the same share of population at 48% as ethnic Fijians, Mr Speight responded: "It doesn't matter whether we are a majority in our own country, whether we are 5% or 100% - our rights are uncontestable and cannot be overridden by any other rights. What's the use of democratic constitutional correctness in the eyes of the world if  our people are suffering?"

Mr Speight said he would accept any decision from the council of chiefs, but he appears to have won key concessions in the composition of an interim government. Mr Speight and some of his men are to have places in the new government, although none is expected to become prime minister. This comes on top of other concessions he has already wrung from the military, which declared martial law on Monday.

Mr Speight secured three initial demands from Commodore Frank Bainimarama, the commander of Fiji's armed forces: that the prime minister be replaced; the constitution torn up; and an amnesty for him and his fellow plotters. Mr Speight was due to meet Cmdr Bainimarama for a second time today.

webTitle: Small & Beautiful and Meson Bilbao, London NW6

fields.headline: Small & Beautiful and Meson Bilbao, London NW6
fields.trailText: The bare tables, bare floors, bare bricks and heavy-duty gilt-framed mirrors sum up Small & Beautiful
fields.body:
Telephone: 020-7328 2637
Address: Small & Beautiful, 351-353 Kilburn High Road, London NW6.

The bare tables, bare floors, bare bricks and heavy-duty gilt-framed mirrors sum up Small & Beautiful. Keeps cheap with the bare essentials, except for the food, which has an unexpected turn of, well, if not luxury, style certainly. Holiday around the Med without leaving north-west London. Good olives. The obligatory grilled goat's cheese (what would we do with all those goats' cheeses if they weren't melted under the grill in a thousand variations?). Terrific and unconventional pasta and pizza. Big on steaks, too. Puddings owe more to the British sweet tooth than Med asceticism, viz toffee cream pie, toffee mousse. Service bright and breezy. Bills aesthetically pleasing and miniature by London standards.

Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Telephone: 020-7328 1744.
Address: Meson Bilbao, 33 Malvern Road, London NW6.
A tapas local, run with cheerful, if not always coherent, sense of style. Cooking generally well above your run-of-the-mill patatas-bravas-chorizo-bouncy-Spanish-omelette of more loudly trumpeted places. Chipirones en su tinta (squid in its ink) sets the standard for London. Boquerones (anchovies), mussels Bilbaina, grilled sardines and the rest are top-notch nibbles. Heftier dishes for longer lunchers are cooked to the same high standard. Hake is the favoured fish when it comes to serious cooking. Paella goes down well with the locals. Multiple riojas go down even quicker. Service is sometimes a bit leisurely for consistent quick bites, but tapas should get you in and out under the time limit.

webTitle: Travolta lays low after Battlefield bombs

fields.headline: Travolta lays low after Battlefield bombs
fields.trailText: Paramount has delayed the scheduled opening of John Travolta's new film Numbers, following the embarrassing failure of the project with which he's currently, inextricably associated, Battlefield Earth
fields.body:
Paramount has delayed the scheduled opening of John Travolta's new film Numbers, following the embarrassing failure of the project with which he's currently, inextricably associated, Battlefield Earth. The New York Post says that Paramount, which had planned a July 14 release of the film, now says only that "the film is currently scheduled for a summer release." Analysts speculated that the studio wanted to distance itself from the Battlefield debacle. The Hollywood Reporter told the Post, "on the heels of Battlefield Earth having crashed and burned, Travolta would do well to lay low for a period of time. If he does interviews now, all people are going to ask him about is Battlefield Earth."

According to Robert Bucksbaum, president of box-office tracking agency Reel Source, "it could very well be they [the studio] wanted to distance themselves from Battlefield Earth, which left a bad taste in moviegoers' mouths."

But Numbers director Nora Ephron sees it differently. "The July opening was a hilariously optimistic thing on the part of [studio] people," she tells the Post. "It was always our profoundest hope we'd be coming out in the winter." The film stars Travolta as a lowlife TV meteorologist who tries to coerce a lottery ball girl (Lisa Kudrow) into rigging the draw.

fields.headline: Fowl play afoot
fields.standfirst: Stuart Husband grills Aardman's Nick Park and Peter Lord, creators of Wallace and Gromit, about their first feature film, a Great Escape for chickens
fields.trailText: Stuart Husband grills Aardman's Nick Park and Peter Lord, creators of Wallace and Gromit, about their first feature film, a Great Escape for chickens
fields.body:
Do you remember a Fast Show sketch in which reporter Paul Whitehouse, covering the making of a plasticine-animation movie, gradually loses the will to live as an earnest young model-maker painstakingly shows him how he moves the dog's eyebrow a millionth of a millimetre before taking a shot, then moves it another millionth of a millimetre before taking another shot, thereby producing about one frame of film every six months?

This reporter can't help recalling it while standing on the set of Aardman Animation's first full-length claymation feature, the £30m Chicken Run, while an earnest young animator named Merlin, in sweat-top-baggy-short-skate-kid-chic, patiently explains how it took him two weeks to shoot a 30-second scene in which a motorbike and sidecar crashes to the ground. Plus a further week of reshoots after the film's co-directors, Nick Park and Peter Lord, reckoned it wasn't kicking up enough dust on landing. Whitehouse & co may even have underestimated the laboriousness of such an enterprise.

Aardman's unassuming creations - Morph, Wallace & Gromit, Creature Comforts - are seen as a kitchen-table cottage industry, but the scale of their operation takes you by surprise. They started small - the company was founded by Lord and partner Dave Sproxton (who now heads up the company's business end) over a bunch of doodles on the former's kitchen table, while Park, who joined later, dreamt up his first ideas in the family potting shed - but, nearly 25 years and rafts of Baftas and Oscars later, Aardman is a vast warehouse nestling among Homebases and mobile phone HQs in a business park outside Bristol.

Chicken Run - the first fruit of a £155m five-movie deal with the DreamWorks studio - is only two and a half times longer than the Wallace & Gromit films, but Lord calculates that the whole enterprise, in terms of sets, models and man-hours, is "20 times greater than anything we've attempted before." You get a flavour of this on Merlin's set - a perfect miniature replica of a prison camp, Colditz Hornby-style, down to the hand-crafted barbed wire and tiny wooden five-bar gates, with hills and trees backlit by a sky that goes from starry to sun-drenched at the flick of a switch. This is impressive in itself, but then you wander the maze-like corridors and discover 30 other sets behind tarpaulin drapes, featuring everything from pocket battery henhouse interiors to sinister-looking pieces of midget machinery bristling with levers and flashing lights.

The production floors hum with white-coated young people - the average age of Aardman's 300 employees, most recruited locally, is 28 - crafting, assembling, painting, and glazing the 2,000 or so plasticine models consumed by the production with a zeal bordering on the messianic. Macabre sights abound - boxes of eyeballs and mouths, running the gamut from beatific smiles to hideous grimaces; half-built models, their wet clay tapering off to reveal the spindly wire armatures beneath, holding them together; other, finished characters being loaded into industrial-sized ovens to be baked. The overall effect is Frankenstein's laboratory meets the Ford assembly line; look out in the film's credits for Feather Gluers, Beak Wranglers and Claw Operatives.

"Basically," says Nick Park about Chicken Run, "and this is the line we've used with everybody, I'm afraid, it's The Great Escape with battery hens." The plot has an egg-layer named Ginger (voiced by Julia Sawalha) leading a revolt among the birds enslaved on a dismal farm in northern England, including the heroically dim Babs (Jane Horrocks in Bubble mode), against its fearsome proprietor, Mrs Tweedy, and her (of course) hen-pecked husband. She enlists the help of a fast-talking Rhode Island rooster (Mel Gibson, no less) who crash-lands in the coop, but the installation of Mrs Tweedy's new pie-making machine (the mini-Heath Robinson contraption glimpsed earlier) means it's a race against time.

Chicken Run makes knowing nods in the direction of numerous PoW movies, but it comes replete with the ultra-English love of punnery and skewed hint-of-darkness surrealism that have become Aardman trademarks. Despite the Hollywood big-gun patronage, Park and Lord's vision seems to have survived intact. When we meet in the Aardman canteen, ostentatiously adorned with posters for DreamWorks movies, they look exhausted - the fruit of three years' labour on a movie that, at the time of the visit, three months before its release date, was still being filmed (perhaps inevitable when a hard day's work produces three seconds of footage at best).

It's obvious that Park and Lord are very different personalities. Lord, 42, looks like the lost fifth member of Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young - unkempt hair, expensive glasses, abundant facial hair - and tends to lead the conversation, punctuating his observations with a big, booming laugh. Park is endearingly gauche; he hunches down in his chair and speaks in a murmur.

Despite the accolades - the Oscars, the CBE, the freedom of the city of Preston - he has the air of an awkward adolescent, though those who recall the home-made outsize luminous green bow-tie he wore when collecting the Oscar for A Close Shave would find it hard to conclude that there wasn't a latent extrovert lurking in there somewhere. (He sat next to Naomi Campbell. What did you talk about, I ask. He thinks for a minute. "She said she liked my tie." Anything else? "She said 'Well done' when I won.")

As co-directors, Park and Lord have maintained a daily vigil of walking the miles of studio floor, conferring with animators. Park: "We go round all the sets every single day, briefing people, checking cameras, lighting, shots. It's funny: it should be a slow, painstaking process, but we don't have time to be patient; we're trying to use all the parts of our brains at once. There's been a lot of improvising. One minute we're being asked whether a character's holding something in their right hand or left hand, the next we're trying to figure out the ending of the film."

Park and Lord came up with the models for the characters. In an office plastered with wallcharts detailing various breeds of British poultry in exhausting detail, they've inevitably had to delegate a lot of responsibility to under-animators. Has this vexed them? Are they control freaks? Lord: "There are, shall we say, competing visions. The animators are effectively actors, so I'm afraid we do sometimes get people asking what their puppet's motivation is. And we've got a few method animators."

Park: "The learning curve for me has been that I've had to stop assuming people know what's in my head. I've had to learn to be a better communicator and be open to what other people can give you, because I have a tendency to be a dictator. In a quiet way, of course." Lord: "You do get the bizarre situation where on any given day there are maybe 12 people performing the same character at various stages in the film. So it's important for them to be synchronised."

Park: "All the animators have been meeting for lunch once a week and compare notes." Lord: "It gets down to incredibly fine detail, you know, like the thickness of the plasticine on the eyelids."

This is edging dangerously close to Fast Show territory (Lord says he and Park know the sketch well, and can vouch for its spooky veracity - "Nick and I have done that interview many times"), so we hurriedly move the conversation along. If Aardman has grown organically up to now, is the leap to features the equivalent of the Big Bang? Lord: "Sort of, but it's just another stage in our evolution. Disney first mooted the idea of a feature around 10 years ago, but we wouldn't have been ready for it then. We've had that much more time in the intervening period to grow and build up a head of steam. This has always seemed the ultimate destination for us, the thing we'd end up doing."

Park says the important thing with the DreamWorks deal is that it gives Aardman autonomy within what he calls the studio's "benign embrace". "They've kept at arm's length," he says, "but they've also been very helpful, in that Jeffrey Katzenberg has been flying over in his private jet from Burbank to Bristol to offer help and advice."

And not interfere? Park: "No, he's pushing us to make it better, but he definitely wants our sort of film."

Lord: "He's not saying he wants another Toy Story, but there's a little tension in there, as there would naturally be. Their business is huge box office and they have a vision of how to get that, but they're not forcing our hand, saying 'That won't play in Nebraska' or whatever. And they've taught us about how to structure a story, keep it flowing through the peaks and plateaux." Park: "And it's also, like, a proper film, in terms of depth of shot and camera movements. I hadn't seen A Close Shave for a couple of years, and when I went back to it I couldn't believe how much I think differently now, the action and editing seemed so slow."

Aardman's next feature will be an updated version of The Tortoise and the Hare, though Lord and Park will act only as executive producers; the latter will meanwhile be developing the project closest to his heart, a Wallace & Gromit movie. The pair seem abashed at how far they've come. Lord: "It's amazing how things grow, how we're filling ever-bigger buildings with more and more stuff. We employ all these people now, and I suppose the dream is to take more people on and become a sort of powerhouse of animated creativity. And we won't be upping sticks and moving to Burbank - it's important for us to stay around Bristol. We've made our own culture here. We actually have a CGI department, but whatever we do, we don't want it to be too slick. With Chicken Run, we wanted to keep that personal, handmade look, and that's been our biggest challenge."

And finally, - why chickens? Park: "We knew we'd hit the right note when we went to LA to pitch the idea to DreamWorks. We were having dinner, and Spielberg said 'Oh, The Great Escape's my favourite movie, and I also have a farm with 300 chickens.' It was a dream result." Lord: "And I believe it was a chicken dinner to boot. It was obviously fated."

 Chicken Run will be released on June 30.

This reporter can't help recalling it while standing on the set of Aardman Animation's first full-length claymation feature, the £30m Chicken Run, while an earnest young animator named Merlin, in sweat-top-baggy-short-skate-kid-chic, patiently explains how it took him two weeks to shoot a 30-second scene in which a motorbike and sidecar crashes to the ground. Plus a further week of reshoots after the film's co-directors, Nick Park and Peter Lord, reckoned it wasn't kicking up enough dust on landing. Whitehouse & co may even have underestimated the laboriousness of such an enterprise. Aardman's unassuming creations - Morph, Wallace & Gromit, Creature Comforts - are seen as a kitchen-table cottage industry, but the scale of their operation takes you by surprise. They started small - the company was founded by Lord and partner Dave Sproxton (who now heads up the company's business end) over a bunch of doodles on the former's kitchen table, while Park, who joined later, dreamt up his first ideas in the family potting shed - but, nearly 25 years and rafts of Baftas and Oscars later, Aardman is a vast warehouse nestling among Homebases and mobile phone HQs in a business park outside Bristol. Chicken Run - the first fruit of a £155m five-movie deal with the DreamWorks studio - is only two and a half times longer than the Wallace & Gromit films, but Lord calculates that the whole enterprise, in terms of sets, models and man-hours, is "20 times greater than anything we've attempted before." You get a flavour of this on Merlin's set - a perfect miniature replica of a prison camp, Colditz Hornby-style, down to the hand-crafted barbed wire and tiny wooden five-bar gates, with hills and trees backlit by a sky that goes from starry to sun-drenched at the flick of a switch. This is impressive in itself, but then you wander the maze-like corridors and discover 30 other sets behind tarpaulin drapes, featuring everything from pocket battery henhouse interiors to sinister-looking pieces of midget machinery bristling with levers and flashing lights. The production floors hum with white-coated young people - the average age of Aardman's 300 employees, most recruited locally, is 28 - crafting, assembling, painting, and glazing the 2,000 or so plasticine models consumed by the production with a zeal bordering on the messianic. Macabre sights abound - boxes of eyeballs and mouths, running the gamut from beatific smiles to hideous grimaces; half-built models, their wet clay tapering off to reveal the spindly wire armatures beneath, holding them together; other, finished characters being loaded into industrial-sized ovens to be baked. The overall effect is Frankenstein's laboratory meets the Ford assembly line; look out in the film's credits for Feather Gluers, Beak Wranglers and Claw Operatives. "Basically," says Nick Park about Chicken Run, "and this is the line we've used with everybody, I'm afraid, it's The Great Escape with battery hens." The plot has an egg-layer named Ginger (voiced by Julia Sawalha) leading a revolt among the birds enslaved on a dismal farm in northern England, including the heroically dim Babs (Jane Horrocks in Bubble mode), against its fearsome proprietor, Mrs Tweedy, and her (of course) hen-pecked husband. She enlists the help of a fast-talking Rhode Island rooster (Mel Gibson, no less) who crash-lands in the coop, but the installation of Mrs Tweedy's new pie-making machine (the mini-Heath Robinson contraption glimpsed earlier) means it's a race against time. Chicken Run makes knowing nods in the direction of numerous PoW movies, but it comes replete with the ultra-English love of punnery and skewed hint-of-darkness surrealism that have become Aardman trademarks. Despite the Hollywood big-gun patronage, Park and Lord's vision seems to have survived intact. When we meet in the Aardman canteen, ostentatiously adorned with posters for DreamWorks movies, they look exhausted - the fruit of three years' labour on a movie that, at the time of the visit, three months before its release date, was still being filmed (perhaps inevitable when a hard day's work produces three seconds of footage at best). It's obvious that Park and Lord are very different personalities. Lord, 42, looks like the lost fifth member of Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young - unkempt hair, expensive glasses, abundant facial hair - and tends to lead the conversation, punctuating his observations with a big, booming laugh. Park is endearingly gauche; he hunches down in his chair and speaks in a murmur. Despite the accolades - the Oscars, the CBE, the freedom of the city of Preston - he has the air of an awkward adolescent, though those who recall the home-made outsize luminous green bow-tie he wore when collecting the Oscar for A Close Shave would find it hard to conclude that there wasn't a latent extrovert lurking in there somewhere. (He sat next to Naomi Campbell. What did you talk about, I ask. He thinks for a minute. "She said she liked my tie." Anything else? "She said 'Well done' when I won.") As co-directors, Park and Lord have maintained a daily vigil of walking the miles of studio floor, conferring with animators. Park: "We go round all the sets every single day, briefing people, checking cameras, lighting, shots. It's funny: it should be a slow, painstaking process, but we don't have time to be patient; we're trying to use all the parts of our brains at once. There's been a lot of improvising. One minute we're being asked whether a character's holding something in their right hand or left hand, the next we're trying to figure out the ending of the film." Park and Lord came up with the models for the characters. In an office plastered with wallcharts detailing various breeds of British poultry in exhausting detail, they've inevitably had to delegate a lot of responsibility to under-animators. Has this vexed them? Are they control freaks? Lord: "There are, shall we say, competing visions. The animators are effectively actors, so I'm afraid we do sometimes get people asking what their puppet's motivation is. And we've got a few method animators." Park: "The learning curve for me has been that I've had to stop assuming people know what's in my head. I've had to learn to be a better communicator and be open to what other people can give you, because I have a tendency to be a dictator. In a quiet way, of course." Lord: "You do get the bizarre situation where on any given day there are maybe 12 people performing the same character at various stages in the film. So it's important for them to be synchronised." Park: "All the animators have been meeting for lunch once a week and compare notes." Lord: "It gets down to incredibly fine detail, you know, like the thickness of the plasticine on the eyelids." This is edging dangerously close to Fast Show territory (Lord says he and Park know the sketch well, and can vouch for its spooky veracity - "Nick and I have done that interview many times"), so we hurriedly move the conversation along. If Aardman has grown organically up to now, is the leap to features the equivalent of the Big Bang? Lord: "Sort of, but it's just another stage in our evolution. Disney first mooted the idea of a feature around 10 years ago, but we wouldn't have been ready for it then. We've had that much more time in the intervening period to grow and build up a head of steam. This has always seemed the ultimate destination for us, the thing we'd end up doing." Park says the important thing with the DreamWorks deal is that it gives Aardman autonomy within what he calls the studio's "benign embrace". "They've kept at arm's length," he says, "but they've also been very helpful, in that Jeffrey Katzenberg has been flying over in his private jet from Burbank to Bristol to offer help and advice." And not interfere? Park: "No, he's pushing us to make it better, but he definitely wants our sort of film." Lord: "He's not saying he wants another Toy Story, but there's a little tension in there, as there would naturally be. Their business is huge box office and they have a vision of how to get that, but they're not forcing our hand, saying 'That won't play in Nebraska' or whatever. And they've taught us about how to structure a story, keep it flowing through the peaks and plateaux." Park: "And it's also, like, a proper film, in terms of depth of shot and camera movements. I hadn't seen A Close Shave for a couple of years, and when I went back to it I couldn't believe how much I think differently now, the action and editing seemed so slow." Aardman's next feature will be an updated version of The Tortoise and the Hare, though Lord and Park will act only as executive producers; the latter will meanwhile be developing the project closest to his heart, a Wallace & Gromit movie. The pair seem abashed at how far they've come. Lord: "It's amazing how things grow, how we're filling ever-bigger buildings with more and more stuff. We employ all these people now, and I suppose the dream is to take more people on and become a sort of powerhouse of animated creativity. And we won't be upping sticks and moving to Burbank - it's important for us to stay around Bristol. We've made our own culture here. We actually have a CGI department, but whatever we do, we don't want it to be too slick. With Chicken Run, we wanted to keep that personal, handmade look, and that's been our biggest challenge." And finally, - why chickens? Park: "We knew we'd hit the right note when we went to LA to pitch the idea to DreamWorks. We were having dinner, and Spielberg said 'Oh, The Great Escape's my favourite movie, and I also have a farm with 300 chickens.' It was a dream result." Lord: "And I believe it was a chicken dinner to boot. It was obviously fated."  Chicken Run will be released on June 30.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer rumours buffed, cleaned, polished and preened
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo has indicated he could leave Stamford Bridge after the arrival of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. "Now I think it is about time that Chelsea sell one striker. We are now too many," Flo told the Daily Mail. "I have registered the interest in me from Deportivo La Coruna. As long as Chelsea want to keep me, I would like to stay. But Hasselbaink is a very good striker and the competition for places up front is now very tough."
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo has indicated he could leave Stamford Bridge after the arrival of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. "Now I think it is about time that Chelsea sell one striker. We are now too many," Flo told the Daily Mail. "I have registered the interest in me from Deportivo La Coruna. As long as Chelsea want to keep me, I would like to stay. But Hasselbaink is a very good striker and the competition for places up front is now very tough."

Emmanuel Petit has insisted he is not seeking a summer transfer, according to Planet Football. "My contract with Arsenal runs for the next three years and there is no reason for not staying there," Petit said. "If something comes up, maybe I will consider the opportunity to go but I won't do anything to trigger a transfer now. My first goal is to have a good European Championship."

Planet Football also reports that Bayern Munich are favourites to sign Galatasaray striker Hakan Sukur for around £8m. The 28-year-old Turkish international is believed to be close to agreeing a three-year contract worth £4.75m and Bayern boss Ottmar Hitzfeld has admitted: "He is on my purchase list."

Andrei Kanchelskis has rejected Manchester City's advances and wants to stay at Rangers, reports the Star. The 31-year-old Russian winger said: "I'm having a great time at Rangers now. I've been playing regularly in the first team and I'm playing better than ever before."

Southampton are favourites to sign Aston Villa midfielder Mark Draper - but Everton are also interested. Draper told Teamtalk: "I am going on holiday for a couple of weeks and will not be making any decision until I return home. Southampton have indicated they would like to sign me. But there is also interest from Everton although I have not actually spoken to them."

Southampton are also hoping to beat off competition from West Ham and Coventry to sign Moroccan defender Abdelilah Saber from Sporting Lisbon.

But don't expect West Ham to sign Davor Suker on a free transfer. According to the Star, Harry Redknapp has been told there is no money to bring in new players this summer.

webTitle: Legendary Cinerama system revived by Microsoft billionaire

fields.headline: Legendary Cinerama system revived by Microsoft billionaire
fields.trailText: The co-founder of Microsoft, Seattle billionaire Paul Allen, is investing in the revival of the legendary movie format, Cinerama. Allen has enlisted a team of experts to refit his Cinerama picture house to accommodate the spectacular ultra-wide format it was built to show
fields.body:
The co-founder of Microsoft, Seattle billionaire Paul Allen, is investing in the revival of the legendary movie format, Cinerama. Allen has enlisted a team of experts to refit his Cinerama picture house to accommodate the spectacular ultra-wide format it was built to show.

Cinerama was created before the war, when it was used by the US military to train aircraft turret gunners, and reached the height of its popularity in the 1950s and 60s, when seven films, including the epic How the West Was Won, were made especially for the format.

Cinerama uses a 96-foot-long curved screen, 50% bigger than screens used today. Three giant projectors cast three images side-by-side. Recreating the means to screen Cinerama wasn't easy. "We took every screw out, every bolt out, repainted - we basically have brand-new projectors, brand-new from 1952," says Jeff Graves, Cinerama project manager. Prints for the Seattle project were pieced together from scraps by John Harvey, a 63-year-old enthusiast who kept Cinerama alive in the US by screening movies in Ohio home.

"People have not seen a Cinerama movie inside a Cinerama theater for some 35 years," says Jeff Graves, Cinerama project manager. "It's just a great opportunity to show this fantastic format." Larry Smith, president of the Cinerama Preservation Society, argues that his beloved format presaged IMAX and the blockbuster. "When you're going down a canal in Venice (in a Cinerama film), you feel like you can reach out and touch the walls. In How the West Was Won, with the horses galloping and kicking up dust, you want to cough," says Smith. "It's a virtual reality system."

Those involved in the project hope to persuade Hollywood to take up the Cinerama cause, Graves said, so later generations accustomed to (comparatively) tiny screens can experience the eye-goggling marvel that is Cinerama.
