fields.headline: Roberts reclaims her domain name
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts has triumphed in cybercourt over the use of the domain name juliaroberts.com
fields.body:
Julia Roberts has triumphed in cybercourt over the use of the domain name juliaroberts.com. The toothy starlet employed a crew of web savvy legal eagles who took her case, by email only, to an international arbitration panel.

The Pretty Woman and Notting Hill megastar first filed her complaint on March 25 this year, with the World Intellectual Property Organisation - one of only a handful of firms authorised by the Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers to resolve cybersquatting squabbles. Roberts' charge was that New Jersey nethead Russell Boyd had registered the domain name then tried to auction it at eBay, and that it wasn't until after Roberts complained that he created a fansite using the URL. Agreeing with the $20m-a-movie actress, WIPO said, "the respondent registered and used the domain name in bad faith."

Boyd sees the matter differently. "Julia the multimillionaire and her team of lawyers have struck a powerful blow against the common man and his mistaken belief in free speech," the chancer wrote this week on his soon-to-be-defunct website.

webTitle: 'They took my body from me and used it'

fields.headline: 'They took my body from me and used it'
fields.standfirst: Last year  Andrea Dworkin  was drugged and raped in her hotel room. Here the leading feminist describes the devastating experience
fields.trailText: Last year Andrea Dworkin was drugged and raped in her hotel room. Here the leading feminist describes the devastating experience
fields.body:
I was in Europe. I was 52. It was 1999. I was in a garden in a hotel. I was reading a book. French Literary Fascism. I was drinking kir royale. I had two. The second one didn't taste right. I didn't finish it. Then I became sort of sickish or weakish or something, and all I could think about was getting to my bed and not making a fool of myself in public view. I prayed: "Let me get to my room, please let me get to my room." I had ordered dinner from room service and the waiter, who had also made the drinks, had said: "It will be my great pleasure to serve you your dinner tonight." I conked out.

Then a boy was in the room with dinner. He had served me the second drink. I tried to get up and I fell against the far wall because I couldn't stand. I signed the cheque, but could barely balance myself. I fell back on to the bed. I didn't lock the door. I came to four or five hours later. I didn't know where I was. The curtains hadn't been drawn. Now it was dark; before it had been light, long before dusk.

I had internal pain. I hurt deep inside my vagina. I said to myself. "Well, it's cancer, and there's nothing you can do about it now so worry about it when you get home." I went to the toilet and found blood on my right hand, fresh, bright red, not menstrual blood, not clotted blood. I'm past bleeding. I tried to find the source of the blood. My hand got covered in it again. I found huge, deep gashes on my right leg from the middle of the back of the leg to the middle of the front. I couldn't stop the bleeding of the gashes so I tried to keep them clean.

A few hours later, I took a shower. I had a big, strange bruise on my left breast, next to the aureole, not a regular bruise, huge, black and blue with solid white skin in the centre, as if someone had sucked it up and chewed it. I didn't feel good the next day or the day after. I thought I had been drugged and raped, but I felt confused. I couldn't stand the thought of making a wrong allegation. I thought that the bartender had done it, because he had made the drinks and he was on the room-service phone and he had flirted grandly with me, though I had not reciprocated. I thought that maybe the boy, who had brought me the second drink, was supposed to report that I had passed out. I thought the bartender had raped me. I didn't know if the boy had been there or not, but I thought yes.

I couldn't remember, but I thought they had pulled me down toward the bottom of the bed so that my vagina was near the bed's edge and my legs were easy to manipulate. I thought that the deep, bleeding scratches, right leg, and the big bruise, left breast, were the span of a man on top of me. I had been wearing sweatpants that just fell right down. I had been wearing an undershirt. Usually I covered myself, but I had felt too sick to manage it before the boy came in with the dinner. Besides, I don't know how he got inside since the door was dead-bolted. He appeared suddenly, already in.

In my own life, I don't have intercourse. That is my choice. I got an internal infection in the aftermath. How? It was horrible not knowing. I had literally no memory of what the man and the boy had done. It's like being operated on. You don't feel anything until you feel the pain that comes with a return to consciousness. I speculated that my body must have been relaxed, no muscles straining, no physical resistance or even tension. This repelled me.

The hours were gone, missing. My mind went over and over that day and night for weeks and weeks turning into months and months. I couldn't find the missing hours because they weren't there, in my brain. That is why drugs such as Rohypnol and gamma hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) are called amnesiac drugs. (Since I could taste something in my drink, it was probably GHB, called on the street Grievous Bodily Harm.)

I lost all hope. I couldn't defend myself. I had been helpless. I had decided long ago that no one would ever rape me again; he or they or I would die. But this rape was necrophiliac: they wanted to fuck a dead woman. Why? I was scared. I thought that being forced and being conscious was better, because then you knew; even if no one ever believed you, you knew. Most rape experts agree: how can you face what you can't remember? I tried to hammer through the amnesia, but nothing broke. I was so hurt.

A few days later, on a Sunday, at the suggestion of my mate, John, at home in Brooklyn, I placed a call to my New York feminist gynaecologist of more than a decade. I said that I thought I had been drugged and raped. She said that a gynaecological exam wouldn't prove anything one way or the other and that the call from me convinced her that she should have an unlisted phone number. I thanked her (I'm a girl) and collapsed in tears. On the plane trip home, I huddled and shook. I felt overwhelming grief as if I had died. I also felt grief for this sick world.

I started hating every day. I hated seeing the sun rise. I couldn't put one foot in front of the other and I wanted to put a butcher's knife into my heart behind my ribs. I was very lonely. I was consumed by grief and sorrow until I was lucky enough to become numb. I thought I could resist by not dying, but that might be too hard and maybe I was too old and too tired and couldn't do it any more. My body was a curse and had betrayed me. I couldn't figure out why they would want to do this and why they would want to do it to me.

I couldn't be consoled. I couldn't talk to anyone. How could I say the words to the people I loved, most of whom work precisely to stop violence against women: this is what he, someone or they, did to me. Yeah, I know I represent something to you, but really I'm a piece of crap because I just got raped. No, no, you're not a piece of crap when you get raped, but I am. John looked for any other explanation than rape. He abandoned me emotionally. Now a year has passed and sometimes he's with me in his heart and sometimes not.

I don't know why the world didn't stop right then, when the creatures drugged and raped me. I don't know how the earth can still turn. I don't believe that it should be possible. I don't. I think everyone should have stopped everything because I was 52 and this happened to me. I think every person should have been in mourning. I think no one should work or spend money or love anyone ever again. I ask: "Why me?" I say: "It can't have happened to me." I say: "My bad pheromones or karma brought the rapist pigs to me." I blame me no matter what it takes. I go down the checklist: no short skirt; it was daylight; I didn't drink a lot even though it was alcohol and I rarely drink, but so what? It could have been Wild Turkey or coffee. I didn't drink with a man, I sat alone and read a book, I didn't go somewhere I shouldn't have been, wherever that might be when you are 52, I didn't flirt, I didn't want it to happen. I wasn't hungry for a good, hard fuck that would leave me pummelled with pain inside.

And after: I don't want it to have happened. I can't remember it. They took my body from me and used it. They were inside me. I felt for stickiness. There was none. I prayed that meant they had used condoms. (I'm waiting for the outcome of a second round of HIV and other STD testing. Immediately after a drug-rape, as I didn't know then, there are about 24 hours in which to get a urine sample and 48 to 72 hours to get a blood test.)

And then there is that I know too much. Forgive me for saying this, but it makes everything harder. I know a lot about rape. I study it. I read about it. I think about it. I listen to rape victims. I engage with prosecutors and lawyers and legislators. I write about it. I was raped before this. I remember being raped. I say that we're fighting back. I give speeches and say that women and girls are being raped and we need to do this and this and this. I know hundreds if not thousands of raped women.

But this is new. Rape with amnesiac drugs is new. It's so easy. In most studies on rape and pornography, about 30% of men say they would rape if they could get away with it. They can. This is foolproof rape. The gang that couldn't shoot straight can do this kind of rape. You can do this hundreds of times with virtually no chance of getting caught, let alone having anyone be able to make a legal case in any court of law. And smart women with attitudes like myself can't stop these pieces of dog excrement through militance or violence or persuasion or just being reasonably polite.

See, if there were feminist vigilantes, I couldn't even ask a favour. I can't put the bartender in the hotel room with me. I know it was he and his little accomplice, but how do I know? The circumstantial evidence that leads to the conclusion that the rape happened does not identify the rapist(s). One point for prosecutors: this is poisoning as well as rape; always bring both charges.

As for me: about 10 days after I came home, my 84-year-old father broke his knee. He was never out of a hospital or nursing or convalescent home again until he died on December 4 1999. A few days before Christmas, I was hospitalised for bronchitis, pneumonia, cellulitis (an infection of the soft tissues in the legs - lethal if not treated with antibiotics) and blood clots. I had been wandering in delirium from a high fever on New York City streets until a young woman helped get me off the street and called John.

I was in the hospital a month, which caused my leg muscles to atrophy, so I am learning how to use them again. I used to worry about taking a Valium or two to fall asleep in strange hotels. Now I take on average 12 pills to sleep and they only work sometimes. How can I close my eyes and voluntarily become unconscious? For the first time in my life I go to shrinks, a lucid one who prescribes drugs and an empathetic one whose speciality is in dealing with people who have been tortured. I have been tortured and this drug-rape runs through it, a river of horror. I'm feeling perpetual terror, they both tell me. I stare blankly or I say some words. I'm ready to die.

This article appears in the current issue of the New Statesman (£2, available from newsagents; for subscriptions call 0800 731 8496). Andrea Dworkin's new book, Scapegoat, is published by Virago on June 8 (£22.50).

I signed the cheque, but could barely balance myself. I fell back on to the bed. I didn't lock the door. I came to four or five hours later. I didn't know where I was. The curtains hadn't been drawn. Now it was dark; before it had been light, long before dusk. I had internal pain. I hurt deep inside my vagina. I said to myself. "Well, it's cancer, and there's nothing you can do about it now so worry about it when you get home." I went to the toilet and found blood on my right hand, fresh, bright red, not menstrual blood, not clotted blood. I'm past bleeding. I tried to find the source of the blood. My hand got covered in it again. I found huge, deep gashes on my right leg from the middle of the back of the leg to the middle of the front. I couldn't stop the bleeding of the gashes so I tried to keep them clean. A few hours later, I took a shower. I had a big, strange bruise on my left breast, next to the aureole, not a regular bruise, huge, black and blue with solid white skin in the centre, as if someone had sucked it up and chewed it. I didn't feel good the next day or the day after. I thought I had been drugged and raped, but I felt confused. I couldn't stand the thought of making a wrong allegation. I thought that the bartender had done it, because he had made the drinks and he was on the room-service phone and he had flirted grandly with me, though I had not reciprocated. I thought that maybe the boy, who had brought me the second drink, was supposed to report that I had passed out. I thought the bartender had raped me. I didn't know if the boy had been there or not, but I thought yes. I couldn't remember, but I thought they had pulled me down toward the bottom of the bed so that my vagina was near the bed's edge and my legs were easy to manipulate. I thought that the deep, bleeding scratches, right leg, and the big bruise, left breast, were the span of a man on top of me. I had been wearing sweatpants that just fell right down. I had been wearing an undershirt. Usually I covered myself, but I had felt too sick to manage it before the boy came in with the dinner. Besides, I don't know how he got inside since the door was dead-bolted. He appeared suddenly, already in. In my own life, I don't have intercourse. That is my choice. I got an internal infection in the aftermath. How? It was horrible not knowing. I had literally no memory of what the man and the boy had done. It's like being operated on. You don't feel anything until you feel the pain that comes with a return to consciousness. I speculated that my body must have been relaxed, no muscles straining, no physical resistance or even tension. This repelled me. The hours were gone, missing. My mind went over and over that day and night for weeks and weeks turning into months and months. I couldn't find the missing hours because they weren't there, in my brain. That is why drugs such as Rohypnol and gamma hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) are called amnesiac drugs. (Since I could taste something in my drink, it was probably GHB, called on the street Grievous Bodily Harm.) I lost all hope. I couldn't defend myself. I had been helpless. I had decided long ago that no one would ever rape me again; he or they or I would die. But this rape was necrophiliac: they wanted to fuck a dead woman. Why? I was scared. I thought that being forced and being conscious was better, because then you knew; even if no one ever believed you, you knew. Most rape experts agree: how can you face what you can't remember? I tried to hammer through the amnesia, but nothing broke. I was so hurt. A few days later, on a Sunday, at the suggestion of my mate, John, at home in Brooklyn, I placed a call to my New York feminist gynaecologist of more than a decade. I said that I thought I had been drugged and raped. She said that a gynaecological exam wouldn't prove anything one way or the other and that the call from me convinced her that she should have an unlisted phone number. I thanked her (I'm a girl) and collapsed in tears. On the plane trip home, I huddled and shook. I felt overwhelming grief as if I had died. I also felt grief for this sick world. I started hating every day. I hated seeing the sun rise. I couldn't put one foot in front of the other and I wanted to put a butcher's knife into my heart behind my ribs. I was very lonely. I was consumed by grief and sorrow until I was lucky enough to become numb. I thought I could resist by not dying, but that might be too hard and maybe I was too old and too tired and couldn't do it any more. My body was a curse and had betrayed me. I couldn't figure out why they would want to do this and why they would want to do it to me. I couldn't be consoled. I couldn't talk to anyone. How could I say the words to the people I loved, most of whom work precisely to stop violence against women: this is what he, someone or they, did to me. Yeah, I know I represent something to you, but really I'm a piece of crap because I just got raped. No, no, you're not a piece of crap when you get raped, but I am. John looked for any other explanation than rape. He abandoned me emotionally. Now a year has passed and sometimes he's with me in his heart and sometimes not. I don't know why the world didn't stop right then, when the creatures drugged and raped me. I don't know how the earth can still turn. I don't believe that it should be possible. I don't. I think everyone should have stopped everything because I was 52 and this happened to me. I think every person should have been in mourning. I think no one should work or spend money or love anyone ever again. I ask: "Why me?" I say: "It can't have happened to me." I say: "My bad pheromones or karma brought the rapist pigs to me." Forgive me for saying this, but it makes everything harder. I know a lot about rape. I study it. I read about it. I think about it. I listen to rape victims. I engage with prosecutors and lawyers and legislators. I write about it. I was raped before this. I remember being raped. I say that we're fighting back. I give speeches and say that women and girls are being raped and we need to do this and this and this. I know hundreds if not thousands of raped women. But this is new. Rape with amnesiac drugs is new. It's so easy. In most studies on rape and pornography, about 30% of men say they would rape if they could get away with it. They can. This is foolproof rape. The gang that couldn't shoot straight can do this kind of rape. You can do this hundreds of times with virtually no chance of getting caught, let alone having anyone be able to make a legal case in any court of law. And smart women with attitudes like myself can't stop these pieces of dog excrement through militance or violence or persuasion or just being reasonably polite. See, if there were feminist vigilantes, I couldn't even ask a favour. I can't put the bartender in the hotel room with me. I know it was he and his little accomplice, but how do I know? He was never out of a hospital or nursing or convalescent home again until he died on December 4 1999. I had been wandering in delirium from a high fever on New York City streets until a young woman helped get me off the street and called John. I was in the hospital a month, which caused my leg muscles to atrophy, so I am learning how to use them again. I used to worry about taking a Valium or two to fall asleep in strange hotels. Now I take on average 12 pills to sleep and they only work sometimes. How can I close my eyes and voluntarily become unconscious? For the first time in my life I go to shrinks, a lucid one who prescribes drugs and an empathetic one whose speciality is in dealing with people who have been tortured. I have been tortured and this drug-rape runs through it, a river of horror. I'm feeling perpetual terror, they both tell me. I stare blankly or I say some words. I'm ready to die. webTitle: The best rallying the troops scene: U-571

fields.headline: The best rallying the troops scene: U-571
fields.trailText: 1942. Without notice, the crew of a US Submarine have been called back from leave. Lieutenant Commander Mike Dahldren (Bill Paxton), Lieutenant Andrew Tyler (Matthew McConaughey) and Captain Klough (Harvey Keitel) stand on dock as the crew begins loading equipment aboard.
fields.body:
1942. Without notice, the crew of a US Submarine have been called back from leave. Lieutenant Commander Mike Dahldren (Bill Paxton), Lieutenant Andrew Tyler (Matthew McConaughey) and Captain Klough (Harvey Keitel) stand on dock as the crew begins loading equipment aboard.

"Mr Tyler," instructs Dahldren, "call the crew to quarters."

"Aye, Sir."

Tyler then bellows at the crew, "Everybody file in! In formation! Now! Let's go!"

The men assemble in rank, standing to attention. Tyler turns to Dahldren, "Captain? All crew members present and accounted for, Sir." "Very well, at ease."

Dahldren addresses the crew, "I'm sorry your liberty has been cut short, but our schedule's changed. We have two hours to get stowed for sea. Mr Larson, have the torpedo men load the tubes with their four best fish. Mr Emmet, clean up the diesels and line up a battery charge. Mr Taylor, we have dry stores, ordnance and perishables to get below decks." He pauses.

"Gentlemen, it's our turn . That's all."

"Attention!" screams Tyler. The men fall in.

"Dismissed!"

"You heard the man," Klough declares, "Stores to load, you've got six seconds to get into your boondockers and dungarees."

The men disperse, but a few crowd around Tyler, asking,

"Is this for real or is it a drill?" and "What's going on?"

Tyler looks out to sea and says, "I don't know, but I'm going to find out."

See Also: Braveheart, Saving Private Ryan, Henry V

Don't See Also: Independence Day

Pointless Trivia: Harvey Keitel served in the US Marines in real life, before turning his hand to acting.

fields.headline: Honest to badness
fields.standfirst:
The turkeys are coming home to roost

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The British take a pride - which sometimes merges into unforgivable superiority - in their creativity. In recent years, this has been politically appropriated by New Labour as Cool Britannia; this summer, it is being given new force by a love-fest with the visual arts as an ambitious programme unrolls of new and revamped galleries and museums. We glory in our versatile strengths in making lucrative music for a global audience.
fields.body:
The British take a pride - which sometimes merges into unforgivable superiority - in their creativity. In recent years, this has been politically appropriated by New Labour as Cool Britannia; this summer, it is being given new force by a love-fest with the visual arts as an ambitious programme unrolls of new and revamped galleries and museums. We glory in our versatile strengths in making lucrative music for a global audience. But the one prize which continually eludes our grasp is success in the most dominant medium of the last century: the cinema. Every time one of our directors succeeds in Hollywood - Sam Mendes or Anthony Minghella - we treat them like national war heroes, such is our envious cinematic rivalry with the US. Last weekend rammed the national humiliation home; while Gladiators (British director, but US made) took critical acclaim and a succulent £3m at the box office, Honest managed only a meagre £111,309 and a pasting.

For decades, we have searched around for explanations for the collapse of a vibrant British film industry. We have plenty of acting and directorial talent and some of the best technicians. So we blamed lack of funding and poor distribution systems. The answer was to throw £100m of lottery money at the industry. But just now, the results look pretty depressing. Ben Elton's Maybe Baby is being panned by the critics and not even the usual publicity stunt of a revealing-dress-at-premiere - this time Joely Richardson's bare back - will help. Honest, the film due to launch the All Saints as film stars, has been hastily withdrawn from dozens of cinemas after it bombed. It has plumbed new box office depths for British films, beating other recent home-grown flops such as Rancid Aluminium and Guest House Paradiso. The truth is that British film-making is on a steep - and painful - learning curve. It is still a very erratic affair, producing a few fine successes, but a yardful of turkeys too.

fields.headline: Box office: improbable
fields.trailText: Box office: improbable
fields.body:
Not long ago, I was sitting in a cinema in Mexico City waiting for the main feature to start. What seemed like a fairly predictable commercial was being shown. The bride and groom were standing hand-in-hand at the front of the church as the wedding ceremony reached its climax. The priest asked the Spanish equivalent of "Does anyone know why this man and woman should not be joined together in holy matrimony?" Suddenly the young man sitting next to me in the stalls leapt to his feet. "Yes," he cried, "I do!"

On screen, the bride turned round and, looking right at our corner of the cinema, asked something along the lines of: "Jorge - is that you?" "Yes," shouted the young man as all heads turned towards him. "I still love you!" The groom intervened, also looking angrily in our direction, and the young man fled the cinema to much laughter and bemusement from all of us as the logo of the advertiser, Celebrando.com, was shown on screen. The advertiser, as I discovered when I clicked on later to their website, caters for every wedding eventuality from receptions to contraception and this was its way of making a stir in the city, using out-of-work young actors in selected cinemas to play the part of the jilted lover.

It was the first and only interactive commercial I have ever come across and inquiries of ad people, both in Mexico and here in Los Angeles have failed to elicit any others.

The stunt came to mind watching John Woo's Mission: Impossible 2, or M:I-2 as it must be called, which has now opened to cheerful and friendly reviews all over the US. All that seemed to be missing from the stunts - hanging from cliffs, flying through the air on motorbikes - was someone in the audience to leap up and take part in the action; when I saw it they nearly did so to prevent Tom Cruise from being, well... they managed to stop themselves. The stunts are so spectacularly realistic that surely this must be the next stage: after virtual reality, reality.

M:I-2 has already beaten some record, as films so often do these days; this one, I think, for the largest grossing movie to open on a Wednesday. It has been playing to full houses as the US takes its Memorial Day holiday. The reviews have been mainly favourable and more than one critic has noted the similarities in plot to Hitchcock's Notorious, although the backdrop here is Sydney, looking as lovely as she is, rather than Rio. Then it was Cary Grant, Ingrid Bergman and Claude Rains; now it is Cruise, Thandie Newton and Dougray Scott.

Anyone who shoots someone in the thigh and then rubs his heel in the wound as Dougray Scott's character does in M:I-2 is clearly not a nice person and it is encouraging to see that Scots are finally taking over from Russians, South Africans and Arabs as leading Hollywood villains. It started with Fat Bastard in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me last year and has continued through Robert Carlyle in the last Bond film. Now Scott is playing a complete swine. For too long Scots have had to play noble losers (see Braveheart, everyone called Jock in war films, Trainspotting and Scottish football 1970 to present day) so it is refreshing if they are take over as international bastards, whether fat or slim.

Watching all the actors strut their stuff reminds us, of course, that the 135,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA) have been on strike for four weeks as part of their dispute over attempts to change the way in which they are paid. Advertisers want to pay them in lump sums rather than residuals, which actors say would cost them dear. The advertisers say the actors would be better off under the new scheme, which the unions have suggested must mean this is the first time employers have ever offered employees a better deal than they asked for.

Even in Los Angeles, where many of the strikers live, there has been only limited coverage of the dispute and the strike has had to rely on extraneous events to make itself heard. The strikers got a boost when golfer Tiger Woods announced that he would not film commercials until the strike was settled, and then suffered a set-back when former general and current George W Bush backer Colin Powell filmed a public service announcement against the unions' wishes.

But, as was reported last week, the strike has led to one dust-up that focussed attention on the dispute in unintended ways. The commercials firm owned by British directors Ridley and Tony Scott, RSA USA, placed an ad in a trade journal which showed an elderly black woman naked from the waist up with the caption: "In South Africa, this is what SAG means."

The ad was a come-on to advertisers to beat the strike by filming in South Africa and led to a picketing of RSA's Los Angeles office by angry union members and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Neither of the Scotts knew anything about the ad until it appeared and they were livid, issuing a fulsome apology to all concerned and expressing their anger.

Now those responsible have all been given the thumbs down by the director of Gladiator. A press release from RSA USA this week announces that "due to the offensive ad" RSA has ended its business relationships with director Marcus Nispel and others involved. They should have put that Dougray Scott on to them.

 John Patterson is on holiday.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: A Personal Journey | The Rage - Carrie 2 | Wild Strawberries | Raiders of the Lost Fridge
fields.trailText: A Personal Journey | The Rage - Carrie 2 | Wild Strawberries | Raiders of the Lost Fridge
fields.body:
A Personal Journey
DVD (£19.99)
BFI Cert E
*****

If you wanted someone to give you an illustrated lecture on American film in your living room, you couldn't ask for a better guide than Martin Scorsese and DVD, where it debuts, is the perfect format (it's also available on retail). It enables you to dip in to a specific chapter, like a good reference book, but it's far more seductive.

The director has all the clips you could ask for and uses them intelligently to discuss the changing philosophy and psychology of Hollywood and independent cinema, the technical advances and the eternal struggle of art vs commerce. He's particularly astute on Busby Berkeley, film noir and the B-picture, whose directors he regards as "smugglers" sneaking subversive ideas past the Hays Code heavy mob.

Scorsese's commentary is perfectly lucid but seems to come from the heart rather than the autocue. He adds a good range of directorial interviews including Wilder, Capra, Eastwood, Welles, Lang, Fuller, Cassavetes, Hawks and a hilariously monosyllabic John Ford. Scorsese's tape (the full title is A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American Movies) was originally a C4 series. In 224 minutes, it does its job with elegance, economy and wit, and it will make you want to see some of the more obscure films he provides tantalising glimpses of - T-Men, Shock Corridor or Detour, perhaps.

The Rage - Carrie 2
Rental
Warner Cert 18
**

A bad case of sequelitis at Bates High School as Katt Shea's loosely directed and very belated follow-up to Carrie provides an identikit plot, and makes the bad mistake of using clips from Brian de Palma's blinding original as memory flashbacks for its surviving character, Amy Irving. Once a tormenting teen, guilt-ridden Irving is now a teacher trying to help telekinetic pupil Emily Bergl avoid the disasters that befell Carrie 23 years ago. (Weirdly, given the age-gap, Bergl is her half-sister). Where Carrie had teens with distinct personalities, raging hormones and gleefully vindictive spite, The Rage just has a bunch of obnoxious rentadorks; where Carrie had cinema's only worthwhile prom scene, this just has a predictable ending. No Carrie 3, please.

Wild Strawberries
Retail (£15.99)
Tartan Cert 15
****

Wild Strawberries starts with its central figure, 78-year-old Isak Berg having a frightening dream: a clock has no hands, a coffin falls off a hearse, a hand slips out of the coffin. After this memorably short, sharp shock (much imitated since), the rest of Ingmar Bergman's 1958 film is more reverie than nightmare as a trip with his daughter-in-law to pick up an honorary degree triggers memories of his life as the car fills up with strangers - three hitch-hikers and a bickering couple who have crashed their car.

The film's main theme is emotional frigidity, but this is not the bleak, harsh Bergman of legend: it has great warmth and humour, especially in Berg's relationship with his housekeeper of 40 years. It's shot in a very relaxed manner by a director at the height of his powers with a performance of great dignity by Victor Sjostrom, himself a great Swedish director of the silent era. In lucid black and white with clear subtitles.

Raiders of the Lost Fridge
Retail (£14.99)
Fox Pathé Cert PG
***

"We want someone who doesn't immediately pooh-pooh everything he eats." "No, it usually takes a few hours." Homer becomes a food critic in Guess Who's Coming To Criticise Dinner, one of two Simpsons episodes new to me, along with King Size Homer in which the patriarch learns he's a fat man with an obese man struggling to get out. Also Burns Verkaufen der Kraftwerk (Kraftwerk = power station, rock fans) which includes Homer's wonderful Land of Chocolate daydream and Lisa the Vegetarian, which comes over all Paul & Linda on us.

It enables you to dip in to a specific chapter, like a good reference book, but it's far more seductive. The director has all the clips you could ask for and uses them intelligently to discuss the changing philosophy and psychology of Hollywood and independent cinema, the technical advances and the eternal struggle of art vs commerce. He's particularly astute on Busby Berkeley, film noir and the B-picture, whose directors he regards as "smugglers" sneaking subversive ideas past the Hays Code heavy mob. Scorsese's commentary is perfectly lucid but seems to come from the heart rather than the autocue. He adds a good range of directorial interviews including Wilder, Capra, Eastwood, Welles, Lang, Fuller, Cassavetes, Hawks and a hilariously monosyllabic John Ford. Scorsese's tape (the full title is A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American Movies) was originally a C4 series. In 224 minutes, it does its job with elegance, economy and wit, and it will make you want to see some of the more obscure films he provides tantalising glimpses of - T-Men, Shock Corridor or Detour, perhaps. The Rage - Carrie 2 Rental Warner Cert 18 ** A bad case of sequelitis at Bates High School as Katt Shea's loosely directed and very belated follow-up to Carrie provides an identikit plot, and makes the bad mistake of using clips from Brian de Palma's blinding original as memory flashbacks for its surviving character, Amy Irving. Once a tormenting teen, guilt-ridden Irving is now a teacher trying to help telekinetic pupil Emily Bergl avoid the disasters that befell Carrie 23 years ago. (Weirdly, given the age-gap, Bergl is her half-sister). Where Carrie had teens with distinct personalities, raging hormones and gleefully vindictive spite, The Rage just has a bunch of obnoxious rentadorks; where Carrie had cinema's only worthwhile prom scene, this just has a predictable ending. No Carrie 3, please. Wild Strawberries Retail (£15.99) Tartan Cert 15 **** Wild Strawberries starts with its central figure, 78-year-old Isak Berg having a frightening dream: a clock has no hands, a coffin falls off a hearse, a hand slips out of the coffin. After this memorably short, sharp shock (much imitated since), the rest of Ingmar Bergman's 1958 film is more reverie than nightmare as a trip with his daughter-in-law to pick up an honorary degree triggers memories of his life as the car fills up with strangers - three hitch-hikers and a bickering couple who have crashed their car. The film's main theme is emotional frigidity, but this is not the bleak, harsh Bergman of legend: it has great warmth and humour, especially in Berg's relationship with his housekeeper of 40 years. It's shot in a very relaxed manner by a director at the height of his powers with a performance of great dignity by Victor Sjostrom, himself a great Swedish director of the silent era. In lucid black and white with clear subtitles. Raiders of the Lost Fridge Retail (£14.99) Fox Pathé Cert PG *** "We want someone who doesn't immediately pooh-pooh everything he eats." "No, it usually takes a few hours." Homer becomes a food critic in Guess Who's Coming To Criticise Dinner, one of two Simpsons episodes new to me, along with King Size Homer in which the patriarch learns he's a fat man with an obese man struggling to get out. Also Burns Verkaufen der Kraftwerk (Kraftwerk = power station, rock fans) which includes Homer's wonderful Land of Chocolate daydream and Lisa the Vegetarian, which comes over all Paul & Linda on us.

fields.headline: The Ninth Gate
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This really is an exasperatingly boring film... A real miss
fields.body:
The Ninth Gate is a supernatural thriller produced and directed by Roman Polanski, starring Johnny Depp as Dean Corso, dealer in antiquarian books - a scholarly, recondite trade which Depp denotes by sporting a goatee, spectacles, and a canvas shoulder bag slung bandolier-style over his Oxfam coat, like a student from the 1980s. It is not clear how exactly Johnny acquired the aptitude or expertise for the job; I would like to have seen him frowning over, say, William Rees-Mogg's classic text How to Buy Rare Books. And the niceties of watermarks, chain-lines and slightly foxed endpapers do not detain him.

No, he is engaged by the sumptuously-named Bori Balkan (Frank Langella), a fleshy bibliophile, to track down the few remaining copies of The Nine Gates of the Kingdom of Shadows, a satanic manual which contains the runic clues and occult spells for calling up the Prince of Darkness. It really is a very boring book, and this really is an exasperatingly boring film, and it is incredible that it is from the man who long ago brought us authentically frightening films in which evil really means something. In fact, as Johnny scoots in and out of five-star hotel lobbies in Paris, it is closer to Polanski's dull 1988 film Frantic. A real miss.

fields.headline: Battlefield Earth
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: With this journey into the heart of rubbish, this full-throttle adventure into the hyper-space of drivel, Travolta not only incinerates what is left of his own reputation, but takes someone else down with him: Forest Whitaker
fields.body:
With his magnificent comeback in Tarantino's Pulp Fiction, John Travolta disproved the adage about there being no second acts in American lives. But now? Now - with his much cherished personal project Battlefield Earth, a gigantic sci-fi epic based on the personal vision of scientology maestro L Ron Hubbard? Now he seems to want a third act, together with curtain-calls, flowers, champagne and a laurel wreath to adorn that increasingly plump head of his. Now he tries our patience sorely.

In this latest opus, Mr Travolta essays the role of Terl, brutal Chief of Security on planet earth in 3000, which has been cruelly colonised by the Planet Psychlo, a place whose utter moral turpitude can be divined by the fact that it is the word "psycho" with an "l" in it. He has a huge, puffed-up elongated head - not that much different from his real head - and a sort of inflated face, paunchy body and claw-like hands, like Jackie "Mr TV" Pallo in panto.

Travolta's oppressive incarnation of evil is pitted against the force of human goodness in the form of earth rebel Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper) - leading an uprising of noble-savage homo sapiens types, who make a funny dog-like barking sound at (frequent) moments of excitement. With this journey into the heart of rubbish, this full-throttle adventure into the hyper-space of drivel, Travolta not only incinerates what is left of his own reputation, but takes someone else down with him: Forest Whitaker, making a prat of himself as Terl's sidekick.

fields.headline: U-571
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A very efficient, action-packed movie with some terrific thrills and excitement, written and directed with gusto
fields.body:
Now that the Dunkirk anniversary is upon us, it is time for Hollywood cheerfully to erase from the record one of Britain's great maritime triumphs from the second world war. Just as Saving Private Ryan saluted the British involvement in D-Day by having Sam from Cheers call Montgomery "overrated", so U-571 is inspired by the Royal Navy's capture of an Enigma code machine from a sinking, stricken U-boat during the battle of the Atlantic, thus scoring a stunning strategic blow for the Allies - only for the movie, the British element is corrected to American.

The bug-eyed Texan Matthew McConaughey is Lt Andrew Tyler, the hero supported by a somewhat unlikely and overweight-looking Harvey Keitel as his doggedly loyal chief. Here and there U-571 looks a little like Das Boot or Crimson Tide, and there is even a moment where it modifies Jack Hawkins's "But there are some chaps in the water!" line from The Cruel Sea. Familiar it may be, but for the most part, U-571 is a very efficient, action-packed movie with some terrific thrills and excitement, written and directed with gusto by Jonathan Mostow.

fields.headline: Maybe Baby
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw takes the temperature of Ben Elton's adaptation of his own infertility novel
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: When most of British film-making is so brain-dead and scandalously bad, Ben Elton and BBC Films have made a respectable film, which promises to get plenty of laughs - and its investment back at the box office
fields.body:
"That's very good! That's very funny!" It takes a special kind of chutzpah, a real head for heights, to make one of the characters in your film a writer, and then make him lavish writerly praise on the dialogue you've written for him to overhear.

But such a writer, and now such a film-maker is Ben Elton, that prodigiously industrious man whose fate it has been to be patronised by pundits with a fraction of his abilities, and despite having written one of the most brilliant west end stage comedies of the 90s in the form of Gasping, and a gripping Hollywood novel in Popcorn, destined to have each new product discussed only in relation to a dimly-remembered past as the spangly-jacketed scourge of Thatch.

His debut film, Maybe Baby, follows so closely on the heels of his novel, Inconceivable, that it isn't an adaptation so much as the second prong of a multi-media pincer-movement on the cinemagoing public.

The speaker is Hugh Laurie, playing Sam, a lovely, gentle chap who is trying for a baby with his delectable wife Lucy (Joely Richardson). On their combined salaries as BBC producer and agent, they are evidently able to afford a sumptuous riverside apartment, whose spectacular views are glimpsed by day and - with twinkling lights - by night. Together, they endure the indignities of IVF with regulation self-deprecatory humour and unhappily undiminished physical ardour. There is a prime example of what Ben Elton, in his genteel way, calls a "knob gag": "I've seen harder knobs on the door of a bouncy castle!"

But Lucy is on the verge of an affair with a dishy actor, and Sam commits an adultery of the mind. Against her wishes, he is plagiarising their life and Lucy's observations for a film he is secretly writing - about a lovely, gentle chap and his delectable wife trying for a baby. (His chortling line about something being very good and very funny is in tribute to an artless remark of Lucy's about wishing she'd had her bikini line done, wanting to look her best for the gynaecologist.)

In the novel, Lucy and Sam tell the story alternately from their diaries, a neat, epistolary device which gives unmediated access to the principals' minds and also fabricates an effect of authenticity in representing that trickiest of things for the male writer: the woman's point of view. Elton keeps the diaries for the film but it is a small, but distinct triumph for his directorial debut that he is able to keep it together without translating them into smirking voiceovers.

There are many things to drive you mad with irritation in this film. The legion of Britcom superstars in gaggy, sitcommy walk-on roles is often just appalling. When Dawn French bustles on as the comedy Australian nurse who packs Hugh off to a cubicle for a discreet "five-knuckle shuffle", all you can do is shut your eyes, put your fingers in your ears and wait for this unteachably smug and unfunny cameo to be over. And, frankly, hanging, flogging and electronic tagging are too good for Emma Thompson as Desiree, the New Agey hippy woman who tells them to have it off on a ley-line. As the consultant, Rowan Atkinson at least has a funny line about his moped.

The film's most insultingly unfunny and unconvincing character is a shouting BBC executive who bullies our Hugh about the need to get into film production. Like many of the supporting cast, he has a mute retinue of hangers-on, pouting, glowering, slouching and taking unfunniness and unconvincingness to a new level. He, and they, are from sitcom land and don't stand up to big-screen scrutiny. Tellingly, Richard Curtis keeps this kind of very broad characterisation under control in his movies. Furthermore, the executive, often seen against huge and not-quite-up-to-the-minute slogans reading "Stay On Message", snaps: "British movies have never been hipper!" - a line clearly conceived when they actually were hip, and when making fun of their hipness was an affordable luxury.

Yet set against all this are perfectly decent, watchable performances from Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson, who are endowed with a sweetly comic existence by Elton, never ranging too far into ickiness, and directed with clarity and assurance. Laurie was the redemptive presence in the sick-making Peter's Friends, then playing a grieving father with dignity, intelligence and restraint. He brings all these qualities into Maybe Baby, together with an insouciant lightness, and Joely Richardson induces the souffle of light comedy to rise perfectly satisfactorily.

The younger, and more radical Ben Elton might have realised the ironies embedded in a well-off couple from the prosperous west straining for an IVF baby, while the developing countries struggle with overpopulation and poverty. But he gives no hint of that here, which is perhaps a blessing, considering his propensity for right-on solemnity. When most of British film-making is so brain-dead and scandalously bad, Ben Elton and BBC Films have made a respectable film, which promises to get plenty of laughs - and its investment back at the box office.

fields.headline: James Wong
fields.trailText: James Wong
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

One of the Monkey series in Hong Kong. I don't know the name but I remember the female star flying through the air, slicing everyone up.

What's your favourite film?

Apocalypse Now. It embodied artistic film-making and made me realise I should become a film-maker.

When did you last walk out of the cinema?

I nearly walked out of The Cook, The Thief, His Wife and Her Lover. It was the first date with my wife and I wanted to impress her. The guy at the beginning pissing and rubbing shit over a person didn't help. At least we both laugh about it now.

The most erotic scene?

Greta Scacchi in The Coca-Cola Kid. She's in a Santa Claus costume and when she undresses, feathers fly everywhere.

What's the most annoying habit in cinema?

Directors using people they know for cameos.

When did you last you snog at the movies?

Ages ago with a high-school girlfriend named Sandie. I wouldn't think of doing it now.

When did you last hide under your seat?

In The Exorcist, when the mother hears noises from the attic.

And the last time you cried?

Old Yeller, when the man shoots his dog which has caught rabies. Earlier the dog had saved him from the same fate.

Your favourite snatch of dialogue?

"Who wrote this stinking burger?" from My Favourite Year.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Jackie Chan. He's a super-star, funny and acrobatic, and my mom knows who he is.

Which actress?

Claudette Colbert, especially in It Happened One Night. No other woman can deliver dialogue in such a funny way.

Which film character?

Indiana Jones.

Will you be working on the sequel to Final Destination?

No, it should have fresh input and we don't want to do another horror movie for a while. We are working on different ventures, such as a new TV show with Spielberg.

 James Wong is the director of Final Destination, now on general release.

fields.headline: Into Africa
fields.standfirst: Arthur Howes on veteran film-maker Jean Rouch, who is the star of an ICA documentary season
fields.trailText: Arthur Howes on veteran film-maker Jean Rouch, who is the star of an ICA documentary season
fields.body:
With a prolific output of more than 90 films, Jean Rouch at a youthful 82 continues producing an imposing body of work. Twenty of his films will be screening at London's ICA over the next 10 days. Moi un Noir (1959), Rouch's first feature film - praised by Jean-Luc Godard as the greatest French film since the liberation - will screen for the second time ever to a public audience in London.

Moi un Noir is raw cinema with an enormous vitality and spontaneity, closer to the free improvisational methods in the early work of John Cassavetes and Shirley Clarke - except that with Rouch, unlike Cassavetes, we are never quite sure whether we are witnessing actors or real people. The main character of this film is Oumaru Ganda, a young migrant worker from Niger surviving precariously as a dock worker in the slum area of Trashville in Abdijan on the Ivory Coast. Oumaru takes the pseudonym of Edward G Robinson, the American film star.

The film is an account of a week in the life of Robinson and his friends. It can be viewed as an exposure of the conflicts between a traditional way of life and the western values encroaching upon it; as a conflict of life, dream and desires; and as a document that attempts to expose the joys and anxieties of the African urban generation in the late 50s.

The visuals, which were shot mute, are accompanied by a commentary from Robinson, a monologue in which he expresses his aspirations, his uncertainties and his day-to-day realities. It has an overpowering sense of honesty, intimacy and poignancy - a quality that can be at least partly attributed to the power of the spoken word in an oral society.

Moi un Noir is an interplay of styles. The dialogue is never in synch, the camera restless and handheld, the editing dynamic. It also anticipates many of the cinematic styles which were to change the vocabulary of cinema when taken up by the French New Wave: specifically, the jump-cut; the use of fiction constructed with the stylistic devices of documentary film; the handheld camera; voiceover commentary; the actor addressing the camera; shooting sequences with minimal lighting; and the use of advertisements, posters and slogans as punctuation. No wonder Godard, writing for Cahiers du Cinema, says: "Everything, in effect, is completely new in Jean Rouch's film - script, shooting and sound recording. We are presented with a text of wonderful verve and spontaneity... his film consequently offers the open sesame to poetry."

On a more sober note, but no less innovative, is Chronicle of a Summer (Chronique d'un été, 1960). This is Rouch's best known work, the film that redefined the documentary and was arguably responsible for spawning the term cinema vérité. Chronicle of a Summer was co-directed with the sociologist Edgar Morin and made use for the first time of new technology: a portable 16mm lightweight handheld camera with a portable synchronised sound recorder. Though this was only 40 years ago, it was the first time film crews could be reduced to two, a camera person and a sound recordist, who could now walk the streets of Paris, filming and recording simultaneously.

The film opens with a random sample of passers-by being asked: "How do you live?" Gradually the answers develop into explorations of politics, loneliness, memory, work and alienation. The film is both a portrait of Paris life in the summer of 1960, and an examination of the difficulty of making an honest film, of the inevitable gap between reality as lived and reality as filmed.

Screening in this programme are many of the early African short films by Rouch. From his early 50s films it is definitely worth catching the memorable Les Maîtres Fous (The Mad Masters), by far the most controversial and sensational film in the programme. Les Maîtres Fous, banned by the British government in the 50s, was supposedly the inspiration for Genet's play The Blacks, and an influence on Peter Brook's theatre production of Marat-Sade.

The 36-minute film follows a possession ceremony of the Hauka sect in Ghana during British colonial rule. After a series of public confessions around an altar in a forest clearing, a group of men enter into a state of collective possession. We expect the initiated to be possessed by spirits of their ancestors - but no, the possessed are taken over by the spirits of "power" personified in the form of the oppressors, the English ruling class, the colonial masters in Ghana.

Mimicking and writhing in frantic caricatures of their "Mad Masters," the possessed become the colonial officials - the English governor, the lieutenant, the doctor and his wife, the governor's secretary. This hysterical ritual culminates with the sacrificial killing and eating of a dog. The Hauka, being Muslim, undergo total debasement by eating the dog, which is strictly forbidden in Islam.

The following day we revisit the Hauka again. They are relaxed and happy. Rouch's commentary concludes the film: "When you compare these faces to yesterday's horrible faces you cannot help but ask whether these men know of some remedies which allow them not to be abnormal, but perfectly integrated to their surroundings." Rouch's commentary points out that by acting out and identifying with aspects of European power, this frenzied possession achieves a psychotherapeutic function that allows the Hauka to overcome the tensions of colonialism. The anxieties that accumulate when traditional life is disrupted by colonialism express themselves through acts of hysteria and self-debasement, which allows the Hauka to conform to their present social condition.

Unlike Les Maîtres Fous, where Rouch attempts to explain and position the ritual within a socio-political context, Robert Gardner in Forests of Bliss does the opposite. This is a feature-length film with no voice-over, no facts, no information and no subtitles. It is a film of absolute visual poetry, as incomprehensible and hypnotic as magic and religion, requiring from the viewer only to succumb to the experience.

Shot by Gardner in Benares, India, in the 80s, Forests of Bliss relies purely on the aesthetic capacity of the filmed image and the exquisite use, and editing, of sound to create feelings and mood of place. It is a film that reinforces our capacity as passing travellers in a city of temples, a holy city of incomprehensible rituals and a labyrinth of circling passageways that lead to the river Ganges and eventually to death.

Whereas Forests of Bliss is often criticised for being too sensuous and apolitical, the opposite can be said of N'ai - The Story of a Kung Woman. In 1951, co-director John Marshall, at the age of 17, started filming with a clockwork wind-up Bolex camera with no sound, and completed filming in 1978. He made several seminal short films on the Kung San people of Namibia; but also, from all this film shot over a period of 28 years, one major film emerged.

N'ai - The Story of a Kung Woman is narrated by the 33-year-old N'ai, who is dependent on food aid and is living in the desolate waste grounds of a relocation camp in Namibia. Facing the camera, she begins to tell her story: "Before the white people came, I was a young girl..." Through flashbacks and juxtaposition the tragedy of the Kung San people unfolds. The living conditions of N'ai and her family are intercut with earlier sequences filmed from her life: her childhood, her marriage at the age of eight, the arrival of the white man, the arrival of the church, the army and the war. It is an extraordinarily powerful testament to the degradation and the damage done to a people who were once self-sufficient and autonomous.

These are only a few of a stunning programme of films, seminal works within the history of documentary cinema. You won't see them on television, and they are rarely, or never, seen in this country.

 Possessing Vision starts today, and runs to June 11, at the ICA, London SW1. Details: 020-7930 3647.
fields.bodyText: With a prolific output of more than 90 films, Jean Rouch at a youthful 82 continues producing an imposing body of work. Twenty of his films will be screening at London's ICA over the next 10 days. Moi un Noir (1959), Rouch's first feature film - praised by Jean-Luc Godard as the greatest French film since the liberation - will screen for the second time ever to a public audience in London. Moi un Noir is raw cinema with an enormous vitality and spontaneity, closer to the free improvisational methods in the early work of John Cassavetes and Shirley Clarke - except that with Rouch, unlike Cassavetes, we are never quite sure whether we are witnessing actors or real people. The main character of this film is Oumaru Ganda, a young migrant worker from Niger surviving precariously as a dock worker in the slum area of Trashville in Abdijan on the Ivory Coast. Oumaru takes the pseudonym of Edward G Robinson, the American film star. The film is an account of a week in the life of Robinson and his friends. It can be viewed as an exposure of the conflicts between a traditional way of life and the western values encroaching upon it; as a conflict of life, dream and desires; and as a document that attempts to expose the joys and anxieties of the African urban generation in the late 50s. The visuals, which were shot mute, are accompanied by a commentary from Robinson, a monologue in which he expresses his aspirations, his uncertainties and his day-to-day realities. It has an overpowering sense of honesty, intimacy and poignancy - a quality that can be at least partly attributed to the power of the spoken word in an oral society. Moi un Noir is an interplay of styles. The dialogue is never in synch, the camera restless and handheld, the editing dynamic. It also anticipates many of the cinematic styles which were to change the vocabulary of cinema when taken up by the French New Wave: specifically, the jump-cut; the use of fiction constructed with the stylistic devices of documentary film; the handheld camera; voiceover commentary; the actor addressing the camera; shooting sequences with minimal lighting; and the use of advertisements, posters and slogans as punctuation. No wonder Godard, writing for Cahiers du Cinema, says: "Everything, in effect, is completely new in Jean Rouch's film - script, shooting and sound recording. We are presented with a text of wonderful verve and spontaneity... his film consequently offers the open sesame to poetry." On a more sober note, but no less innovative, is Chronicle of a Summer (Chronique d'un été, 1960). This is Rouch's best known work, the film that redefined the documentary and was arguably responsible for spawning the term cinema vérité. Chronicle of a Summer was co-directed with the sociologist Edgar Morin and made use for the first time of new technology: a portable 16mm lightweight handheld camera with a portable synchronised sound recorder. Though this was only 40 years ago, it was the first time film crews could be reduced to two, a camera person and a sound recordist, who could now walk the streets of Paris, filming and recording simultaneously. After a series of public confessions around an altar in a forest clearing, a group of men enter into a state of collective possession. We expect the initiated to be possessed by spirits of their ancestors - but no, the possessed are taken over by the spirits of "power" personified in the form of the oppressors, the English ruling class, the colonial masters in Ghana. Mimicking and writhing in frantic caricatures of their "Mad Masters," the possessed become the colonial officials - the English governor, the lieutenant, the doctor and his wife, the governor's secretary. This hysterical ritual culminates with the sacrificial killing and eating of a dog. The Hauka, being Muslim, undergo total debasement by eating the dog, which is strictly forbidden in Islam. fields.headline: Web triumph for Guardian
fields.standfirst:
New Media Age awards
New Media Age
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian's website, last night won its fifth major award this year. It won best consumer site in the New Media Age awards.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian's website, last night won its fifth major award this year. It won best consumer site in the New Media Age awards.

The citation from the judges said: "Over the last year it has gradually become clearer that the Guardian was one of the few media organisations to forge a rock solid online strategy. Its niche sites were tailor-made for the web and it has not stood still, moving on to other platforms faster and further than many other larger and richer companies."

Guardian Unlimited also won the digital advertising sponsorship and brand awareness award.

webTitle: Comic trio enjoy financial rewards of a sample life

fields.headline: Comic trio enjoy financial rewards of a sample life
fields.trailText: A London DJ's first chart hit has proved lucrative for a comedy trio who have successfully claimed publishing rights for a sample used in the track.
fields.body:
A London DJ's first chart hit has proved lucrative for a comedy trio who have successfully claimed publishing rights for a sample used in the track.

"I Don't Smoke (Da Reefa)", by Dee Kline, a DJ for Flex FM, has been a nationwide club favourite for a year with its: "I don't smoke cigarettes, I don't smoke cigars, I don't smoke a pipe" lyric.

Dee Kline's tune was heard by Dan Tetsell in March while shopping in central London. Mr Tetsell, 25, from Stoke Newington, north-east London, noted the voice of stand-up comedian Marcus Brigstocke intoning: "Do you smoke, Paul?"

After making inquiries he discovered his line, from a sketch originally performed in 1997 as part of a Bristol University revue by Brigstocke, Tetsell and Danny Robins, was reprised in 1998 for Channel 4's ill fated comedy sketch show Barking and taken as a sample on Dee Kline's record.

An agent for the trio secured publishing rights to the track that entered the charts last week at number 11.

Dee Kline, 21, who first heard the line on a friend's voicemail, will make his debut on Top of the Pops tonight with MC Hyperactive providing lyrics.

Brigstocke, whose voice appeared on the track, was not invited to perform. But he said: "We've already been paid much more for this than the original work we did. Which is nice."

webTitle: Police urge vigilance after Hammersmith bombing

fields.headline: Police urge vigilance after Hammersmith bombing
fields.trailText:
Police were today urging members of the public to be vigilant as the hunt continued for bombers who damaged London's
Hammersmith Bridge.
fields.body:
Police were today urging members of the public to be vigilant as the hunt continued for bombers who damaged London's Hammersmith Bridge.

Fifty officers worked through the night stopping passers-by on both sides of the Thames at Hammersmith and on neighbouring west London bridges, in a bid to find witnesses who saw anything suspicious.

More than 24 hours after the explosion, no group has admitted planting the bomb, amid speculation that it was the work of dissident Irish republicans.

Security was being stepped up as police last night confirmed that the device comprised between 1kg and 2kg of high explosive, and was fully detonated.

Anti-terrorist officers supported by uniform officers stopped members of the public on neighbouring west London road bridges in Chiswick and Putney from about 1am today.

"We are speaking to motorists and passers-by who may have been in the area during that time period the previous night," said a Scotland Yard spokeswoman.

"We will be asking if they saw anyone acting suspiciously near the bridge or in a car before the explosion."

Deputy assistant commissioner Alan Fry, the head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, urged people to be vigilant in the wake of the attack. "I am asking people that if they see a suspect package to contact us immediately on 999."

He added there would be more high visibility policing on London's streets in the wake of the bomb and said measures would be taken to reassure the public.

"I can tell you police had no prior notice - no threatening calls or anybody claiming responsibility."

Asked if there was a possible link with Irish terrorists he said: "I am not going to speculate but clearly they would be a line of inquiry."

The bomb went off without warning at around 4.30am yesterday, causing traffic chaos. The device, attached to a girder on the bridge, caused structural damage but no injuries. Residents living nearby described how windows in their homes were blown out by the force of the blast. The bridge might be closed to pedestrians and traffic for a number of weeks while engineers assess the damage and ensure the structure is safe.

The attack triggered a number of hoax calls including warnings a device had been planted in the Dartford Tunnel in Kent, causing it to be closed for 35 minutes.

Hammersmith bridge has been targeted twice before by terrorists, the last time in 1996 when the most-powerful Semtex bomb ever used by the IRA on the mainland failed to go off.

Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor said dissident republicans trying to destabilise the peace process could have been behind the blast.

"If it's terrorist-linked I would expect it to be the breakaway groups within the republican movement, something like the Real IRA or the Continuity IRA," he said.

"Clearly, their objective now is to upset the Provisional IRA programme of putting arms out of use. It must always be remembered there are minority republican terrorist groups still on the ground, still potentially active."

Terrorism expert David George agreed that the attack was most probably the work of the Real/Continuity IRA, which broke from the Provisionals three years ago.

The bomb would have been planted by a small cell of activists, so-called "lilywhites" with no link to republican activities, who probably travelled from Northern Ireland, said Mr George, a lecturer in terrorism at Newcastle University.

If dissident republicans were involved, then this would be the first time they have launched an attack in mainland Britain.

fields.headline: Whitehall's secret warfare
fields.standfirst:
An attack on Dame Stella reveals the ugly dispute behind the scenes

More about Melita Norwood and the Mitrokhin archive
Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: An astonishing diatribe was unleashed the other day against Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5 who has submitted her memoirs for Whitehall vetting.
fields.body:
An astonishing diatribe was unleashed the other day against Dame Stella Rimington, the former head of MI5 who has submitted her memoirs for Whitehall vetting. "However little she writes," it was claimed, "she will provide data and information which will confirm existing or create new intelligence for those countries who are hostile to the United Kingdom and those political, terrorist and international criminal organisations that choose this country as a base, killing ground or marketplace".

It went on: "If she makes money by writing why should not others of lower rank? . . . It will make no difference if she and her publisher agree to so many deletions that her book has become emasculated. It is the principle of not putting pen to paper that matters."

It added: "All members of the country's security forces should keep silent about their work, for life. When there is a requirement to publish, it is the government alone who should do so." The bitter rant, which appeared in the letter columns of the Times, was not a missive from some retired blimp residing in a home counties vicarage. It was written by David Lyon, colonel commandant of the SAS.

The extraordinary public spectacle of of such an attack by a serving soldier on the former head of the Security Service, a woman once widely respected by the Whitehall establishment, reflects the ferocity of the dispute provoked by Dame Stella's initiative.

It is a key issue on the increasingly crowded agenda of a sinister committee of officials from the darker corners of Whitehall which meets at the Cabinet Office. The official title of the committee is an official secret, appropriately perhaps, given that its task is to suppress information. It is an offshoot of the joint intelligence committee chaired by a diplomat, Michael Pakenham, son of Lord Longford.

P arties to this spectacular Whitehall dispute include David Omand, permanent secretary at the Home Office, said to be on the side of the doves. Stephen Lander, Dame Stella's successor at MI5, is said to have calmed down after initially expressing alarm. In the hawks' camp, along with the SAS and the ministry of defence, is MI6, headed by Richard Dearlove. MI6, even more protective than MI5 about its secrets, is being blamed in Whitehall for leaking Rimington's intentions to the Sun.

MI6, it is said, wanted to get its own back on its "sister service" and its former head, who in her time dominated Whitehall committees in her pursuit of an ever-expanding role for MI5. A key figure in the row is Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, who says he has Tony Blair's ear. The prime minister, he tells the Pakenham committee, takes an ex tremely hard line on the need to prosecute all renegade spooks and silence any journalist who writes about them.

Other ministers have no say in all this. They do not attend meetings of Pakenham's committee. Foreign secretary Robin Cook - to whom MI6 is nominally responsible - and Peter Hain, his minister of state, say they are horrified by the way the secret police are threatening to send journalists to jail. Apparently they can do nothing about it. Meanwhile, a battery of government lawyers waits in the wings, ready to fire off their next injunction, or court order demanding newspapers (including the Guardian, the Observer, and the Sunday Times) hand over material to help Whitehall in its battles against renegade spooks.

Across the road from the Cabinet Office, a secret MoD cell has obtained no fewer than nine injunctions preventing former members of the special forces from blowing the whistle. Among them is "Martin Ingram", the pseudonym of a former undercover intelligence officer in Northern Ireland. Police in pursuit of him recently burgled a house and his manuscript was stolen. Liam Clarke, the Sunday Times Northern Ireland editor has been summoned to the MoD and advised to bring a lawyer with him. Fortunately neither this MoD cell nor Lyon succeeded in preventing soldiers from making startling revelations to Peter Taylor, presenter of the BBC trilogy, Brits, which ended this week.

Last week Nigel Wylde, a former army officer awarded the Queen's gallantry medal for his working defusing bombs, was committed for trial at the Old Bailey. His alleged crime? Disclosing information about how army computers secretly monitor the activities of two thirds of the population in Northern Ireland. Army sources concede he has done no damage to national security.

This is not the point at issue, despite Lyon's outburst. It is the right of whistleblowers and the media in a so-called mature democracy to reveal the past activities of our secret services. Instead of relying on unaccountable and self-serving members of a secret committee, ministers should wake up and set up a credible and independent vetting system for former spooks - and repeal the Official Secrets Act.

webTitle: Steadied by the British, and with the world on their side

fields.headline: Steadied by the British, and with the world on their side
fields.standfirst:
Martin Woollacott in Sierra Leone The regime's spine is stiffened - for now

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone is a place whose inhabitants have often feared that the order they had established would be overwhelmed, by outside forces, by internal decline, or by a combination of both factors.
fields.body:
Soon after midday, schoolgirls in their royal blue gymslips begin to toil up Spur Road in Freetown on their way home from the big school down the hill, the smaller ones shielding their pigtailed heads against the sun with opened exercise books. Nigerian troops hang their socks out to dry on the verandas of abandoned villas, while the white Toyotas of ministers buzz up and down on their way to and from the president's lodge on the crest. Above, British helicopters beat breathlessly through the heated air. Such scenes, strangely mixing the normal and the abnormal, can be seen everywhere in Freetown, a city at once dilapidated and lively, damaged but under repair, pathetic in its weaknesses and admirable in its strengths.

Sierra Leone is a place whose inhabitants have often feared that the order they had established would be overwhelmed, by outside forces, by internal decline, or by a combination of both factors. A century ago, after massacres of Freetown traders and missionaries in the interior, the city feared that the tribesmen would soon be at the gates. "Shall the property, the labour of years . . . be given up and destroyed in a day: shall the lives of innocent British subjects be abandoned to savage butchery?" asked the Sierra Leone Weekly News in 1899. The free blacks from Britain and the West Indies and the recaptured slaves who settled on the Sierra Leone penin sula regarded themselves as in the forefront of the British civilising and missionary effort in west Africa. Conversely, they often feared that this effort would falter and that they themselves would become the victims of a resurgence of dark forces. That is how some of them still see the story today.

In 1899, British ships and troops were soon on hand. The 12-gun cruiser Blake steamed into the harbour, boosting local confidence, as columns of soldiers moved inland against the rebels. The reappearance of the British a month ago thus seems to people in Sierra Leone to represent the restoration of the proper pattern of history, in which Europe and America, and Britain in particular, recognise their connection to, and responsibility for, the state of civilisation in west Africa. That may sound overdone or neo-colonialist, but there is a sense in which it is nevertheless true. What was, and is, at stake in Sierra Leone is far more than the fate of a single city.

On the 48th floor of the United Nations building in New York, where the Secretary General and his aides confer, there must have been moments last month when it seemed that the end of peacekeeping, not just in Africa but worldwide, was in sight. Was Kofi Annan's campaign to revive and expand peacekeeping to end ignominiously, as the UN contingents fell back and Freetown was put to the sword? There is little doubt that the arrival of the British did avert an occupation of the city by the Rev olutionary United Front, and thus saved the UN from a disaster that would have been hugely damaging to its operations everywhere.

There are theatres of war, and there is theatre in war, and Sierra Leone has both. The British armed forces have for years been exponents of moral ascendancy - the phrase used by one of the Falklands commander, Jeremy Moore - and of the decisive importance of establishing "normal" conditions among threatened populations, whether in Belfast or Freetown.

They have of course fought here only at the edges, instead putting on what one aid agency worker calls "a circus" including ships offshore, Harriers overhead, and soldiers on the ground. But it has been a circus that has had the intended effect, at least for the time being. One government adviser, after a trip to the British at Lungi International airport, enthused that "in everything they do, and from their body language, you see that they are disciplined, that they know their job . . . they should be a model to our soldiers, who only shout at each other."

The second, far more fearful circus, which the British by these means have sought to disrupt, is that of the RUF, who have risen to command territory and diamonds in Sierra Leone by the repetition of a formula of calculated atrocity and of coercive recruitment that has been undeniably efficient. Those who have studied the RUF see logic in its amputations, murders and rapes. They both intimidate the larger society and cement the separation from it of the perpetrators. In a society without opportunity, some young people may see the only advancement available to them to lie in becoming apprentices to war, which is then their education. Whatever real political content the RUF may once have had, and many would say it never had more than a fraudulent programme, it is strong in Sierra Leone mainly because of the replication of evil technique that it brought with it from Liberia nine years ago.

The power and the terror of that technique led many in Sierra Leone to believe that the RUF could not be successfully resisted, and it is this readiness to accept defeat that those who deploy the British forces have sought to dispel. Attitude, the British teach, is half the battle.

In this war of morale the third ring of the circus is that represented by the United Nations. Sent here to supervise a process of compromise and reconciliation, the UN force has now inevitably been drawn into the campaign to achieve ascendancy over the RUF. Such an on the spot assessment of a current UN operation is almost unheard of, and it is an indication of New York's sense of urgency.
