fields.headline: Empty encounters
fields.standfirst:
Clinton's visit to Putin will achieve little. He has failed with Moscow and Russia still has the Chechen problem

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Clinton's visit to Putin will achieve little. He has failed with Moscow and Russia still has the Chechen problem
fields.body:
It would be easy to dismiss Bill Clinton's visit to Vladimir Putin in Moscow this weekend as the powerless in pursuit of the faceless. Lameduck American president with dwindling influence meets new-boy Russian counterpart who has no programme. So no agreements of any significance can be expected.

Yet this policy vacuum is not just dictated by the electoral calendar. It highlights a much deeper crisis and a need for radical choices. On the western side, the empty encounter in Moscow epitomises the failure of Clinton's Russian project in every field - political, economic and strategic. Back in 1993 when Clinton held his first summit with a Russian president, he and his advisers hoped gradually to transform their defeated cold war enemy into a democratic market economy and a partner in for eign affairs. But every step they took worked against their stated goals.

In the fierce arguments between the Kremlin and the Russian parliament over the distribution of power, which was the big theme of 1993, the US president repeatedly urged Boris Yeltsin to impose executive supremacy by closing parliament down and changing the constitution. Instead of a democracy with checks and balances, Russia became what Lilya Shevtsova, one of its best independent analysts calls, "an elective autocracy". This was confirmed in 1996, when with full Clinton support Yeltsin combined American advertising techniques with ruthless editorial control of TV, partly still under state ownership and partly in the hands of friendly oligarchs, to demonise the opposition and win re-election.

Russia's economic reforms were as badly distorted as its path to pluralism. The corruption-prone privatisation which the west encouraged, the failure to regulate the new private banks, and the transfer of the country's energy resources to Kremlin cronies led to a haemorrhage of national capital into off-shore accounts. In response, western financial institutions merely stepped up pressure for cuts in government spending to stem the budget deficit. The result was a massive drop in industrial output and the pauperisation of millions.

In foreign affairs Clinton's campaign to expand Nato eastwards alienated Russians of all political persuasions and is still at the core of the country's suspicions of the west. It has been compounded by Washington's continuing efforts to woo the former Soviet republics of Central Asia, and divert their oil and gas reserves as well as those of the Caspian, from flowing through Russia.

So the fact that an unknown ex-KGB man with illiberal instincts was nominated by the financial oligarchy to exploit another flawed electoral process and become Russia's new leader is in part a measure of Clinton's mistakes. Russian factors, of course, also play a role. The country's long history of authoritarianism, its power-holders' inability to accept a legitimate role for opposition, and the intelligentsia's habits of swinging wildly from servility to alienation, meant that the transition to democracy should have been handled more gradually and with greater sensitivity.

Now Russia stands at a new crossroads. Its internal policies are moving away from western control since rising oil prices have given it the first chance of growth for a decade, as well as less need for foreign loans.

But it faces a key strategic choice in foreign affairs. During the Yeltsin period it veered from subservient pro-westernism under Andrei Kozyrev as foreign minister to an emphasis on "multi- polarity" under Yevgeni Primakov. Some Moscow think-tanks are now counselling "selective engagement" with the west and a pronounced orientation towards Europe.

This makes sense for several reasons. The switch towards close relations with China, which Primakov encouraged, was largely a reaction to Nato's expansion and a way of cocking a snook at the west. Russia needs good relations with its largest Asian neighbour, but to make them a lever for solving problems in other regions is dangerous.

The external changes which will affect Russia most in the next half-decade are not in Asia, but Europe. They are the gradual enlargement of the European Union, the slow build-up of a European defence identity, and the future shape of Nato. Putin was right recently to stress that Russia is a European state, and to affirm this by inviting EU leaders to Moscow this week before Clinton comes. Russia can no longer pretend to a global role, no more than European powers can, whether individually or as the European Union. But Russia needs to engage closely with Europe for economic and well as political reasons. If it is to have any hope of delaying the further expansion of Nato - which would be good for most Europeans, and not just Russia - it must work hard in Europe to show it can be a genuine long-term partner.

For that to happen Russia must end its Chechen folly. Having secured his election with the Chechen war, Putin has a chance to enhance his foreign policy by ending it through dialogue with Chechen leaders and an acceptance that atrocities against civilians only provide new grounds for Chechen resentment. The values which the Chechen operation have so far embodied cannot help Russia's cause in Europe.

webTitle: Will Bush step in to save deathrow convict?

fields.headline: Will Bush step in to save deathrow convict?
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush, the Republican presidential contender, hinted yesterday that he would grant a stay of execution for the first time in more than five years as governor of Texas, arguing that a death-row convict has the right to a DNA test.
fields.body:
George W Bush, the Republican presidential contender, hinted yesterday that he would grant a stay of execution for the first time in more than five years as governor of Texas, arguing that a death-row convict has the right to a DNA test.

With only hours to go before his scheduled execution, Ricky McGinn told the Guardian he was innocent of the rape and axe-murder of his stepdaughter seven years ago, and appealed to the governor to give him a chance to prove it.

"It would help his political career to give a man a chance to prove his innocence," McGinn said in an interview at the Terrell Unit high-security prison near Livingston.

His fate has become a politically charged test case for the use of DNA in US criminal appeals, at a time when a group of lawyers and politicians is pushing for legislation granting prisoners an automatic right to genetic "fingerprinting" to prove their innocence.

The new measures are being opposed by prosecutors who say they will be used by convicts as a delaying tactic to slow down the justice system.

After a man was exonerated of a rape two years ago, thanks to DNA testing, a Texas county clerk's office destroyed "rape kits" which preserved genetic evidence from 50 other old cases.

Lee Haney, the prosecutor in McGinn's case, has argued against the DNA tests, saying that the outcome should not affect his conviction.

McGinn spoke to the Guardian a day after the Texas court of criminal appeals rejected his appeal for DNA tests of semen and hair found on the body of Stephanie Flanary, 12, who was found dead in a ditch in 1993.

Police found her blood in McGinn's car and an axe with her blood on it in the back of his van.

But police only found the axe four days after the girl disappeared and after three previous searches of the same vehicle. Witness testimony also suggested that the girl's body only appeared in the roadside ditch after McGinn had been arrested.

McGinn claims he was framed by a policeman in the Brown County sheriff's office.

"He told me in 1987 I better get out of Brown county," he said. "My little girl was killed after she saw a cop selling drugs at her school. Then that policeman was the one who came back and found the so-called weapon. He came back and just happens to find it. It's kind of strange."

The McGinn case has focused attention on Mr Bush's record on capital punishment in an election year. He has overseen a record 131 executions since his election as Texas governor. He has commuted one death sentence on the recommendation of the state's parole board, but before yesterday had never exercised his right to grant a 30-day stay of execution.

The death penalty is not normally a political issue in US elections, as a significant majority of the population supports capital punishment.

However, after a string of cases in which convicts were proved innocent - some with the help of DNA evidence - after spending years on death row, the Illinois governor, George Ryan, declared a moratorium on executions earlier this year. Several other states are considering following his lead.

Advances in DNA analysis have boosted the moves towards reform. The FBI recently released figures showing that out of 18,000 DNA tests it carried out in rape cases in recent years, 26% had ruled out the principal suspect.

Mr Bush has voiced support for DNA tests in capital cases. Asked about McGinn's case he said: "I'm inclined to [intervene] because I want the man to have his full day in court. If there is any doubt, any outstanding evidence that exon erates him from the rape, we ought to look at it."

A spokeswoman for Mr Bush said yesterday that he was waiting for a regional appeal court to carry out an 11th-hour examination of McGinn's case before stepping in, but political observers in Texas said they thought he was almost certain to grant the 30-day reprieve if the court turns down the prisoner's appeal.

If a DNA test proves that the semen and pubic hair found on Stephanie Flanary is not McGinn's it would technically clear him of the rape, not the murder. But without an "aggravating factor" in the killing, it would not be a capital offence under Texas law.

"I live on hope and faith that he will do the right thing," McGinn said. "Like everyone else I would like to live a hundred more years, as long as it was not another hundred years in this place."

He added: "If I am to die, I hope that somewhere further down the road, there is a law passed that each and every prisoner has the right to prove his innocence. "

webTitle: Elian's father wins right to take him home

fields.headline: Elian's father wins right to take him home
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: A US federal appeal court effectively restored six-year-old Elian Gonzalez to the guardianship of his Cuban father yesterday, upholding the immigration and naturalisation service's view that only Juan Miguel Gonzalez can act for his son in asylum matters.
fields.body:
A US federal appeal court effectively restored six-year-old Elian Gonzalez to the guardianship of his Cuban father yesterday, upholding the immigration and naturalisation service's view that only Juan Miguel Gonzalez can act for his son in asylum matters.

Elian must remain in the US for at least another fortnight, however, for the court gave his great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, 14 days in which to appeal against its ruling.

The unanimous judgment of the panel of three was nevertheless a significant legal rebuff to the boy's Miami relatives, who want to keep him in the US and have argued that a child should be entitled to make an asylum application independently of his parents.

"I am pleased the court of appeals has upheld the decision," the US attorney general, Janet Reno, said in a statement. "We have said all along that Elian belongs with his father. Today's ruling affirms that view."

Elian and his father are living in suburban Washington with relatives and a group of the boy's Cuban school friends. Mr Gonzalez is reported to have told friends that he wants to get back to Cuba with his son as soon as the injunction is lifted, but that may be many weeks off if the Miami lawyers have their way.

They said within minutes of the ruling that they would ask the federal supreme court to extend the ban on Elian leaving the US while they prepare an appeal to the court, the summit of the US judiciary.

"Surely this traumatised and innocent child deserves the court's consideration and protection," one said in a statement.

The ruling met with gloom and foreboding in the Little Havana district of Miami. A small crowd waving Cuban and American flags - plus one incongruous Union Jack - gathered outside the house from which Elian was snatched by federal agents in on April 22. But the mood was mostly more fatalistic than on earlier occasions.

"It is not over yet. God is with us," said Sandra Linar, holding a photograph of Elian with his mother, who drowned at sea while trying to bring her son to the US in November.

"To hell with being peaceful. We have been peaceful long enough," said Daniel Jimenez.

The local police chief, Lieutenant Bill Schwartz, said he was not expecting street protests or violence. "Our meetings with community leaders have indicated to us that we don't expect any problems," he said.

Senator Patrick Leahy, a Democrat who favours closer relations with Cuba, said the decision confirmed "what every parent knows - that parents speak for their children". But the Republican congressional whip, Tom DeLay, said the court had "failed to weigh adequately the sad reality of life under Fidel Castro's oppressive communist regime".

The judges said in their 33-page ruling that the immigration service's ruling was "within the outside border of reasonable choices" - a form of words which the Miami relatives' lawyers saw as only a grudging win for Juan Miguel Gonzalez. But independent legal observers said the unanimous ruling was a decisive blow to attempts to block the father's wishes.

"The INS did not abuse its discretion or act arbitrarily in applying the policy and rejecting the plaintiff's purported asylum application," the ruling concluded.

The court's refusal to let Elian make an asylum application reduces the legal avenues open to the Miami relatives to an improbable appeal to the full appeal court in Atlanta and a more likely attempt to take the issue to the supreme court in Washington, which could take months.

It would be for the supreme court to decide whether to keep in force the injunction requiring Elian to remain in the US until the final legal outcome is known.

"The INS did not abuse its discretion or act arbitrarily in applying the policy and rejecting the plaintiff's purported asylum application," the ruling concluded. The court's refusal to let Elian make an asylum application reduces the legal avenues open to the Miami relatives to an improbable appeal to the full appeal court in Atlanta and a more likely attempt to take the issue to the supreme court in Washington, which could take months. It would be for the supreme court to decide whether to keep in force the injunction requiring Elian to remain in the US until the final legal outcome is known.

fields.headline: Home soon for Elian
fields.standfirst:
An American court moves the case on

The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: After a merciful lull in the hysteria surrounding the six-year-old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, an American appeals court has brought the issue back into the limelight. Ruling in his father's favour, the three-judge panel says the Immigration and Naturalisation Service was entitled to decide the child was too young to argue his own case.
fields.body:
After a merciful lull in the hysteria surrounding the six-year-old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, an American appeals court has brought the issue back into the limelight. Ruling in his father's favour, the three-judge panel says the Immigration and Naturalisation Service was entitled to decide the child was too young to argue his own case. Common sense would surely agree, but common sense has been remarkably absent in this whole affair. Little Elian was turned into a political football by distant relatives with a selfish agenda. In the name of the distant goal of allegedly giving him a better life in the United States than he would have in Cuba, they grossly undermined his immediate welfare. After surviving a traumatic shipwreck and seeing his mother drown, he became a hostage, paraded on television and forced to make statements under psychological duress.

In the six weeks Elian has had with his father since attorney general Janet Reno freed him from the Miami hothouse, he has had a chance to resume something like a normal life away from the cameras. He has been able to play with schoolfriends from Cuba who have come to visit him in Washington. He is in a family again with his father's new wife and his baby half-sister. Now he can look forward to the prospect of returning to his old environment.

The journey to sanity is not quite over yet. Yesterday's ruling has taken the case closer to a Supreme Court hearing which is where it was always bound to end up. In the meantime Elian must remain in the United States. But the political climate surrounding the case has eased. The cynical proposal by some Congressmen to pass a bill giving the boy US citizenship seems to have fizzled out. The polls showed that a majority of the American public had lost patience with the Miami relatives and their rightwing supporters. When Elian's father came to the United States to rescue the boy, many were won over by his quiet dignity and the obvious love and rapport between him and his son. But this should not have been necessary. The Elian case should never have become a soap opera with ratings given for how telegenic the father was or how wickedly the distant relatives behaved. It was always a matter of law, in which the natural father patently had the prior claim. The hope must be that the Supreme Court gives a quick decision. The saga has already gone on long enough.

webTitle: Bodies In Motion and at Rest by Thomas Lynch

fields.headline: Bodies In Motion and at Rest by Thomas Lynch
fields.standfirst: (Jonathan Cape, £10), digested in the style of the original
fields.trailText: Alternately idiosyncratic, profound and whimsical essays on life, death and the bits in between by the undertaker turned poet, that keeps the right side of twee.
fields.body:
Death is the proof of our existence. I die therefore I am. Imagine the first Neanderthal widow, waking to the dead lump of her man 40,000 to 50,000 years ago. He is stiller than ever before, changed utterly. Did she wait till he started to smell before she did anything? Or did she instinctively know a dead thing when she saw it? And when did she start to think, "Is this it?" quickly followed by, "Will this happen to me?" and, "What next?"

Today, the route to what next is the burial or cremation. It gets both the dead and the living to where they need to be. The funeral serves the living by caring for the dead. In Britain, the preferred way of death is enshrined in the notices of the Daily Telegraph. Most everyone dies "peacefully in hospital after a short illness, bravely fought, retaining their sense of humour to the last", though occasionally you will come across the odd "tragically while walking in the Dolomites".

The funerals are similarly tightly scripted. "Close family only" and "no flowers", not even a Princess Diana memorial rose. And the very words "thanksgiving service" mean you can only be grateful, not aggrieved.

Americans are not kept on such a tight emotional rein in matters of grief, but they are just as susceptible to fashion. When my father ran the mortuary business, he peddled protection and permanence; a casket of 32oz solid copper that, unlike steel which rusts or corrodes, oxidises with age and grows stronger and stronger. I offer options and New Age alternatives, eco-friendly, combustibles and cyber-obsequies.

People are dying, not with a bang, nor with a whimper, but with a boom. The baby boom. Over the next 20 to 30 years, the boomers will die off and deaths in the US will increase by 1m a year. But if sex and love were free for the boomers, dying is most certainly not.

The death-care industry is big business; one in eight deaths in Britain is handled by Service Corporation International, the Houston-based conglomerate. For the US, the figure is one in five, and most everything in Australia and Paris. Every sadness, every guilt-ridden, grief-disabled, confused consumer is just another sales opportunity.

The caskets, the stones and the rituals. The boomers throw their money at them to understand their grief and to rediscover their lost connections. But there is no real mystery to death. It just is. Working in a funeral parlour, you spend a lot of time with those to whom the worst has happened and you don't hear a word of complaint from the corpse. Nor does the world fall in.

Life, it turns out, goes on much as before. All is well. And there is nothing like the sight of a dead body for the hypochondriac to separate the good days from the bad. The facts of death are every bit as much required reading as the facts of life.

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested

fields.headline: England canvass Maltese cross
fields.standfirst:
Keegan has plenty to think about including the hosts' key vote for 2006
All the squads from all the countries
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has plenty to think about including the hosts' key vote for 2006, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
If a team can be inspired by sudden contrasts in their surroundings then, for England, the European Championship is already half-won. Within hours of beating Ukraine 2-0 on a chilly Wembley evening England flew into summer here yesterday to prepare for tomorrow's game against Malta, which will complete their warm-up programme.

Precisely what the value of this exercise is remains obscure. True, there is a Maltese vote on the Fifa executive to be sought before the hosts for the 2006 World Cup are decided in Zurich in a month's time, and England's bid cannot afford to miss a trick just now.

From a footballing point of view, however, Kevin Keegan will learn little, especially as his squad of 22 has been finalised. It is not as if England needed to come to Malta GC to be reminded of the importance of outstanding crosses, David Beckham having spent the last two games pressing the point home.

Yet Keegan will have plenty to ponder by the Mediterranean. Encouraging though much of England's performance was in beating Ukraine, the match posed more questions than it answered.

Hard though Steve McManaman tried, he again became trapped on the left wing and was never remotely the influence Keegan had wanted him to be. The England coach had asked McManaman to do what he did for Real Madrid in the latter stages of the Champions League, but the circumstances were always going to make this a well-nigh impossible task.

Quite apart from the fact that the right-footed Phil Neville is no Roberto Carlos on the left, McManaman did not get the ball frequently or early enough. "Steve did OK," said Keegan yesterday, "but we didn't get the ball to him enough in the areas where we wanted him to be."

Keegan may persist with McManaman in a free role but the performances of two others will surely have given him food for thought.

Paul Scholes offered further evidence that he is best equipped to be the fulcrum of the team. Whether holding in midfield, moving forward with the ball or appearing in scoring positions through shrewd runs, Scholes confirmed his club manager's view that eventually he will prove to be the best footballer England have.

Then there is Nick Barmby, who after coming off the bench wasted no time in supplying the element of surprise that has gone missing from England's game. The pass that set up Emile Heskey for a chance the striker fumbled was a reminder of what the player was starting to bring to England's performances before he vanished from the international scene four years ago.

"I can't remember anyone coming off the bench for England and making an impact so quickly," Keegan mused. "Barmby is now playing better than he has ever done and you find yourself wanting to get that into the England side. He has made a late run into the squad. When we played Argentina in February he was not under consideration."

Keegan, then, is a in a relatively healthy position from an attacking point of view. Andy Cole's omission on fitness grounds is now an irrelevance.

While Barmby and the impressive Steven Gerrard, resting a tweaked achilles, are unlikely to start against Portugal on Monday week, few England teams stay unchanged for long in major tournaments.

In the meantime Richard Wright, the third choice in goal, will play the whole match tomorrow, a game Keegan promises will not be a training session. Given the narrowness of Malta's recent defeats against superior opposition, that would be unlikely anyway.

 The £475m Wembley redevelopment was unanimously approved by Brent Council last night after a compromise was reached over a funding row.

webTitle: Cancer patient dies after four surgery delays

fields.headline: Cancer patient dies after four surgery delays
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A cancer patient whose operation was cancelled four times because of a shortage of intensive care beds has died, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A cancer patient whose operation was cancelled four times because of a shortage of intensive care beds has died, it emerged yesterday.

The case of Mavis Skeet, 74, of Wakefield, West Yorkshire, caused a political storm in January when her operation for cancer of the oesophagus was deferred.

No beds were free in Leeds because of the flu epidemic.

She was later told by doctors at Leeds general infirmary that the cancer had spread, making surgery impossible. Her family blamed the delays for the progression of the disease. She died last week and her funeral was held yesterday.

A spokesman for Leeds Teaching Hospitals said: "We are very sorry to learn of the death at home of Mrs Skeet."

He said an inquiry was conducted into the circumstances surrounding her treatment.

"The report is with the secretary of state for health."

Mrs Skeet's plight led to accusations that the government failed to act to resolve the crisis caused by the flu bug which gripped the NHS last winter.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, ordered a full inquiry into the case.

She was admitted to Leeds general infirmary last December but surgery was cancelled initially because a key member of the surgical team came down with flu.

The operation was then cancelled a further three times at the last minute because no intensive care beds were available in Leeds.

Doctors then told her the cancer was inoperable because it had spread too far.

Mrs Skeet's daughter Jane, 32, of Horbury, near Wakefield, criticised the government for allowing the shortage of intensive care beds.

She said at the time: "The medical team told us she was operable on and say the five-week delay caused it to spread.

"You put your faith and your lives in the hands of the NHS and you feel no need to question it.

"She fell back on the NHS and still believed in it.

"She always felt it was understaffed, underfunded and the doctors overworked but she never imagined it could come to this. The government say they are dealing with the situation but they obviously are not."

A spokesman for the Department of Health expressed sympathy at the news of Mrs Skeet's death and said the report into her case ordered by Mr Milburn was being considered by her family and would not be published until they gave permission.

fields.headline: Internet 'steals' new Madonna single
fields.trailText: Madonna's next single, which is not due for release until the autumn has been stolen and leaked on the internet, to the fury of the singer and her record company.
fields.body:
Madonna's next single, which is not due for release until the autumn has been stolen and leaked on the internet, to the fury of the singer and her record company.

The official release date for the new album, Music, is September or early October but sections of between 30 seconds and three minutes of the title track have been made available on the internet.

The song can be accessed through fan sites and allegedly via the controversial computer programme, Napster, which allows users to download music.

Caresse Norman, Madonna's manager in America issued a statement last night. It said: "This music was stolen and was not intended for release for several months. It is still a work in progress. Ultimately those sites that offered a download of Madonna's music are violating her rights as an artist."

Warner Bros Records, the parent company of the singer's Maverick label, released a stronger statement, declaring the alleged copyright infringement an "extremely serious matter" and threatened that "any site that does not remove our copyrighted material runs the risk of civil and criminal prosecution".

Madonna, 41, is not the first star to have problems with the online music site, Napster. Last month the rock group Metallica began a legal battle with the company.

The group said that Napster computer software was being used to flout copyright laws and deny it money from record sales.

Napster grew out of the MP3 technology, a term used to describe compressed computer files. A normal CD quality song would need many megabytes of disc space to be stored on a computer but MP3s are smaller files which sound as good as the original.

Metallica won the right to monitor Napster's traffic for a short period and compiled a list of more than 300,000 users which it said had allegedly downloaded songs. The list was presented to Napster's management and court proceedings were threatened unless users were banned from the site. Napster complied.

However the latest targeting of Madonna has taken the debate a stage further. "She is really angry that this has happened. It really is up to the courts to do something now or it will ruin the music industry," one source said last night.

Warner Bros declined to comment on how the music might have been leaked. A spokesman added: "We expect site owners who have included this material on their site will comply immediately with our legitimate request that they cease permitting unauthorised downloads of this song."

webTitle: Climate of fear let surgeon maim women

fields.headline: Climate of fear let surgeon maim women
fields.standfirst:
Climate of fear allowed surgeon to maim women

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The disgraced gynaecologist, Rodney Ledward, was able to severely maim hundreds of women patients because of a hospital culture in which consultants were treated as "gods" and junior staff were afraid of "telling tales", the official inquiry into his conduct reported yesterday.
fields.body:
The disgraced gynaecologist, Rodney Ledward, was able to severely maim hundreds of women patients because of a hospital culture in which consultants were treated as "gods" and junior staff were afraid of "telling tales", the official inquiry into his conduct reported yesterday.

Mr Ledward botched hundreds of operations during his 16 years at the William Harvey hospital in Ashford, Kent, because he was protected by a combination of "failures in senior NHS management", the "old boys' network" and a "climate of fear and retribution" which prevented colleagues from reporting their concerns about his surgical skills.

In one of the most critical reports published into a doctor's work, the year-long inquiry, chaired by Jean Ritchie QC, blamed senior managers at the William Harvey hospital and the then local health authority, south-east Kent, for failing to investigate concerns raised by staff and patients.

The report recommended a series of measures to prevent further tragedies, including occupational health screening for all doctors to root out those unsuitable for the pro fession, an "open culture" to encourage whistle-blowing and nationwide "benchmark" complication rates for all surgeons.

More than 400 women have come forward to complain about their treatment by Mr Ledward and to date 198 have filed claims against the man who dubbed himself "the fastest gynaecologist in the south of England" after he performed seven hysterectomies in less than four hours.

The health minister, John Denham, welcomed the report and said that in future every doctor would have an annual appraisal and trusts would be held legally accountable for the quality of care given by all staff for the first time. He told BBC Radio 4: "The bottom line is that patients' interests must be protected above all else."

The NHS compensation bill is expected to exceed £1m for women who claim he left them physically and mentally scarred when he unnecessarily removed healthy wombs and bungled routine operations, leaving them with bladder, kidney and liver damage.

Police are examining allegations of assault against Mr Ledward and are expected to investigate the deaths of six women patients.

Despite concerns being raised about his performance at the William Harvey as early as 1980, Mr Ledward, 62, was not suspended from his £200,000-a-year post until February 1996, after a routine hysterectomy went wrong.

The inquiry report said NHS management should have been alerted to serious concerns many years earlier, adding: "It is a sad and sorry tale that it took until the end of January 1996 for the matter to be taken in hand the way it should have been many years previously.

"There had been opportunities, there had been matters raised by staff and patients which should have been investigated. Had senior management acted earlier, as in our view they should have done, many of the problems with which we have been confronted would have been avoided."

But the report added: "Rodney Ledward bears the greatest responsibility for the failures in his practice."

Mr Ledward, who is understood to be seriously ill with prostate cancer, was struck off the medical register in 1998, following an investigation by the General Medical Council in which he was found to have bungled 13 operations on women at the William Harvey and at private hospitals.

Yesterday, Ms Ritchie called on the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to consider the inquiry's recommendations "as a matter of urgency" to prevent such an appalling catalogue of errors being allowed to occur again.

She said: "We are so sorry that these things were not picked up sooner. It is very much our view that the NHS is going in the right direction now, with the emphasis on creating a new whistleblower culture and a more responsible and professional key management structure."

Among the detailed recommendations of the report was a call for changes in the GMC's professional conduct committee hearings, including an independent judge acting as chairman and a reduction in the burden of proof from that of criminal trials - beyond reasonable doubt - to that used in civil cases, the balance of probabilities.

The report also recommended that senior managers should develop methods for complaints and concerns to be dealt with at the earliest opportunity.

Key to this was the creation of an open culture in which patients and staff, particularly junior doctors, felt able to express their concerns.

Before flying to Spain for a holiday from his home in County Cork, Ireland, the gynaecologist said: "This whole thing has been a political soap opera. I know I have done nothing wrong. I'm not going to appeal because I don't feel there is any point. I have been a fall guy."

The report was personally presented to members of the Ledward victims support group by the inquiry team yesterday.

The group's vice-chairman, Maureen Goldingay, said: "We are hoping to change the law in Britain with this report. He has been struck off but we want further action taken against him. If that means criminal courts, then so be it."

Mr Ledward botched hundreds of operations during his 16 years at the William Harvey hospital in Ashford, Kent, because he was protected by a combination of "failures in senior NHS management", the "old boys' network" and a "climate of fear and retribution" which prevented colleagues from reporting their concerns about his surgical skills. In one of the most critical reports published into a doctor's work, the year-long inquiry, chaired by Jean Ritchie QC, blamed senior managers at the William Harvey hospital and the then local health authority, south-east Kent, for failing to investigate concerns raised by staff and patients. The report recommended a series of measures to prevent further tragedies, including occupational health screening for all doctors to root out those unsuitable for the pro fession, an "open culture" to encourage whistle-blowing and nationwide "benchmark" complication rates for all surgeons. More than 400 women have come forward to complain about their treatment by Mr Ledward and to date 198 have filed claims against the man who dubbed himself "the fastest gynaecologist in the south of England" after he performed seven hysterectomies in less than four hours. The health minister, John Denham, welcomed the report and said that in future every doctor would have an annual appraisal and trusts would be held legally accountable for the quality of care given by all staff for the first time. He told BBC Radio 4: "The bottom line is that patients' interests must be protected above all else." The NHS compensation bill is expected to exceed £1m for women who claim he left them physically and mentally scarred when he unnecessarily removed healthy wombs and bungled routine operations, leaving them with bladder, kidney and liver damage. Police are examining allegations of assault against Mr Ledward and are expected to investigate the deaths of six women patients. Despite concerns being raised about his performance at the William Harvey as early as 1980, Mr Ledward, 62, was not suspended from his £200,000-a-year post until February 1996, after a routine hysterectomy went wrong. The inquiry report said NHS management should have been alerted to serious concerns many years earlier, adding: "It is a sad and sorry tale that it took until the end of January 1996 for the matter to be taken in hand the way it should have been many years previously. "There had been opportunities, there had been matters raised by staff and patients which should have been investigated. Had senior management acted earlier, as in our view they should have done, many of the problems with which we have been confronted would have been avoided." But the report added: "Rodney Ledward bears the greatest responsibility for the failures in his practice." Mr Ledward, who is understood to be seriously ill with prostate cancer, was struck off the medical register in 1998, following an investigation by the General Medical Council in which he was found to have bungled 13 operations on women at the William Harvey and at private hospitals. Yesterday, Ms Ritchie called on the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to consider the inquiry's recommendations "as a matter of urgency" to prevent such an appalling catalogue of errors being allowed to occur again. She said: "We are so sorry that these things were not picked up sooner. It is very much our view that the NHS is going in the right direction now, with the emphasis on creating a new whistleblower culture and a more responsible and professional key management structure." Among the detailed recommendations of the report was a call for changes in the GMC's professional conduct committee hearings, including an independent judge acting as chairman and a reduction in the burden of proof from that of criminal trials - beyond reasonable doubt - to that used in civil cases, the balance of probabilities. The report also recommended that senior managers should develop methods for complaints and concerns to be dealt with at the earliest opportunity. Key to this was the creation of an open culture in which patients and staff, particularly junior doctors, felt able to express their concerns. Before flying to Spain for a holiday from his home in County Cork, Ireland, the gynaecologist said: "This whole thing has been a political soap opera. I know I have done nothing wrong. I'm not going to appeal because I don't feel there is any point. I have been a fall guy." The report was personally presented to members of the Ledward victims support group by the inquiry team yesterday. The group's vice-chairman, Maureen Goldingay, said: "We are hoping to change the law in Britain with this report. He has been struck off but we want further action taken against him. If that means criminal courts, then so be it."

webTitle: Godfather of Latin jazz, Puente, dies

fields.headline: Godfather of Latin jazz, Puente, dies
fields.trailText: Tito Puente, the godfather of Latin jazz who helped popularise dance music styles including the cha-cha-cha, mambo and salsa, has died aged 77.
fields.body:
Tito Puente, the godfather of Latin jazz who helped popularise dance music styles including the cha-cha-cha, mambo and salsa, has died aged 77.

Puente, a bandleader and percussionist who recorded more than 100 albums in his six decades in the business, died on Wednesday night at New York University medical centre after complications during heart surgery.

President Bill Clinton - who once said "Just hearing Tito Puente's name makes you want to get up and dance" - paid tribute to the star by saying that his spirit would endure in his music.

The Cuban-born salsa singer Celia Cruz added: "Our world is in mourning because one of the souls of Latin music has died."

Puente, who was born in new York to Puerto Rican parents, won the last of his five Grammy awards in February for his Mambo Birdland album.

Puente's music was rooted in Spanish Harlem and he raised the mambo and cha-cha-cha to artistic and commercial heights during the 1950s. He became a regular headliner at the New York palladium and in the 1960s he headed to Hollywood where he collaborated with the brightest Latino and jazz stars of the day.

His early 60s composition Oye Como Va became a huge hit for rock star Carlos Santana almost 10 years later, raising Puente's profile outside a circle of tropical jazz connoisseurs.

"In front of a bandstand you've got to be a showman," Puente, who made the playing of the timbales his trademark, said. "Once, I was strictly a musician with a long face and back to the audience. Now I'm a showman, selling what I'm doing, giving the people good vibes."

webTitle: Bombing raises fear of Real IRA campaign

fields.headline: Bombing raises fear of Real IRA campaign
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The spectre of a new bombing campaign by dissident Irish republicans was raised in London yesterday as scientists from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch began analysing debris from a high-explosive device planted beneath Hammersmith Bridge.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins  and  Richard Norton Taylor
fields.body:
The spectre of a new bombing campaign by dissident Irish republicans was raised in London yesterday as scientists from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch began analysing debris from a high-explosive device planted beneath Hammersmith Bridge.

Nobody was injured and the blast did not cause significant damage, but security sources fear it was designed as a "shot across the bows", showing that hardline republicans opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process still have a destructive capability and can easily avoid detection.

If dissident republicans were involved, the bomb would mark their first successful attack in England.

No warnings were received before the bomb exploded at 4.30am and no groups have claimed responsibility.

Speaking from the scene in west London, Deputy Assistant Commissioner Alan Fry, the head of the anti-terrorist branch, said he was open-minded about who was responsible but indicated that republican involvement was an obvious line of inquiry.

Seven months ago, Scotland Yard said Britain was on its highest level of terrorist alert since 1998 because of the "credible and real threat" posed to the capital by a coalition of republican terrorist groups.

The warning came after intelligence gathering operations in the UK and Ireland, and risk assessments by MI5. Yesterday, sources said the level had not changed since then, remaining at the second highest possible.

MI5 has been quietly warning for some months about the threat of bomb attacks in Northern Ireland and Britain, particularly from the Real IRA, the splinter group behind the bomb in Omagh, Co Tyrone, which killed 29 people in August 1998.

Security sources said yesterday's bomb could have been placed by a British-based cell sympathetic to the rejectionist groups, or by "day trippers" who came from Northern Ireland via the republic.

Although dangerous, MI5 sources yesterday insisted that the dissident groups do not possess the manpower or material resources of the provisional IRA. One of the problems police face is that the dissidents have not revealed a system of coded warnings.

Yesterday's bomb was planted on a girder beneath the bridge, above the towpath on the south side of the Thames.

Scotland Yard sources said the bomb was a "sophisticated device" that was packed with between one and two kilos (2-4lbs) of Semtex high explosives. It had fully detonated.

The explosion shattered a number of windows in nearby homes and caused structural damage to the bridge, which was only reopened to traffic last December after strengthening work which cost £3.5m.

Hammersmith, which has a large Irish community, has been targeted by terrorists before. In April 1996, a 32lb Semtex bomb planted on the bridge failed to detonate.

The bridge and many surrounding roads were closed yesterday as 60 officers joined forensic experts and police frogmen in a search for clues among the debris.

John Randall, 80, who lives in a block of flats overlooking the river, described how his kitchen windows were shattered by the blast. Mr Randall, a former army officer, said: "The bomb went off in exactly the same place as the device was put four years ago. This spot is a very easy target. The towpath goes under the bridge and there is a wide open space."

Mr Fry said Londoners were used to coping with the threat of terrorism but urged extra vigilance in the coming weeks: "It was a small high-explosive device. We are maintaining an open mind. I ask for sensible vigilance by the London public who are well used to being in this situation."

He added: "What has been shown in the past is that the community can defeat this kind of crime. We would appeal to anyone who saw someone acting suspiciously to assist us by calling our hotline on 0800 789 321."

The timing of the blast, so soon after the return of devolved government to Northern Ireland, is also significant. The bomb went off just hours before one of Sinn Fein's most influential figures, Gerry Kelly, was due to arrive in London for a meeting on the policing bill which is due to get its second reading in the Commons next Tuesday.

The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor said: "It must always be remembered that there are minority republican terrorist groups still on the ground, still potentially active."

"Hammersmith Bridge has been the subject of previous attacks by Irish republican terrorists," said a Scotland Yard source last night.

"Historically they have used high explosives. We have a situation of the executive [of the Northern Ireland assembly] meeting today for the first time since the Good Friday agreement came back into place and we have got to look at that as being a line of investigation."

Mr Fry later added: "In light of this, we can only anticipate that there might be further attacks but without claims of responsibility, it's that much more difficult to determine."

webTitle: Star jockeys survive plane crash inferno

fields.headline: Star jockeys survive plane crash inferno
fields.standfirst: Escape - Dettori helped to safety as accident kills pilot
fields.trailText: The leading jockeys Frankie Dettori and Ray Cochrane had a miraculous escape yesterday when the light aircraft in which they were travelling crashed and burst into flames moments after take off, killing the pilot.
fields.body:
The leading jockeys Frankie Dettori and Ray Cochrane had a miraculous escape yesterday when the light aircraft in which they were travelling crashed and burst into flames moments after take off, killing the pilot.

Dettori and Cochrane were last night being treated at Addenbrooke's hospital, in Cambridge. Both men had managed to escape the wreckage through the plane's luggage compartment but were unable to save the pilot.

Dettori, who was to race in the Derby in two weeks, fractured his right ankle and damaged a thumb. Cochrane suffered minor burns and was last night undergoing tests.

The crash happened shortly after 12.30pm yesterday as Dettori and Cochrane left Newmarket race course, in Suffolk, for Goodwood, in West Sussex where they were to take part in a meeting yesterday afternoon.

Inspector Steve Brown of Suffolk police said: "It would certainly seem to be a miracle that anyone got out of the crash alive."

The crash is the third high profile plane accident in the last six months to involve sporting celebrities. Last year, the golfer Payne Stewart and four others were killed in a Learjet crash in South Dakota. Last month the formula one driver David Coulthard and his fiancee Heidi Wichlinski, escaped with minor injuries after a Learjet crash in France which left two pilots dead.

The crashes have raised fears about the safety of pri vate aircraft. The country's top jockeys often use them to travel between meetings.

The men were travelling in an American-built, twin-engined Piper Seneca. The plane crashed between the July and Rowly Mile courses at Newmarket in an area known as the Devil's Ditch.

The plane exploded into flames on impact. Racecourse workers who rushed to the scene were unable to get near to the wreckage because of the heat of the fire.

Both jockeys had managed to scramble free and were lying on the grass nearby. Rescue workers were unable to help the pilot who was trapped in the wreckage.

Peter Burrell, Dettori's commercial agent visited him in hospital last night and said afterwards that the jockey had numerous cuts to his leg, arms and head.

"I've just been in to see him. He is pretty smashed up," he said. "Ray helped Frankie get out of the plane, then he went back to get the pilot, but by that time the plane was on fire. From what I can gather the pilot did a great job. He managed to miss a dyke and then he was fighting to get control of the plane and it went down.

"Ray screamed at Frankie to get out and then tried to get back to the pilot but by then the plane was on fire."

Dettori was due to fly to Japan on Friday to take part in a meeting and to ride in the Epsom Derby on June 10. Mr Burrell said that was now out of the question.

Mr Burrell added: "Frankie thinks this it is a miracle."

Captain Nick Lees, the director of racing at Newmarket who was one of the first people at the scene of the crash, said: "I ran on to the field and saw Frankie and Ray huddled about 50 yards from the plane. They were both conscious.

"I cannot even describe the emotions that went through my head. I just saw smoke billowing out of the plane."

Two officers from the air accident investigation branch arrived at the crash scene yesterday and a full investigation will be held.

webTitle: Cardinal brands Scots parliament a failure

fields.headline: Cardinal brands Scots parliament a failure
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The leader of Scotland's Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, has branded the Scottish parliament an "utter failure" a year after its creation.
fields.body:
The leader of Scotland's Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, has branded the Scottish parliament an "utter failure" a year after its creation.

The cardinal, who has been an outspoken critic of the parliament's efforts to repeal section 28, accused Holyrood of pursuing a "liberal agenda" and said he felt deeply let down by MSPs.

"I was enthusiastic but I almost feel ashamed of them now. I am ashamed of our politicians and the way they have behaved and the things they have done over the past year. I think it has been an utter failure," he is reported as saying.

"I defended them for months and months in different parts of the press and I said they needed five to 10 years to give them credibility. I still think that, but I don't think the achievements of the past year are anything to be proud of ... on the big issues they have achieved nothing."

In an interview with the Scottish Catholic Observer to mark his 75th birthday today, the cardinal praised the Stagecoach millionaire Brian Souter, who funded a private ballot on section 28.

He said Mr Souter was not trying to ram his views down other people's throats but had tapped into a "statement of society in Scotland" with his anti-repeal campaign.

"It is up to society to show they don't accept the libertarian agenda they are proposing," the cardinal said. He found it staggering that the parliament had resisted efforts to enshrine marriage in the legislation that will replace section 28.

Last week the Catholic church backed an amendment to legislation put forward by a Labour MSP, stressing the importance of marriage. The amendment was rejected earlier this week by a committee of MSPs.

The executive plans to replace section 28 with a clause highlighting the value of "stable family life" and has tough ened guidelines covering sex education.

"They have given me the impression that there is a very liberal agenda, and come hell or high water they are going to see it through," said Cardinal Winning.

Responding to the remarks, the deputy first minister, Jim Wallace, said that the cardinal was entitled to his own views, but the executive believed it had made clear efforts to address concerns over repeal and to strengthen guidelines on sex education.

fields.headline: Summer E coli warning
fields.trailText: Traditional British summer events, including rock festivals and car boot sales, are under threat from European scientists.
fields.body:
Traditional British summer events, including rock festivals and car boot sales, are under threat from European scientists.

Event organisers are being warned of the dangers posed to the health of young children and old people by muddy and cowpat laden fields.

EU scientists say organisers should avoid land recently grazed by livestock and provide clean running water and soap to reduce the risk of E coli bugs being spread.

The scientists recommend protective clothing for schoolchildren going on farm visits and compulsory food hygiene lessons in all EU primary schools.

fields.headline: Will Expo become Germany's Dome?
fields.trailText: Germany's first world fair, Expo 2000 opened in Hanover yesterday amid a fanfare of publicity, protests from anti-capitalists and doubts that the multimillion dollar project would attract enough visitors.
fields.body:
Germany's first world fair, Expo 2000 opened in Hanover yesterday amid a fanfare of publicity, protests from anti-capitalists and doubts that the multimillion dollar project would attract enough visitors.

The German president, Johannes Rau, officially opened what has been billed the biggest spectacle in German history. Despite fears that it could become Germany's version of the Millennium Dome, Expo's chief organiser, Birgit Breuel told hundreds of invited dignitaries at the opening ceremony: "The Expo has been made by people for people - our guests. It is not virtual, it is there to touch."

The ceremony was marred at the outset by chants from more than 100 anarchist anti- Expo protesters gathered outside the perimeter fence chanting "Expo No". Police arrested 14 demonstrators who were protesting that the event was a "glorification of capitalism."

Earlier, rail authorities had to suspend train links to the city for half an hour after burning tyres were discovered on the Hanover-Berlin line.

The Expo, which incorporates pavilions and exhibits from over 170 nations and international organisations is located on a space almost as large as Monaco. Its main aim is to combine recent hi-tech industrial developments with a rich offering of cultural exhibits and a dash of environmental philosophy.

But even before the spectacle opened yesterday, the Germany green watchdog group, the German Association for Environment and Nature Protection had dismissed it as: "Merely exhibiting hi-tech euphoria instead of the promised examples of solutions to man's central problems."

Expo is expected to lose around DM400m (£127m). It has been dogged by controversy ever since it was conceived as a showcase for the "new" Germany that emerged from unification a decade ago.

One of the gravest setbacks has been the decision by the US not to exhibit at the show - a shortcoming underlined yesterday by the arrival of President Bill Clinton in Germany and his absence from the opening ceremony.

But the organisers are hoping to attract as many as 60,000 visitors to Expo every day until the it closes in five months time. An opinion poll conducted for Der Spiegel magazine this week provided some encouragement. It calculated that 24% of all Germans intended to visit with 45% of 18-24 year olds either "dead certain" or "probable" that they would make the trip.

But the facts surrounding yesterday's figures were not so promising. Although nearly 100,000 were said to have attended the opening ceremony, the organisers admitted that they had given free admission to over 30,000 local schoolchildren and 6,000 Expo building workers to keep the figures high.

The cause of the visitors' reluctance was later revealed: the organisers had deliberately nearly doubled the price of the tickets from DM69. to DM120 in an attempt to increase profits.

One of the gravest setbacks has been the decision by the US not to exhibit at the show - a shortcoming underlined yesterday by the arrival of President Bill Clinton in Germany and his absence from the opening ceremony. But the organisers are hoping to attract as many as 60,000 visitors to Expo every day until the it closes in five months time. An opinion poll conducted for Der Spiegel magazine this week provided some encouragement. It calculated that 24% of all Germans intended to visit with 45% of 18-24 year olds either "dead certain" or "probable" that they would make the trip. But the facts surrounding yesterday's figures were not so promising. Although nearly 100,000 were said to have attended the opening ceremony, the organisers admitted that they had given free admission to over 30,000 local schoolchildren and 6,000 Expo building workers to keep the figures high. The cause of the visitors' reluctance was later revealed: the organisers had deliberately nearly doubled the price of the tickets from DM69. to DM120 in an attempt to increase profits.

webTitle: Attack was third on bridge that has become strategic target

fields.headline: Attack was third on bridge that has become strategic target
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday's explosion on Hammersmith bridge was the third such attack in 61 years. In 1939 and again in 1996 IRA active service units targeted the bridge in west London with devices far larger than yesterday's bomb.
fields.body:
Yesterday's explosion on Hammersmith bridge was the third such attack in 61 years. In 1939 and again in 1996 IRA active service units targeted the bridge in west London with devices far larger than yesterday's bomb.

The strategic value of the bridge as a target was clear yesterday when congestion slowed traffic heading into London to a crawl, and delays continued to afflict west London well into the afternoon. Several major arterial routes pass through Hammersmith, including the A4.

In April 1996 the bridge escaped massive damage when two Semtex bombs planted at a substation under a walkway on the south side of the river failed to go off properly.

At the time the bombs, planned as an Easter Rising 80th anniversary "spectacular", were the biggest planted by the IRA on the British mainland.

One detonator exploded but did not trigger the 40lb of Semtex attached to it, while the other device, similar in size, failed entirely.

The IRA's first attempt to blow up the 113-year-old bridge on March 29 1939 was foiled by a passerby. Maurice Childs, a hairdresser from Chiswick, west London, was walking home across the bridge in the early morning when he noticed a suitcase and opened it to find a bomb smoking and sparking. He tossed the bag into the river where it exploded. Moments later a second device blew up, collapsing girders on the west side of the bridge and shattering windows in houses. Eddie Connell, 22, was jailed for 20 years at the Old Bailey for planting the bomb.

The most severe disruption to the bridge was caused between 1996 and 1999 when it was closed for repairs and strengthening.

webTitle: Unionists join forces to keep Sinn Fein out of mayor's office

fields.headline: Unionists join forces to keep Sinn Fein out of mayor's office
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein lost out in the race for the post of lord mayor of Belfast last night, as the Democratic Unionist party assembly member Sammy Wilson claimed it by two votes.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein lost out in the race for the post of lord mayor of Belfast last night, as the Democratic Unionist party assembly member Sammy Wilson claimed it by two votes.

Mr Wilson, who was mayor in 1986-87, won by 26 votes to 24. Ulster Unionists backed the DUP, stopping the assemblyman Alex Maskey becoming the first Sinn Fein mayor of an Irish city since 1920.

There was irony in the Ulster Unionists' approach. The party had earlier been discussing with Sinn Fein at the power-sharing executive how to take on the DUP over its refusal to attend cabinet.

Sir Reg Empey and Michael McGimpsey, two of the Ulster Unionists' ministers, are also Belfast city councillors. They voted for Mr Wilson, a key supporter of the DUP's tactics at Stormont.

Sinn Fein, with 13 of the 51 seats in the council, could have expected to take the top post had an informal understanding held. It is only three years since Belfast had its first nationalist mayor.

But it will have some consolation on Monday, when the former IRA prisoner Cathal Crumley is expected to become Londonderry's first citizen.

Mr Wilson's victory led to the resignation from the DUP of Eric Smyth, who was mayor five years ago, when Bill Clinton first visited. Mr Smyth, a lay preacher, felt that he had been carved out of the contest.

Mr Wilson, whose mayoress last time round was Ian Paisley's daughter, Rhonda, is a teacher by profession. An enemy of Martin McGuinness, he is deputy chair of the education at Stormont. He is a colourful character. Four years ago a Sunday newspaper published photographs of him on a nudist beach.

The executive met yesterday for the first time since it was suspended February. The DUP ministers Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds stayed away.

David Trimble, the first minister, and Seamus Mallon, the deputy first minister, yesterday called them to a meeting on Monday to explain DUP plans to rotate ministries assigned to the party through its assembly team. The DUP's avowed aim is to wreck the Good Friday agreement.

The controversial flags issue was unresolved in time for today, Coronation Day. The union flag will fly at Parliament Buildings, but will not be unfurled over Sinn Fein's departments, health and education.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, will not be called into the dispute today. Mr Trimble was hoping the parties could eventually resolve it, but there is likely to be a row among hardline unionists over the issue today.

webTitle: Women face jail for Wailing Wall prayers

fields.headline: Women face jail for Wailing Wall prayers
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Women who worship in prayer shawls or chant from Torah scrolls at the Western Wall, the holiest shrine in Judaism, could go to prison for seven years under new legislation proposed by Israel's knesset.
fields.body:
Women who worship in prayer shawls or chant from Torah scrolls at the Western Wall, the holiest shrine in Judaism, could go to prison for seven years under new legislation proposed by Israel's knesset.

A bill to criminalise women who hold group prayer sessions at the wall - also known as the Wailing Wall - which was passed in a preliminary reading on Wednesday, has horrified the Jewish majority, which is not Orthodox, not least because it seeks to circumvent a supreme court ruling 10 days ago to modernise the rules of worship at the shrine.

"If a man beats me up at the wall, he goes to prison for a year. If he rapes me at the wall, he gets three years. If I put on a prayer shawl, I go to prison for seven years. It's insane," said a Jerusalem city councillor, Anat Hoffman.

For 11 years, Ms Hoffman has campaigned to end the stranglehold of Orthodox Jewish tradition on worship at the site, demanding the right of women to conduct services in the same way as men.

On May 22 Ms Hoffman's Women of the Wall group tasted victory when the supreme court ruled that the wall, venerated as the last remnant of a temple destroyed by the Romans in AD70, was a national place of pilgrimage where all Jews could worship in different ways.

The court gave the govern ment six months to arrange for women to hold services at the shrine. However, the ruling by three judges was immediately condemned by Orthodox rabbis, who called it an assault on Jewish practice. Mindful of the enormous influence the religious parties exercise on Israel's coalition politics, members of Ehud Barak's government rallied to their side.

"I think the court has made an erroneous decision," said Michael Melchior, the minister of diaspora affairs. "We cannot solve our problems by making either side make painful concessions. For many people in our society this decision is against the basic primordial order of things. It will bring violent confrontation instead of compromise."

Women of the Wall, which represents some 110 women who conduct services at the shrine on the first day of each Jewish month, fear that Orthodox rabbis will lobby the supreme court to review its verdict.

Although Women of the Wall pray in the Orthodox fashion, never enter the male preserve and only put on prayer shawls or read aloud from Torah scrolls at some distance from the shrine, they have been regularly abused by Orthodox male worshippers - and occasionally attacked.

"We are threatening the total control men have over religious life in Israel," said Ms Hoffman. "How could a group of women praying possibly be sacrilegious?"

webTitle: Gunman shot as hostage crisis ends

fields.headline: Gunman shot as hostage crisis ends
fields.standfirst: Luxembourg police free children after 30-hour stand-off
fields.trailText: Luxembourg police yesterday stormed a creche and shot a lone, heavily-armed gunman who had held 25 children and three adults hostage for more than 30 hours.
fields.body:
Luxembourg police yesterday stormed a creche and shot a lone, heavily-armed gunman who had held 25 children and three adults hostage for more than 30 hours.

A police spokesman said the man, who was carrying a pistol, a knife and a hand grenade, had agreed to be interviewed on television. As he left the building with two hostages, he was shot by a detective disguised as a cameraman.

"We set up a little interview and this allowed us to approach the hostage taker and neutralise him," he said.

The prime minister of Luxembourg, Jean-Claude Juncker, said the hostage taker had demanded to flee in a car with three hostages, forcing police to move in.

The gunman was seriously injured but all the hostages, many of whom were under four years old, were released unharmed.

The siege began when the gunman - who locals claim is a Tunisian national whose own children once attended the day care centre - walked into the building and took more than 40 adults and children hostage.

He freed 17 of the hostages on Wednesday and a further four yesterday morning but it became obvious that he would not drop his demand that a plane should fly him to Libya.

The 39-year-old gunman had a history of mental problems and police used his own psychologist as a go-between in negotiations.

Locals in Wasserbillig, a small town with a population of 2,300 on the German border, claim that the man was motivated by a profound hatred of the day care centre staff, whom he blamed for the fact that his own two children were taken away from him by social services after he separated from his wife.

The man had earlier set a deadline of 8.30am for him to be taken to a nearby airport to be flown to Libya. That ultimatum passed without incident.

Police also did not confirm reports that the man had demanded $1m to release the hostages.

Meanwhile, marksmen surrounded the day care centre, backed by members of the German special forces. Thirteen of the children were of Portuguese nationality and Portugal's ambassador to Luxembourg also offered his assistance to police.

The interior minister later confirmed that a jet had been waiting at Luxembourg airport, as per the gunman's demands.

A volley of gun shots rang out and it was over. A police helicopter hovered over the day care centre and the waiting emergency services sprang into action.

Some of the onlookers gave a muted cheer as it became clear that the hostages had been freed without injury.

Yesterday was a bank holiday in Luxembourg and was supposed to be a day of relaxation for the inhabitants of Wasserbillig. The circus was coming to town and billboards featuring a laughing clown promised a day of family fun. But there was just relief yesterday as the deadly stand-off came to its dramatic conclu sion, watched by the world's media and the people of the town. Wasserbillig, which is just about big enough to have a railway station, did not know what had hit it. Satellite television vans clogged the town square and the local town hall was converted into an impromptu press centre.

Picnickers who were enjoying sumptuous spreads on the banks of the Moselle river seemed determined to carry on as normal, but tension in this prosperous town had reached breaking point last night.

The storming of the building was wildly welcomed. A woman whose friend's children were among the freed hostages said it had been a disaster waiting to happen.

"There was no security at the centre and anyone could walk in," she said. "It was unbelievable. My daughter was going to start there in August but I'm not so sure now. Nobody thought that anything like this could happen."

Bored teenagers lolling on the town's street corners had a different take on the crisis; they seemed to be enjoying the attention which their town had attracted. "It's incredible," one teenage girl said. "We've been on American TV and everything. There's never been anything like this before."

webTitle: Hong Kong fends off Beijing's business advice

fields.headline: Hong Kong fends off Beijing's business advice
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Hong Kong's senior leaders finally rebelled yesterday against unwanted Chinese advice by openly accusing a mainland official of "interference" in the territory's affairs.
fields.body:
Hong Kong's senior leaders finally rebelled yesterday against unwanted Chinese advice by openly accusing a mainland official of "interference" in the territory's affairs.

The storm followed a speech on Wednesday by He Zhiming, a vice-director of Beijing's liaison office in Hong Kong, who warned local businessmen not to trade with Taiwanese companies which support independence.

Mr He said that anyone doing so was "taking a risk" and would have to "face the consequences." His words were seen as a threat to Hong Kong's much-prized business autonomy.

The chief executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa, yesterday moved quickly to get the offending remarks repudiated by a more senior Hong Kong-based Beijing official.

Mr Tung told reporters that he had secured a pledge from Jiang Enzhu, Mr He's immediate superior, that China "will not interfere with business here".

Mr Tung's deputy, chief secretary Anson Chan, also issued a statement refuting Mr He's remarks, which she said had caused widespread concern.

"In our view", she concluded, "business decisions are best left to businessmen and should not invite the interference of any official of whatever status."

Both Mr Tung and his deputy have tried to avoid open controversy with Beijing officials until now, although Ms Chan has expressed veiled disapproval.

Last month Wang Fengchao, a colleague of Mr He in the liaison office, warned the Hong Kong media not to print views advocating Taiwanese independence. His warning was supported by senior officials in Beijing.

Mr Tung and Ms Chan then gave assurances that Hong Kong's press freedom was not in doubt, but avoided directly criticising Mr Wang.

By stirring up alarm in the business community, Mr He appears to have overstepped the mark. Mr Tung's natural constituency lies in the business world and his family shipping company has had extensive dealings in Taiwan.

A legislator, James Tien, who represents the Hong Kong general chamber of commerce, said that business people, "will simply look at each business deal to see whether it is profitable, rather than asking the trading partners about their political views".

The Chinese liaison office in Hong Kong functioned for years as Beijing's unofficial embassy under its previous name of the New China News Agency. Its name was changed in January.

No journalists ever worked for the agency and its senior officials were known for their hardline views. More recently it has been accused by Hong Kong democrats of lobbying for pro-Beijing votes in the legislature.
