fields.headline: Vote tote
fields.standfirst:
There is a gulf between what electors tell the pollsters and what they actually do and it is Labour that needs to motivate its supporters

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: There is a gulf between what electors tell the pollsters and what they actually do and it is Labour that needs to motivate its supporters
fields.body:
Labour is still doing well in the polls. Successive results show it has a comfortable lead over the Tories when people are asked how they would vote if an election were to be held now. This position held since the general election in May 1997. But why then does Labour keep losing - the European parliament last year, May's council contests and London's new government?

The ready explanation is that while electors tell pollsters they prefer Labour, when it comes to casting a vote Labour supporters are reluctant to turn out and do the deed. As part of an Economic and Social Research Council programme on the state of democracy in the United Kingdom we have been examining participation. We asked people to assess the likelihood of their voting at the next general election on a scale from one to ten. Some 71% were categorised as likely voters (with a rating from eight to ten), which is fairly close to the proportion who actually did turn out in 1997.

If we compare the size of this group of likely voters across the parties, clear differences emerge in the relationship between support and voting intention. Interestingly enough the nationalists have the most determined backers. Some 94% of their supporters fall into this "likely to vote" group. The Tories are enthusiasts, too: some 87% of their supporters are likely to vote. Liberal Democrats came third with 85%. Labour, in contrast, came a clear fourth with only 80% of their supporters in the likely to vote category.

Differences in willingness to vote have clear electoral effects as can be seen by applying these proportions to the results of the Guardian/ ICM poll published on May 16. The table sums it up. Labour's lead over the Tories in that survey was 7%. If we adjust the figures for differences in the likelihood that people will vote, according to our model Labour's lead has to be cut to 3%. The adjusted figures include non-voters (those who we assessed as unlikely to turn out). They expressed a party preference to interviewers but most of them are unlikely to translate that preference into a cross on a ballot paper one bright morn in May 2001 or whenever.

These figures tell us why Labour cannot translate the poll leads it keeps chalking up into victories in real contests. To be fair, there are other recent polls which give Labour a larger lead over the Tories than the Guardian/ ICM survey. But the same need for adjustment applies to them too, namely that polls need to be tempered for the willingness of electors to turn out and vote - if we are to get an accurate picture of the standing of the parties in actual elections.

The evidence also shows clearly how big a problem Labour has in its heartlands. In the southeast of England outside London, some 82% of respondents fall into the "likely to vote" category. In Leeds and Hull they are lethargic. In Yorkshire and Humberside only 65% are in this category. A similar point can be made about Scotland with 75% likely to vote; in the northwest of England 73% are in this group. An extra discount has to be applied to parliamentary seats in these regions because the Tories who live there appear to be more willing to vote than Labour supporters. As a consequence Labour is more likely to lose marginal seats in these areas than in other parts of the country. Since there is also a tendency for working-class people to turn out less than white collar workers, class and geography combine to reduce Labour support in these areas.

Why is this happening? The most popular explanation is that differential turnout reflects disaffection with New Labour's delivery of policies, particularly in relation to the NHS and education. Surprisingly there is not much evidence to support this idea in our survey. There is little difference in turnouts between individuals who think that the government is doing a good job in health and education and those who think it is doing a bad job.

However, just over a fifth of Labour supporters think that the government has done a bad job in managing the economy and they are much less likely to vote than Labour supporters who think that it is doing a good job. The latter group, who are satisfied with the government's performance on the economy, greatly outnumber the dissatisfied but there are enough Labour supporters who dislike Gordon Brown's policies to bring down turnouts.

Most interesting of all is the fact that 28% of Labour supporters think that the government is not being honest and is not trustworthy. Supporters who think this are very much less likely to vote compared with those who think the opposite. So it appears that a combination of generalised disaffection among a minority of Labour supporters over the handling of the economy, coupled with a belief by a larger group that the government cannot be trusted is driving the decline in turnout. This is much more important than specific beefs over the state of the NHS or education.

The scope for changing economic policy at this late stage in the electoral cycle is very limited, but the government can do something about the issue of trust. It should rein in the spin- doctors and stop over-hyping achievements, otherwise it runs a real risk of losing the trust of its supporters and with it the next general election.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University. He collaborated with Harold Clarke, David Sanders and Marianne Stewart of North Texas, Essex and Texas at Dallas Universities, respectively

We asked people to assess the likelihood of their voting at the next general election on a scale from one to ten. Some 71% were categorised as likely voters (with a rating from eight to ten), which is fairly close to the proportion who actually did turn out in 1997. If we compare the size of this group of likely voters across the parties, clear differences emerge in the relationship between support and voting intention. Interestingly enough the nationalists have the most determined backers. Some 94% of their supporters fall into this "likely to vote" group. The Tories are enthusiasts, too: some 87% of their supporters are likely to vote. Liberal Democrats came third with 85%. Labour, in contrast, came a clear fourth with only 80% of their supporters in the likely to vote category. Differences in willingness to vote have clear electoral effects as can be seen by applying these proportions to the results of the Guardian/ ICM poll published on May 16. The table sums it up. Labour's lead over the Tories in that survey was 7%. If we adjust the figures for differences in the likelihood that people will vote, according to our model Labour's lead has to be cut to 3%. The adjusted figures include non-voters (those who we assessed as unlikely to turn out). They expressed a party preference to interviewers but most of them are unlikely to translate that preference into a cross on a ballot paper one bright morn in May 2001 or whenever. These figures tell us why Labour cannot translate the poll leads it keeps chalking up into victories in real contests. To be fair, there are other recent polls which give Labour a larger lead over the Tories than the Guardian/ ICM survey. But the same need for adjustment applies to them too, namely that polls need to be tempered for the willingness of electors to turn out and vote - if we are to get an accurate picture of the standing of the parties in actual elections. The evidence also shows clearly how big a problem Labour has in its heartlands. In the southeast of England outside London, some 82% of respondents fall into the "likely to vote" category. In Leeds and Hull they are lethargic. In Yorkshire and Humberside only 65% are in this category. A similar point can be made about Scotland with 75% likely to vote; in the northwest of England 73% are in this group. An extra discount has to be applied to parliamentary seats in these regions because the Tories who live there appear to be more willing to vote than Labour supporters. As a consequence Labour is more likely to lose marginal seats in these areas than in other parts of the country. Since there is also a tendency for working-class people to turn out less than white collar workers, class and geography combine to reduce Labour support in these areas. Why is this happening? The most popular explanation is that differential turnout reflects disaffection with New Labour's delivery of policies, particularly in relation to the NHS and education. Surprisingly there is not much evidence to support this idea in our survey. There is little difference in turnouts between individuals who think that the government is doing a good job in health and education and those who think it is doing a bad job. However, just over a fifth of Labour supporters think that the government has done a bad job in managing the economy and they are much less likely to vote than Labour supporters who think that it is doing a good job. The latter group, who are satisfied with the government's performance on the economy, greatly outnumber the dissatisfied but there are enough Labour supporters who dislike Gordon Brown's policies to bring down turnouts. Most interesting of all is the fact that 28% of Labour supporters think that the government is not being honest and is not trustworthy. Supporters who think this are very much less likely to vote compared with those who think the opposite. So it appears that a combination of generalised disaffection among a minority of Labour supporters over the handling of the economy, coupled with a belief by a larger group that the government cannot be trusted is driving the decline in turnout. This is much more important than specific beefs over the state of the NHS or education. The scope for changing economic policy at this late stage in the electoral cycle is very limited, but the government can do something about the issue of trust. It should rein in the spin- doctors and stop over-hyping achievements, otherwise it runs a real risk of losing the trust of its supporters and with it the next general election. Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University. He collaborated with Harold Clarke, David Sanders and Marianne Stewart of North Texas, Essex and Texas at Dallas Universities, respectively P.Whiteley@sheffield.ac.uk

webTitle: Hardliners' sharp reminder of deadly threat

fields.headline: Hardliners' sharp reminder of deadly threat
fields.standfirst:
Dissident republicans: Security sources fear one-off attack by small groups could wreck peace

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Small bomb: nobody hurt. In another time or place, the device which left behind little more than a damaged road surface would hardly have raised an eyebrow. Except this was in London, and all that terrorist stuff about Northern Ireland was supposed to be finished.
fields.body:
Small bomb: nobody hurt. In another time or place, the device which left behind little more than a damaged road surface would hardly have raised an eyebrow. Except this was in London, and all that terrorist stuff about Northern Ireland was supposed to be finished.

Yesterday's bomb, which came without a warning, and which security sources believe was the work of dissident republicans, was a wake-up call. As the power-sharing executive met in Belfast for the first time since devolution was restored, it was a sharp reminder against complacency in Britain.

Attacks in Northern Ireland, such as that on an army watchtower in south Armagh last week - the fifth attempted hit on a security force base in three months - garner little media attention. But shutting a bridge on an arterial route into London results in headlines and panic.

Dissident republicans were sowing the seeds of doubt, proving they can still mount attacks, even in England. They aimed to leave people pondering what the group, which killed 29 people in Omagh, Co Tyrone in August 1998, could achieve if it really tried.

It was, too, a warning to security forces in the Irish Republic, who give the impression they have the dissidents under control. Garda ar rested 15 alleged members of the Real IRA last week, including the outfit's 50-year-old leader, after raiding a bomb factory in Dublin.

But yesterday's attack was also designed to embarrass mainstream republicans - the dissidents' favourite trick at critical points in the peace process. They bombed Markethill, Co Armagh, on the day Sinn Fein joined all-party talks in September 1997. The RUC has intercepted several devices at key moments since.

While the former IRA chief of staff Martin McGuinness was attending yesterday's ex ecutive, Gerry Kelly, an ex-IRA hardliner turned leading Sinn Fein figure, was in London to address diplomats. Some find the distinctions between the IRA and dissidents beyond them, and yesterday's bomb made Mr Kelly's task all the more difficult.

According to one security source, Hammersmith Bridge was selected particularly to infuriate mainstream republicans. The IRA failed twice to bomb it, most recently four years ago. To target it now was to highlight both IRA ineptitude and Sinn Fein's sell out.

Security sources on both sides of the Irish border spend little time drawing distinctions between the Real IRA, now three years old, Continuity IRA, dating from the Sinn Fein split of 1986, and dissident elements in the Irish National Liberation Army. They believe they switch flags of convenience as it suits.

But there is no doubt the impetus to dissident republicanism came when the IRA's quartermaster quit the IRA with his partner and a dozen others in the autumn of 1997. They were opposed to Sinn Fein's entry to the talks, and reject the Good Friday agreement which followed in April 1998.

The Real IRA is the largest in a coalition of dissidents, which, security sources estimate, numbers 120 people. But it is unclear how many are either active or potential terrorists.

Security sources are detecting an increase in the shift to the dissidents from the IRA since its offer to put arms beyond use and to allow weapons inspectors to see some of its dumps. However, they say it is hard to quantify.

It is believed that IRA units in hardline areas such as south Armagh and east Tyrone may have secured guarantees from the leadership that their arms dumps will be excluded from any inspections. The former ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa and ex-Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari are expected to be taken to the first dumps this month.

A recent BBC Northern Ireland poll underlined the splits within republicanism. No fewer than 22.5% of Sinn Fein voters believed the initiative was tantamount to surrender.

That may sound an easily manageable figure, but strip away the middle-class Catholic support Sinn Fein is now en joying because of the IRA ceasefire, and it is clear that the figure rises dramatically among the party's natural constituency. Sinn Fein has only moved forward with difficult policies when the leadership has 90% backing.

The Real IRA has, officially, remained on the ceasefire it called in the aftermath of the Omagh bombing - the largest single atrocity of the Troubles. No one is much convinced.

The Continuity IRA was predominantly seen as a few grey-haired ideologues linked to Republican Sinn Fein. Led by the former IRA chief Ruairi O Bradaigh, it broke away in 1986 over Sinn Fein's decision to recognise the Irish parliament - a key step in the Adams-McGuinness strategy.

The Continuity IRA, which has never killed anyone in Ireland, is the only republican outfit not on ceasefire. Its name has been used to claim attacks this year which were the work of the Real IRA, to the fury of its more philosophically pure figures.

There was a short warning when dissident republicans attacked a hotel in Co Fermanagh in February, just as the tumultuous developments leading to the suspension of the devolved institutions were getting under way. The blast was claimed by Continuity IRA, though one of its leading figures later denied it.

Dissidents gave no warnings in March when they attempted to bomb an army barracks at Ballykelly, Co Londonderry and Dungannon, Co Tyrone. Nor was there any claim of responsibility.

They also tried to bomb Ebrington barracks in Londonderry, an army base in Co Fermanagh and the Glassdrummond army watchtower in south Armagh. The RUC in March intercepted a 500lb homemade car bomb outside Hillsborough, Co Down. It is believed it was intended for Thiepval Barracks in nearby Lisburn, which was bombed by the IRA four years ago.

Until yesterday dissidents had failed to mount an attack in Britain. Three youngsters were jailed last year after they were caught in an amateurish effort to firebomb stores in London. A car bomb was intercepted in April 1998, the month the agreement was signed, as its driver was taking it from Dublin to Holyhead.

Semtex was seized in Dublin last week and in an earlier raid on a training camp, so the dissidents have now breached IRA security. Security sources fear a unit is in place in south-east England.

While they remain confident the Real IRA has neither enough expertise or widespread support to mount a concerted campaign, either in Northern Ireland or Britain, they believe it could carry out a one-off spectacular. And they know that might be all they need to bring the fragile peace process crashing down.

webTitle: Downfall of surgeon who ruined lives

fields.headline: Downfall of surgeon who ruined lives
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of women suffered at the hands of the 'fastest gynaecologist in the south-east'. Yet it took 16 years to stop his arrogance and bullying
fields.trailText: Rodney Ledward was greeted as "a breath of fresh air" when he first arrived at the William Harvey Hospital at Ashford, Kent, in January 1980.
fields.body:
Rodney Ledward was greeted as "a breath of fresh air" when he first arrived at the William Harvey Hospital at Ashford, Kent, in January 1980.

A flamboyant character with an impeccable track record and a glowing CV, the gynaecologist looked set for a glittering career and was even described by a former patient as "very dashing, quite the Women's Weekly Hero".

He was regarded by his colleagues in Ashford as an eccentric character, who regularly arrived for consultations wearing riding boots and jodhpurs, and occasionally gave his patients carnations.

But in the inquiry report published yesterday, he was criticised for arrogance, lack of compassion and his "intimidating and frightening" manner with patients and junior staff, whom he regularly "belittled".

He claimed to be "the fastest gynaecologist in the south-east" after he performed seven hysterectomies in three hours and 40 minutes.

It was this attention to the speed rather than the quality of his work which led to his downfall - and to that of the hundreds of women he treated in the 16 years he worked at the William Harvey.

Mr Ledward obtained a degree in pharmacy in 1959 before becoming a mature medical student, but after a series of house officer, senior house officer and registrar jobs at hospitals across Britain, he was appointed senior registrar at the City and Women's hospital in Nottingham and clinical teacher at Nottingham university in 1975. He was also seconded to the Riyadh military hospital in Saudi Arabia in 1979, months before joining the William Harvey.

During his years in Kent he reaped lucrative fees for his extensive private work, based at various private hospitals, including St Saviour's clinic in Hythe.

Now 62 and living alone in Ireland, Mr Ledward has never made any secret of his love of the high life. He has a £750,000 bungalow and stud farm in County Cork, and a Rolls-Royce.

His careless attitude was evident even before Mr Ledward moved to Kent, according to the inquiry team chaired by Jean Ritchie, QC. "There was something slapdash and unmethodical in his character; an element of seeing what he could get away with," the report said.

Concerned GPs were said to have had deep worries about Mr Ledward early on, but most "tended to bury their heads in the sand".

By 1991 there was ample evidence that something was terribly wrong with his work but junior doctors and nursing staff were reluctant to speak out in a "closed and closet atmosphere where there was and probably still is a culture of junior doctors being reluctant to criticise their seniors". A nurse who planned to speak to the inquiry was told by her colleagues: "More fool you."

"It is our impression that everyone hoped that someone else would deal with Rodney Ledward," the report concluded, something which they blamed in part on his powerful and stubborn personality. "We found the analogy with Mr Toad very graphic," the inquiry team noted.

Although hundreds of patients have come forward to complain about Mr Ledward since he was struck off by the General Medical Council in 1998, only a handful of women complained at the time of their treatment.

Most thought they had just been unlucky, while many simply did not know how or to whom to complain, and others were too embarrassed to discuss intimate problems such as incontinence.

Yet, despite the huge number of complications, "it never seems to have crossed his mind that there was anything amiss with his technique. He seems to have been supremely confident in his abilities and actions," the report found.

His self-belief was not even shaken in 1993 when he was dismissed from his contracts at two private hospitals in Kent - the Buckland hospital in Dover, and the Chaucer private hospital in Canterbury - following complaints from patients.

It was not until 1996 that his colleagues at Ashford finally blew the whistle on Mr Ledward when they were unable to contact him as a patient he had treated lay bleeding to death. Even after he was struck off by the GMC for gross professional misconduct, some staff closest to him claimed he was the "victim of a vendetta".

Nevertheless, the Ritchie report, ordered in March 1999 by the then health secretary Frank Dobson, raised serious concerns not only about Mr Ledward's medical skills but also his surgical practice, accusing him of pressurising NHS patients to go private, asking patients to bring cash with them when they were admitted for surgery and having a cold and bullying attitude.

Among the litany of complaints against him were numerous cases of rushed and incompetent surgery, in which he repeatedly made mistakes that surgeons would normally expect to make only once or twice in their entire careers, numerous unnecessary operations, and damage to patients' bladders, kidneys and livers, about which they were never told.

The report also notes compaints about Mr Ledward's brutality in internal examinations - some of which were undertaken without gloves - and routine belittling of patients.

A woman was pressurised to have a caesarean birth five weeks early because he was going on holiday. She refused and went on to bear a healthy child. Another was attended by Ledward in riding clothes. Tapping his boots with a riding crop, he suggested her post-operative complications were her own fault and asked: "Who's a naughty girl then?"

A woman of 22 was told she had cancer which would kill her in six months if she did not have a hysterectomy. The operation was carried out but, the report says, there was no evidence that she had cancer.

Officials at East Kent NHS trust yesterday apologised to Mr Ledward's former patients, insisting that the lessons of his case had been learned.

But Mr Ledward, who gave only written evidence because he is reported to be suffering from terminal prostate cancer, was travelling to Spain for a holiday, insisting - as he has all along - that he has done nothing wrong.

fields.headline: Victims recollect levels of incompetence
fields.trailText: Valerie Cant, 66, from Folkestone, Kent, almost died of renal failure following a hysterectomy performed by Ledward.
fields.body:
Valerie Cant, 66, from Folkestone, Kent, almost died of renal failure following a hysterectomy performed by Ledward.

He cut her uterus tubes during her first operation in July 1980, then performed an operation for renal problems - surgery which he was not qualified to perform. She was readmitted to the William Harvey hospital, in Ashford, with septicaemia.

Her life was saved by a doctor who performed an emergency kidney operation 15 months later.

She said: "I personally think Ledward belongs in prison. I think he is mentally unbalanced, someone who gets satisfaction from the power he has over women. At first I trusted him. It was only when his case became known that I realised what had been done to me."

Brenda Johnson , 53, of Folkestone, has suffered constant pain and bladder problems since she was operated on by Ledward.

She went to him in 1981 with a bladder problem and he told her she needed a hysterectomy. Later she discovered there was a less drastic alternative.

Ledward's procedure left her bleeding "all day and all night". She had to undergo a "brutal emergency operation" to save her life. She has not worked since.

Mrs Johnson, who helped found the victim support group, said: "They call for strong managers and better management - so what have they got now, a bunch of idiots? This man destroyed lives and there was a big 16-year cover up."

Ann Dowling , 60, from Dover, Kent, was left with a hole in her bladder after Ledward let junior doctors perform her hysterectomy at the William Harvey hospital in 1984. Despite four more operations since then, she has remained incontinent as a result of the bungled first operation.

Mrs Dowling said: "I thought Ledward would do the operation, as it was major surgery and supposed to be done by a consultant, but he left it to a junior doctor. It has ruined my life. I was left in pain and unable to work for 11 years."

She was critical of his attitude. "Ledward used to sweep through the ward like a god. It was as if he was saying: 'Who are you to ask me questions?' When I went back to him after the operation and said I had problems, he just said it was normal and dismissed me with a wave of his hands."

fields.headline: MPs look into Blair's 'secret department'
fields.standfirst:
Select committee examines allegations that prime minister's insistence on centralised government has put Britain in constitutional limbo

Downing Street website
fields.trailText: A claim that the prime minister has set up a secret department under his direct control is to be examined by the Commons select committee on public administration.
fields.body:
A claim that the prime minister has set up a secret department under his direct control is to be examined by the Commons select committee on public administration.

The committee, chaired by the Tony Wright, Labour MP for Cannock Chase, has already made an unprecedented request for Tony Blair to appear before it to discuss the civil service code. But the committee is planning a wider inquiry into the degree to which he has, in an ad hoc fashion, set up his own central government department.

It is expected to call in Lord Falconer, Mr Blair's right-hand man in the Cabinet Office, Sir Richard Wilson, head of the civil service, and Lord Simon, Mr Blair's adviser on reform of the civil service.

Lord Simon has been pressing the prime minister to set up an inner cabinet and revolutionise the communication of information within government. The committee is expected to question him on claims that the government's anti-poverty strategy is hopelessly ill coordinated across departments, despite claims that Mr Blair is running a "joined-up" administration.

It is expected that Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, will be asked to give evidence.

A member of the select committee claimed that Britain was in constitutional limbo, with Mr Blair determined to create a strong centre without any form of political accountability.

The committee also plans to examine the relationship between the Treasury and the new prime minister's department. Apart from the social exclusion unit, the strategic communication unit, the performance and innovation unit and the centre for management and policy studies, Mr Blair has brought into the Cabinet Office the central information technology unit, the government communications and information service, the chief scientific officer, the prime minister's e-envoy, the efficiency and effectiveness unit, and the anti-drugs coordination unit.

In addition he has his expanded policy unit, dedicated to addressing issues in a cross-departmental way and acting as Mr Blair's eyes and ears in all areas of government. The unit oversees the bilateral ministerial meetings that form the centrepiece of government decision making.

The development is in part a reflection of the pressure on all governments, but it also reflects Mr Blair's impatience with the slowness of government.

In a lecture a fortnight ago, Peter Hennessy, the eminent constitutional historian, described the prime minister's department and quoted a senior figure as saying it was "an extremely flexible and informal piece of central government machinery. It makes it possible to bring a large number of advisers at short notice".

"The centre is now not just a person, the prime minister, and a small staff, it is a machinery around him.

"Almost all the people in this structure hold office at the pleasure of the PM. It is, sui generis, a case apart from the rest of Whitehall."

Professor Hennessy claimed that the only additional responsibility given to cabinet members since Mr Blair took command was "the grid", a memo compiled by the strategic communications unit, a copy of which is published on this page.

"The grid integrates over the coming week all important government announcements and initiatives, interweaving them with sporting or cultural events and, where known, what the opposition is planning to do," Prof Hennessy said.

Sir Richard has admitted "there is a greater effort to coordinate, in a strategic way, presentation of the government's policies and messages in a positive light across the whole of government than I can remember since the time I have been in the senior civil service".

Alongside the grid, the strategic communications unit sends ministers key themes for the week. For the week of May 15-21, these were based on the four set piece speeches of the week.

The memo states: "TB is keen that all ministers should be referring to each other's work, in this instance drawing together these four big speeches to explain: we have a clear mission and purpose; we have set out the goals; we are making progress towards them; we have further to go ... (Monday) no child need grow up in poverty; (Tuesday) families are protected from boom and bust and enjoy rising living standards; (Wednesday) people need not live in fear; (Thursday) we can get an NHS fit for the 21st century."

The message goes on: "Big goals. Big argument. Serious government versus opportunistic opposition."

The drive for the prime minister's department and its evolution along the lines of the White House model came from Mr Blair's desire to avoid gridlock in the civil service, the NHS, the EU and, at one point during the Balkans war, Nato, said Prof Hennessy.

Workings of the inner cabinet

 Social exclusion unit

Set up in 1998; produced reports on truancy and school exclusion, rough sleeping, poor neighbourhoods, teenage pregnancy

 Strategic communications unit

Run from Downing Street by permanent civil servants and special advisers; coordinates government announcements, advises departments and works with the No 10 press office

 Performance and innovation unit

Aims to improve capacity to address strategic, cross-departmental issues and promote innovation in policy development. Reports direct to PM

 Centre for management and policy studies

Based in the Cabinet Office, incorporating the civil service college; runs joint policy seminars to enable ministers and civil servants to learn together

webTitle: Consultants call for reform of GMC

fields.headline: Consultants call for reform of GMC
fields.trailText: Hospital consultants yesterday called for wholesale reform of the General Medical Council, claiming it had lost the confidence of the medical profession, in a move likely to have reverberations throughout the health service.
fields.body:
Hospital consultants yesterday called for wholesale reform of the General Medical Council, claiming it had lost the confidence of the medical profession, in a move likely to have reverberations throughout the health service.

The British Medical Association's annual consultants' conference unanimously passed a motion of no confidence in the GMC, the profession's regulatory body, as it is at present constituted and functioning.

Delegates accused the GMC, made up of elected doctors and members of the public appointed by the Privy Council, of pandering to the media and politicians by making kneejerk responses and failing to convey a positive image of the profession.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the central consultants and specialists committee, said it was time the GMC "reformed itself and reformed itself radically".

He accused the GMC of failing to protect patients or to guide doctors.

The GMC has been under fire for some time because of the length of time it takes to adjudicate on cases brought against doctors.

Speaking against the motion Sir Denis Pereira-Gray, of the Royal College of General Practitioners, said the move would divide the British medical profession for the first time since the 19th century by splitting hospital doctors from GPs.

As expected, the hospital consultants rejected proposals for a new grade of specialist doctor to work alongside consultants.

Delegates unanimously passed a motion to resist at all costs the Department of Health's proposal.

webTitle: Tebbit speaks: 'Too many gay ministers and Hague's small, bald with odd voice'

fields.headline: Tebbit speaks: 'Too many gay ministers and Hague's small, bald with odd voice'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The government has too many gay ministers, the former Conservative party chairman, Lord Tebbit, complains today.
fields.body:
The government has too many gay ministers, the former Conservative party chairman, Lord Tebbit, complains today.

In an interview in the New Statesman, the uncompromising rightwinger complains that the number of gay people in government is "over quota" compared with a male homosexual population which he claims is 2%.

However, the peer and Tory elder statesman once known as the Chingford skinhead, also suggests that the same trend may be reflected in his own party, though he dismisses any question marks over the sexuality of his married party leader William Hague.

The peer's outspoken remarks will not surprise either Labour opponents or moderates in his own party who have been outraged in previous years by his hardline views. His intolerant reputation was sealed more than 10 years ago when he suggested, amid spiralling unemployment, that jobless people look to the example of his own father - a former pawnbroker - who "got on his bike" and searched for work.

No gay minister should be home secretary, he argues, saying: "The Home Office is responsible for laws affecting society - the adoption of children and the strengthening of the family. It is better not in the care of someone who doesn't feel for those issues."

Asked whether his party leader is among the "one or two people" he knows in his own party who are "very good and who, I suspect, may be homosexual", he says: "Nah, I think he and Ffion are very happy."

Other politicians have been accused of being gay when in fact they were celibate, he says. "For example, there's Ted Heath. He was celibate. But Ted wasn't a raving queer."

Confirming the reality of the Tory leader's shift to the right, regularly denied by central office, Lord Tebbit offers Mr Hague a series of backhanded compliments.

"Something somewhere sparked him off and suddenly he became an interesting politician - having previously been uninteresting," he says.

But he adds, crushingly: "As he gets more interesting, people forget that he's bald, he's got an unusual voice and he's small."

But, in a damaging analysis coming just as his party believes it has finally turned a corner and is closing on Labour at the polls, he acknowledges it will be "hard for Mr Hague to win an election". He blames the stable economy, widespread job security and sense among voters that they are comfortably off, which will be difficult for the Conservatives to counter.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, who returned to parliament last December as MP for Kensington and Chelsea, is one of the prime targets of Lord Tebbit's broadside.

Mr Portillo's failure to tell the whole truth about past gay experiences prompts the peer to suggest that the man once considered his successor as darling of the Tory right is unlikely to take over from Mr Hague as Conservative leader.

Lord Tebbit supported the former Enfield Southgate MP in his campaign to rejoin the Commons, arguing that his youthful experiences should not be an obstacle, but was furious when further allegations of a longer gay affair - rejected as "completely inaccurate" by the shadow chancellor - emerged.

He says today: "Michael made a terrible mistake. His initial answer was truthful but it didn't embrace the whole truth ... It was damaging for him, because he didn't do that."

Lord Tebbit, who criticises Mr Hague's decision to drop fellow rightwinger John Redwood from his shadow cabinet, suggests Mr Portillo's recently softened image is more accurate than the hardline approach he once adopted.

Clearly irritated at the shadow chancellor's call while outside parliament for a more "compassionate Conservatism", he says: "I have never been a Portillo fan. I could never make him out.

"Remember his great SAS speech? Who dares wins. It made my toes curl in my shoes because it was so singularly inappropriate.

"I never thought Michael was the tough, rightwing ideologue he presented himself as - that was not the natural Portillo. We have seen the more natural Portillo since."

The shadow chancellor now seems "hesitant" and will take "a few years" to reestablish himself, he says. "By the time Hague goes, the Redwood/Portillo generation will look rather outdated."

fields.headline: Because it's there
fields.standfirst: Explorer's exploits
fields.trailText: Explorer's exploits
fields.body:
1981 Made one of the fastest ascents of Mount McKinley in Alaska.

1982-1995 Climbed the highest mountain in each continent.

1984 First person to reach the magnetic north pole alone, with no dogs, snow mobiles or air supplies.

1996 Walked 680 miles alone to the geographic south pole, losing 1lb of body weight a day. He later went to the magnetic south pole, becoming the first person to reach both in the same year.

1998 Hauled a 150lb sledge unsupported for 600 miles across shifting pack ice to the geographic north pole, becoming the first person to complete the explorers' "grand slam" of the geographic and magnetic north and south poles and the highest mountain in each continent.

1998 First person to balloon solo over the Andes in an open basket with no parachute. Angelique Chrisafis

webTitle: Up, up but still 12.9 miles away ...

fields.headline: Up, up but still 12.9 miles away ...
fields.standfirst: Balloonist claims north pole record - but misses top of world
fields.trailText: Another curious chapter in Britain's troubled relationship with the polar icecaps was written yesterday when balloonist David Hempleman-Adams just missed his goal of becoming the first person to fly over the top of the world.
fields.body:
Another curious chapter in Britain's troubled relationship with the polar icecaps was written yesterday when balloonist David Hempleman-Adams just missed his goal of becoming the first person to fly over the top of the world.

Crouched in the chilly wicker basket of his balloon and sucking boiled sweets in the Captain Scott tradition of roughing it unnecessarily, the Wiltshire businessman nonetheless claimed an endurance triumph and his "mission control" near Birmingham cracked open the champagne.

That his balloon, the Britannic Challenge, was actually 12.9 nautical miles adrift of the invisible dot where the world's lines of longitude meet was airily dismissed as meaningless in a world of constantly shifting icefloes.

"There isn't a sign saying 'Welcome to the north pole' anyway," said Clive Bailey, the logistics director of what organisers are calling an epic journey - even though it only began on Sunday afternoon. "If you put one up now, it would have drifted 50 miles away by tomorrow morning."

The fogbound adventurer was drifting home towards Spitzbergen last night, after delivering the quintessential British reaction over a satellite phone to Brum. "I'm looking forward to a cup of tea and a sleep," he told Mr Bailey. "I've only had four hours sleep in the past four days and I need to get my head down."

His prolonged dangle beneath an ice-freckled gasbag was marked by similar hazards to those which faced Scott, Shackleton and his other predecessors in the polar wastes. Hempleman-Adams, 43, ran out of pork scratchings, almost froze to a lavatory seat and suffered from sleep-walking. After only four hours of sleep in 84 hours of flying, he woke to find himself 4,000ft above the icecap, trying to clamber out of his wicker nest - an unpressurised secondhand basket previously used to take tourists over Bristol.

A spokeswoman for the mission said: "Luckily, part of his safety equipment is a harness which stopped him getting out, but it's given him an almighty fright. When he called in to tell us, he was quite shaken up and the conversation was turning the air blue."

The venture was nearly aborted on Wednesday night when Arctic airflows threatened to send the balloon bobbing back towards Iceland, but intervention by the sponsors Britannic Assurance stiffened morale. "The sales and marketing director came into mission control and said there'd be a very large sum of money for the charity of David's choice for every mile we kept going," Mr Bailey said.

Polar legends

The Britannic Challenge balloon had equipment which the great polar legends could only dream of - including an autopilot - but its crude basic design of a tent inside a log basket meant that Hempleman-Adams was at real risk of freezing or meeting a speedy end in the Arctic ocean. To avoid the latter, he wore a complete immersion suit for the three days of the flight over the sea - for those who wonder about the intimate details, he filled one whole leg of it with waste.

Over the ice, that side of things was dealt with by a portable lavatory whose insulated seat had to be checked regularly to prevent adhesion. "Even so," said Mr Bailey, "David said that was the most uncomfortable perch he had on the ride."

The sea crossing earned Hempleman-Adams the genuine title of the first person to balloon solo across the Arctic ocean. He used a scaled-down version of the Breitling Orbiter, the balloon which went round the world non-stop last year.

But the adventurer, who has three daughters, modelled his modest basket on the Eagle balloon which crashed on its way to the north pole in 1897, killing the Swedish pioneer Solomon Andree, two companions and 35 carrier pigeons.

On board the Britannic Challenger, the explorer carried a sledge, tent, shotgun, rations, sleeping bag, flares and a dinghy. He longed, he revealed in a diary phoned in exclusively to the Birmingham Post, for someone to bring him a takeaway pizza.

Final co-ordinates were changed to end the flight about the width of Birmingham short of the pole when the balloon crossed the polar ring - an area generally recognised as sufficiently close to the pole because of the area's loose ice and stretches of unfrozen water. Mr Bailey told him over the satellite link: "We are absolutely ecstatic. You've done it. You have made history."

There were, however, no reports of the magic moment on international, as opposed to British, news agency wires.

fields.headline: Ministers push for healthier eating
fields.standfirst:
Food industry and schools urged to offer children better diets

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Food industry and schools urged to offer children better diets
fields.body:
Food industry executives will be asked to tone down the way they advertise fizzy drinks, crisps and snacks popular with children and help to promote healthy lifestyles instead, after a government study revealed that young people were eating far too little fruit and vegetables.

The style of TV commercials, education materials in schools and nutritional information on labels are expected to be discussed in meetings between the companies and the food standards agency.

Ministers are expected to lay down nutritional guidelines in schools amid mounting fears that some children find it easier to get drugs than cheap, good food.

The guidelines will not tell parents what they must put in children's lunchboxes, but school canteens will be told that from next April they must ensure a proper choice of four main categories of food: fruit and vegetables, meat and protein, starchy foods, and milk and dairy products.

The government, ever sensitive to the charge of creating a nanny state, will settle for voluntary agreements but is worried by renewed evidence that the poorest children are eating least fruit and veg and storing up the potential for health problems in later life. It also wants action to cut children's sugar and salt intake.

But the industry trade body, the Food and Drink Federation, said "the ciabatta and sun-dried tomatoes set's patronising approach does not work".

A spokesman, Martin Paterson, said: "Ask anyone in the street; they all know they should eat five portions of fruit and veg each day, but most would confess to not doing so. The issue is not communicating the message but converting it into action."

The study of the diets of more than 2,000 children aged four to 18 over a week in 1997 suggested that on average British young people were eating fewer than half the recommended five portions. One in five children ate no fruit over the week and most did not take enough exercise.

A third of girls aged 15 to 18 smoked, while only 20% ate citrus fruits. They also drank two thirds more fizzy drinks than milk. One in 10 said they were vegetarian or vegan, and one in six said they were trying to lose weight.

But there was no evidence of widespread malnourishment, and consumption of fat was falling.

Suzi Leather, deputy chairwoman of the food agency, said it was considering developing a code of practice with industry on the promotion of food.

"Diet has increasingly become a marker for social exclusion, with an increasing nutrition gap mirroring the income divide," she said.

Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, said the government had to ensure that the situation changed. "Work by the social exclusion unit has showed that on many low income estates there is no access to shops selling affordable fruit and vegetables."

Pilot schemes to improve diets and kitchen skills through education and community programmes are under way. There is also increasing government pressure on supermarkets to help corner shops to survive.

Sausage fry-up for breakfast, lager for lunch

Jimmy Henshaw, 17, from Longsight, Manchester. Left school last year. Mother: cleaner

"Today for breakfast, I cooked myself two fried eggs, four sausages and three pieces of white bread. I always do myself a fry-up in the mornings. At 1pm, I had a fag and two lagers. For lunch I'll have a Big Mac and chips and a vanilla milkshake. For tea I'll probably have a Chinese takeaway.

Ministers are expected to lay down nutritional guidelines in schools amid mounting fears that some children find it easier to get drugs than cheap, good food. The guidelines will not tell parents what they must put in children's lunchboxes, but school canteens will be told that from next April they must ensure a proper choice of four main categories of food: fruit and vegetables, meat and protein, starchy foods, and milk and dairy products. The government, ever sensitive to the charge of creating a nanny state, will settle for voluntary agreements but is worried by renewed evidence that the poorest children are eating least fruit and veg and storing up the potential for health problems in later life. It also wants action to cut children's sugar and salt intake. But the industry trade body, the Food and Drink Federation, said "the ciabatta and sun-dried tomatoes set's patronising approach does not work". A spokesman, Martin Paterson, said: "Ask anyone in the street; they all know they should eat five portions of fruit and veg each day, but most would confess to not doing so. The issue is not communicating the message but converting it into action." "Work by the social exclusion unit has showed that on many low income estates there is no access to shops selling affordable fruit and vegetables." webTitle: 'No tits' men's mag gets bum's rush

fields.headline: 'No tits' men's mag gets bum's rush
fields.trailText: A men's magazine that eschewed the "tits and bums" formula favoured by big sellers such as Loaded and FHM is closing after only two issues.
fields.body:
A men's magazine that eschewed the "tits and bums" formula favoured by big sellers such as Loaded and FHM is closing after only two issues.

Men's Quest, which banned scantily clad women and chose not to take advertising, thought it could succeed by presenting serious journalism to readers who had outgrown more puerile publications. But it has fallen victim to its ambition: the magazine's first print run was set far too high, at 100,000.

Admitting defeat yesterday, its founder and publisher, Angus Kennedy, said: "It's better to fail at doing something good than succeed at doing something wicked. We stuck to our policy of no bums or tits, and it probably finished us off."

The magazine's first issue had features about prostate cancer, buying a car in Europe and "cerebral health". The second moved on to wine, books and property. It was far removed from the celebrity and sport mix favoured by big-name rivals.

Sales figures are not yet available, but the magazine needed to sell 35,000 a month to stay afloat.

Mr Kennedy insisted yesterday that there was a market for a serious-minded publication such as Men's Quest.

"It was an antidote to the current offerings of men's magazines - great though they are, there didn't appear to be anything for guys in their 30s who had moved on from fast cars, clubbing in Ibiza and downing 20 pints every night, to making serious decisions about buying a house and getting married." He had lost almost £200,000 in the venture. He was now talking to a number of magazine publishers with a view to securing a partnership that would allow the magazine to continue in some form. "I still believe it will sell, and it is selling. We achieved a big following."

He said it was difficult for entrepreneurs in Britain to find the right backing for good ideas. "If you want to start a magazine this is not the country to do it in. I have given up on venture capitalists, and business angels are no use. Our local enterprise company didn't have a clue. There is just no support."

If Mr Kennedy manages to save his venture he plans to set up a publishing house to nurse new magazine ideas. "I'll call it the People's Publishing Company," he said.

FHM is by far the most popular men's magazine, with sales of 700,000. Loaded sells about 370,000 and Maxim about 310,000.

Distributors told Mr Kennedy he needed to print at least 100,000 if he wanted his publication to be taken seriously, but even the well-established GQ sells only about 140,000 copies.

webTitle: Blunkett pledges backing for heads on violent pupils

fields.headline: Blunkett pledges backing for heads on violent pupils
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pupils excluded for violent behaviour should not be allowed to return to school against the wishes of the headteacher, David Blunkett, the education secretary, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Pupils excluded for violent behaviour should not be allowed to return to school against the wishes of the headteacher, David Blunkett, the education secretary, said yesterday.

In a speech to the National Association of Head Teachers conference in Jersey, Mr Blunkett pledged to deal with most of a raft of complaints raised by delegates this week, unveiling plans to reduce council control of budgets, promising a "levelling up" of school funding across the country and launching a war on red tape.

In response to an NAHT claim that heads were being forced to take back violent pupils against their will, Mr Blunkett said he was considering new instructions to independent appeal panels not to override heads when pupils had been excluded for "violence or the threat of severe violence".

His recent call to this effect had not "entirely filtered through."

But he was confident that new guidance would not affect his campaign to reduce exclusions by a third by 2002 from their present level of 12,000.

Mr Blunkett said his proposal to separate school and local education authority budgets "would cut away the undergrowth and ensure that every penny is spent on teachers and training".

Local education authorities take between 20p and 30p in every £1 for education. But under Mr Blunkett's plan LEAs would be left with "a bare minimum" role.

Heads would be in control of their budgets in a fashion similar to the system for grant maintained schools introduced by the previous Tory government.

In the expectation of a substantial cash injection for education after Gordon Brown's comprehensive spending review, Mr Blunkett said: "Whatever funding formula we adopt there will not be losers. There will have to be levelling up, not levelling down." The Local Government Association said that was unlikely, and predicted a national funding agency for schools could cost £300m a year to run.

The plan will depend on the green paper on local government finance being published by John Prescott, environment secretary, next month. Education accounts for 40% of local government spending.

David Hart, NAHT general secretary, said: "I think that the government is moving as close as it possibly can to make all schools quasi-grant maintained. I certainly don't think schools will have any qualms about that."

The shadow education secretary, Teresa May, said the Tories would hand over the entire school budget to heads.

On the row over admissions to Oxford, Mr Blunkett urged schools and further education colleges to try to match the help given students in private schools when applying for university - including, as for Oxford, preparing them for interview.

Department for Education and Employment

webTitle: Millionaire given life term for killing wife

fields.headline: Millionaire given life term for killing wife
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman who suffocated his wife with a pillow when she told him he was mean for not wanting to buy her a flat in an exclusive district of London was jailed for life yesterday.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman who suffocated his wife with a pillow when she told him he was mean for not wanting to buy her a flat in an exclusive district of London was jailed for life yesterday.

Malcolm Horsman, 66, was found guilty at the Old Bailey of murdering his Swiss-born wife, Ursula, whose body he left on the bathroom floor in their leased flat in Knightsbridge while he went "through the routine of the day". He told police of the death only after he clinched a £1m takeover deal and paid £15,000 in bills.

Horsman showed no emotion as the jury rejected his claim that the death of his wife, an art specialist, had been an accident.

The court had heard that he had already bought Mrs Horsman, 54, a £300,000 apartment in Switzerland and she had wanted him to buy the £730,000 flat in Belgravia. When he argued that they needed only one home, she allegedly told him: "The trouble with you is that you're mean, and everybody says so."

The Recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, jailed Horsman for life but did not specify a tariff. He said: "It is clearly a tragic case, and you must pay the penalty for what you have done."

As he was led from the dock Horsman, who defended himself after being refused legal aid, asked the judge if he thought there were grounds for appeal. He was advised to seek legal advice. Horsman's daughter, Juliet Hope, 36, an investment banker, said afterwards: "We are launching an appeal straight away."

Horsman was arrested in December 1998 after walking into a police station and saying his wife was dead.

He told police that the "drip, drip" of her constant and forceful remarks over property were hurtful, the court heard. He had snapped when he took his wife the morning papers on December 16 and she began nagging him. The pair had wrestled on the bed and may have fallen on the floor.

The next Horsman could recall was that his wife was limp. She had made a sound resembling a "death rattle". He dragged her into the bathroom, stripped off her nightgown and threw it in the bath with his pyjamas. After wrap ping the body in a sheet, he tidied the bedroom and resolved to carry on with his routine "to get some of his sanity back".

Horsman told the court: "I have no idea how it happened. It was the most bizarre and traumatic thing. She was my companion, the person I loved. We had a very happy marriage."

Her comment about his being mean "was the most extraordinary remark anyone could make to me. It was so unfair, so hurtful, so I went forward and put my hands on her shoulders." The death could have been an accident, he said.

Horseman, a director of two companies which specialise in company recovery and a former director of the Bowater Corporation, married Ursula, his second wife, in 1983.

After the verdict, Horsman declined to pay prosecution costs of £19,504, saying the 12 months' jail in default did not really matter when he was facing 20 years. The judge praised him for conducting his case "in a polite and courteous" way.

Outside court, Detective Sergeant Wilf Hodder said: "I do not think he was mean, but I don't think he wanted to buy the house in Belgravia or the flat in Switzerland. Under pressure he acted in this callous way.

"The fact that he defended himself shows that he is man who wants to be in control. He does not like people disagreeing with him."

webTitle: Speight celebrates concessions by Fiji's new military rulers

fields.headline: Speight celebrates concessions by Fiji's new military rulers
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: A heady cocktail of alcohol, a local drug called kava and knowledge of imminent victory clearly packed a powerful punch for the Fijian coup leader, George Speight, last night.
fields.body:
A heady cocktail of alcohol, a local drug called kava and knowledge of imminent victory clearly packed a powerful punch for the Fijian coup leader, George Speight, last night.

He was in party mood as his 2,000-strong rag-tag army celebrated the news that the failed businessman turned hostage taker had won further major concessions from the country's nascent military regime to settle the two-week political crisis.

"How do I look? Do I look happy?" a clearly intoxicated but composed Mr Speight told the Guardian when asked how the day had gone. "You can't have a meeting in Fiji without having kava," he said by way of explanation. "You have to follow traditional correctness."

Kava is a stimulant drink made by mixing extract of a local root vegetable with water. It is not a banned substance, although its effects can be stronger than alcohol.

Angry scowls that had been a feature of most of the rebels' faces for the past 10 days were replaced by cheerful grins; taunts and obscenities gave way to traditional, albeit slurred, folk songs.

In several hours of talks with Commodore Frank Bainimarama, the commander of Fiji's armed forces, who on Monday declared martial law, Mr Speight first secured his three initial demands: that the prime minister be replaced; the constitution torn up; and an amnesty for him and his lieutenants.

Then the 44-year-old former insurance executive wrung the key promise out of Cmdr Bainimarama that is likely to lead to the release of the 30-odd hostages, including the ousted ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry. Mr Speight and some of his men are to have places in the new interim government, although none is expected to become prime minister.

Applause and incantations issued from the drawn-out meetings that began when military officers escorted an unarmed Mr Speight from the parliament compound to the Queen Elizabeth barracks, perched on a hill overlooking the capital.

Mr Speight refused to divulge details of the deal, which had been described as "a very major breakthrough" three hours earlier by a military spokesman, Captain Eroni Volavola. But Mr Speight said: "Monday, that's D-day for everyone."

Fiji's ethnic Indian community which makes up 44% of the population now faces a bleak future as power returns to the indigenous Fijians.

As it does, the true nature of Mr Speight's victory over the forces of democracy will become plain.

"The economy will suffer enormously, we will probably see a brain drain and greater demands from some provinces for independence," Samisoni Pareti, a senior journalist with the Fiji Broadcasting Corporation, said.

Some regions are already becoming restless, he said, particularly those in the west of the main island, Viti Levu. "They have the resources, lower unemployment, some of the best tourist destinations and the international airport. They could easily survive by themselves."

Many areas nearer Suva, including Mr Speight's home, are much poorer and definitely not self-sufficient. Unemployment is well over 33% and there is little hope of an immediate economic upturn, particularly now that the coup has shattered the tourist industry.

Remaining loyal only to their commanders, it is unclear how the troops who are currently manning dozens of roadblocks around Suva would act if the country's unity came under threat.

But many Fijians are more concerned by the floundering fortunes of Fiji's rugby team than politics, although none can deny that the events of the last two weeks will have an impact on their lives.

Mr Speight has achieved his goals. The only remaining question is how complete will his victory be.

fields.headline: 'Elitist' Oxford don rounds on ministers
fields.standfirst:
'Real scandal' is lack of cash to help dyslexics, says professor

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: 'Real scandal' is lack of cash to help dyslexics, says professor
fields.body:
A pioneering research programme to help youngsters overcome dyslexia and other early reading problems is facing extinction because of lack of cash, the don at the centre of the "elitist" university row warned yesterday.

John Stein, professor of physiology at Magdalen College, Oxford, hit back at ministers and said the real scandal was their failure to support efforts - including his own - to help educationally disadvantaged pupils get into Oxbridge.

Prof Stein, who was behind the university's rejection of the oustanding comprehensive pupil Laura Spence, said he felt he had been publicly insulted by chancellor Gordon Brown's claims that he had discriminated against state sector applicants.

He also criticised the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, and former school standards minister, Stephen Byers, for showing a "polite interest" in his summer school pro gramme for state school pupils, before giving him the "runaround" for two years and failing to give him any cash to finance it.

The scientist is an authority on the diagnosis and treatment of early reading problems, including dyslexia. But yesterday he warned that his attempts to improve the lot of the educationally disadvantaged were at risk because his respected research unit faced extinction in four months unless it received more funding.

"It would be a tragedy if this were to happen just as we are about to make a real impact on reading problems and a waste of my life for the last 10 years" he said. "We have already proved that there is a relationship between children's basic auditory and visual functioning and how they learn to read.

"The next step we have planned is a pilot which would involve tests for primary schools to alert them to particular reading problems".

He said there were already signs of interest from some American universities. "They are starting to take note of what we are doing in the UK" .

The Dyslexia Research Trust had been hoping to set up a new research centre at Oxford to take the work forward, but had failed to secure funding, he added. The project has been financed by the Wellcome Trust for the past 15 years but the funding is not being renewed.

The Department for Education and Employment said Prof Stein had submitted an application for funding two years ago, but as the project at that stage related to the causes of dyslexia, it was seen as an issue for the Department of Health.

Prof Stein launched his counter-attack in a letter to the Daily Telegraph.

fields.headline: Swordsman in church attack 'heard voices'
fields.trailText: A naked man wielding a samurai sword tried to kill members of a south London church congregation after hearing voices telling him they were demons in human form, a jury at the Old Bailey was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A naked man wielding a samurai sword tried to kill members of a south London church congregation after hearing voices telling him they were demons in human form, a jury at the Old Bailey was told yesterday.

Eleven worshippers were left seriously injured after Eden Strang, 26, attacked them with the three foot sword at St Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Thornton Heath last November.

Strang, who is unemployed, was overcome only after members of the Sunday morning congregation bravely tackled him with a crucifix and an organ pipe, the court heard. He was restrained by five men who sat on top of him until police arrived.

Nicholas Hilliard, prosecuting, told the jury that Strang had been seen by two psychiatrists. Both were of the view that he was insane at the time of the incident.

He said there was no dispute between the crown and the defence that Strang had carried out the offences. But it was for the jury to decide whether he was not guilty on grounds of insanity.

Mr Hilliard told the court that the defendant was suffering from schizophrenia and that voices told him to go and attack the people in the church. "He was suffering insane delusions that the people he was attacking were not human beings but demons, evil spirits, who had taken on human form."

Strang, of Thornton Heath, has pleaded not guilty to seven counts of attempted murder, three of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, two of inflicting grievous bodily harm, and one of causing grievous bodily harm with intent.

The court heard that he left his home close to the church on the morning of November 28, carrying the sword and a knife.

He first attacked Paul Chilton, 50, who was waiting outside the church, raising the sword in both hands before bringing it down and delivering criss-cross blows.

The thumb and a finger on Mr Chilton's right hand were severed as he raised his hands to try to defend himself.

Strang then moved inside the church and began attacking members of the congregation.

Among those injured were 83-year-old Margaret Sharp. The assault caused a cut in her back and left her with a collapsed left lung.

Margaret Lucas, 66, who is partially deaf and walks with the aid of a walking frame, also suffered injuries. Mr Hilliard said that after she was taken to hospital it was revealed that her shoulder bone had been completely shattered.

Strang who had also cut himself, was taken to Bromley hospital to have his cuts stitched.

"He was asked by a nurse why he had done it. He replied: 'I passed judgment. The good book says thou shalt not worship false idols'."

In a statement read by Nadine Radford QC, defending, Strang's wife Michelle said they met while he was studying business at Paisley University and they had a young daughter.

He had been made redundant from his computer job in June 1999 and had taken to spending the day in bed reading the Bible, as well as spending hours on his computer.

She said Strang had had a tragic life. His stepfather had taken an overdose and died in front of him when he was 11, and his drug addict mother had died of Aids a year later.

He was bought up by his grandmother in Glasgow and said he had been stabbed three times there, the first time when he was 15, and had nearly died as a result.

Mrs Strang said her husband had talked of taking her away from "Satan's world" and on another occasion that he was married to God.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Softbank sells some of the crown jewels

fields.headline: Softbank sells some of the crown jewels
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Softbank, the web corporation woven by Masayoshi Son, appeared to be unravelling yesterday with the partial sale of its most prized asset.
fields.body:
Softbank, the web corporation woven by Masayoshi Son, appeared to be unravelling yesterday with the partial sale of its most prized asset.

The Tokyo-based holding company - which is one of the world's biggest e-investors - announced that it had sold 3.1m shares in the American internet portal Yahoo! for a $336m (£225m) profit.

Although the shares represent only 2.5% of Softbank's total stake in Yahoo!, the unloading of stock in one of the few undisputed money-spinners in the company's portfolio raises fresh doubts about Mr Son's ability to generate sufficient revenues to keep his business on an even keel.

Largely thanks to the strength of its holdings in Yahoo!, Softbank has been able to invest in more than 400 internet start-up companies around the world.

By nurturing these young businesses Mr Son has said his aim is to build an internet corporation that will soar in value when the firms are ready for public stock flotations.

"Our company is a bet on the internet," he has boasted.

This strategy helped Soft bank's stock soar twentyfold in the 12 months until February, when Mr Son appeared ready to overtake Bill Gates as the world's richest man.

The worldwide collapse of the internet bubble, however, has hit the Japanese-Korean tycoon harder than most, and his empire is now contracting fast. Yesterday, Softbank's stock price was ¥17,200, less than a tenth of its peak. Its profits last year were 70% down and it is believed to have been forced to sell off assets to stay liquid.

But there is a limit to how quickly Softbank can unwind.

The company has promised to hold on to many of its shares for six months. A further brake is that overseas sales would result in punishing taxes of up to 60%.

In another sign that Mr Son is scaling down his ambitions, Softbank appears to be pulling back from a proposed buy-out of the Nippon Credit Bank.

On Wednesday the government said it would no longer give a Softbank-led consortium exclusive rights to negotiate for the nationalised bank. The two sides had failed to hammer out a deal despite an extended deadline.

Mr Son - whose Korean background has always made him something of an outsider in Japan's conservative business world - is said to have hoped the purchase of such an institution would boost his prestige among Japan's business establishment.

He intended to convert Nippon Credit into an internet bank that would be positioned at the heart of his conglomerate and offer seed funding to start-up companies.

With the government's latest announcement that dream is fading fast.

Yesterday evening Japanese newspapers were suggesting that survival was now Mr Son's priority: "Anxieties over possible collapse of Softbank," read one headline.

But Mr Son, who has ridden out several previous credit crunches, is far from finished because Softbank remains Yahoo!'s biggest shareholder.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Teenager faces hacking charges
fields.body:
Teenager faces hacking charges

A teenager accused of hacking into computers across the globe was bailed until June 15 by magistrates in Carmarthen, west Wales, yesterday on charges under the Computer Misuse Act 1990. Raphael Gray, 18, of Narbeth, has been charged with 10 counts of downloading unauthorised information from computers in the US, Canada, Thailand and Britain.

Three held in 'decoder scam'

Three people have been charged in connection with an alleged worldwide scam involving the manufacture and supply of illegal cable TV decoding boxes. They were arrested in Milton Keynes yesterday after a five month investigation by Thames Valley police and telecommunications operator NTL. A man aged 59 and two women aged 53 and 39 have been bailed by police.

'Sinister' drink advert curbed

The Independent Television Commission has barred a drink advert for Metz from being shown before 7.30pm - to avoid scaring children. It said the "sinister, angular, puppet-style figures" could unnerve youngsters.

Woman to head maps agency

Britain's national mapping agency, Ordnance Survey, has appointed the first female director general and chief executive to head the company in its 209-year history. Vanessa Lawrence, 37, will also become the youngest person to take the helm of the agency.

Actors mourn Gielgud

Sir Alec Guinness, Sir Donald Sinden, Sir John Mills, Dame Maggie Smith and Lord Attenborough were among the stars who paid their respects to the late Sir John Gielgud yesterday at an afternoon service near his Buckinghamshire home. The actor, who died last month aged 96, was later cremated in Oxford.

Trio 'had 1,600 ecstasy tablets'

Police in central Sicily have charged two Britons and an Irishman allegedly found in possession of 1,645 ecstasy tablets with drug trafficking. They say the three were part of a multinational group attempting to organise a rave party. Carl Watford, 41, of Milton Keynes, Timothy Wayre, 27, of London, and Eamon McRenna, 29, of Dublin, face up to eight years jail if convicted.
Philip Willan

Women in bras picture banned

A town council has banned a poster featuring a picture of local women revealing their bras for charity. It says the poster - advertising a photographic exhibition - could cause offence if displayed on its notice boards. The poster shows several of the 50 women from Llantwit Major, near Cardiff, who took part in the Playtex Moon Walk in London last month to raise £10,000 for breast cancer research. In all 3,000 women took part.

Near-miss for dog walker

Norman Leach, 48, narrowly escaped injury when a frozen block of aircraft toilet water landed at his feet as he walked through Greenwich Park in south-east London with his dog.

webTitle: 'Saintly' Elvis Presili hailed as a son of Wales

fields.headline: 'Saintly' Elvis Presili hailed as a son of Wales
fields.trailText: Elvis Presley has been claimed as Russian, Japanese, Irish and Scottish - and now, according to a lecturer at Cardiff University, clear evidence exists that he was Welsh.
fields.body:
Elvis Presley has been claimed as Russian, Japanese, Irish and Scottish - and now, according to a lecturer at Cardiff University, clear evidence exists that he was Welsh.

Terry Breverton, who teaches business studies at Cardiff University, yesterday published an A to Z of Wales, and placed the dead singer's name confidently among the Ps.

Mr Breverton identifies the rock star's ancestors not only as coming from the Presili hills but as having links with a nearby chapel dedicated to St Elvis, "the only one known in Britain".

The claim places the singer high in the history of Ireland as well as Wales.

St Elvis of Munster was the monk who baptised the Welsh patron saint, St David, at Porth Clais in 454 AD.

"Divine providence had brought St Elvis over from Ireland at that conjuncture," says the Catholic Encyclopaedia.

Presley's fans have linked him with sainthood since hearing of his last words on his bathroom floor at Gracelands: "This must be like what Jesus suffered."

It was the death, they say, of a profoundly spiritual man "ultimately exhausted by his merciless admirers".

Mr Breverton is not the singer's first academic champion. At a conference in Memphis last year Vernon Chadwick said: "Many of Elvis's moves that were considered vulgar were in fact bodily expressions of religious exaltation that he learned growing up in church."

But Mr Breverton is the first to link him with Wales. Other facts point to this, he says.

"His dead twin, Jesse Garon Presley, had a Welsh second name, and his mother Gladys had a Welsh name too.

"His grandmother Doll Mansell may have come from the famous family of Mansel from Oxwich on the Gower peninsula.

"Although most 'Elvisologists' believe that Elvis came from Scottish and Cherokee blood, further research would probably solidify the Welsh connection at the expense of the Scottish."

The secretary of the Gower Society, Ruth Ridge, said she was amazed by the claim.

"It does not feature in society literature about Gower's history.

"We will be appealing for help to see if there is any truth in the claims," she added. "It would be wonderful if there was."

webTitle: Driver fined over sip of water at red light

fields.headline: Driver fined over sip of water at red light
fields.trailText: A motorist has been fined £20 by Wiltshire police for sipping a bottle of mineral water as she sat at red traffic lights.
fields.body:
A motorist has been fined £20 by Wiltshire police for sipping a bottle of mineral water as she sat at red traffic lights.

Linda Smart, of Calne, was stopped by an officer as she pulled away from the light in Chippenham and was handed a £20 ticket.

The fine follows an incident in which a man was stopped by Hampshire police for eating a Kit-Kat at the wheel.

Both the Wiltshire and Hampshire forces have warned drivers they will take action over anyone spotted eating or drinking at the wheel.

Ms Smart said: "I was not even moving when I took a sip from the bottle, yet this policeman decided I was not in control of my car."

She added: "I drove off and had the bottle in my hand as I changed out of first gear, but I put it straight down after that. I wasn't even going at 10mph when I was stopped." The officer had told her she could either go to court, which could result in four penalty points and a £200 fine, or opt for an on-the-spot £20 fine.

She said she would refuse to pay the fine and would take the matter to court.

"They may slap me with a bigger fine and four points, but I am hoping the courts will realise just how ridiculous the situation is."

A police spokeswoman said: "A fixed penalty ticket was issued to a motorist who, in the judgment of a police officer, was not in proper control of a moving vehicle."

She added that officers would do the same again if necessary. "Our concern is for the safety of other road users. If a police officer feels a driver is not in charge of their vehicle while it is moving they will be stopped and advice or a ticket will be given."
