webTitle: Man 'lured wife to Venezuela before murdering her'

fields.headline: Man 'lured wife to Venezuela before murdering her'
fields.trailText: A woman believed to have been murdered and buried in the garden by her husband, was found dead 4,000 miles away in the Venezuelan forest, the Old Bailey was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman believed to have been murdered and buried in the garden by her husband, was found dead 4,000 miles away in the Venezuelan forest, the Old Bailey was told yesterday.

Chigusa Turner, 32, had been lured to Caracas in June last year by her occupational therapist husband Ray, 29, alleged David Farrer QC, prosecuting.

Mr Turner then strangled her, wrapped her in black plastic binliners he had packed from their home in Willesden, north-west London, hid her in a suitcase and dumped her in a wood, Mr Farrer said.

Turner and his alleged accomplice, Danny Draghici, 32, then returned to London believing the body would never be found or identified.

But Venezuelan police found it within a week and it was eventually identified from dental records after Mrs Turner's family launched a search for her, said Mr Farrer.

Meanwhile, Mr Turner, who also worked as a showbiz bodyguard, had installed his Korean mistress in the flat and was withdrawing money from his wife's bank accounts.

In August, before the body was linked to Britain, police arrested Mr Turner, initially for stealing from the accounts but later rearrested him for suspected murder.

Mr Farrer said: "Police searched the ground-floor flat, digging in the garden, pulling up floors. Obviously, they were contemplating the possibility that she was dead and buried at their home in London." But the police were, in fact, "4,000 miles wide of the mark", he said.

Mr Turner pleaded not guilty to murdering his Japanese-born wife by strangling her shortly after she arrived in Caracas on June 3, and to conspiracy to murder - a charge also denied by his Romanian friend, Mr Draghici.

Both men had travelled to Venezuela together and had been jointly involved in the killing, Mr Farrer said.

After their arrests, they blamed each other for the death.

Mr Draghici, of Crawley, West Sussex, said Mr Turner had returned from the airport claiming that his wife had never arrived.

Mr Turner told officers "an utterly bizarre" story in which he claimed he had been beaten up by Venezuelan police, robbed at gunpoint and returned to the Hilton hotel in Caracas to find Mr Draghici with his wife's blood-covered body.

Mr Farrer said Mrs Turner had not been seen after she arrived at the airport.

Mr Turner had given various explanations for her not returning home, he said, and had forged her signature on a resignation letter to the Japanese Tourist Board where she worked.

But the pair appeared not to have allowed for the curiosity and suspicion that her absence aroused in her family and friends, he said.

The woman's father and brother travelled to London and contacted police after finding Mr Turner's mistress, Nak Sim-choi, in the flat.

The case continues.

Obviously, they were contemplating the possibility that she was dead and buried at their home in London." But the police were, in fact, "4,000 miles wide of the mark", he said. Mr Turner pleaded not guilty to murdering his Japanese-born wife by strangling her shortly after she arrived in Caracas on June 3, and to conspiracy to murder - a charge also denied by his Romanian friend, Mr Draghici. Both men had travelled to Venezuela together and had been jointly involved in the killing, Mr Farrer said. After their arrests, they blamed each other for the death. Mr Draghici, of Crawley, West Sussex, said Mr Turner had returned from the airport claiming that his wife had never arrived. Mr Turner told officers "an utterly bizarre" story in which he claimed he had been beaten up by Venezuelan police, robbed at gunpoint and returned to the Hilton hotel in Caracas to find Mr Draghici with his wife's blood-covered body. Mr Farrer said Mrs Turner had not been seen after she arrived at the airport. Mr Turner had given various explanations for her not returning home, he said, and had forged her signature on a resignation letter to the Japanese Tourist Board where she worked. But the pair appeared not to have allowed for the curiosity and suspicion that her absence aroused in her family and friends, he said. The woman's father and brother travelled to London and contacted police after finding Mr Turner's mistress, Nak Sim-choi, in the flat. The case continues.

webTitle: BT delays retail launch of GPRS mobile phones

fields.headline: BT delays retail launch of GPRS mobile phones
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications has delayed the retail introduction of its "second-and-a-half generation" mobile telephones in order to capture higher retail sales over the Christmas period.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications has delayed the retail introduction of its "second-and-a-half generation" mobile telephones in order to capture higher retail sales over the Christmas period.

BT Cellnet intends to launch its new telephones - which operate on the General Packet Radio Switch system, or GPRS - to business customers next month, claiming that there is pent-up demand from those higher value clients.

GPRS is an upgrade of the present GSM system and uses network time only when there is information to be sent.

It is designed to send data in "bursts", and is ideal for applications such as email. It also enables a continuously open net connection for browsing. Retail customers, however, will have to wait until December to buy the telephones.

BT claims the delay has been caused by the need to perfect its offering to retail clients, which includes fine tuning its content package.

Vodafone has also pencilled its launch date for GPRS phones as "later this year", and is unwilling to rule out Christmas as a possible date, though it promises to have its GPRS network operating by January.

Orange chief executive Hans Snook has batted away the question by stating "we will be introducing GPRS at least as early as anyone else".

One2One says it is aiming at the beginning of next year for its launch. Like some other operators, it says the standards set for the GPRS network and handsets are still being finalised and that it is foolish to rush into the market without those in place.

However, some analysts argue the delay in GRPS's introduction is disadvantageous to customers who have already bought WAP-enabled mobile phones that provide a browser.

Those WAP phones operate on the existing network which is slower and more expensive.

Ovum new media consultant John Davison said the revenues on WAP phones for the mobile phone operators would certainly be higher on the existing net as users pay on a timed basis as well as for the initial connection.

Using a GPRS phone, internet connections would be charged by the volume of data downloaded or sent. Mr Davison said the WAP phones available had drawn widespread criticism from users claiming they were inefficient.

"The GPRS and WAP launches have been horribly out of step," he said. "The combination of the two will deliver speed and functionality."

Mary Kirby, BT Cellnet commercial development manager, denied that there had been a deliberate delay in the retail launch: "I would dispute that point. We will go into the market later, and by that time the mass market will be fully conversant with our high-speed data product.

"Our content provider services will then also be ready to meet the need of of the mass consumer market."

Another argument for GPRS phones is that operators will be able to find out what consumers want from Universal Mobile Telecommunications System phones when they are introduced in 2002.

"They have paid large sums of money for 3G licences," Mr Davison said. "By only playing with GPRS can they learn what consumers want."

fields.headline: Euro 2000 tickets taken off website
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: QXL.com, Europe's largest online auction house, has been forced to remove from its website dozens of offers of Euro 2000 tickets for sale after complaints from clients and tournament organisers that it is illegal to sell them.
fields.body:
QXL.com, Europe's largest online auction house, has been forced to remove from its website dozens of offers of Euro 2000 tickets for sale after complaints from clients and tournament organisers that it is illegal to sell them.

Trading standards officers were also warned of the sale on the internet for fear that tickets could be bought by hooligans and lead to the breakdown of segregation within grounds.

Many of the tickets were being offered by sellers in Holland and Belgium, where the tournament is taking place, and were meant for neutral parts of grounds.

All tickets bear the name of the person who originally purchased them, and Euro 2000 organisers and the Football Association have warned that it is illegal to sell them on.

Tournament organisers have also warned anyone buying tickets which do not bear their name that they could be refused entry to grounds and that checks will be carried out at high-profile games, where there is the potential for trouble.

QXL.com, which is listed on the stock exchange, generates most of its money by taking a commission from online auctions it offers on its website. It was recently involved in auctioning parts of Wembley stadium and offers a number of other football-related items on its website.

The company admitted yesterday that Euro 2000 tickets were on offer but that transactions were between seller and buyer; it was not involved in any negotiations.

A spokeswoman said: "We have been made aware of the problem and have now removed all offers for Euro 2000 tickets. We will continue to monitor our websites to ensure that no other Euro 2000 offers are posted on it, and will take down any other offers that may appear.

"These sales had nothing to do with us. We just offered the technical platform for them to take place."

Problems came to light after Chris Martin, who regularly uses the online auction company, bought three tickets from a seller for £300 and was then warned that he might not be allowed to enter the ground because they did not bear his name.

Mr Martin said: "It's not right that such a large company should be involved in the illegal selling of tickets.

"Everybody who is scanning the internet looking for Euro 2000 tickets should be made aware that they are breaking the law and might not even be able to get into the ground to watch the match."

The QXL case highlights wider concerns of Euro 2000 tickets being offered on the internet.

A number of sites have been set up offering tickets at inflated prices, and trading standards officers and tournament organisers have warned that they will monitor the situation and take action against anyone caught selling tickets.

Authorities in Holland and Belgium have introduced legislation to deal with ticket touts, and all fans will be required to carry identification when they attend the matches.

A number of sellers in Holland are to face prosecution as tournament organisers try to ensure that tickets do not end up on the black market.

A spokesman for Euro 2000 said: "We will be writing to any company in England that is selling tickets warning them that we will take legal action. We have a very strict ticket policy that is designed to ensure safety within grounds.

"We are aware that a large number of tickets are being offered for sale via the internet, and we will be working with authorities around Europe to try to stop it."

Around 1.2m tickets have been sold, and for the first time organisers have said that the majority of tickets would be set aside for genuine fans.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •There is little more pleasing than observing the health secretary Alan Milburn go about his work so smoothly . . . such a contrast from the fiery bruiser of his Newcastle days in the 80s, when he was married to his ex-wife Mo O'Toole. Alan needs those silky skills, of course, in his present job, especially with those 12m imbecilic NHS questionnaires being greeted with such contempt. The section in which Alan requests three pieces of advice about improving the health service attracts particular scorn. Many people, we gather, are receiving identical answers: (1 Resign; 2 Bring back Dobbo; 3 Stop sending out stupid questionnaires).
fields.body:
There is little more pleasing than observing the health secretary Alan Milburn go about his work so smoothly . . . such a contrast from the fiery bruiser of his Newcastle days in the 80s, when he was married to his ex-wife Mo O'Toole. Alan needs those silky skills, of course, in his present job, especially with those 12m imbecilic NHS questionnaires being greeted with such contempt. The section in which Alan requests three pieces of advice about improving the health service attracts particular scorn. Many people, we gather, are receiving identical answers: (1 Resign; 2 Bring back Dobbo; 3 Stop sending out stupid questionnaires).

Five weeks after her trauma at the hands of British Airways, Victoria Beckham is about to dip into her compensation. In late April, three of Posh's Louis Vuitton suitcases went missing at Heathrow, and although BA denied her typically restrained demand (free first class air tickets for life), it did stump up £100,000-worth of freebies. So this weekend she is going to New York on Concorde. But not with David. No, Posh is taking her interior designer for a bit of shopping. As I've always said, when you're nipping out for the leopard- skin sofas, there's no excuse not to travel in style.

There is mixed news of the frontrunner and defending champion in the race for Stupidest MP 2000. Labour dimwit David Winnick slips back by allowing an entire day to pass without sending us a silly letter, replete with self-aggrandising photocopies of Hansard. However his momentum is restored by an email from a one-time member of his constituency party concerning his self-portrayal as independent of New Labour. More of this next week.

Very good to see the Mirror back on top form yesterday, with the word "exclusive" rightly appearing above a report on the £2.7m placed in my friend Jonathan Aitken's Swiss bank account by Saudi Prince Mohammed. The fact that every fact appeared on our front page on Wednesday is irrelevant. Much of the punctuation was exclusive to the Mirror, and in the end that is all that counts.

In Barcelona, reluctant bridegroom Raul Hortena has narrowly failed to have his marriage cancelled. A month into wedlock, the 24-year-old carpenter's assistant asked a judge for an annulment on the grounds that the marriage certificate was invalid. The judge agreed that the groom's signature was indeed absent from the document. However, having determined the reason - that Senor Hortena had signed in invisible ink - he ruled that the marriage contract was binding and fined him £100.

This column's addiction to the Spectator musings of Steven Glover must be sated - so when the workaholic takes a week off, as now, we grub through back issues like a chain smoker rifling the bin for fag ends. Today's fix comes from his recent article about the temporary departure of Times editor Peter Stothard due to serious illness. For years Steve (once an editor himself for so tragically short a time) rubbished Stodgy and relentlessly predicted his imminent sacking - a campaign that climaxed recently, of course, with the Times becoming newspaper of the year. And yet here his compassion almost melts the page. Sneering loftily at the Guardian for speculating, before the medical news emerged, on whether Rupert Murdoch had dispensed with his editor's services , Steve concludes: "From the bottom of my heart, I wish Peter a speedy recovery." How sweet - but how odd too that Steve should forget to mention his own original piece on the subject - an unusually poisonous attack on Stodgy that was pulled barely 45 minutes before it was due to press after a tip-off. Perhaps it's the thin air on the moral high ground that causes the memory loss.

fields.headline: MEPC to be sold for £1.9bn
fields.standfirst: British property group puts itself in hands of midatlantic joint venture
fields.trailText: MEPC, one of the grandest names in the British property business and the nation's third-largest real estate company, is to be sold for £1.92bn, it was announced yesterday. The buyer, Leconport, is a joint venture between the financial arm of America's General Electric company and the British Telecom pension fund.
fields.body:
MEPC, one of the grandest names in the British property business and the nation's third-largest real estate company, is to be sold for £1.92bn, it was announced yesterday. The buyer, Leconport, is a joint venture between the financial arm of America's General Electric company and the British Telecom pension fund.

Should shareholders, as seems likely, accept the recommended bid, decades of independence for MEPC will come to an end. The company has, at different times, owned huge swathes of the City and West End, but barely survived the crash of the early 1970s.

More recently, MEPC has been the subject of a number of takeover rumours, and last year decided on a radical slim-down strategy, having concluded that the days of the general property group, spanning office and retail development, were over.

The company said it would focus on office space, and last month announced £190m of retail-development disposals.

But MEPC never ruled out what it described as exploring "the feasibility of securing an attractive cash bid that would in effect return all shareholder capital in a single step".

In what ought to be a boom period for property companies, with office rents rebounding from the slump of the early 1990s, MEPC and other property companies have found their shares dragging behind the more popular hi-tech stocks.

Even by the standards of the "old economy", property shares have been faring badly. MEPC shares fell to lows of around 300p in February, from more than 545p last July.

Chief executive James Dundas said the Leconport price, at 550p a share, "relates closely to our adjusted net asset value ... and at that level we are not in doubt about recommending it to shareholders".

In its results for the half year to March 31, also reported yesterday, MEPC reported a net asset value per share of 569p, after adjusting for debts and deferred tax. Pre-tax profits before disposal gains rose to £57.7m for the six months to March 31, against £49.1m previously.

Mr Dundas said MEPC already knew GE Capital through a £200m joint venture. BT pension fund's involvement is being managed by Hermes, the investment management group.

MEPC management is to continue in place after MEPC becomes a private concern.

Chairman Sir John Egan said yesterday that MEPC's strategic review in 1999 had identified two hurdles to better performance. The market for property was changing, with technological developments acting against the traditional broadly-based property company. Secondly, the combination of relatively expensive debt carried over from MEPC's part and its low share price "remained a constraint on the shareholder return we could extract from the business".

Sir John said that MEPC had no doubt as to its ability to create value, but feared the market would continue to discount the group's achievements.

webTitle: Late arrivals fail to cotton on

fields.headline: Late arrivals fail to cotton on
fields.standfirst: New economy, old mistakes
fields.trailText: The recent market shake-out, knocking some sense into the world of new economy investment, has clearly arrived too late for some members of the old economy.
fields.body:
The recent market shake-out, knocking some sense into the world of new economy investment, has clearly arrived too late for some members of the old economy.

This week we have had an offer from Lord Jacob Rothschild to take Coats Viyella - the threads business until last year run by his old mate Sir David Alliance - into private ownership. MEPC, meanwhile, has come to the conclusion that the market will never value its shares at anything other than a whacking great discount to net assets. It is, in effect, recommending the sale of the whole shooting match to one long-term investor - the BT pension fund.

Then there is Peel Holdings, the ragbag of shopping centres, Liverpool airport, Manchester Ship Canal and a clutch of Caribbean properties. Chairman John Whittaker, whose family is also the controlling shareholder, tried in vain to take the business private last September. So now he has started to shrink its public company status, moving Peel down from the main market in London to the Alternative Investment Market and then yesterday announcing an £80m share buy-back.

Lord Rothschild has clearly noticed that in the new economy, "threads" are lines of discussion in internet chat rooms rather than things to keep your buttons on. Coats, however, is still resisting his advances - saying that nothing he has said really adds up to anything substantive.

In the case of MEPC, one reason the stock has remained out of vogue is that pure new economy thinking says that in the wireless, portable computing world of the future, the demand for prime location office blocks will decline.

As for Peel Holdings, there is a sense that the only reason the company still has a quote is that institutional investors do not trust the incumbent owner-management - with their inside knowledge - to pay a fair price.

Of course, if anything, the trend towards taking companies private is likely to accelerate - if only because there is so much venture capital sloshing around. And, setting the recent dot.commery splurge aside, venture money has always proved to be very remarkably unadventurous, gravitating towards buying out of big stable businesses with minimal risk.

Evidence of this can be found in the competition to win the right to buy Rank Hovis McDougall from Tomkins, where at least four private equity funds are in the queue. It also explains the persistent speculation to the effect that once the RHM deal is out of the way, the rump of the Tomkins conglomerate will also find its way into private hands. It is also fuelling rumours that buy-out plans at metal basher Morgan Crucible, abandoned last year, will soon be revived.

Stand by for a heated debate among institutional investors over whether they are being paid a fair price when the management doing the recommending is also staying with the business on new, private incentive schemes.

On the rails

With the government in the throes of putting together an integrated transport policy and the regulator reviewing how much Railtrack should be allowed to charge operators over the next five years, it should come as little surprise that the company itself is at pains to stress all the challenges ahead.

Lower profits last year, a warning that this year could be as bad if not worse and a freeze on the final dividend is not a bad way of suggesting to government and regulator alike that shareholders are already shouldering a fair share of the burden of building a bigger, better, safer network.

Having softened up those controlling the strings, Railtrack has set out its stall for the need for further support - much of it likely to be taken from the public purse. The case is not without merit. Railtrack argues, cogently enough, that its original financial framework was designed for a very different industry. Freight and passenger traffic has increased; spending has grown faster than envisaged. The balance sheet has had to take the strain.

The snag comes at the next stage of the argument. Railtrack claims subsidies are used to help purchase a public "good" - a better, more efficient transport infrastructure. That does not alter the fact that public money will be continuing to go to a private sector company for rather longer and in greater quantities than initially intended.

The only alternative may be clapped-out rolling stock running on an ageing network. But Railtrack and its shareholders should be asked to bear more of the load: the balance sheet can stand it. The level of interest cover will not be keeping its bankers awake at night and there are other ways of raising cash.

After all, if the growth forecasts on which the funding projections are based are correct then it is Railtrack shareholders who will benefit. Shareholder value may not be an optional extra, but nor should its enhancement be an object of public policy.

And, setting the recent dot.commery splurge aside, venture money has always proved to be very remarkably unadventurous, gravitating towards buying out of big stable businesses with minimal risk. Evidence of this can be found in the competition to win the right to buy Rank Hovis McDougall from Tomkins, where at least four private equity funds are in the queue. It also explains the persistent speculation to the effect that once the RHM deal is out of the way, the rump of the Tomkins conglomerate will also find its way into private hands. It is also fuelling rumours that buy-out plans at metal basher Morgan Crucible, abandoned last year, will soon be revived. Stand by for a heated debate among institutional investors over whether they are being paid a fair price when the management doing the recommending is also staying with the business on new, private incentive schemes. On the rails With the government in the throes of putting together an integrated transport policy and the regulator reviewing how much Railtrack should be allowed to charge operators over the next five years, it should come as little surprise that the company itself is at pains to stress all the challenges ahead. Lower profits last year, a warning that this year could be as bad if not worse and a freeze on the final dividend is not a bad way of suggesting to government and regulator alike that shareholders are already shouldering a fair share of the burden of building a bigger, better, safer network. Having softened up those controlling the strings, Railtrack has set out its stall for the need for further support - much of it likely to be taken from the public purse. The case is not without merit. Railtrack argues, cogently enough, that its original financial framework was designed for a very different industry. Freight and passenger traffic has increased; spending has grown faster than envisaged. The balance sheet has had to take the strain. The snag comes at the next stage of the argument. Railtrack claims subsidies are used to help purchase a public "good" - a better, more efficient transport infrastructure. That does not alter the fact that public money will be continuing to go to a private sector company for rather longer and in greater quantities than initially intended. The only alternative may be clapped-out rolling stock running on an ageing network. But Railtrack and its shareholders should be asked to bear more of the load: the balance sheet can stand it. The level of interest cover will not be keeping its bankers awake at night and there are other ways of raising cash. After all, if the growth forecasts on which the funding projections are based are correct then it is Railtrack shareholders who will benefit. Shareholder value may not be an optional extra, but nor should its enhancement be an object of public policy.

fields.headline: Scottish Power's 300 job cuts abandoned
fields.trailText: Scottish Power, Britain's biggest energy group, yesterday became the latest power company to back down in the face of threatened industrial action and scrapped plans to axe 300 engineering jobs over the next three years under a cost-saving programme.
fields.body:
Scottish Power, Britain's biggest energy group, yesterday became the latest power company to back down in the face of threatened industrial action and scrapped plans to axe 300 engineering jobs over the next three years under a cost-saving programme.

The Glasgow-based group is also set to back down on a further 150 redundancies among clerical staff under the same programme to save £75m in operating costs in its heavily regulated electricity distribution business.

Unions led by the AEEU and TGWU hailed the move as the latest climbdown by power groups seeking widespread changes in staffing levels and employment contracts in order to counteract the squeeze on prices imposed by regulators. Northern Electric made a similar move last year.

The AEEU said it had won 90% backing in a ballot for a series of three-day strikes at Scottish Power this month and next in protest at the planned voluntary redundancies and changes to contracts of employment, including a cut in holiday entitlement by five days and no sick pay for the first three days of illness.

Dougie Rooney, AEEU energy officer, said: "This is a victory for common sense. We have avoided confrontation and now have an opportunity to work in partnership."

Union sources added: "We always argue that you can't guarantee safety and security of supply if you suddenly sack this number of staff."

The planned cuts in a workforce of 4,000 would have affected staff in both southern Scotland and north-west England and north Wales, where the group owns electricity company Manweb.

But company officials said the cost-saving remained on track and would be achieved by union agreement to greater efficiency, productivity and flexibility as the group tried to retain its leading position in the UK sector.

Scottish Power is one of the rare utilities to continue to enjoy City favour, and last month announced a £91m rise in pre-tax profits for 1999 to £736m. But following its $6.5bn acquisition of US power group PacifiCorp last year, it is increasingly looking overseas for future earnings growth.

webTitle: Centre Point, a symbol of 70s' excess

fields.headline: Centre Point, a symbol of 70s' excess
fields.trailText: MEPC's best-known property is that symbol of the excesses of the go-go early-1970s, Centre Point. But the group did not come to own the tower in Bloomsbury, London, until 1986, and only then in the teeth of opposition from its creator, Harry Hyams.
fields.body:
MEPC's best-known property is that symbol of the excesses of the go-go early-1970s, Centre Point. But the group did not come to own the tower in Bloomsbury, London, until 1986, and only then in the teeth of opposition from its creator, Harry Hyams.

That said, MEPC had been a big player in the "Barber boom" and the crash of 1973-74 nearly sank the company, given that MEPC had too much debt secured against chunks of Oxford Street that had collapsed in value.

Built in the mid-1960s, Centre Point stood empty for more than 10 years, as Mr Hyams' Oldham Estates believed that in those inflationary times it was worth more as a pure asset than it would be full of office workers causing wear and tear.

The outrage generated by this state of affairs came close to persuading the then Conservative government to change the law to force big landlords to let. Among Mr Hyams' most persistent critics was Labour-controlled Camden council, of which Frank Dobson was a prominent member.

This in itself was ironic, in that Centre Point had originally been so named as it stood at the junction of three boroughs, St Pancras, Holborn and Westminster, the first two of which were merged into Camden.

Eventually, in 1979, the Confederation of British Industry agreed to occupy 13 floors until 2004. In 1998, the CBI bought itself out of the more onerous parts of the deal.

Meanwhile, MEPC went on to build its own Centre Point, the Alban Gate colossus near the Barbican in London.

This "pink elephant"was completed in the early 1990s, just as the City of London property market collapsed.

webTitle: Deliverance:  Express seeks to milk new-economy potential

fields.headline: Deliverance:  Express seeks to milk new-economy potential
fields.trailText: Express Dairies, Britain's largest milk seller, is on the verge of a venture which could see up to 40% of homes receiving a range of home-delivered goods from their milkman.
fields.body:
Express Dairies, Britain's largest milk seller, is on the verge of a venture which could see up to 40% of homes receiving a range of home-delivered goods from their milkman.

Following weaker than expected year-end results, the company confirmed that it was in talks with "a number of companies in the new economy sector".

A spokesman said the company was exploring the possibility of "using our fleet of delivery vehicles to distribute products ordered through 'new economy' channels such as interactive TV and the internet".

Express and other dairies have long sought a way of reversing the decline of doorstep deliveries, but chief executive Neil Davidson said revenue projections would be at the con servative end of the scale. Express, which controls more than 20% of the milk production and distribution market in England and Wales, saw pre-tax profits slump 11% to £52m from £60m in 1999.

Express said profits had been affected by difficult trading conditions, including the strong pound and a £6.6m increase in pension costs. A final dividend of 8.4p is expected, up 1% on last year. Total sales were up 16.9% to £928m. Express' share price closed down 8.5 at 77p yesterday.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: • Dealing Internet service provider Affinity Internet said it would offer unlimited, unmetered internet access to its client ISPs for £100 for two years. The company said it is offering two other unmetered options - unlimited off peak access for £4.99 a month, or unlimited access at any time on a pay as you go basis for £9.99 a month. Affinity has no direct end users, but said that its clients' total user base was around 1.5m people. The announcement comes as ISPs including Freeserve - whose declared prices are comparable to Affinity's - announced their own unmetered services. The moves follow Oftel's decision last week to force BT to offer its competitors its unmetered service at wholesale rates.

fields.headline: Media mergers make headway
fields.trailText: The further consolidation of the ITV network cleared another hurdle yesterday when the Independent Television Commission ruled that none of the potential mergers in train should be thrown out over concerns on cross-media ownership.
fields.body:
The further consolidation of the ITV network cleared another hurdle yesterday when the Independent Television Commission ruled that none of the potential mergers in train should be thrown out over concerns on cross-media ownership.

The inquiry was part of the ongoing investigation into United News & Media's proposed merger with Carlton Communications and Granada's subsequent statement that it was minded to bid for either company. United's ownership of a stable of national newspapers triggered an automatic investigation.

The report follows wider reports by the ITC on the possible mergers which have already been submitted to the competition commission. The ITC's previous comments were also viewed as broadly positive and importantly suggested a flexible approach to the current limits on a company's share of the TV advertising cake. All three possible combinations would significantly break existing rules.

fields.headline: Barclays
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, the new chief executive of Barclays, won applause in February when he set a target to double economic profit - jargon linked to "value-based management" - every four years.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, the new chief executive of Barclays, won applause in February when he set a target to double economic profit - jargon linked to "value-based management" - every four years.

This, according to analysts at Robert Fleming, means the bank needs to increase its economic profit every year by 19%, a challenge for such a bureaucratic organisation.

By their calculations, the analysts reckon Barclays' shares would be trading at £22 if Mr Barrett were to be believed. The fact they were sitting at £17.37 after the bank issued its last pre-profits statement in August, appears to suggest investors believe there may be more rhetoric than substance.

At the present price, Flemings' analysts reckon the City expects Mr Barrett to double economic profit every seven years. For their part, the Flemings analysts describe themselves as "slightly more bullish", expecting economic profits to double roughly every six years, which suggests a share price of £17.93.

Barclays attempts to achieve economic profits goals hinge on the organisation's ability to stop costs rising faster than profit margins fall due to competition. It is pinning its hopes on the net to keep its costs under control and is already claiming to be the country's biggest net bank.

While the City needs more persuading that it can achieve its economic profit aims, it appeared cheered by yesterday's pre-close statement. After its recent bout of bad publicity, the bank said its mortgage lending was in line with the market's and savings were also in line with the overall trend.

The corporate banking business, the subject of an industry competitive review, claimed to be achieving business slightly above the average rate of growth in 1999.

While Flemings believes that the bank is "ahead of the pack in e-transforming its business", the management team at Barclays appear to have plenty of work on their hands if they are to keep the City happy and achieve those possible mega-bonuses.

fields.headline: Compel recovers as takeover target
fields.trailText: The past year has been a rollercoaster ride for shareholders of information technology services firm Compel, even involving an appearance in the dreaded City Slickers column in the Mirror.
fields.body:
The past year has been a rollercoaster ride for shareholders of information technology services firm Compel, even involving an appearance in the dreaded City Slickers column in the Mirror.

Last October the shares in the computer services company were worth more than £4 each. Before yesterday they had been nearer £2. But now that Compel has become a takeover target, the share price is back on the rise. The stock reached its highest level since a profit warning last month, rising almost 25% in early trading to 265p. It closed up 57.5p at 270p.

The only official deal on the table is from Computacenter, which yesterday confirmed it is seeking a recommended bid from Compel at 275p a share. This would value Compel at around £85m.

Compel later said Computacenter's move significantly undervalues the company. It added that it met Computacenter on May 25 to try to persuade it to increase the offer, but found it would not do so.

Last year Computacenter, which floated in 1998 at 670p a share, mulled over a merger with Compel but eventually walked away, instead acquiring another rival, Synstar.

Computacenter is not the only IT company examining a deal with Compel. Reuters news wire yesterday suggested that ICM Group was preparing a parallel bid and was seeking a meeting with Compel within the next few days.

To add to the listed interest, Peter Rigby is already said to have built up a substantial interest in Compel. Mr Rigby owns Birmingham-based Specialist Computer Holdings, which is said to be Britain's largest privately held IT services company.

Less than a fortnight ago Mr Rigby revealed that he has built up an 11.3% interest in Compel. He has yet, how ever, to make his long-term intentions clear. Compel yesterday said it was consulting its financial advisers, Close Brothers, and told its shareholders to sit tight, presumably either believing that the company could maintain its independence (unlikely), or that an increased offer from Computacenter will eventually be forthcoming (more likely), or that this is just the beginning of a bidding war.

Computacenter, which is being advised by HSBC Investment Bank, said Compel has not so far agreed to provide the due diligence information and added: "This announcement is being made to facilitate a more open discussion with Compel's shareholders on the attractions of Computacenter's proposals."

Computacenter chief executive Mike Norris said: "An offer would provide Compel shareholders with the opportunity to exit, at a significant premium to the current share price and in cash, from a market which is both scale sensitive and consolidating."

Computacenter saw its shares dip 2.5p to 700p.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Railtrack 's profits might be falling, the national transport infrastructure might need billions invested to make it safe, let alone more efficient, and yet its share price rose comfortably yesterday.
fields.body:
Railtrack 's profits might be falling, the national transport infrastructure might need billions invested to make it safe, let alone more efficient, and yet its share price rose comfortably yesterday.

Dealers claimed that Railtrack was worth its positive movement because its poor figures were far from unexpected. One would have thought, however, that a pre-tax profit of £421m, propped up as it is by subsidies, plus the revelation that the eventual figure will be lower once exceptionals are accounted for, might have hindered support.

More pertinent, in traders' minds, then, might be the very clear indication by the chief executive, Gerald Corbett, that money for reinvest ment will have to come from the public coffers, reversing the decline in public subsidy to the railways.

It is almost as if the railways never stopped being a nationalised industry: poor service, huge drain on the taxpayer, whingeing management. However, shareholders are doing well enough - the price rose 32p to 872p.

The FTSE 100 index as a whole closed 111.2 points firmer at 6,470.2, while the Techmark 100 index rose 95.70 points at 3,351.95.

One of the few marketing moving moves of the day was the surprise bid for property company MEPC, which rose 101.25p to 541.25p. A couple of weeks ago a story had been circulating that a big property deal was in the offing, with Land Securities the centre of the speculation. However, time and yesterday's announcement have revealed that that deal which would not quite show itself was the £1.9bn bid for MEPC from Leconport Estates, a joint venture formed by GE Capital and Hermes Venture.

Also in the property sector, British Land bounced back after the previous day's post-result falls to rise 25p to 425p.

South African Breweries also firmed, rising 2p to 411p - after it posted forecast busting full year figures, with pre-tax profit of £844m - £717m better than last year.

Boots , despite lots of whizzy ideas surrounding two of the greatest fads in Britain today, the net and our health, lost 44.5p to 512.5p.

Tech and media stocks had one of their better days: Telewest rose 30p to 302p, Baltimore added 57p to 512p, Sage Group firmed 37.5p to 686p and BSkyB rose 100p to £13.25. The continued speculation about Freeserve's future again aided Dixons, up 13.75p at 330.25p.

Bucking the trend was Lastminute.com, off 6.5p at 131.5p, despite Lehman Brothers giving it a "buy" rating and a price target of 300p.

fields.headline: Dumb and dumber
fields.standfirst: The Word, The Girlie Show, dotcomedy ,and now the return of Denise Van Outen in Something For The Weekend. Why, asks  Adam Sweeting  , are Friday nights on Channel 4 so abysmal?
fields.trailText: Somebody at Channel 4 bears a grudge against the 11pm slot on Friday nights. You thought it couldn't get any worse than dotcomedy, the pitiful Gail Porter vehicle featuring hapless nerds having the murky secrets of their computer hard disks paraded before an audience of dozens, at least. Of course, to winkle out the latent hilarity which is surely lurking behind the grey plastic façade and bleeping noises of our digital epoch, it might have been wise to take the elementary step of hiring presenters with a sense of humour.
fields.body:
Somebody at Channel 4 bears a grudge against the 11pm slot on Friday nights. You thought it couldn't get any worse than dotcomedy, the pitiful Gail Porter vehicle featuring hapless nerds having the murky secrets of their computer hard disks paraded before an audience of dozens, at least. Of course, to winkle out the latent hilarity which is surely lurking behind the grey plastic façade and bleeping noises of our digital epoch, it might have been wise to take the elementary step of hiring presenters with a sense of humour.

But you could argue that at least Gail Porter is merely witless and inept, a sort of irritating non- presence. That's the last thing you could ever say about the terrifying Denise Van Outen, who ousts Gail from the back-from-the-pub graveyard tonight with the first of a new series of Something For The Weekend. Lewd, rude and crude, Something is the TV equivalent of being made to run naked through the streets of Basildon, Denise's home town, while being beaten over the head with rolled-up copies of Loaded.

Van Outen knows the market sector she's aiming for, and panders to it shamelessly. The opening titles feature Denise swaggering brassily across the screen in skin-tight red leatherette, with a cutaway front designed to lift and squeeze her swelling cleavage. Her presenting style falls somewhere between sadistic prison warder and somebody flogging boxes of dodgy videos at a car-boot sale. "Volunteers" in the studio audience are visibly cowed when Denise commands them to come on down and prepare to be humiliated.

The harder Denise mugs, shouts and does her peculiar "OK, you can applaud now" hand-gestures, the more a sense of desperation comes seeping up through the cracks. Jokes? She's got 'em. "In my book, you know you're a slapper when the council puts a park and ride sign outside your house," she barks, stridently.

Still, it's nice to see that the show operates an equal opportunities policy. Last time around, in the Private Dicks slot, female contestants had to identify their boyfriend's penis from an identity parade of several similar organs. In the new series, the boys get to play Mammary Man, in which five pairs of boobs are revealed by yanking off the pair of plastic breasts covering them up. Then, after the concealed girls all switch places, the "lucky" bloke has to match the breasts to their owners. "It's more tit-art than Brit-art!" brays Denise, flashing her own. Fair enough, this sort of threadbare TV offal is the stock in trade of the abysmal Granada Men And Motors, with its gruesome parade of strippers, slags and slobbering beer-drinkers. But Granada M&M is unrepentant late-night filler in the twilight zone of digital and cable, made on a shoestring and grateful for even totally pissed viewers unconscious in front of the TV, just as long as they've left the set switched on so it can count as a statistic.

No matter that laddism was last decade's thing, and now looks as embarrassing as Oasis and Cool Britannia.

In fact the only career accessory she lacks is that vital designer-baby.

webTitle: I have money and prospects - so why do women betray me?

fields.headline: I have money and prospects - so why do women betray me?
fields.trailText: I am a 37-year-old single man with a well-paid job and excellent prospects. My problem is that I have been betrayed by two women and I can't understand why.
fields.body:
I am a 37-year-old single man with a well-paid job and excellent prospects. My problem is that I have been betrayed by two women and I can't understand why.

Until seven months ago I was involved for five years with a girl much younger than me. During this time I paid her rent, paid off her debts, bought her expensive jewellery and got her a good job - only to find that she was sleeping with her ex-boyfriend. I was devastated but feel that she should pay me back. She has refused.

I met the second woman at a conference. She is 31 and was engaged to another man. I thought I had found someone special, but she said that although she liked me, she wanted to stay with her fiancé. She told me that if she split up with him she would go out with me. Last month, they did just that, but she now says that she is not interested in me.

I have a lot of money and everything to offer but have been let down twice and it's tearing me apart. What should I do?

Open your eyes

This may sound harsh, but I suspect you had an idea that your ex-girlfriend was still involved with her former boyfriend. But, at the time, the relationship was working for both of you, so you turned a blind eye. I also think you should ask yourself why you become attracted to younger and obviously unavailable women. What do you hope to gain from such liaisons? I also became involved with an older man whose idea of commitment was to offer to pay my rent. Believe it or not, it wasn't his money I was after. After several months I called it off and, yes, I did return to my former boyfriend.
Name and address withheld

No strings attached

Your problem is not that you have been betrayed. It is that your love in both the cases you mention has been conditional. You tried to buy the love of your much younger girlfriend. By paying off her debts, by giving her expensive jewellery and by paying her rent you felt that she owed you something. She didn't.

In your second relationship your love was also conditional and was again bound to fail. I am sure that you do have "everything to offer", but until it is given without strings attached I am sure no one will take it up.
Sheila K Madhvani
London

It's not about money

Finding the right partner is not about having "excellent prospects" or having "everything to offer" materially. If you try and base your relationships on material concerns alone, you will only attract materialists - people who will take you for a ride and give you little in return. And it sounds as if the first girl you mention was certainly one of these.

It's an age-old cliche, but all the money and prospects in the world won't buy you love or affection. You may have money to throw about, but that doesn't mean you automatically deserve a girlfriend. A woman is not a trophy, to be won by the most eligible and wealthy competitor.

You also seem to have unfair expectations of the women you meet socially and, I hate to say it, an overblown sense of your own importance. The woman you met at the conference did not betray you. She told you in all honesty that she had a fiancé, and, sad though it is, she probably told you she would go out with you if she were unattached to let you down gently. But she was under no obligation to do so when she and her boyfriend did split up.

If you want a true, fulfilling relationship, you should begin by treating the women you meet as people, rather than potential rewards for what you consider to be your own material and professional success. If you don't start doing this, you are destined for a series of short-term affairs with immature women who will use you for the indulgent fool they see you to be. Remember: a mature women with her own income and independence is unlikely to be attracted to someone who believes that buying her the occasional flash gift gives him sole rights over the way she lives her life.

I wish you luck.
Jane Wright
London

Spend, spend, spend

I understand how frustrating it must be that, despite your obvious ability and willingness to pay for a loving and devoted partner, these two women have failed to keep their part of the bargain. There is clearly no alternative left other than to buy a mail-order bride or take out a long-term lease on a prostitute. After all, if your wealth and status don't impress, why should personal qualities such as sensitivity, respect and humility be any more effective?
Julian Baggini
London

Choose more carefully

Men and women "betray" each other all the time - it is part of the psychological battles between them. You must get used to this and chalk it up to experience, but you should also hold back the full force of your feelings until you decide that the other person is worth your emotional investment.

You seem to have chosen badly. The first woman could have been an opportunistic gold-digger. You emphasise your wealth, so perhaps spending it comes easily to you. Did you make it clear the money you paid to her was a loan? If so, of course she should pay it back. But that's almost irrelevant - you allowed her to treat you as a meal ticket. If it wasn't a loan, then why should she pay it back when you were no longer together? Why did you do so much for her and what did you get out of it? Good sex? A youthful companion? A boost to your self-esteem?

The second woman was committed to someone else when you met her, so how could she be "someone special" for you? What she said to you sounds like a classic gentle let-down that didn't commit her at all. It was a white lie, not betrayal. It's no surprise that when she was free, she didn't choose you. Perhaps she doesn't want to be with anyone for a while after a commitment that didn't work out.

Put these women down to experience. Hold on to your heart and your cash, and choose more wisely next time. Value yourself and your feelings. Don't be a doormat. And, just because two women have treated you badly, don't offload that on to the next woman you meet.
Rachael Whalley
London

Private lives: Next week

Our youngest daughter has just told us that her 18-year marriage has been a misery and she is now feeling so low she wishes she were dead. We are devastated. She has the most devoted husband who has been a loving and considerate son-in-law and a superb father to their four teenagers. She can give no coherent explanation or reason that makes any sense.

Our son-in-law is determined to keep the family together and we want to help him all we can. We believe our daughter must be mentally ill and this is causing her irrational feelings, yet she refuses to see a doctor. How can we get her the help she obviously needs before she causes the pain that a divorce would bring us all? Can readers suggest our next step?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, with an account of your own experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. webTitle: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: American media moguls know how to throw a party. And this week Turner Broadcasting corporation, incorporating CNN, is hosting the mightiest of them all.
fields.body:
American media moguls know how to throw a party. And this week Turner Broadcasting corporation, incorporating CNN, is hosting the mightiest of them all.

CNN is celebrating its 20th anniversary in style in its home town of Atlanta this week. It's the sort of deal where if Rod Stewart cancels a gig at the last minute (having had emergency surgery on his thyroid or throat), they get Diana Ross to fill in. Just like that. But the roadie in the lift this morning said she's "bitchin'" as ever, so who knows what the show will be like.

Leading the whole thing is the man himself, Ted Turner (pictured). But instead of partying along with the rest of the delegates, it seems Ted is a little down at the moment. With his Turner empire now part of Time Warner - itself set to merge with AOL - he's been gradually sidelined by the men in grey suits.

Talking about life without a direct line into the head of CNN newsgathering, Turner admitted he's not so happy these days. And what's even sadder is he wishes his marriages were as successful as his business. Like that's worked out well for him.

Turner recently divorced his wife of nine years, Jane Fonda, and has since been seen around town with a number of other beauties on his arm (qualifying criterion: they must be just a third of his own age - 61).

Bizarrely, Fonda made an appearance at the event, hosting a lunch to draw attention to one of her favourite causes: women's rights in the third world, under her title as founder of the Georgia Campaign for Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention and a goodwill ambassador to the UN populations.

So all eyes were on Ted - also at the lunch - to see how he'd cope with having his ex in such close proximity. "Hi Jane," he bawled in his usual 40-decibel drawl, giving her a stiff kiss on the cheek. They could almost still have been married.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

webTitle: Killing of president's aide shakes Montenegro

fields.headline: Killing of president's aide shakes Montenegro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Tension was high in Montenegro yesterday after a security adviser and close friend of the Yugoslav republic's pro-western president was assassinated outside his home.
fields.body:
Tension was high in Montenegro yesterday after a security adviser and close friend of the Yugoslav republic's pro-western president was assassinated outside his home.

Police roadblocks throughout the capital failed to catch the gunman who ambushed Goran Zugic, 39, late on Wednesday night outside his home in the capital, Podgorica.

It was the first Serbia-style assassination in the country and comes ahead of crucial elections in the towns of Herceg Novi and Podgorica that are viewed as a vital test of the pro-west and pro-Belgrade forces in the republic.

The murder of Zugic is a blow to the president, Milo Djukanovic. Zugic was one of his closest friends, and was best man at his wedding.

A gunman with an automatic weapon shot Zugic in the head a number of times at 11pm on Wednesday night. Police sealed off the area soon after and have declared that they will try their utmost to solve the killing.

"It was a classic politically motivated assassination with all the characteristics of a series of murders in Serbia," said Rifat Rastoder, deputy speaker of Montenegro's parliament.

"It is a direct and desperate attempt to transfer Serbia's shotgun policies to Montenegro and create conditions for the imposition of a state of emergency and dictatorship" by [Yugoslav president Slobodan] Milosevic's regime, Mr Rastoder added.

Mr Djukanovic is at odds with Mr Milosevic. Montenegro is seeking autonomy or outright independence from Yugoslavia because of Mr Milosevic's autocratic policies.

Montenegro's opposition leader, Miroslav Vickovic, said that in both Serbia and Montenegro "the thin line between politics and crime has disappeared".

In Serbia, the Milosevic administration yesterday took over a municipal bus company in the opposition-controlled capital. The decision to take away the Belgrade City Transport company from the hands of the municipal authorities followed a four-day strike by private carriers which brought public transport in the capital to a virtual halt.

A government statement on the takeover carried on the official Tanjug news agency said: "The total collapse of public transport in Belgrade has jeopardised living and working conditions of all the citizens, as well as the functioning of enterprises, schools and hospitals."

The takeover is part of an ongoing campaign by Mr Milosevic's government to discredit the opposition ahead of Serbia's municipal elections, due by the end of the year.

The victims of gangland-style killings in Serbia this year include the warlord Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic; the defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic; the head of Yugoslav Airlines and a close ally of Mr Milosevic, Zika Petrovic; and a senior official of the ruling party, Bosko Perosevic.

According to the Belgrade daily Danas, Zugic was born in Montenegro but grew up in Bosnia and Herzegovina and was a police officer there before returning home in 1992.

He was made chief of police in Herceg Novi and in 1995 took up the same post in Podgorica. The elections there are to be held on June 11.

His death follows statements by officials of Montenegro's pro-Belgrade opposition party that Mr Milosevic would visit the small Yugoslav republic.

Few believe that will happen, but one analyst said the reports had destablised Montenegro because it highlighted the vulnerability of Mr Djukanovic's party's pro-western wing. It would be virtually impossible to arrest Mr Milosevic, he said, without triggering massive turmoil.

He was made chief of police in Herceg Novi and in 1995 took up the same post in Podgorica. The elections there are to be held on June 11. His death follows statements by officials of Montenegro's pro-Belgrade opposition party that Mr Milosevic would visit the small Yugoslav republic. Few believe that will happen, but one analyst said the reports had destablised Montenegro because it highlighted the vulnerability of Mr Djukanovic's party's pro-western wing. It would be virtually impossible to arrest Mr Milosevic, he said, without triggering massive turmoil.

fields.headline: Golf stream
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Gower

A 7.45am start on a Monday in mid-May saw me heading off to Wales for a day of golf over the Pennard Burrows, a links course on the southern coast of the Gower peninsula. I was accompanying young Peter, a former academic colleague of mine in the Open University and arguably one of the best living authorities on the witchcraft trials of earlier centuries. He has real world skills too - he can competently relief manage a betting shop. He had arranged a match against two old friends of his who are members of the Pennard club.

Although I have visited and enjoyed the area before, with its raised beaches and interesting geology, the course was entirely new to me - I had to be pointed in the right direction on every tee. However, I have played enough links courses, notably in Ulster, to know what to expect in the form of blind drives over sand hills and tight lies even if you can consistently stay on fairways. I suspect the local members thought we might be easy scalps and a fiver on the match was suggested and agreed on the first tee.

At 62, and waiting still for my winter fuel payment, I struggle for length, but I do tend to keep it straight in a style often characterised as boring by those who are longer off the tee but in deep rough. So, when I recorded two birdies in the first four holes we were on our way to a surprising win over the local members by a convincing margin of ten Stableford points. My 39 was a score I have not matched at home for a long time so there must have been a lot of flukes in it.

Our hosts graciously drew attention to the natural beauties of the links. The skylarks sang sweetly overhead and the burnet roses were just opening to release their fragrance. Residual mist closed in the views to Lundy and the north Devon coast which are the bonuses of this location, but the Pena Pill snaking across the sands as the tide came in glittered in the increasing sunlight. A lunchtime pint tasted extraordinarily agreeable, but then it would, would it not, after such an unlikely outcome to the morning's sport?

fields.headline: Slow asphyxiation
fields.standfirst:
The life is ebbing out of local government

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: When he spoke to headteachers yesterday, David Blunkett as good as said that elected councillors have no future place in the schools. There is a green paper to come with "options", but the writing has been on the blackboard for a while. Local education authorities are deemed to have failed. Not all of them of course, but enough to support the generalisation, which rarely gets contradicted by parents or teachers.
fields.body:
When he spoke to headteachers yesterday, David Blunkett as good as said that elected councillors have no future place in the schools. There is a green paper to come with "options", but the writing has been on the blackboard for a while. Local education authorities are deemed to have failed. Not all of them of course, but enough to support the generalisation, which rarely gets contradicted by parents or teachers. LEAs hold back too large a proportion of central funds intended for schools. The inspectors condemn them. Their very existence excuses variability of performance by schools and pupils and that annoys a government with egalitarian hopes for education. As a result they have to go.

If that were the Blair government's conclusion, at least it would be clear cut. We could discuss new forms of accountability for schools, for the private companies being drafted into local education, for the agencies which in future will provide the Cinderella services, special needs schooling, music, county sports. But the LEAs are not being despatched with a clean blow to the neck. David Blunkett hacks away. One week Chris Woodhead condemns Bradford and Waltham Forest in terms which suggest that all LEAs share their faults. The next, Mr Blunkett suggests specific grants to pay for their residual functions, which would turn them into little more than agents of Whitehall.

There is no sign of "joined-up" thinking about what to do next. Round the corner from Mr Blunkett, John Prescott, supposedly the councils' friend at court, is busy promoting a bill to regenerate local democracy by means of elected mayors and streamlined cabinets. So what does the would-be mayor of Birmingham spend her or his time doing if the city (though this a bad example, since so far its education service has won plaudits) no longer runs major services? It is not just education that is at stake. Whitehall insinuates that councils cannot be relied upon to provide satisfactory levels of care for the elderly or to protect children; perhaps the NHS could take over. So councils will no longer have housing or schools or home helps. Some sense could be made of city mayors as coordinators and "entrepreneurs": we do not hear the prime minister or colleagues making it.

To call David Blunkett an enemy of local democracy would be puzzling. He was the great exponent of municipal socialism in the 80s in Sheffield, a heartlands man who surely realises a large part of his party's identity is carried by its representatives in the town and county halls. Still. So what role does he see for councillors if they are no longer spenders or service providers? A lacuna in government thinking is fast becoming a gaping hole. "If they were not in existence, we would have to invent an alternative structure," Mr Blunkett says. Does he really think the existence he and Alan Milburn envisage for councillors is worth much? The time has come for them to tell us what they think the alternative to local democracy is. The NHS model, struggling desperately to reconcile central control while creating space for local leadership? Regions, which barely exist as potential vessels for democracy outside perhaps the north-east? It is not just that, as the Local Government Association says, "nationalising" education would require the centre to grow new arms and legs in order to manage schools. Local choice, responding to local conditions, arguing for local needs - these are essential ingredients in any scheme for public services. Removing councillors is a way to dramatise the problem, not to solve it.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In a report on page 9, May 26, we said that "millions of national lottery players may have been deprived of some of their winnings due to a computer fault ... " Camelot says the true position is that far fewer were affected. They say that after checking 14bn individual player selections made between November 1994 and July 1998 - 90% of the total amount for that period - their investigation so far shows that 78,187 winning player selections were underpaid by a matter of pounds and 34,897 were overpaid. The total amount underpaid in prizes was £85,974 and the total amount overpaid was £94,380. George Galloway MP has asked us to point out that contrary to the implication of a reference to him in our obituary of Andrew Faulds, page 26, yesterday, no Speaker has ever asked him to leave the chamber of the Commons or warned him of any danger of his being asked to leave. In a report on page 29 (Finance) yesterday, we said Marketmerger.com when we should have referred to Mergermarket.com Apologies Süddeutsche Zeitung is, as the name suggests, a newspaper and not a magazine, page 1, May 29. Homophone corner, from page 24, May 31, "The dye was cast." In yesterday's crossword, page 36, the solution to 7 down required solvers to believe that Settle was in Cumbria. Several readers from North Yorkshire rang to protest. Apologies for the rude anatomical note introduced into yesterday's Country Diary, page 22, where we noted the common sandpiper's "whirring flight over the bum". It should, of course, have been "burn".

webTitle: Mugabe praises farm invasions as two more die in violence claims more

fields.headline: Mugabe praises farm invasions as two more die in violence claims more
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe reaffirmed his support for the illegal occupation of white-owned farms in Zimbabwe yesterday as a new round of violence claimed the lives of a white farmer and an opposition candidate in the parliamentary elections later this month.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe reaffirmed his support for the illegal occupation of white-owned farms in Zimbabwe yesterday as a new round of violence claimed the lives of a white farmer and an opposition candidate in the parliamentary elections later this month.

"We are actually very happy for them to be there," Mr Mugabe told about 500 veterans of the country's independence war and supporters of his Zanu-PF party in Harare.

"They [the white farmers] wanted us to evict the war veterans from the farms, but why should they evict their own people? When they said [we] should evict them, we said we would never do that."

Thadeus Rukuni, the Movement for Democratic Change's candidate for Bikita east, was beaten to death at his home, the police confirmed yesterday. He was attacked by a gang who sang Zanu-PF songs as they delivered the fatal blows, relatives said.

The farmer, Tony Oates, 65, was shot dead on Wednesday night in his home in the Trelawney area, north-west of Harare. Two men with automatic pistols broke into his home at about 9.30, shot him and hit his wife on the head. Mr Oates shot one of the intruders dead before he collapsed and died. Mrs Oates is recovering.

Oates was the fifth white farmer killed since Mr Mugabe's supporters invaded white-owned farms in March. He and Rukuni bring the total number killed to 27.

The MDC's candidate for Mberengwa, in south-east Zimbabwe, Sekai Holland, is meanwhile being held at the Mataga police station with about 30 supporters. She has not been charged but the police have refused to release her, her husband Jim said.

Zanu-PF supporters went on the rampage in Mataga on Wednesday, burning down the houses of suspected MDC sup porters and razing a shelter for victims of violence set up by Mrs Holland.They beat and axed several of her supporters.

Eight of her supporters have been charged with attempted murder for protecting themselves against their attackers.

"My wife was giving a workshop when armed police barged in and took her away," Mr Holland said. "Police are preventing seriously injured people from getting medical care. There is a real danger that more people will die and yet Zanu-PF thugs are free to roam the streets. It's lawlessness, it's like the wild west."

David Coltart, legal affairs secretary of the MDC, said: "This is government-sponsored violence against the opposition, plain and simple. It is an aggressive push before international [election] observers are deployed to the rural areas. We hope the presence of observers will decrease the violence, but it won't stop the violence."

Mr Mugabe's government was "canny enough to know of the danger of having the international community reject the elections as not free and fair, but cynical enough to continue with the violence far from the cities, where it will not be in the glare of the international observer corps".

The violence is hindering MDC candidates getting their registration papers in.

Government supporters surrounded the British high commission office in Harare yesterday. The ruling party's candidate for Mbare township, Tendai Savanhu, presented a petition accusing the British government of lying "to land-hungry Zimbabweans" that it would provide funds for the land reform programme. "Instead you are funding the MDC to form a puppet government to suppress the people on the land issue."

The deputy high commissioner, Ian Hay-Campbell, replied that land redistribution was indeed needed, "but it should be equitable and on the basis of the rule of law".

webTitle: Sex slaves: the facts and the fantasies

fields.headline: Sex slaves: the facts and the fantasies
fields.trailText: As a researcher and activist around "trafficking in women", I have found one of the biggest problems is the notion that sex workers who are not "forced" into the profession are somehow less deserving of rights (Prostitutes imported into slavery, May 30).
fields.body:
As a researcher and activist around "trafficking in women", I have found one of the biggest problems is the notion that sex workers who are not "forced" into the profession are somehow less deserving of rights (Prostitutes imported into slavery, May 30). The experience of most non governmental organisations in the field supports the view that the majority of migrant sex workers, including those in forced labour or debt bondage, are aware of the nature of jobs on offer.

But you still find it necessary to conjure up images of helpless, unknowing, young and beautiful "sex slaves". This reinforces the distinction between "good girls" and "bad girls" that is at the heart of much prostitution law. Sex workers in Britain, whether nationals or migrants, face working conditions that would be unacceptable in any other sort of industry. A necessary first step towards eliminating abuses in the sex industry, including "trafficking in women", is the recognition of sex work as labour.
Jo Doezema
Network of Sex Work Projects
idp41@ids.ac.uk

 Separating fact from moral panic is not assisted by terms like "sex slaves" that add a deeply suspect pornographic frisson. European Projects for Aids Prevention in Prostitution has had extensive contact with migrant sex workers. In 1999, 17 UK projects reported on this issue. Only those in London said over 10% of their contacts were with non-UK nationals and only two reported instances of coercion from traffickers, affecting a handful of sex workers.

Situations where sex workers cannot select their clients, nor decide what services they will give, and where exploitation is so severe that they are deprived of virtually all earnings cannot be addressed in law without decriminalisation. This would allow the setting of acceptable standards against which such unacceptable working conditions could be judged. To argue for further criminalisation of commercial sex to protect the vulnerable ignores the fact that current legislation - also intended to protect the vulnerable - does no such thing. Acceptance of sex work would allow those who are exploited to seek help without fear of being stigmatised, prosecuted or deported.
Hilary Kinnell
Europap-UK
HKinnell@aol.com

fields.headline: Lack of care
fields.trailText: There is no automatic right to provision of a carer for Britain's 23,000 deafblind people (Beyond what you can touch, May 31).
fields.body:
There is no automatic right to provision of a carer for Britain's 23,000 deafblind people (Beyond what you can touch, May 31). According to a survey by Sense, the deafblind association, only one in eight receive the crucial one-to-one help they need, and four out of 10 have no support at all. The government is now conducting a consultation exercise following the presentation of my deafblind persons bill in the Lords. This is a big advance on neglect by previous governments. But the only realistic way to rescue thousands of deafblind people from isolation is for the government to reconsider its opposition to the bill, now in the Lords.
Lord Ashley of Stoke
House of Lords

fields.headline: 'Blunders' in the NHS
fields.trailText: Ray Rowden (Carry on regardless, Society, May 31) suggests that the failure of regulation in the health service is due to the predominance of professionals on the regulatory bodies.
fields.body:
Ray Rowden (Carry on regardless, Society, May 31) suggests that the failure of regulation in the health service is due to the predominance of professionals on the regulatory bodies. He fails to consider the possibility that it arises because this method is flawed, and such bodies can be of little use. It is flawed because most failures of quality are not due to "incompetent" individuals, but to problems of organisation and resources, which are beyond most individual practitioners to influence. This was clearly the case in the problems in cytology at Kent and Canterbury Hospital.

Even when individuals are incompetent (or worse) the regulatory bodies are pretty irrelevant. A committee in London cannot stop doctors in Manchester murdering patients; all it can do is strike them off afterwards. We could ask why "clinical issues" are excluded from health and safety legislation; we could also ask advocates of changes in regulation to provide evidence that those changes will benefit patients. As it is, some of the proposals have more to do with the self-interest of competing "professions" than with the safety of patients.
Phil McShane
John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford

 I am appalled by your article reporting the computer error in assessing tests for the risk of Down's Syndrome (Down's blunder angers parents, May 31). You would not be so offensive about other forms of diversity such as race, ethnicity or sexuality. Thank you for the names of your sources, our three delightful Downs children (who are capable of reading and understanding the article) may consider seeking redress for the distress caused them. Our 11-year-old has already questioned the use of "blunder" in relation to Downs testing. They wonder why the world does not want them to be born. When I look at the world I think that it can only be because they are too good for it.
DA WharamCromer, Norfolk
Bellswharam@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Surgeons' scalpels out
fields.trailText: You have fallen for the easy fallacy (Conflict between public and private care, June 1) that the number of hours spent completing elective operations by a surgeon is under their control.
fields.body:
You have fallen for the easy fallacy (Conflict between public and private care, June 1) that the number of hours spent completing elective operations by a surgeon is under their control.

As a health services researcher (and not a surgeon) I was astonished to find that the orthopaedic surgeons at a London teaching hospital had up to two-thirds of their hip and knee replacement operations cancelled over a period of several months earlier this year. This was not due to the surgeons boosting their private incomes but simply the fact that there were no beds in which to put patients. The government's proposal to introduce ring-fenced elective surgery units has some merit in addressing this problem, although I for one wouldn't want to work on a surgery conveyer belt.
