Kings College, London
n.glozier@iop.kcl.ac.uk

 The news of Tony Blair's NHS strategy appeared on the same day that my mother found out that the earliest she can expect to be called for a knee replacement is February next year, having already been waiting a year.

She was told that the hospital has carried out no NHS orthopaedic operations for six weeks; but, meanwhile, a friend who finally gave into the temptation of going private, reported that her hospital was full of cheerfully convalescent - but newly poor - orthopaedic patients.
Anne Cowper
Swansea

 Many people wait for months to see a consultant about medical problems which have nothing to do with surgery. For instance, on Monday you wrote at length about undiagnosed diabetes and its possible consequences; many diabetics wait months to see a consultant physician for a first appointment and after that cannot be seen again as often their doctors would wish. People with chronic diseases often need repeated visits to an outpatient department. Finding beds for medical patients who need to come in to hos pital for a few days for investigations is a problem too.
Jenny Walmsley
Lancaster
Jenny@Moorlands2.demon.co.uk

 Just two statistics underline the need for consultants to relinquish their grip over patient care in hospitals. Of the 1,000 patients who took this option, only 8% needed to be referred on to the consultant. As a result the waiting list has been cut by 29 weeks. A similar scheme at the Withington in Manchester produced equivalent results.

It cannot be professionally satisfying for consultant surgeons to see patients who are best dealt with by other healthcare professionals.
Phil Gray
Chief executive, Chartered Society of Physiotherapy

 Where will the staff come from to support this initiative (An end to waiting, May 31)? It takes much more than one surgeon to perform an operation: for this initiative to succeed we will need more ward and theatre nurses, anaesthetists, theatre ODAs, physiotherapists and junior doctors. It is the junior doctors who assess and prepare patients for theatre and take responsibility for, ensuring that any co-existing medical problems are optimally managed the post-operative care of the patient. At a time when one-third of junior doctors are still working over 72 hours per week, I find it difficult to see how there can be an increase in the number of operations performed without compromising patient safety.
Dr R Lindley
Sheffield
Richard.Lindley@csuh.nhs.ukt

fields.headline: Des Lynam's errant eyebrow
fields.trailText: The BMA needs to look at media bias against women in sport and the passivity this fosters in young women (Skinny models 'send unhealthy message', May 31).
fields.body:
The BMA needs to look at media bias against women in sport and the passivity this fosters in young women (Skinny models 'send unhealthy message', May 31). To be healthy you need to exercise; to exercise, God knows, we need to be inspired. On Saturday afternoons, girls go shopping and boys watch or participate in sports. The girls spend hours developing sophisticated levels of anxiety about how they present themselves to the world, whilst the boys get inspired to be Michael Owen. It is as foolish to criticise the fashion industry for using beautiful models as it is to criticise the Premier League for showing world-class footballers for fear it may harm the self-esteem of young boys who are not as good as Michael Owen. (Has anyone noticed how skinny Steve McManaman is?)

The BMA needs to get Des Lynam on side. His subtle eyebrow-raising at sportswomen who do not look as good as Anna Kournikova is powerfully destructive to women's desire to be fit and healthy. Did anyone ever restrict airtime because Martin Keown, Tony Adams and Nigel Winterburn weren't pretty? When the US won the Women's World Cup, Brandi Chastain was a beautiful, healthy, inspirational role model for young women, yet no British terrestrial TV channel showed any of the games. Passivity is far more dangerous than wanting to look like Posh Spice.
Jeanie O'Hare
London

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Amnesty for woman's killers
fields.body:
Amnesty for woman's killers

Apartheid-era security agents Craig Williamson and Roger Raven, who admitted killing academic Ruth First in a 1982 bomb attack, were granted amnesty yesterday by South Africa's truth and reconciliation commission.

The parcel bomb was intended for First's husband, Joe Slovo, the late leader of the South African Communist party.
Reuters, Johannesburg

UN observers taken hostage

Four members of the UN observer mission in Georgia's separatist region of Abkhazia were taken hostage yesterday, the Interfax news agency quoted an official as saying.

The hostage-takers had not released any demands , the Abkhazian prosecutor- general, Anri Dzhergenia, said.
AP, Tbilisi

12 die in Nigeria land dispute

At least 12 people have died in renewed fighting between two towns involved in a land dispute in south-west Nigeria.

Armed factions ambushed vehicles, burned homes and looted property, community leaders in Ife and Modakeke said.
AP, Lagos

Son locked up for 30 years

A 91-year-old woman kept her son locked up in a two-square-metre room for 30 years after doctors said his mental health problems could not be cured, Spanish police said yesterday.

They added that the son, Aurelio Mourelle, 72, of Galicia had a ragged appearance but seemed physically well.
AP, Madrid

Children first to visit Pisa tower

The leaning tower of Pisa will open in two weeks for visits by children - because they weigh less than adults - after work to reduce its inclination, Italy's public works minister Nerio Nesi said. The tower is due to be fully reopened next year.
Philip Willan, Rome

fields.headline: Robert Carroll
fields.trailText: The sudden death of Professor Robert Carroll at the age of 59 has deprived the world of Hebrew biblical scholarship of one of its most gifted and imaginative members. His best-known work is his massive commentary on the Book of Jeremiah.
fields.body:
The sudden death of Professor Robert Carroll at the age of 59 has deprived the world of Hebrew biblical scholarship of one of its most gifted and imaginative members. His best-known work is his massive commentary on the Book of Jeremiah.

Born in Dublin, a graduate of Trinity College, and always an Irishman, he nevertheless pursued his academic career in Scotland. After an Edinburgh PhD in 1967, he was appointed to an assistant lectureship at Glasgow University in 1968, and remained there, being appointed to a professorship in 1991. He could appear cynical and sardonic about university life, and hated committees, but he kept on being appointed to them, for his honesty and commitment were greatly valued by senior colleagues, non-academic staff and students alike.

He was not a churchman, and there were many in the Church of Scotland who were doubtful whether their ministerial candidates should learn about the Bible from one of such unusual views. Some could not cope; but those who persevered recognised the importance of Robert's questioning and probing, and valued the contacts which he maintained for years after they had graduated. He would have been amused to be called a pastor - too churchy a word; but it was a genuine pastoral office that he exercised. The general assembly of the Church of Scotland is to acknowledge the care he took with students.

His work on Jeremiah questioned the assumption that we can have access to the individual figure of the prophet; he saw the Book as in many ways fiction, using a life story to spell out a particular ideology to explain God's dealing with his people. But Robert wrote much more widely, challenging received assumptions, forcing his fellow scholars to think again.

The range of his own reading was enormous: literary criticism, a range of philosophy, ancient and modern, fiction from different cultures. In the Cambridge Companion to Biblical Interpretation, he wrote on poststructural approaches: new historicism and postmodernism.

His extensive bibliography contained nothing written by a member of the professional guild of biblical critics; Robert felt that their agenda was usually much too narrow. Nevertheless, he was appreciated by his fellows, and it was appropriate that the Society for Old Testament Study should invite him to become its president, an office he filled with quirky good humour in 1999. His work was mostly published by the SCM Press, and it was after a party to honour the retiring editor John Bowden, that he suffered a heart attack.

He is survived by his wife, Mary Anne, two sons and a daughter.

Richard Coggins

Robert Carroll, Old Testament scholar, born January 18 1941; died May 12 2000

fields.headline: Lord MacLehose
fields.standfirst: Governor who sought to modernise Hong Kong
fields.trailText: Lord Murray MacLehose, who has died aged 82, was a generally enlightened and always energetic governor of Hong Kong. From 1971 to 1982 he presided over a critical period of change, supervising the rapid growth of higher education, public housing and mass transport, which led to the emergence of a new autonomous Hong Kong identity. By the time he left, the word "colony" had become politically incorrect, and he had opened up (though perhaps ill-advisedly) the question of Hong Kong's future with Beijing.
fields.body:
Lord Murray MacLehose, who has died aged 82, was a generally enlightened and always energetic governor of Hong Kong. From 1971 to 1982 he presided over a critical period of change, supervising the rapid growth of higher education, public housing and mass transport, which led to the emergence of a new autonomous Hong Kong identity. By the time he left, the word "colony" had become politically incorrect, and he had opened up (though perhaps ill-advisedly) the question of Hong Kong's future with Beijing.

"I pushed very hard to achieve quick expansion of social services and housing," he recalled later. "All this seemed to me right and essential on its merits." It was also a necessary response to the riots of the Cultural Revolution, which had underlined the wide gap between colonial anachronism and modern aspiration. "We were determined to build not just dormitories but communities," said MacLehose. He pushed for the development of new towns in the New Territories to include all public services, including schools and green space.

Older Hong Kongers remember best his role in creating the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) in 1973, after wide public protest at the case of the expatriate police officer Peter Godber, who fled the colony after being asked to account for his unusual wealth. Until then most colonial officials had turned a blind eye to corruption - while some helped themselves to a slice of it. But after the commission's initial successes MacLehose blinked, too, in 1977, when he was forced to grant a partial amnesty after threatened policemen stormed the ICAC offices and assaulted its staff. Later, MacLehose justified the climb-down.

MacLehose was first sent to Hong Kong in 1963 as political adviser, the Foreign Office's eyes and ears next to the governor. He was already a Chinese linguist, having served in the British consulate in Hankou, witnessing the Chinese communist victory in 1949. It was his first posting abroad for the Foreign Office, after Rugby school, Balliol College, Oxford, and naval service during the second world war. He also served as ambassador to Vietnam (1967-69) and Denmark (1969-71).

MacLehose's ideas on how to modernise Hong Kong did not include nurturing its first shoots of democracy. Senior officials under his administration, and for years afterwards, scoffed at the modest aims of the new middle-class "pressure groups" who were subjected to covert Special Branch scrutiny.

The current leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, Martin Lee, argues that MacLehose missed a chance to advance democracy before it became a contentious issue with China. MacLehose insisted till the end that he was right to take no action and quietly expressed disapproval of the efforts made, very late in the day, by Chris Patten as governor, to force the pace of democratic change. His appointment signifed a shift from the colonial mode, and his successors - until Patten - also came from the Foreign Office. It was tacit recognition that Hong Kong's future would not be determined by de-colonisation but by negotiation with Beijing.

An invitation to the Chinese capital by the post-Mao government of Deng Xiaoping in 1979 raised hopes unduly high. MacLehose made the tactical mistake of trying to suggest something original instead of just listening to what Deng had to say. The message from the Chinese leader was that "capitalism in Hong Kong can continue well into the next century" and that its people - specifically its business people - should "set their hearts at ease".

MacLehose sought to finesse this concession into the political sphere, floating the idea that Britain could continue to "administer" Hong Kong after the crucial 1997 deadline for the leased New Territories expired. Later he would say defensively that his visit had not started negotiations for the future. Indeed it had not, but it alerted Deng to a new scenario where he was quick to suspect devious British intentions.

Public confidence in Hong Kong soared and the Hang Seng Index doubled in a year. But three years later Mrs Thatcher's stubborn attempt to secure the same deal for the future was slapped down contemptuously, getting the negotiations for the 1984 Joint Declaration off to a dismal start.

At the present time, when urban Hong Kong spends most days shrouded in pollution, the fruits of MacLehose's efforts to conserve the countryside provide welcome relief. The birth of the country park system owes much to his vision. He established a team of keen foresters, naturalists and administrators, and 21 parks were set up before he retired. He was himself a keen walker. The 100-kilometre MacLehose Trail now includes the splendid heights of the New Territories.

He is survived by his wife, Noël, and two daughters.

John Gittings

Lord Wilson of Tillyorn writes: There is a splendid picture of Murray MacLehose in 1979, during the first official visit by a governor of Hong Kong to Beijing since the communist victory in China. The 6ft 3in MacLehose towers over the powerful but diminutive figure of Deng Xiaoping, then just establishing his position as China's leader.

What was striking though was not so much the disparity of size and background of the two men but their ability to find things in common. MacLehose came to be governor of Hong Kong with a quite unique background. He could, and did, talk to Chinese leaders about being on different sides of the line as the communist armies swept south in 1949. He had worked behind the Japanese lines in south-east China during the second world war. He had been studying Chinese in Amoy. He could feel China through the pores of his skin. And Chinese people knew that with the ability to feel went great affection and understanding.

His other great asset was a down-to-earth lack of formality and a keen enthusiasm for getting things done. He was never happier than when tackling some major problem: the need for a massive housing programme; dealing with corruption in the police force; setting up district boards to bring government closer to ordinary people; or building up a pragmatic relationship with China after years of conflict and mistrust.

Inaction made him uneasy, and his ability to cope with a mass of different issues, and a mass of paper, often late into the night, was legendary. Perhaps that was learned when he was private secretary to foreign secretary George Brown - in itself no easy ride and a good training for any difficulties to follow.

Many things, and the memories of many people, are there in Hong Kong to mark the time of Murray MacLehose. Among them is the MacLehose Trail spanning Hong Kong from east to west. It is a very fitting memorial to set beside the hundreds of high-rise blocks of public housing and the bustling harbour and airport. He relished the countryside of Hong Kong and its surrounding seas and islands, and was never happier than when paddling about in a small rowing boat or walking in the hills of the New Territories.

When he left Hong Kong in April 1982, after 10 outstanding years as governor, the editor of the leading English language paper wrote that he was: "The right man at the right time." He was indeed.

fields.headline: Donald Davies
fields.standfirst: Simple idea that made the internet possible
fields.trailText: The internet and other networks are based on a fundamental idea developed by the computer scientist Donald Watts Davies, who has died aged 75. fields.body:
The internet and other networks are based on a fundamental idea developed by the computer scientist Donald Watts Davies, who has died aged 75. He is not always given full credit for his contribution because Paul Baran, an American working at the Rand Corporation in California, had independently come up with the same idea. However, Baran was focusing on a way to restructure AT&T's telephone system. Davies was creating a data network, and the design of the Arpanet, the precursor of the internet, was changed completely to adopt his technique.

Also, Davies's term for the idea, which he called "packet switching", was much catchier than Baran's "distributed adaptive message block switching". Davies had considered many possibilities - block, unit, segment, etc - before deciding on packet as a sort of small package. And as he later told Baran: "Well, you may have got there first, but I got the name."

Like all beautiful ideas, "packet switching" is fundamentally simple. The problem with long-distance communications is that it is difficult and expensive to maintain a connection that stretches a long way across many different telephone lines through many different exchanges, some run by different companies. Why not chop the message into small packets first, then shove them on to the network and let them make their own way to their destination by the easiest route available? The receiving system can shuffle them into the right order, and ask for any missing packets to be re-sent.

The postal service works in the same way. Packet switching is just like sending someone a book, each page in its own numbered envelope, for the recipient to reassemble on arrival. Once you've put all the envelopes in the nearest post box, you don't care how they get to the destina tion address. In the context of voice telephony, of course, this idea sounds outrageous, and Baran's proposals met with considerable hostility. But as a way of building computer networks, such as Davies proposed, it was wonderfully simple and logical. It was rapidly adopted, with British Telecom offering a data service called Packet SwitchStream (PSS).

There he worked with Alan Turing, the computer pioneer best known for his wartime code-breaking work at Bletchley Park, and stayed for 37 years, a well-respected member of Britain's scientific civil service.

NPL gave Davies the opportunity to work in a wide range of fields from machine translation (Russian into English) to superconducting materials, and it was at NPL that he developed the packet switching idea in 1965. He was a leader, and also liked.

In his last years at NPL, Davies formed a computer security group and worked with the clearing banks on cryptography and the security of their networks. After retiring in 1984, he continued to work as a data security consultant, and for fun developed a PC simulation of the first computer he had helped design, Turing's Pilot ACE.

This idea neatly encapsulated a career that - thanks to the incredible pace of technological development - covered the entire history of digital computing and data communications. Davies was privileged to work on one of the first computers, and lived to see them become part of everyday life. He was also one of the originators of distributed data communications networks, an idea that seemed abstruse in 1965 but led directly to the ubiquity of the internet.

He is survived by his wife, Diane, a daughter and two sons.

He is not always given full credit for his contribution because Paul Baran, an American working at the Rand Corporation in California, had independently come up with the same idea. fields.headline: Broadcaster jailed for inciting genocide
fields.standfirst: International tribunal gives Belgian journalist 12 years for role in 1994 slaughter of Rwandan Tutsis
fields.trailText: Georges Ruggiu, a minor civil servant in Belgium, is like many Europeans who become infatuated with foreign parts. He immersed himself in the culture of his adopted land, Rwanda, and ended up even more partisan than the locals.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Georges Ruggiu, a minor civil servant in Belgium, is like many Europeans who become infatuated with foreign parts. He immersed himself in the culture of his adopted land, Rwanda, and ended up even more partisan than the locals.

But in one painful way he is very different. His partisanship led him to join in a programme of genocide, and yesterday he began a 12-year jail sentence.

Up to 800,000 people died in Rwanda between April and July 1994 in the massacres he helped to promote as a radio journalist, inciting the Hutus, whom he took as his own, to violence against the minority Tutsis.

In the week before the carnage began, Ruggiu broadcast a typical tirade against the Tutsis. "You cockroaches must know you are made of flesh. We won't let you kill. We will kill you," he said.

The international criminal tribunal for Rwanda sentenced Ruggiu, 42, on two counts of directly and publicly inciting people to commit genocide in his broadcasts for Radio Television Libre des Mille Collines in Rwanda.

There were mixed opinions yesterday on what lay behind his behaviour. Some who knew him described him as unhinged. International human rights groups, pleased to see the tribunal achieving results, were less forgiving, describing him as fully complicit in the genocide and stressing the influence his broadcasts had.

Amnesty International's UK director, Kate Allen, said: "Rwandese radio was a powerful tool for spreading genocidal hate and today's sentence demonstrates the international community's determination to send out its own message that systematic killing will not go unpunished."

The judges had a more sympathetic explanation for his behaviour, portraying him as a weak individual whose infatuation made him easy for the Hutu leaders to manipulate.

They told him: "Your character is easily influenced by individuals who would take undue advantage of your idealism to involve you in a situation which led to the crimes for which you are convicted."

Ruggiu was born in Verviers, south of Brussels, the youngest of four children of a Belgian mother and Italian father. He worked as a teacher of the mentally handicapped in Verviers, living at home until he was 35, when he left to work in Liège, two years before the Rwandan massacre.

He was civil servant in a social security office, where colleagues remember him as quiet and law-abiding.

He befriended a Rwandan Hutu, was drawn into the Rwandan expatriate community and was soon seen in the company of Rwandan diplomats and officials of President Juvenal Habyarimana's,party, the MRND.

On his first trip to Rwanda he was met by about 50 people at the airport. It must have stroked the ego of one from such a bland background.

His visits to Rwanda convinced him of the Hutu view that they were being dominated by the Tutsi minority.

By the time Habyarimana died in a plane crash in April 1994 Ruggiu, who had no previous experience as a journalist, was an announcer for Radio Mille Collines, the propaganda mouthpiece of extremist Hutu politicians.

When the Hutu regime was overthrown after the three months of slaughter, Ruggiu lay low for a while and then fled to Kenya, where he converted to Islam and took the name Omar.

He was sought by the tribunal and Belgium for his alleged role in the killing of 10 Belgian paratroopers whom he accused of involvement in the president's murder.

He was living in Mombasa and on the verge of fleeing to Iraq when the Kenyan police arrested him on an international arrest warrant in July 1997. On October 24 last year he pleaded innocent to inciting Hutus to kill Tutsis. He later changed his plea to guilty.

"I regret the events and I have decided to assume the responsibility," he told the court. "I am guilty because of what I was directly doing."

The judges noted that he had shown a deep and abiding sense of remorse and regret. They sentenced him to 12 years instead of life as an act of clemency.

He asked to serve his sentence in Italy.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Microsoft wins a few more days
fields.body:
Microsoft wins a few more days

A ruling in the Microsoft anti-monopoly trial is not expected this week as Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has agreed to the US justice department's request to respond to the company's latest court brief, according to legal sources. The judge will allow Microsoft to review the justice department's brief for a few days, the sources said. This would push back a ruling to no sooner than the end of next week.

Boo buyout speculation

The website of collapsed internet retailer Boo.com has been bought by the American fashion portal, fashionmall.com, according to an announcement on the Boo website.

"Fashionmall.com is very proud to announce our acquisition of boo.com," the website announced. "We will be working over the next few weeks to position Boo as the ultimate fashion portal - to deliver all the great things you loved about Boo." Neither company could be contacted for comment. An official for the company's receiver, KPMG, said he was unaware of any such deal.

Signet buys US rival for £77m

Jewellery retailer Signet Group yesterday reported a 7.5% rise in comparable sales in the first quarter and said it had bought privately held US jewellery firm Marks & Morgan for $115m (&#

) in cash.

Signet's American like- for-like sales rose 7.3%, while British like-for-like sales climbed 8%. The US accounts for about 67% of annual sales, while Britain accounts for 33%.

Signet, which operates the H Samuel and Ernest Jones stores in Britain, said first quarter pre-tax profits rose to £16.9m from £9.5m in 1999.

Wickes refusals climb to 46%

Wickes said it has received confirmations from shareholders representing a further 3.25% of the firm's issued capital that they do not intend to accept Focus Do-It-All's revised offer for the group. The number of confirmations is at 46.5%.

Bank of Japan reviews policy

The Bank of Japan's policy board has begun to discuss when and how to end its policy of guiding key short-term rates virtually to zero, board member Kazuo Ueda said. "The possibility of ending the zero-rate policy at some point is now on the horizon. Although we don't know when we will end it, we think we should discuss how to end it well in advance and the policy board has been seriously discussing how to do it," he wrote in a magazine article published yesterday.

fields.headline: Secret of sweet noise unwrapped
fields.trailText: When Jean-Paul Sartre said that hell is other people he might have extended the observation specifically to those who cough, receive phone calls and unwrap sweets during live performances.
fields.body:
When Jean-Paul Sartre said that hell is other people he might have extended the observation specifically to those who cough, receive phone calls and unwrap sweets during live performances.

We all know why they do it in cinemas, theatres and concert halls: because they are thoughtless dolts. And, in the cases of mobile phones and coughing, we also know how they do it. But, until today, we did not know exactly how sweet wrappers always make the irritating noise they do.

A conference in Atlanta is hearing the results of research by physicists in which crinkled plastic was recorded coming off the candy in a silent chamber, digitised and then analysed by computers.

Eric Kramer of Simon's Rock College, Massachusetts, and Alexander Lobkovsky of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, Maryland, wanted to find out why no amount of care reduces the crackle.

"You can follow that sequence as slowly as you want but each step in the sequence is accompanied by a click," said Dr Kramer. The team found the sound is made up of a series of pops, thousandths of a second long, and happening at random volumes as small creases in the paper rearrange in the act of unwrapping.

Lest anyone should regard this as a petty subject for research, there is the recent case of Alexander Weaver to consider.

When he could no longer take the sound of a sweet being unwrapped during a performance of Verdi's La Traviata at Chicago's Lyric Opera, Mr Weaver told the people behind him to desist. He then turned round, returning his attention to the stage, and was slapped on the back of the head.

John Gaginni, who said he had fallen asleep and struck Mr Weaver involuntarily after he was startled, was cleared of battery when the case came to court.

BBC Radio 3 acknowledged the sweet wrapper problem three years ago when it started handing out, at concerts, sweets wrapped in specially coated wax paper which is almost silent when removed.

But there is no hope of taming the standard variety. "There's nothing you can do about it," said Dr Kramer. "Unwrap it as quickly as possible and get it over with."

fields.headline: No: 1648 Chrysler Grand Voyager SE
fields.trailText: The golden child has probably puked over its upholstery
fields.body:
Age: Three.

Provenance: One careful, if powerful, owner.

Asking price: £30,000+.

Blimey. How much are they new? About £26,000.

Hang on, your sums don't quite add up. You mean it sounds like some cowboy is trying to peddle a clapped out old crock by passing it off as something new?

Sure does. Well it's not just any old cowboy we're talking about. Matters of national importance have been discussed in this car. The hands that guide the nation have masterfully gripped its steering wheel. The golden child has probably puked over its upholstery. It's the prime minister's motor. And it's up for sale.

But surely he drives a British car? Ahem. Unlike John Prescott, who is famously doubly patriotic in his driving habits, the Blairs prefer to take a third way for their personal motors.

Which is? Buy American.

At least he's seen sense and decided to offload it. Presumably he'll be switching to a Rover 25. No again. A "near-identical" Chrysler was purchased out of the prime ministerial pay packet last week.

What is it about Chryslers? Hmm, let's see. The company's website describes the Voyager as having "a sporty visage that is both elegant and slightly imposing, with a handsome, almost regal look". And by the way, it's also available in "patriotic blue".

I still don't understand how he has the gall to charge more than he paid for it. The dealers handling the sale insist the price has nothing to do with the identity of the previous owner. Apparently it's because of the little extras to which the little Blairs were treated in the back seat, which included two TVs, a fridge, and a Sony Playstation. It is not clear whether the new vehicle comes with cot, baby alarms and a nanny as standard.

Not to be confused with: The bandwagon.

webTitle: Less drug taking by British teenagers

fields.headline: Less drug taking by British teenagers
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Illegal drug-taking among British youngsters has dropped for the first time since the 1960s, a survey reveals today.
fields.body:
Illegal drug-taking among British youngsters has dropped for the first time since the 1960s, a survey reveals today.

The authors of the study, published in the British Medical Journal, describe the result as a "startling" turnaround since 1995, when research showed UK teenagers had the highest rates of drug use in the world.

Use of ecstasy halved among girls and dropped by nearly two-thirds among boys. The latest figures, based on answers to questionnaires by more than 2,600 boys and girls aged between 15 and 16, nevertheless show widespread drug use.

One-third of girls and almost two-fifths of boys admitted to having used illicit drugs. Cannabis was the most popular narcotic, and more than one in 10 respondents said they had abused glues or solvents. Scottish teenagers confessed to higher rates of drug use than those in any other part of Britain. The report's co-author Martin Plant, director of the Edinburgh-based Alcohol and Health Research Centre, said one reason for the drop could be that drug use had reached a "natural saturation point".

A decline in drug use in the US in the early 1990s was hailed as proof that the "Nancy Reagan approach of Just Say No" had paid off, Dr Plant said. But this had turned out to be a blip, and it might be that the UK was going through a similar short-term dip.

Certain drugs, such as ecstasy, had acquired a bad name and gone out of fashion, Dr Plant said.

He went on: "Since drug use began to develop in Britain in the early 1960s the evidence has been of increased use. The picture from the 1995 study showed that the level of drug use was much higher than in any other industrialised country. But now there is a substantial drop in reported use of drugs in this age group, with the exception of girls in Northern Ireland, amongst whom drug use continues to rise."

However, heroin use among both boys and girls has risen, the survey shows, although the drug remains a minority choice.

Precautions were taken to prevent boastful claims distorting the survey by having the children fill out the questionnaires individually, and then post them directly to the researchers.

Dr Plant added: "We did check through each survey individually, and if there was any obviously silly stuff - such as a 13-year-old boy claiming that he had drunk enough alcohol the night before to kill a grown man - we would take it out."

fields.headline: Bearing witness
fields.standfirst: Britain's first major Holocaust exhibition opens at the Imperial War Museum next week.  Anne Karpf, whose mother survived Auschwitz-Birkenau, gives her verdict
fields.trailText: Britain's first major Holocaust exhibition opens at the Imperial War Museum next week.  Anne Karpf, whose mother survived Auschwitz-Birkenau, gives her verdict
fields.body:
To reach the Imperial War Museum's new, permanent Holocaust exhibition you must pass through the atrium. Known as the biggest boys' bedroom in London, it houses the "dinosaurs of war" - giant weapons used by both sides during the second world war. This isn't just a physical passage: it's also an ideological one. It points to the obsession with technology which, along with triumphalism and the much mythologised spirit of defiant optimism, for so long characterised the war in British popular imagination. They tell us why it has taken Britain until now to mount any national historical display about the Holocaust.

When the Queen opens the exhibition on Tuesday, she will see a very different story. Four years in the making, the Holocaust exhibition travels through this now deeply mined subject without avoiding the contentious issues.

The project director, Suzanne Bardgett, believes the exhibition will be a good thing both for the museum and for the Holocaust. She had to anchor the exhibition within the rest of the museum and hopes that it will restore the Holocaust, sometimes thought to lie outside if not beyond history, to its historical context.

With this subject, perhaps more than any other, the way you tell it is as critical as what you're telling. Scholar James Young has argued that since the opening of Daniel Libeskind's Jewish Museum in Berlin, Holocaust displays must articulate a void without filling it; walls become as emblematic as the showcases they house. And the Imperial War Museum's architectonics are eloquent.

The exhibition is laid out on two floors, the upper dealing with the period 1933 to 1939, the lower with the war years, so that you literally descend into the war. The walls are made of terracotta tiles (ironically, German-made) - brown on the upper floor, charcoal black on the lower. The upper floor's walls tilt menacingly towards the visitor, and its floor plan is fractured, with irregularly shaped walkways and recesses. By contrast the lower floor's orthogonal layout is meant to evoke the strictures of occupation. These ideas are there if you look for them and they work on the visitor at a subliminal level, but never obtrude.

The first room, an oval wooden amphitheatre, is designed to contrast in shape and texture with the rest of the museum and create a more "humanistic" feeling. "We wanted visitors arriving at the Holocaust exhibition to realise that they're entering a different space from the machines of war. We briefed the designers to ensure that the entrance space is a place where the visitor can become settled," says Bardgett.

Unlike the Washington Holocaust Memorial Museum, here - in keeping with the general lack of interactive tricksiness - there are no artificial attempts to get the visitor to identify with the victims. One does so automatically through the encounter with the 15 survivors whose testimony, intercut with archival footage on nine monitors, is veined through the exhibition.

And in contrast to those Holocaust museums that begin with the destruction, omitting to give any sense of what was destroyed, this first room conveys the richness of pre-war European Jewish life. In photos, video accounts and bursts of song (including the incomparably redolent Bei Mir Bist Du Schön), they evoke the gaiety of Yiddishkeit - poverty laced with exuberance and confidence - as well as the sophisticated modernity of many pre-war Jewish communities. It's impossible not to look at these images with hindsight. All those eager, happy Jewish children - how could they not have known what was to come? I find myself involuntarily scanning the photos for my relatives. This is a room that is hard to leave.

Bardgett has tried to focus equally on the state and the officials who perpetrated the Holocaust by skilfully bringing together "top-down" history with testimony. She also wanted to explain abstract concepts, such as the obsession with racial purity and the power of propaganda. Film is instrumental in bringing these ideas to life, and the early rooms make good use of German propaganda material.

As you make your way around the upper floor, you are pursued by the newsreel sound of Goebbels demanding that artistic and cultural life rid itself of the Jews and become German again. Deutsche this, he thunders, and Deutsche that, he repeats, with such insistent, rhetorical rhythm that you find it hard to concentrate on anything else. Bardgett and her six-strong team deal simply with the much debated arguments about the specificity of the Holocaust and the experience of other persecuted groups such as the Gypsies, people with disabilities and gays. Though there's some material on them here, the main focus is unequivocally on the persecution of European Jews. In 2001 a permanent exhibition on other genocides of our time will open.

Still, the racial purity theme enables the curators to look at the origins of the Holocaust in the Nazi euthanasia programme. Artful use is made of artefacts, like the chilling phrenological instruments used by "race scientists" to measure the heads of Jews, Gypsies, and mentally and physically handicapped people to "prove" how far they fell short of the Aryan ideal.

It's extraordinary how poignant a broken comb can be. Three are included in the collection of glasses, keys and buttons belonging to Jews shot by Germans and local collaborators in 1941 at Ponary, near Vilnius, and Kovno. They set off associations with the real and mythological uses to which Jewish hair was put.

Carefully displayed are brutal exhibits that might potentially gratify the voyeuristically inclined, like the book press used to crush prison ers' limbs in the Janowski camp on the outskirts of Lvov. But there's an undeniable shock value in seeing actual, now iconic, objects such as a canister of Zyklon B gas pellets, or a cart used to collect the dead in the Warsaw ghetto.

These relics are in short supply and competed for keenly (120 institutions and individuals have loaned them). Did Bardgett ever feel disgusted at having to pitch so enthusiastically for such gruesome booty? "We got used to the situation where the appearance in the project office of an especially 'good' yellow star was a source of jubilation. You find yourself thinking in quite competitive terms over quite grotesque things, like the marble dissecting-table we found in the psychiatric hospital at Kaufbeuren-Irsee. You have to remind yourself what you're dealing with, but the stories attached to each artefact bring you back to it."

Curatorship's awful ironies are nowhere more apparent than in the exhibition's 800 shoes, on 10-year loan from the Majdanek State Museum from its store of 800,000. Some have their heels torn off as a result of the Nazi search for valuables. On arrival in London last September they were immediately sent to the Museum of London, where a conservator from a six-person team spent over 20 minutes on each one. They cleaned them with swabs soaked in de-ionised water and industrial spirit to remove post-war dirt while attempting to retain wartime mud and polish. The gentle handling accorded to the shoes makes an ineffable contrast with that meted out to their owners.

Exhibitions are inevitably artefact-based; but can everything be illustrated and if not, must museums necessarily neglect it? Bardgett acknowledges that there are no pictorial records of some horrors; for them, testimony must suffice. But her staff have also used ingenuity to represent a complex idea like the bureaucracy of murder. The walls of a large square room, reminiscent of a 30s office, are covered with a massive organisation chart showing the extensive, complex web of Nazi government agencies and private firms which administered the genocide.

Unlike the Washington Museum, there's no attempt to "anglicise" the Holocaust. Although mainland Britain wasn't occupied during the war, Bardgett contends that it was clearly touched by it in a number of ways, among them as a place of refuge for some 50,000 people.

The exhibition tells the story from a European perspective, but also shows its impact on this side of the English Channel in a series of four "News reaches Britain" showcases punctuating the lower floor. They record admirable British actions, like the Kindertransporte , but also the swathes of indifference to the Jewish plight. Britain-as-plucky- little-vanquisher is significantly absent.

The last room, like the first, is an oval wooden amphitheatre and also intended as a reflective space. While the museum isn't a memorial, Bardgett realised that many visitors would want some final space in which to memorialise. Here, one can sit and listen to the survivors' own summing-up, which is usefully varied and conflicting.

The museum has eschewed the American liberal idea that the Holocaust can be used to teach tolerance or any redemptive conclusion. On the contrary, the quotation they use from Anne Frank's diary isn't the usual one about her enduring faith in human goodness despite it all, but one maintaining that she can't believe that the world will ever be normal again for her family.

As you emerge from the Imperial War Museum into the light, you realise that she was right, and not only for her family.

The Holocaust Exhibition is at the Imperial War Museum, London SE1 from Tuesday. Details: 0207416 5320. Anne Karpf's The War After: Living with the Holocaust is published by Minerva, £6.99.

fields.headline: On the menu: ceviche
fields.standfirst: Food on the net
fields.trailText: Or seviche? Indeed, or seviche. It's all one and the same.
fields.body:
Or seviche? Indeed, or seviche. It's all one and the same.

Which is? A method of preparing fish or shellfish by dunking it in lime or lemon juice to "cook" it.

Does it? Not exactly.

What does it do, exactly? The action of the citric acid denatures the protein, breaks it down, paralleling the effect of heat on protein.

Unusually technical for you. How long does this take? Anywhere between 30 minutes and six hours, depending on who you ask for advice.

And to whom do we owe this incomparable technique? The good people of Central and South America, especially those of Ecuador, Peru and Mexico.

Salmon fishcakes with pea sauce

2 x 160g packets M&S salmon fishcakes (2 cakes per packet), 340g petits pois, 55g unsalted butter, sprig of mint, 1/4 lemon, salt, pepper, single cream (optional).

1. Defrost peas.

2. Blend peas with sprig of mint in mixer until smooth.

3. Heat gently. When warm add lemon juice, butter and cream. Continue to heat, whisking in butter.

4. Fry fishcakes as per instructions.

5. Put pea sauce on warm plates, followed by the fish cakes.

(Serves two or makes a nifty first course for four at a supper party.)

C Baker, Northants

www.leapingsalmon.com

Launched with the promise of putting the fun back into home cooking, Leaping Salmon offers seven meal kits, the ingredients for which (everything except salt and pepper) can be on your doorstep within hours. Some might find it a little too simple - none of the menus take more than 30 minutes to prepare - but then cooking isn't meant to be a chore.

Pros: Chopping, peeling and measuring are done for you, leaving you to cook and eat. Menus were devised by a Michelin-starred chef, Stefano Cavallini, and are rather tasty.

Cons: Only one vegetarian option.

Delivery: Same day in London, next day elsewhere, in handy coolbags.

Charges: Meal kits for two start at £14.90. Add £4.50 for delivery.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Macao
fields.body:
Macao

(Josef von Sternberg, Nicholas Ray, 1952)

3pm, Carlton Cinema

Exotic adventures in the Far East, with Robert Mitchum's soldier of fortune and Jane Russell's sultry singer, sexy and snappy together on the trail of a crimelord, Brad Dexter (the one in The Magnificent Seven we can never remember). Gloria Grahame is the moll, William Bendix the cop, but Sternberg was far more interested in the camera's shades of light and dark than the thriller. RKO had to bring in tough guy Ray to reshoot the action.

The Silence Of The Lambs

(Jonathan Demme, 1990)

11pm Carlton Cinema

Hopkins is evil personified as serial killer and people-eater Hannibal Lecter, locked in a hi-tech gothic dungeon and called on to help the FBI trace another multiple murderer known as Buffalo Bill. Jodie Foster as fledgling Fed Clarice Starling, fighting to stay with the job and keep her sanity in the face of horrors, is every bit as good, and both won Oscars. There were three others: best film, director, and adapted screenplay - Hollywood knows a meaty, sharp-toothed thriller when it sees one.

Primary Colors

(Mike Nichols, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Funny, clever adaptation of the bestselling satirical novel (by Anonymous, aka political commentator Joe Klein) digging the dirt on Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. There are some wonderful performances - Billy Bob Thornton's adviser; Kathy Bates' lesbian troubleshooter, Emma Thompson as the wife - but John Travolta's, as governor Jack Stanton, isn't one of them - he does the smoothy womaniser OK, but never really suggests why anyone in their right mind would ever vote for him.

Paul Howlett

Who are you?
 What the Smartgroups.com ad says about you

fields.headline:
Who are you?
 What the Smartgroups.com ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: Cheesy music acts as the soundtrack to home-video-style footage of some character called Mahir, playing by the sea, riding his motorbike, having a go on his accordion and a stab at table-tennis. "If you have internet, you may remember me. My name Mahir," he says, and goes on to "invitate" us to communicate with each another. "We can change the world! We can make it happen! I kiss you!" Mahir concludes.
fields.body:
The ad: Cheesy music acts as the soundtrack to home-video-style footage of some character called Mahir, playing by the sea, riding his motorbike, having a go on his accordion and a stab at table-tennis. "If you have internet, you may remember me. My name Mahir," he says, and goes on to "invitate" us to communicate with each another. "We can change the world! We can make it happen! I kiss you!" Mahir concludes.

The jargon: Smartgroups.com is an internet-based company that helps users communicate with several people at once. This ad uses Turkish internet star Mahir as a sort of prophet for the web, persuading people to share information and organise their lives by using the internet rather than their phones or mobys.

Personality: You're 18-34 (because these are the kind of people who hang out in groups). You might want to organise anything from a stag night to a five-a-side match at the weekend. Basically you're anyone (male or female) who has a group of friends or contacts that would benefit from one centralised noticeboard for planning events.

Financial status: Since you're computer-literate and internet-friendly, chances are you're upmarket, but this is a mass-market product so you're not too fancy. More importantly, setting up a Smartgroup is free.

Telling lifestyle detail: The ad has a sense of irony about it, so you might like watching footie on the telly with your mates while sipping a glass of nicely chilled Chardonnay.

Other relevant data: Mahir is the first-ever real internet star. A self-styled superstud, he's single, 42 (although his age seems to be a moveable feast) and he set up his own website last year to make friends worldwide and to meet people (ie women). He embodies the original, democratic spirit of the net, and he's made recent appearances on The Big Breakfast, Eurotrash and the Eurovision Song Contest.

Belinda Archer

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Julian Joseph digs deep into the archives to retrieve a 30-year-old interview for Jazz Legends (4.00pm, Radio 3). Benny Goodman (pictured) harks back to 1928, when his clarinet-playing was first captured on record. He was just 21 at the time, but his extraordinary virtuosity had already enabled him to be a member of the American Musicians' Union for seven years. After an uncertain start to his band's 1935 tour, its broadcast from the Palomar Ballroom in Los Angeles ushered in the swing era.

fields.headline: Toys for the boys
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Next time you think of Leonardo Da Vinci and what a great painter, engineer and clever bloke he was, consider that he also devised a device to throw dead horses hundreds of feet. Mysteries Of Lost Empires (C4) didn't make his motives clear, but we can only assume he had some time off in between painting the Mona Lisa and sketching the first helicopter, and felt like having a bit of a larf. Why else would you even think about catapulting the cadavers of old nags into space? It's not like it has any practical purpose (unless you're William Hague and think Ann Widdecombe might be getting too big for her boots). Maybe it's just what they did for fun in renaissance Italy.

It's not like it has any practical purpose (unless you're William Hague and think Ann Widdecombe might be getting too big for her boots). Maybe it's just what they did for fun in renaissance Italy.

In medieval Britain, they'd moved on from the Hilarious Horse Catapult to the Scary Destructive Sling, and more precisely War Wolf, a siege machine to strike fear into the hearts of the most courageous of folks holed up in a castle. Edward I besieged Stirling Castle with his War Wolf in 1304 and brought the Scots screaming from the keep in surrender.

War Wolf was legendary, chucking giant stone balls, smashing battlements and causing havoc, bringing Edward victory upon triumph. Of course, with this knowledge, but few plans of the machine itself, it was only natural that Mysteries Of Lost Empires brought a team of international sad blokes into a field near Loch Ness to build their own and see whose could throw the stone balls the furthest.

The planning building and near-misses made for hilarious viewing as the two teams successfully built siege engines and, after a few failed attempts, managed to smash a purpose-built wall with their projectiles. How they whooped and jigged at the camera. Amazing what'll keep men - and they were mostly blokes - occupied.

There is an interesting theory that there's a spectrum of autism and that all men are on it somewhere. Obsessive PlayStation- playing, sci-fi geekery and trainspotting are, apparently, all manifestations of men's autistic leanings. Now you can add building medieval devices in muddy fields in the rain to that list.

The siege engine of the 20th century was probably the supercar. And who better to explain its attraction than Jeremy Clarkson?

In Clarkson's Car Years (BBC2), Jezza has a vehicle infinitely more suitable than his terrible chat show. He scooted about in Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Bugattis, all of which were completely impractical but looked great and went fast. With their heyday back in the excess of the 80s, and their power and speed on conspicuous display, how anachronistic Lotus Esprits and Ferraris look in our urban jungle dominated by herds of people-carriers and gaggles of Golfs. With cars all feminine curves and girly names (Clio, Megane, Fiesta) today, you're more likely to see a War Wolf thundering down your street than a Testarossa. Testarossa is Italian for "I have a tiny penis", as Clarkson himself admitted. If only Edward I could've done the same, there'd have been no need for all those ejaculated stone balls.

There was far too much honesty in the genital department going on in Ex Rated (C5), a Mr And Mrs with knobs on. And not just metaphorically. Two couples have to humiliate each other in order to win a weekend break or a DVD player - how cheap is dignity - so we had John and Brenda, Colin and Kelly, and it was difficult to know whom to feel the most pity and hatred for. But not that difficult, as Colin - who looked and acted like a lobotomised marmoset - edged ahead after being asked if he had any pet names for Kelly. He wrote down "Babe" and "Fat Arss" (sic).

Presiding over the whole embarrassing affair was Mark Little, Olivier-winner and former husband (in Neighbours, anyway) of the lovely Kerry Bishop. Poor girl will be spinning in her grave.

Still, it wasn't all bad. Colin got his PlayStation smashed. We got to see how tiny his penis is, even on a big screen. We can only thank heavens he doesn't have access to fast cars or, worse, weapons of mass destruction.

It must be really annoying having a TV camera in your locker at work. In Always And Everyone (ITV), all poor Louise wanted was to see if she was pregnant (she was, obviously), but every time she went to her locker for the paddle to wee on, there was a film crew staring back. Wouldn't be surprised if there was a mini-Roger Cook in there trying to expose the shortcomings of the NHS. Talk about siege mentality.

webTitle: Remembering the night that Tulsa burned

fields.headline: Remembering the night that Tulsa burned
fields.standfirst: Survivors of the worst race riot in US history are honoured on 79th anniversary, as wrangling continues over compensation for victims
fields.trailText: It was a hot summer night 79 years ago. "My mother saw four men with torches coming towards our house," said George Monroe. "Everything was burning outside and you could hear gunshot.
fields.body:
It was a hot summer night 79 years ago. "My mother saw four men with torches coming towards our house," said George Monroe. "Everything was burning outside and you could hear gunshot.

"She told us kids - I was five - to get under the bed and hide. I could see the boots the men had on as they came in the house and set fire to the curtains and anything else that would burn."

It was the start of the worst race riot in American history and it ended with an estimated 300 dead - the vast majority of whom were black - more than 1,000 buildings destroyed and the area known in the southern states as Black Wall Street wiped out for ever.

Now an 84-year-old war veteran, Mr Monroe is a guest of honour with a dozen other survivors at a service in central Tulsa, a few yards from where the slaughter took place. The survivors are at the centre of the controversial issue of reparation: how the United States makes amends to the victims of racial violence and discrimination.

The riot started following a rumour that a 19-year-old black shoe-shiner named Dick Rowland had molested a white elevator operator named Sarah Page in the lift of the Drexel building on Main Street.

Rowland was accused of a sexual assault and the white-owned newspaper, the Tulsa Tribune, published an article headlined To Lynch Negro Tonight. A white mob headed for the court where Rowland was due to appear. Black friends had heard what was happening and were there too, some armed, to protect him. Shots were fired -who fired first is unclear - and several men fell.

The local police created deputies of many white men, including members of the Ku Klux Klan, and the ensuing battle moved across the tracks and into Greenwood, the black business area of the city, where it raged for 14 hours before being ended by the military.

Public funerals for the black dead were banned to avoid any potentially explosive gatherings, and insurance companies refused to compensate the victims.

"We were taught nothing about it as children," said Don Ross, a Democrat state congressman. "It wasn't until I was in high school that I heard about it."

Reparation

Three years ago, he drafted a law which created the race riot commission, which has since met to recommend ways in which the survivors can be compensated and the dead properly remembered. So far 99 survivors have been traced.

Reparation is part of a growing movement in the US which, at one end of the scale, seeks a proportion of taxes to be paid to the African-American population in reparation for slavery, racial violence and discrimination.

Later this month, the National Coalition of Blacks for Reparation in America meets in conference at Howard University in Washington to discuss its aims of "just recompense for long years of brutal enslavement righteous dollars for the unpaid labour of our ancestors".

They cite reparations paid by the US to Japanese-Americans who were interned during the second world war, and to native Americans, and by Austria to Holocaust survivors, as precedents for governments making amends for past wrongs.

Tulsa was only one of more than 40 race riots between 1874 and the 1940s, but so far only the Oklahoma and the Florida legislatures are seriously discussing reparation. Florida has voted for $2m (£1.3m) in compensation to the survivors of a race riot in Rosewood in 1923. Many US cities are now watching Tulsa to see how far such reparation goes.

The moves in Tulsa have provoked some opposition, said Pete Churchwell, the chairman of the race riot commission.

"People say, 'you're going to pay millions of dollars of tax money and my family wasn't even here in 1921'," he said. "None of the survivors are clamouring for money, they just want their story to be told. That's why we want to stress that it is about reconciliation rather than compensation.

"In our initial report we said we thought reparations should only be made to the living survivors, and we listed a broad band of other possible things that could be done - scholarships, memorials - rather than just paying people money."

Opponents of reparation have accused its proponents of opening old wounds.

Recognition

The survivors are gratified that finally some recognition is being made. "We were on the front line," said Otis Clark, 97, at the evangelical service in his honour.

"My step-daddy got killed. I never saw him again. I wonder if he was incinerated or dumped in the river. Our home was burned down. They were there to get the coloured out of the area.

"They wouldn't let us have funerals," he said. "A lot of our leading folks was missing by the end and then they built a freeway through the property."

Dick Rowland, who was thought to have only accidentally brushed Page in the lift, survived but was never brought to trial as she refused to press charges. One local story suggests they eventually eloped together to Kansas, although other local historians incline to the view that Rowland moved alone to Seattle after the riot.

Since 1921, Tulsa has grown from a city of 75,000 people to one of around 400,000, about 20% of whom are black, Asian or Hispanic. Only a few of the original buildings in Greenwood remain.

At the service on the anniversary of the riot, the survivors were cheered as their names were read out -Ernestine and Otis, Theodore and Beulah, George and Eldoris. The pastor, Debbie McIntosh, asked God to "open the windows of heaven and pour out blessings on the survivors. Father, we look to you tonight for total reparation."

The Oklahoma legislature has a number of months before it has to decide on a more worldy form of reparation.

George Monroe, who served in Staffordshire during the war - "everyone treated you like a human being there" -said he was often asked what a suitable reparation would be. "I just say, well, if you were me, what would you think was right?"

fields.headline: Off-beat candidates face election curbs
fields.trailText: Laws to clean up public life could wipe the smile off the lighter side of election campaigns.
fields.body:
Laws to clean up public life could wipe the smile off the lighter side of election campaigns.

Changes before parliament will curb the colourful drama at the bottom of most returning officers' declarations, where bodies like the All Night Party and the Corrective Party do battle for the wooden spoon.

They face a mountain of paperwork designed for the main parties. Even ratepayers or tenants will have to register as "minor parties" to fight parish elections under a group name, in what opposition peers described as "seriously unnecessary and exceedingly bureaucratic" new rules.

The changes are a minor section of the political parties, elections and referendums bill, primarily designed to clean up the funding of the main political parties after Lord Neill's report on parliamentary standards.

The key clause limits offbeat candidates to the one-word description, Independent, on the ballot paper, unless they register as political parties. Cur rently voluntary, this will mean £150 annual fees for contenders such as the New Millennium Bean party, which beat Socialist Labour into bottom place in the Welsh assembly elections. Failure to maintain proper records will be a criminal offence.

The move is being fought by a national network of small parties, with amendments in the Lords to delay the bill from becoming law in time for a snap spring election.

The Liberal Democrat peer Lord Goodhart told the Lords: "Why should a group of people in Ambridge [the fictional village of Radio 4's The Archers] who want to run as the Ambridge ratepayers have to go through the rigmarole of registering as a political party and paying the fees?"

The changes are defended by the Home Office as shutting a loophole to organisations like the Literal Democrats which appear designed to confuse. The government has also been concerned that returning officers have been liberal in allowing "independent" to be tagged on to party names by an assortment of candidates.
